HEADLINE: THE WHITE HOUSE IS MOVING TO EASE EMBARGO ON HANOI

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 31

 BODY:
Citing progress on Vietnam's efforts to determine the fate of missing Americans, the Clinton Administration is moving toward easing the economic embargo against Hanoi and plans to consult Congress about it early in the new year, Administration officials said today.
A senior Administration official said that President Clinton's top foreign policy advisers would meet "very soon" to decide whether to recommend the lifting of the embargo, which was imposed after the end of the Vietnam War in 1975. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the advisers were "clearly moving toward an easing of the embargo." 
 The advisers last week discussed a range of options, from partial abandonment of the embargo -- including allowing some American companies to enter into contracts with the Vietnamese for a trial period -- to a total lifting of the ban.
 
A 'Reciprocal Gesture'
 The advisers met after Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for Asia, returned from a trip to Southeast Asia in mid-December with an upbeat assessment.
Mr. Lord argued in favor of taking some immediate action to ease the embargo to reward Hanoi for its help in finding out what happened to the more than 2,000 American servicemen who did not return from the Vietnam War.
"Lord felt there had been significant progress made and had argued that the Vietnamese were now expecting to see some kind of reciprocal gesture that would be aimed at easing the embargo," one official said. He added that the Vietnamese were not expecting full normalization of relations between Washington and Hanoi at this time.
Mr. Lord is on a skiing vacation and could not be reached for comment.
 
A Nettlesome Issue
 The trade sanctions against Hanoi have been a nettlesome issue for the Clinton Administration. As a candidate, Mr. Clinton pledged there would be no easing of the embargo until Hanoi made a "full accounting" of missing Americans. Yet that position is at odds with the Administration's emphasis on expanding overseas trade to improve the American economy.
With its well-educated, highly disciplined and motivated people and its natural resources, including offshore deposits of oil and natural gas, Vietnam is considered to have great economic potential. American businesses and a number of members of Congress, both Democratic and Republican, have been pressing for an end to the trade embargo lest American companies lose out to European and Japanese competitors in exploiting the growing Vietnamese market.
Some veterans groups like the Veterans of Foreign Wars have also supported the idea of closer ties with Vietnam so long as progress is made on the prisoner of war issue.
But vocal opposition by organizations representing families of missing Americans and by other veterans groups, including the American Legion, has placed a political roadblock in the way of better relations between Hanoi and Washington.
 
The Pace Quickens
 Because Mr. Clinton's avoidance of military service during the Vietnam War has been a hot political potato, he has tried not to offend opponents of liberalized relations. There are a few members of Congress who are fiercely opposed to widened ties, but their numbers are dropping and in any event the President does not need the approval of Congress to widen diplomatic or trade relations with Vietnam.
While the officials said that no decision has been made on whether to lift the embargo, the pace towards normalization appears to be quickening.
Last week's meeting of foreign policy advisers, reported in The Washington Post today, was the first time they had gathered to consider the next steps to take since Mr. Clinton eased the trade embargo in September. At that time, Mr. Clinton permitted American companies to bid for projects in Vietnam financed by international lending institutions.
The decision in September followed a policy shift in July, when President Clinton said the United States would no longer try to block loans to Vietnam from institutions like the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. At that time, Mr. Clinton's advisers said that the lifting of the economic embargo would be conditioned on solid progress in learning the fate of the servicemen.
Mr. Clinton specifically said he would require tangible progress by Vietnam is four areas: repatriating the remains of Americans known to have died in Southeast Asia; supplying documents that could help in the search; assisting in cases in which downed American airmen were suspected of being alive but were not returned in the large-scale prisoner release in 1973, and working with the Government of Laos to determine what happened to American airmen who were downed in that country.
Virtually all those listed as missing are presumed dead, but the failure to find remains has fueled speculation over the years that some might be alive and held captive by the Vietnamese. For its part, Hanoi lists more than 300,000 Vietnamese soldiers, sailors and airmen as missing from the Indochina war.
 
Search Team Meets
 During his three-day trip, Mr. Lord received the remains of what the Vietnamese said were eight dead Americans at a ceremony in Hanoi. The repatriation brings to 67 the number of remains the Vietnamese have returned this year. Mr. Lord also traveled to Lao Bao, a village on the Vietnam-Laos border, for the first meeting of the United States-Vietnam-Lao search team.
Mr. Lord, whose trip to Vietnam was his second in five months, praised the Vietnamese cooperation on the issue of missing Americans as "absolutely superb." At another point during his trip he told reporters, "If you look over the whole year, we've made very good progress, indeed, tangible progress."
For his part, Mr. Lord gave the Vietnamese three million microfiche pages of captured wartime documents to aid Hanoi in the search for its missing troops. And he announced that Washington was giving Hanoi $2 million help it reintegrate returning Vietnamese boat people.
In their meetings with Mr. Lord, Vietnamese officials told the American envoy that Hanoi wanted to "proceed toward normalization as soon as possible."

HEADLINE: Tariffs Drop as Trade Agreement Kicks In With New Year's Arrival

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 31

 BODY:
Trade barriers to thousands of products shipped between Mexico, the United States and Canada drop or disappear with the arrival of the New Year, as the North American Free Trade Agreement takes effect.
In the first hours of 1994, the Mexican beer that Canadians drink, the Mexican garlic that Americans eat, the American computers on which Mexicans type and the Canadian Christmas trees that strike Mexicans as remarkably sturdy and green could all become slightly cheaper as tariffs on most goods come down by at least half. 
 Under the terms of the accord, nearly all tariffs on goods produced and sold in North America will be eliminated over 15 years. American and Canadian banks will be allowed to establish subsidiaries in Mexico, Mexico will open more of its Government purchases to foreign bidders, and sales of imported cars here should shoot up quickly from the current level of a few thousand a year.
 
 
Arbitration Panels
 New Mexican rules will encourage foreign investment, and new arbitration panels will be set up to resolve trade disputes among the three countries. Prodded by the threat of international sanctions, Mexico will take a series of new steps to insure that it does not become a haven for polluting industries by lax enforcement of its environmental standards.
But for all the apocalyptic visions offered by both opponents and supporters of the agreement in the United States, economists say its most important benefits -- more jobs and higher wages for Mexican workers, hungry new markets for American goods, a waning of illegal Mexican immigration and the like -- will probably not be felt for years.
Indeed, in Canada and the United States, the short-term impact on businesses and jobs may well be negligible. Mexico will feel the accord more and more quickly because its likely effects will range from greater American influence on Mexican politics and culture to billions of dollars in new foreign investment.
Yet along with more Wal-Marts, Pizza Huts and True Value Hardware stores from Tijuana to Cancun, the trade accord will place sharp new competitive pressures on Mexico's sluggish economy just as the country turns toward a presidential election in August that is likely to focus on economic issues.
After a decade's painful adjustment as Mexico suffered through the Latin American debt crisis and then began opening its borders to foreign imports, political and economic analysts believe the trade deal on which President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has staked Mexico's economic future may even disappoint some of his countrymen in the months ahead.
"I think 1994 is going to be a very difficult year," said Soledad Loaeza, a political scientist at the Colegio de Mexico, a leading research institution here.
"The Government won't be able to show people the real benefits of Nafta next year, and it has raised expectations so high," Dr. Loaeza noted. "Do you ask people to be patient in an election year? People have been patient for 10 years now. They are tired."
Weeks before the accord was approved on Nov. 17, Mr. Salinas began a concerted effort to deflate the promises he used to convince Mexicans to join their more powerful northern neighbors. The trade pact would not be "a panacea," he began telling Mexicans, repeating again and again that only hard work would assure them a more prosperous future.
 
 
Little Preparation
 The Government has taken few steps, however, to prepare smaller and medium-sized companies, poor farmers and inefficient industries for the new competition.
Even after a wave of industrial restructuring that cost half a million Mexican jobs, worker re-training programs are almost nonexistent. A new subsidy program has been established to entice peasant farmers away from less competitive crops like corn, but most of them still have little notion of how they might grow and sell grains or vegetables that might find markets across the border.
And manufacturers, who must re-equip their plants to compete with larger, more efficient producers abroad, still have trouble finding commercial bank loans at interest rates below 25 percent.
"We haven't really realized what's coming," said Sergio Jinich, the president of Mexico's National Chamber of the Construction Industry.
 
 
'Always Painful'
 "Businessmen know that in the long run, the treaty will have positive effects, but we don't know how we are going to get there," he added. "This is going to cause a revolution, and revolutions can be good, but they are always painful."
Mexican economic officials generally dismiss such concerns as overblown.
"This economy has been passing through this sort of shock since '86," one official said, referring to the year that Mexico joined the broader worldwide trade pact, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. "And compared to what we have suffered, the opening now will not even be so great."
While customs duties on about half of the American goods that Mexico imports will vanish on Saturday, the average tariff on those goods is now no more than 10.7 percent. Mexico's highest tariffs are already down to 20 percent.
In the other direction, the effect will be even more modest. Because more than a third of Mexican goods benefit from duty reductions under the United States' General System of Preferences, the average tariffs on Mexican products now is actually below the American average of 3.8 percent, American trade officials note.
 
 
Four Phases
 For the most part, tariff and other barriers among the three countries will be brought down in four phases: as of Saturday, five years later, then 10 years after the agreement's implementation and, finally, 15 years from now.
To many Mexican businessmen, the fact that the agreement fixes trade regulations in perpetuity is itself more important than the rate at which the duties fall. In a country where the Government regulated the economy more or less arbitrarily for decades, they invariably hail this change as the advent of "clear rules of the game."
The United States Ambassador to Mexico, James R. Jones, said putting the agreement into effect would itself be a significant challenge.
"It's an election year, and a lot of people who might implement Nafta are going to be tied up in the P.R.I. candidate's election campaign," he said in an interview, referring to Mexico's governing party by its Spanish-language initials. "And any time you have change of this magnitude, there are going to be bureaucrats who will resist it."
Hauling a load of Spanish wines, Russian vodka and Pepperidge Farm cookies out of Mexico City's sprawling new Wal-Mart store this afternoon, Victor Brenes, a 38-year-old grocer, said he believed that the life-or-death struggle would be that of merchants like himself.
"The big fish always eats the little fish, and little shops are going to disappear," he said. "But if the medium-sized ones get smart, they'll be able to get by."

International
Trade barriers on thousands of products shipped among Mexico, the United States and Canada fell or disappeared at midnight as the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect. But economists say the pact's most important benefits -- more jobs and higher wages for Mexican workers, hungry new markets for American goods and a waning of illegal Mexican immigration -- are not likely to be felt for years. [Page 1.]
Promises that Nafta would create thousands of jobs for American auto workers have not been forgotten by the United Automobile Workers union, which was defeated in its attempt to block approval of the accord by Congress. [43.]
Argentina's securities regulators are gaining respect for beginning to root out fraud and market manipulation, aware that such activities deter foreign investment. Yet companies, especially those that are family-owned, have been slow in learning that lesson. [43.]
Lloyd's of London said it had raised about $1.3 billion from 21 corporate investors to back insurance policies. The move, forced by high losses, was a departure from a 305-year-old policy of relying on individuals alone for financing. [45.]
 
Companies
Thomas J. Watson Jr., who led I.B.M. and America into the computer age, died at 79. Mr. Watson took over the company from his father and transformed it from a medium-size concern making punch-card tabulating machinery to a worldwide giant respected for management excellence and technological prowess. He retired as chairman in 1971, before I.B.M.'s troubles with losses and layoffs caused by the decline in mainframe computer sales. [1.]
America West Airlines ousted its president and chief executive, Michael J. Conway, ending a long-simmering conflict with the chairman, William A. Franke. A. Maurice Myers, president and chief executive of Aloha Airlines, was named president and chief operating officer. Tensions heightened recently as the airline sought investors to help it emerge from bankruptcy. [43.]
One Denny's restaurant successfully wooed black customers with a change of menu: it served soul food. Now the entire Denny's chain has decided to use a regionalized menu concept at its 1,504 restaurants as a way of increasing sagging sales. [43.]
Disney's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, told a French news magazine that Euro Disneyland, the struggling theme park outside Paris, could shut down if he was unable to reach an agreement with creditor banks on a financial rescue. [43.]
Zeos International's president and chief operating officer, Martyn Ratcliffe, stepped down. The troubled mail-order computer maker said he was joining another company it did not identify. [45.]
 
Markets
Blue-chip stocks plunged in the last half-hour of trading, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average sharply lower and bringing an indecisive end to a solid year on Wall Street. [44.]
Treasury securities prices closed narrowly mixed, with long-term interest rates mostly unchanged. For the year, the 30-year Treasury bond yield fell more than one percentage point. [52.]
The dollar finished mixed against other currencies in quiet New Year's Eve trading that lasted only a few hours. [51.]
Cattle futures prices rose on expectations of heightened demand for beef after the holidays. Some markets were closed. [51.]

HEADLINE: Giving Denny's a Menu for Change

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31

 BODY:
The Rev. John Shepherd wouldn't have been caught dead in a Denny's restaurant a few months ago. The mundane menu wasn't exactly drawing him in, and charges that Denny's around the country either refused to serve blacks or required them to pay in advance made him too angry to even walk through the door.
But the Denny's restaurant in the predominantly black Watts-Willowbrook section here has wooed back Mr. Shepherd and many other blacks with something as simple as a change of menu: it serves soul food. 
 Listed on the menu with the Grand Slam breakfast, hot roast beef dinner, and spaghetti and meatballs are chitterlings, oxtails, hot wings, collard greens and candied yams.
"This place is different," Mr. Shepherd, 61, of the Sunset Missionary Baptist Church here, said. "The food and atmosphere make you feel welcome, like they are glad to have you here."
Donald J. Bohana is the brains behind the black-eyed peas and collard greens at the corner of Wilmington Avenue and Imperial Highway. And his restaurant's soul food line has been so popular in the last year that for practical as well as public relations purposes, it is now serving as a model for the entire Denny's chain.
"Now we are selling less and less of the standard Denny's fare and more and more soul food," said Mr. Bohana, a former insurance executive who was raised here. "We even get a lot of white customers who exit the freeway near the restaurant and come in just for our soul food."
Though Mr. Bohana did not tell Denny's that he had made a radical change in the menu until after the fact -- a no-no in most franchise systems -- Denny's nevertheless has decided to use the regionalized menu concept at its 1,504 restaurants beginning in 1994 as a way to increase the chain's sagging sales.
Giving franchisees greater control over their menus seems to be a trend in the restaurant industry. "People are tired of eating the same old bland food when they go out to dinner," said Michael G. Mueller, a restaurant analyst with Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. "Consumer tastes are more sophisticated today, and restaurants are starting to respond to that by offering more ethnic and diverse foods."
For example, the Applebee's restaurant chain, which has 350 outlets in the South and Midwest, now allows local managers to determine 40 percent of the items on their menus.
For years, Denny's has allowed restaurant managers and franchisees to offer periodic "manager's specials" to supplement the basic menu. But the company's new strategy will give franchisees like Mr. Bohana even greater freedom to offer items that will bring in more business.
"In order to compete in this tough business environment, we have to start catering to regional tastes in addition to providing some standard fare," a spokesman for Denny's, Coleman Sullivan, said. "We welcome what is being done in the Willowbrook community, and we believe we can learn from their very good ideas."
In fact, the chain could take some lessons in image building from the Watts outlet. In the last year, Denny's has been besieged with dozens of discrimination lawsuits. One filed by six black Secret Service agents, for example, contends that a Denny's in Maryland failed to serve them breakfast in April while their white colleagues received prompt service. Similar charges have come from a group of 32 blacks in California.
Open for more than a year now, Mr. Bohana's Denny's is the only full-service restaurant to open in the neighborhood since the 1965 Watts riots. And the fact that it is a Denny's has not been lost on the people of Watts-Willowbrook.
"This Denny's is something of a godsend for our community," said Gloria Quary, executive director of the Willowbrook Project Area Committee, an economic and community development group. "A lot of local people who were looking for work have found it at Denny's, which as you know doesn't have the best reputation in our community.
"It's also more convenient to have a nice restaurant right around the corner instead of having to drive miles away just to get a decent meal."
 
Kimchi and Burritos
 But Mr. Bohana's restaurant is not the only Denny's that needs extra space in its menus. The Denny's in the Japantown section of San Francisco serves dishes popular among Asians, including fried rice with chicken, pork or sausage; loko moko, a meat patty with steamed rice, gravy and eggs that is common in Hawaii, Korea and Japan, and dakine, a breakfast combination of Maui's Portuguese sausage, eggs, rice, and kimchi. Ahdi Nashashibi, the owner, said Asian dishes account for about 20 percent of his sales.
Also, several Denny's restaurants in the Southwest serve Mexican items like burritos, huevos rancheros and green chilies.
Denny's, a subsidiary of the Flagstar Companies, based in Spartanburg, S.C., said it was also testing Southern vegetables like fried okra and specially prepared green beans at several restaurants in the South and was seeking ideas for other new menu items from its franchisees.
Franchisees will continue to pay Denny's a 4 percent royalty on all restaurant revenues, even if the sales come from items other than those found on the basic Denny's menu. A new Denny's franchise costs about $35,000.
Denny's operating income declined 37.5 percent, to $24.5 million, in the third quarter, compared with $39.3 million in the comparable period a year earlier. The results were hurt by higher food costs and the expenses from advertising efforts to address the discrimination lawsuits. Mr. Sullivan said the company has spent about $6 million on such advertising and several million dollars on legal fees relating to the suits.
Denny's said the recent decline in traffic at its restaurants is due partly to the lawsuits, but that the recession has also played a big role. Denny's does not have a racial breakdown of who eats at its restaurants, but Mr. Sullivan said that of Flagstar's restaurant chains -- including Hardee's, El Pollo Loco and Quincy Family Steakhouses -- Denny's has the lowest number of minority customers.
"It's difficult to isolate the direct impact of the lawsuits, but we suspect that a lot of people stopped coming to Denny's as the result of them," Mr. Sullivan said.
In July, Denny's announced an agreement with the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to give blacks a larger role in the company's management and to increase minority ownership of its franchises.
 
$300,000 Investment
 The Watts-Willowbrook Denny's, however, is not part of the N.A.C.C.P. agreement. It is the brainchild of Mr. Brohana, who sought to put his business skills to work in the inner city.
Mr. Brohana, who is black, said he had invested $300,000 of his own money in the restaurant. He called it "Denny's N the Hood," a reference to "Boyz N the Hood," the John Singleton film about life in inner-city Los Angeles.
That's where Mr. Bohana gets some of his supplies, where he found the man to cook the soul food and where most of his employees live. Many were on public assistance before they came to work for him.
"I get my pies from a local bakery," he said. "One of my waitresses makes the cakes. And some women from the community make the potato salad."
The operating costs of a restaurant in the inner city, including security and insurance, are considerably higher than those in other areas, Mr. Brohana said, but so are the rewards.
When the restaurant opened in September 1992, several local patrons were surprised that they did not have to pay for their meals before being served, Mr. Brohana said. "They were so accustomed to eating in fast-food joints that they would say: 'You mean you trust me to sit here and eat all this food and then pay you when I'm done?' "
Mr. Brohana often encounters situations that are not covered in the Denny's manager's manual. He recently noticed that the soft music the restaurant played was not doing its job of relaxing people as they waited for their food. His customers were fidgety. So he now plays a black radio station.
Neither Denny's nor Mr. Bohana would release sales numbers for his restaurant. He said that he expected to post a profit in 1994 and would have had one in 1993, but his sales were hurt by the negative publicity of the discrimination suits.
"Most people have a dim view of the Watts-Willowbrook area, but there is money to be made in the inner city," he said. "You just have to be willing to be an entrepreneur, a risk taker. I feel fortunate that I have been able to come home and serve my people."

HEADLINE: Rights in China Improve, Envoy Says

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, Dec. 31

 BODY:
Despite what he calls continuing abuses of human rights in China, the United States Ambassador here argues that Beijing has made "dramatic" progress in improving the lives of its citizens and that this record should be taken into account when policy toward China is reviewed early in the new year.
In an interview this week, Ambassador J. Stapleton Roy said that the setbacks in human rights represented by the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989 and the wave of repression that followed were being steadily reversed, and that the Communist Party had loosened its control over many aspects of Chinese life. 
 His comments came before a Congressional review in January of China's record on human rights. Before July, President Clinton must decide whether China has made "overall, significant progress" in human rights and thus deserves to have its beneficial trade status renewed.
 
Question of Progress on Rights
 Mr. Roy, 58, a career diplomat who is to complete his tour in Beijing next summer, said he could not predict whether China would satisfy the standard of "overall, significant progress."
"I can't answer those questions, because the Administration is going to have to define what it views as significant progress," he said.
He acknowledged that there had been important human rights "setbacks" in 1993, including arrests and harsh treatment of political and religious dissidents. But he said the economic and technological revolution promoted by Deng Xiaoping since 1978 had stripped away much of the ideological prison in which the Chinese had lived for three decades.
In an executive order in May, President Clinton said there were seven key areas in which China had to make "overall, significant progress" before he could renew its trade privileges in July 1994. Among the areas are "releasing and providing an acceptable accounting for Chinese citizens imprisoned or detained for the nonviolent expression of their political and religious beliefs."
 
Role of Security Forces
 Mr. Roy said that human rights abuses were likely to persist for the foreseeable future under the Communist Party and the security apparatus that keeps it in power.
But in nearly two hours of discussion this week, the American Ambassador argued that the overall economic and social transformation under way in China should not be ignored.
China now trades with the United States under what is known as "most favored nation" status, which means that its exports face the lowest trade barriers in force when they enter the United States. China has angrily denounced those in Congress who favor revoking this status to punish Beijing for its human rights record.
The Clinton Administration has had to balance its approach to China between those who call for punitive action over rights violations and those who argue that China must be accommodated because of its importance as a growing market for American goods and investment and as a potential security partner.
In addition, the Administration has tried to engage China in trying to persuade North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons program, and many argue that a confrontational approach with Beijing does not work.
In his remarks, Mr. Roy took care to reserve for the White House a full range of policy options should China fail to make further progress in human rights.
 
Opposition to Linkage
 But he was far more explicit than his superiors have been in showing a preference for abandoning the practice of linking of China's trading status to its human rights record, calling the linkage abnormal.
"At the core of our approach," Mr. Roy said, "is not the idea that we can somehow get beyond the human rights factor in our relationship with China.
"Rather, it is a question of what is the most effective way" to press human rights concerns, he said, while conducting normal diplomacy on crucial Asian security issues.
"If you look at the 150 years of modern China's history since the Opium Wars, then you can't avoid the conclusion that the last 15 years are the best 15 years in China's modern history," Mr. Roy said. "And of those 15 years, the last 2 years are the best in terms of prosperity, individual choice, access to outside sources of information, freedom of movement within the country and stable domestic conditions."
Mr. Roy was referring to social and economic forces that have effectively curtailed monolithic Communist Party control over where people live, work and go to school and whether they can be admitted to universities or get married.
He argued that a new "diversity" had taken root in Chinese society, reflected in a willingness to express individual views, an information revolution wrought by satellite television and fax machines and a new Government "tolerance" for many forms of criticism. He also cited the beginnings of a legal foundation that might help Chinese citizens seek redress and compensation for abuses.
 
Advocates Further Dialogue
 Mr. Roy made clear that in his view, the most effective way to resolve disputes with China was through the intensified diplomatic dialogue that began last fall after a review of China policy at the White House and the State Department.
If Secretary of State Warren Christopher "were to recommend next May that we should extend" China's trading privileges "without conditions, that would not remove human rights from our foreign policy agenda with China," Mr. Roy said.
"We would expect to still continue an active human rights dialogue with the Chinese," he said, "and we would continue to expect to see significant progress on human rights issues."
Ambassador Roy said China's top leaders had taken Mr. Clinton's seriously when he had warned that China's favorable trade access to the American market would be on the line in 1994.
"We see progress in some areas, and, yes, we do see continuing negative factors in other areas," he said. "And so our purpose is to try to encourage the further progress in the areas that will be taken into account next May."
Mr. Roy said China had released the "vast bulk" of political prisoners seized in the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown and, with the release of Wei Jingsheng in September, the major figures from the Democracy Wall period of 1978-79.
 
Dissidents Still in Prison
 But a number of democracy campaigners from the Tiananmen Square uprising remain in prison, some of them with severe medical problems, he added. He said Beijing should release them on medical grounds, granting them a form of parole.
With Mr. Clinton having met with President Jiang Zemin in November in Seattle, Mr. Roy said, the two countries are carrying on their most extensive dialogue in five years.
Mr. Roy suggested that with further progress from China in coming months, this dialogue could supplant the contentious annual debate in Congress over whether to extend China's trading privileges, and remove the constant threat of disruption to the increasingly interconnected trade channels between China, Hong Kong, Taiwan and the United States.
The Ambassador, who was born in China to a missionary family in Nanjing and witnessed the Communist takeover in 1949 from Shanghai, said that any new wave of Government repression against Chinese citizens would certainly bring an immediate response from Washington.
"It is impossible for a country like the United States to have normal relations with a country that resorts to overt suppression against its own people," he said. There "will be an impact on the U.S. relationship with China when such repression occurs."
Mr. Roy added that while the widening of individual freedoms represented a "radical transformation" of Chinese society, American policy makers could not forget that China relied fundamentally on "repression as its normal means of maintaining control," mainly through the state security forces.

Stapleton Roy, United States Ambassador to China. He said significant progress has been made in human rights. (Manuel Ceneta/Agence France-Presse for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.A.W. Wants Trade Payoff in Jobs

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 31

 BODY:
Looming over the Edsel Ford Freeway near the General Motors Corporation headquarters here, a billboard recently proclaimed one of the many benefits vaunted by supporters of the North American Free Trade Agreement: 15,000 new auto-related jobs in the United States in the first year.
The billboard is gone now, but the promise is far from forgotten by one group defeated in the free-trade battle: the United Automobile Workers union. 
 "We're going to be waiting and looking with bated breath for those 15,000 good-paying jobs," said Owen F. Bieber, president of the U.A.W.
Union leaders were not impressed recently when the Ford Motor Company announced that it would shift production of some vehicles among its American, Canadian and Mexican plants as a result of the trade agreement, recalling 300 workers in Mexico and creating 550 new jobs north of the border.
All told, Ford said, the move could lead to 6,000 new auto-related jobs. But those jobs, Ford said, would be created in the United States and Canada. And some of them, Ford said, would not be new jobs, but "job equivalents" -- that is, overtime worked by already employed workers.
Such fuzziness, the U.A.W. claims, has overtaken other once-clear benchmarks set by the North American Free Trade Agreement's proponents before the agreement passed.
Before the passage, boosters including President Clinton asserted that in the first year of the agreement, the Big Three would export 60,000 cars to Mexico, compared with 7,700 currently. But recently, top executives of the Big Three -- like their critics before the trade accord passed -- have cast doubt on that number.
"The 60,000 number -- I have to tell you, I have not ever discussed that number, nor do I know the origin of it," Robert J. Eaton, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, told reporters.
"Well, they do know where it came from," Mr. Bieber retorted, pointing out that the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, the Big Three's trade association, pushed the number. "If it was false, then they had an obligation to say, wait a minute. We're for Nafta, but don't get us into a box where we're going to be expected to sell 60,000 cars."
Now that the auto makers are in that box, Mr. Bieber clearly relishes keeping them there, insisting that they sell all 60,000 and create all 15,000 new jobs. "By God, I'll tell you this, we're going to keep tabs of how many are sold there, and we're going to remind people of this," he said.
 
Parts Supplier Movements
 While he does not expect the auto makers to move assembly plants to Mexico overnight, Mr. Bieber said he thought they would begin pushing their parts suppliers to relocate there in pursuit of lower-cost labor.
In a recent interview at Solidarity House, the U.A.W.'s headquarters here, Mr. Bieber reflected both on his recent defeat on the trade agreement and on what most auto analysts regard as his recent victory over the Big Three in national labor contract negotiations. As he spoke about the future of labor and of his union -- whose diverse but declining membership includes not only auto workers but state employees and jai alai players -- he adopted a wait-and-see attitude toward Mr. Clinton, whose support he acknowledged he needs to fulfill a broad legislative agenda.
"I have great respect," Mr. Bieber allowed with the faintest of grins, "for his ability to get people to vote his way."
Indeed, Mr. Bieber has not taken the big picture of him with Mr. Clinton off his office wall, despite the irony that the President's scribble has acquired since the trade agreement vote: "with thanks for all your help."
"We worked hard in 1992 to help elect Bill Clinton President of the United States," Mr. Bieber said. "I have no regrets."
 
Fourth and Final Term at U.A.W.
 At 65, Mr. Bieber, a hulking man and a tenacious bargainer, is serving his fourth and final term as U.A.W. president. He will retire in 1995, ending a career with the U.A.W. that began in 1949.
In contrast to the time Mr. Bieber started negotiating for auto workers, the legal deck is now stacked heavily against labor, he said, which he contends is one reason union membership is declining. The U.A.W.'s membership has dropped from 1.5 million in 1979 to about 850,000 today.
To restore labor's bargaining power, Mr. Bieber said, Mr. Clinton needs to finish making his appointments to the National Labor Relations Board. Mr. Bieber contends that the board tilted drastically toward management during the Reagan-Bush years.
Mr. Bieber also said the President should lobby for the so-called striker-replacement bill. That proposal, which Mr. Clinton has said he strongly supports, would make it illegal for companies to replace striking workers permanently, a practice that became much more common in the last decade. The bill was held up by a Republican filibuster in the Senate.
"The President can help himself tremendously among the trade-union movement by going out and actively campaigning for the right of the Senate to vote" on the bill, Mr. Bieber said. "To say, 'permanently replace' -- you might as well say you don't have the right under law to strike, when you have a situation with a shortage of jobs and a large unemployment pool."
With the playing field leveled again, Mr. Bieber said, unions would begin to grow, which he argued is the best way to preserve the country's middle class.
"You can't just keep talking about good high-paying jobs," he said.
But Mr. Bieber acknowledged that his union had suffered because of inroads overseas competitors had made in the auto industry, seizing about a quarter of the domestic market for new cars and trucks.
To help stem the flow of industrial jobs overseas, Mr. Bieber said, the U.A.W. will continue fighting for Mr. Clinton's health-care plan. While the union favors a single-payer approach, Mr. Bieber said, Mr. Clinton's plan, as presented, offers the best hope for restraining health-care costs for large employers, which will help keep their labor costs competitive.

HEADLINE: Treasury Rates Largely Unchanged

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Treasury securities prices closed narrowly mixed yesterday, with long-term interest rates mostly unchanged and short-term rates fractionally higher.
The trading session closed at 2 P.M., as dealers closed their books early for New Year's Eve. Over all, the market's tone was bearish, with some traders still cautious about the strength in recent economic data and its implications for inflation. 
 On Thursday, a sharp decline in prices came in extremely slow trading, which was prevalent all week, and opened the market to exaggerated movements. Analysts cautioned that volume was too low to draw many conclusions.
 
 
Yield Stuck at 6.34%
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged yesterday, with the yield stuck at 6.34 percent, the same as on Thursday but a five-week high. The bond's yield on the last day of trading was 1.05 percentage points lower than at the start of the year, during which interest rates fell to historic lows.
Rates on three-month bills gained 2 basis points, to 2.99 percent, and the six-month bill declined a basis point, to 3.19 percent. Traders said the one-year bill was unchanged at 3.44 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Peter McTeague, a fixed-income analyst with the Technical Data Division of Thomson Financial Services, described yesterday's bond market activity as indifferent, with some last-minute positioning. "There certainly aren't any buyers," he said.
Analysts at MMS International said economic data to be reported in the first few weeks of the new year would likely determine the market's intermediate-term direction. And while the Jan. 7 release of December's employment report will be important, "the more critical data will be those reflecting first-quarter activity," the analysts said.
They contend that the market will focus on whether the economic strength exhibited in the fourth quarter can be sustained in the new year. Thus, they say, the most important reports coming up will be those reflecting early January data, including initial jobless claims, retail sales and the consumer confidence indexes.
 
 
Livingston Survey
 In its twice-yearly survey of 61 economists, the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank said yesterday that United States economic growth would average around 3 percent in 1994.
It said real gross domestic product would reach a 4 percent growth rate for the fourth quarter of 1993. In the first half of 1994, G.D.P. growth will ease back to 2.8 percent, rising to 2.9 percent in the second half, it predicted.
The survey, known as the Livingston Survey, said consumer inflation would rise at an annual rate of 3.1 percent through June 1994 and 3.3 percent in the second half of the year.
The respondents expect the unemployment rate to fall to 6.2 percent by the end of 1994, and they see long-term interest rates creeping up to about 6.4 percent.
Traders said the report had little impact on the market.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Mixed Results for the Dollar On a Curtailed Trading Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mixed against other leading currencies yesterday in quiet New Year's Eve trading that lasted only a few hours.
With staffs already depleted by the holiday, and European markets mostly closed by the time New York traders arrived at work, few were willing to stake out new market positions. 
 Similarly, gold and silver trading was curtailed, since the Commodity Exchange in New York was closed.
The uneventful day was a sort of counterpoint to a year of tumult on world currency markets. As the Maastricht Treaty for European Union appeared in trouble this summer, many European currencies plunged in value.
Treasury and monetary officials were forced to change their exchange-rate rules to widen the range that currencies could fluctuate against one another. That allowed currencies to fall in line with the demands of foreign-exchange traders, but also made it harder for merchants to anticipate exchange rates when buying and selling in Europe.
Stable exchange rates have been regarded as one key to the success of European union, one of the goals of which has been a common European currency.
A sense that the United States economy is recovering more quickly than economies in Europe also helped the dollar to post strong annual gains against other leading currencies.
 
Tokyo Takes a Holiday
 Financial markets were closed yesterday in Tokyo, but in London the dollar finished at 111.76 yen, down from 112 yen late Thursday. In New York trading, the dollar settled at 111.85 yen, up slightly from 111.81 yen on Thursday.
For all of 1993, the dollar has fallen about 10 percent against the yen, although some analysts expect the dollar to find new strength in 1994 amid continued uncertainty over the Japanese economy.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.4807 from $1.4768 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.4778 to buy one pound, more expensive than Thursday's $1.4765.
The pound has fallen 2 percent against the dollar in the last year, having finished 1992 at $1.5105.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.7388 German marks, up from 1.7353; 1.4884 Swiss francs, up from 1.4820; 5.9213 French francs, up from 5.8930; 1,716.50 Italian lire, up from 1,712.00, and 1.3217 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3296.
A year ago, the dollar finished at 1.6206 German marks, 1.4670 Swiss francs, 5.5265 French francs, 1,472.5 Italian lire and 1.2710 Canadian dollars.
In Zurich, gold fell to $390.20 an ounce, off $1.80. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.50, to $390.65.

HEADLINE: Eisner Says Euro Disney May Close

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 31

 BODY:
In the strongest indication yet that Euro Disney is in danger of closing, Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, has told a news magazine in France that the struggling French theme park could shut down if he failed to reach an agreement with its creditor banks on a financial rescue.
An article published today in the French news magazine Le Point quoted Mr. Eisner as saying that Euro Disney must reach an agreement by March 31 with its banks and investors on a solution to the park's financial crisis. 
 "If the engine of an airplane falls out in full flight, what are the options?" Mr. Eisner said in the article. "Anything is possible today, including closure."
The magazine said Mr. Eisner made the comments two weeks ago. Still, the article today was the second published report in a week in which Mr. Eisner had publicly criticized the performance of the company's unprofitable Euro Disney venture. In Walt Disney's 1993 annual report, released on Tuesday, Mr. Eisner said the French theme park was "our first real financial disappointment" since he took over the company more than a decade ago. Mr. Eisner blamed the dismal performance on Europe's recession and the strong French franc.
Walt Disney, based in Burbank, Calif., owns 49 percent of Euro Disney, which has been losing money since it opened in April 1992. Telephone calls to the offices and homes of Walt Disney officials were not returned.
On the Paris Bourse today, shares of Euro Disney tumbled 2.6 French francs, or 8 percent, to 30.4 francs in reaction to the report. On the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Disney fell $1.125, to $42.625.
Creditors, which include Banque Nationale de Paris, Credit Agricole, Deutsche Bank, Midland Bank, J. P. Morgan and Banque Indosuez, have begun negotiations with Euro Disney and the Walt Disney Company, but progress toward a solution has been slow.
Analysts have said Euro Disney would need a cash infusion of $1.5 billion to give it a chance of paying down its debt of $3.75 billion.
A possibility under review is that part of Euro Disney's debt could be converted into stock, of which Mr. Eisner would assume $750 million if the banks came up with the balance, the analysts said. But so far the banks are reluctant to accept such a plan until they have evidence that the performance of the theme park will improve.
An analyst, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said today that he thought Mr. Eisner's comments in Le Point were intended to "paint a worst-case scenario to expedite an agreement between the bankers."

Attendance Declines
 ANAHEIM, Calif., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Attendance slipped at Disneyland in 1993, an industry publication reported. It also dropped at Knott's Berry Farm, but rose at two other big amusement parks in Southern California, Universal Studios Hollywood and Six Flags Magic Mountain.
Amusement Business magazine said the attendance figure of 11.4 million people for Disneyland in Anaheim this year was down slightly from the 1992 figure.
Amusement Business gets some of its information from the parks, but does not disclose its methods for obtaining figures from parks like Disneyland, which usually does not make its attendance numbers public.
The region's lingering recession was blamed for the reported drop in attendance at Disneyland and Knott's. Southern California has yet to enjoy many of the economic improvements felt elsewhere in the country.

HEADLINE: What New York City Has Done to Attract Biotechnology Labs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
An article on the biotechnology industry in New York City (Dec. 15) leaves the impression that the city's efforts to nurture this growing sector of the economy have sprung into being overnight. This is not the case. For example, in 1990, during the first six months of the Dinkins administration, we moved the long-delayed Audubon Biotechnology Research Center through the public approval process. Construction on this 100,000 square-foot biotechnology facility began last winter. 
 In the last year, a task force led by Deputy Mayor Barry Sullivan developed a biotechnology strategic plan, with three components: financing, real estate and technical assistance. Financing, by the $60 million Advanced Technology Fund, will provide venture capital to early- and middle-stage New York-based companies in advanced technology, including biotechnology. The city is reviewing proposals from private venture firms to manage this fund. The city has committed $10 million of seed capital and will work with the fund manager to secure private investments and Federal support.
A second part of the strategy will also soon bear fruit. The Economic Development Corporation has issued a request-for-proposal seeking a developer for a 200,000 square-foot biotechnology facility for new and established biotechnology companies. The city has been working over the last year with private developers to create a biotechnology center in an existing building. We expect a developer will be selected by late February.
Given the complexity involved in the development of the biotechnology industry, we believe the city has taken active steps for more than three years to support and nurture this area of potential economic growth. The city government, working with research institutions, teaching hospitals, financial institutions and industry representatives has now reached a crucial point where all concerned are engaged in a serious joint effort to create a climate favorable for this industry.
 
ANN WEISBROD
Senior V.P., New York City Economic Development Corporation
New York, Dec. 21, 1993

HEADLINE: On Washington;
Up Close and Personal

BYLINE: By Maureen Dowd

 BODY:
We had settled what we were. Now we were simply haggling over the price.
It was one of those moments of cozy debasement that Washington specializes in, only this time the quid pro quo was more naked than usual. 
 The scene was a holiday party for reporters at the White House, which might conjure up sugarplum visions of scarfing down clam dip with Hillary and trading hair-styling tips with Bill.
Not at all. The party was, in essence, a queue.
As we came into the residence -- which was fairy-tale lovely, with a forest of snowy trees, a gingerbread White House and madrigal singers -- we were given little blue slips. There was a time jotted on each; mine was 6:20 P.M.
The time indicated when we were supposed to go down to a room on the floor below and have our picture taken with the President and First Lady. There was a long line, including some reporters who had viciously attacked Clinton in print and others who had mocked the way White House aides trip over each other to get into the shot with the President.
Most of the reporters insisted that they only wanted the pictures to send to their mothers. But the Clintons and their chroniclers know that access is the coin of their realm.
With such Serious Personal Face Time, as the Clinton crowd calls it, we could see that the President's nose was only a little red from his allergy to evergreens and that Hillary was wearing heavier makeup than usual.
"You got your hair cut," she beamed at me. (Later, I learned she had mistaken me for someone else.)
But if it was debasing for us to line up for party favors -- we also got leather bookmarks with a Presidential seal -- imagine the evening from the Clintons' point of view: You are the most important man in the world. Your wife is the most important woman in the world. (At least, that's what George Stephanopoulos tells you.) And this is how you spend your evenings. Standing still for hours before a fireplace and a picture of George Washington, shaking hands and grinning for the camera, with the very people you most disdain, who are kind enough to bring to the world's attention all your little flaws.
And, the worst of it is, while reporters can be seduced, it rarely works in the long run. Ask George Bush. When he moved into the White House, Bush loved to give the press tours of the family quarters. ("Does anybody want to see the bathroom?" he would ask brightly.)
Wooing the press, as Bush found out, is an exercise roughly akin to picknicking with a tiger. You might enjoy the meal, but the tiger always eats last.
PRESIDENTS WILL ALWAYS try, though. For influential pundits, they dangle even more glamorous dinner-and-movie evenings. I don't get invited to those, but on a recent evening I crashed a screening of "The Pelican Brief" as the last-minute date of an invited guest, a Washington columnist. The Clintons, to their credit, didn't call for the guards to haul me out. They were, in fact, charming. (But then, being charming was the point of the whole exercise.)
As we were coming up on New Year's, I had been worried that we might find the President in his Renaissance Weekend mode, holding forth on the fine points of GATT and Nafta, or NATT and Gafta, or whatever. But I was lucky. It was a few days before the words "Arkansas," "trooper" and "Whitewater" became verboten and the President was in a country boy state of mind. His conversation over cocktails focused on his prowess in cow-chip-tossing and frog-jumping contests. Crouching to show how you kept the frog in its own lane, Clinton explained that Arkansas politicians were expected to show their leadership skills at a festival, held in a place known as (for reasons presumably better left unexplained) Toad Suck.
The President also talked about how much he loved helping Chelsea with her math homework, even though it was often hard. He was asked why he couldn't simply make the Administration's numbers crunchers do it. Laughing, he confessed that once, after he and Chelsea had labored fruitlessly to devise a mathematical calculation explaining "the wave," the synchronized movement of sports fans, he sheepishly asked the advice of Alan Blinder, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers.
He spoke fondly about Camp David and its old-fashioned entertainments, including pinball.
I asked why he hadn't gotten the high-tech Vice President to install some virtual reality games.
"He's virtual reality," Clinton drawled. "I'm reality."
He showed off a Christmas tree decorated with crafts from around the country, stopping when he spotted a needlepoint portrait of him that looked like a horrifying cross between Jimmy Carter and Jackie Mason. And Hillary Clinton held up her favorite ornament: a cookie baking mold of a Christmas tree topped by a feminist symbol.
John Grisham, who wrote the book "The Pelican Brief," told Clinton that they were distantly related. "Well," the President said, "if I'm going to have relatives falling from the sky, I may as well have one rich one."
Dinner was rockfish, but the snack-food President came through during the movie, with bags of popcorn twice as big as the ones in the Bush era. After watching the Washington thriller, Hillary Clinton kidded about the scenes showing closed-circuit cameras spying on the Oval Office. (The idea seemed to amuse the First Lady more than her husband; over the next few days, one aide said, Clinton made uneasy jokes about the hidden cameras, about how that could never happen in real life, could it?)
IT WAS, ALL IN ALL, A very pleasant evening. I got some material for this column, fully aware that propinquity brings its own corruption. Once a reporter has met someone and liked him, it is hard to treat him with the same clinical dispassion.
From afar, Bill Clinton can still seem slick and Hillary Clinton cold; but that night, they came across as warm and likable.
But what is real in this hall of mirrors? Do you see more of the genuine President and First Lady when you go behind the scenes, or are they simply better able to modulate their behavior to win you over? Gaining access to each concentric circle of Presidential access is an exercise in onion peeling. Who is to say which layer of Presidential skin is the real one? In Washington, the first impression is often as valid as the last.
As I write this column, the glossy picture of me and the Clintons, taken at the press party, arrives from the White House. We're all smiling broadly, like we're friends, which we're not, and like we're having a good time, which we weren't. I won't frame it; that would make me feel like a sycophant. I'll stick it in a drawer. Or I'll send it to my mom. That's the only reason I did it, anyway.

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
Cities Are So Much More Orderly Than People

BYLINE: By Vicki Goldberg

 BODY:
For various reasons, starting with long exposures, 19th-century photographers of cities tended to concentrate on the well-ordered majesty of vista and facade while scanting the decidedly irregular appeal of human beings. Yet all through the century, people were racing and pouring into urban centers. In 1800, not one city in the western world had a million inhabitants, but by 1850, Paris did, and London had more than two million. By 1900, 11 cities, including New York, Berlin, Tokyo and Calcutta, had expanded beyond a million. Photographers, like all city dwellers, resorted to strategies to avoid the crowds: Eugene Atget, for one, would get up very early to find Paris pure.
Between about 1890 and 1915, photographers made three discoveries about cities that still influence urban imagery. One: that urban areas were dangerous and destructive to their inhabitants. (Jacob Riis's photographs of tenement life came out around 1890.) Two: that the undistinguished corners of metropolis and the life of its streets were piquant subject matter. Three: that urban geometries were the perfect modernist subject, and that rather than documenting the city's splendors the camera could cull abstractions and personal artistic statements from its surfaces. 
 All three notions are currently on exhibit in two shows that make good browsing: "Urban Visions: The City in the 20th Century" at the Houk Friedman gallery on Madison Avenue, and "Points of View: New York in the 1930's" at Howard Greenberg Gallery in Soho (both through Jan. 15).
"Urban Visions" cuts a wider swath, running lightly across many photographers, from Paul Strand in 1915 to Michael O'Neill in 1986. Most of the pictures combine the grand 19th-century tradition with the more recent dictum that modern design lurks on every corner. These images focus on architecture and engineering, which are much more fastidiously arranged and predictable than human beings. "New York in the 1930's" presents just three photographers in some depth: Berenice Abbott, who took her architecture straight; Alexander Alland, intrigued by the city's economic and political undercurrents; and Arnold Eagle, with a foot in both camps.
What lingers from the 19th century, playing at the edges of "Urban Visions," is a sense of the city as a powerful force that makes visible the socializing, tranquilizing forces of reason and order. Thus Henry Robertson Jr.'s two pictures of the San Francisco World's Fair in 1938 show a mighty structure and a carefully designed walkway, both dwarfing passers-by and reducing the world to pattern. Alfred Cheney Johnson puts one of New York's twin-towered buildings into the mathematical center of his photograph to emphasize the durable satisfactions of symmetry.
Romancing the city also reveals a trust in the promise of urban organization. Soft focus and blur or dramatic light and steam make pictorialist concessions to beauty but also display tenderness for the brick-and-stone fortresses where most of life is passed. Jaromir Funke's 1924 "Staircase of Old Prague" is as soft as if stone were melting, and Kenneth Dudley Smith's 1925 interior of Grand Central with the sun streaming down like hosannas ought to be set to Beethoven.
The most resolutely modernist photographers recorded the 20th-century city as a new form with a claim on times to come. They relished bird's-eye angles overlooking a world transformed by the view into mathematics, mechanics and patterns. Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, ever trying to revise vision itself, saw the people below as decorative shapes; Gordon Coster shot the Chrysler Building on a diagonal that gave it a thrust and force it never quite had under the normal rules of gravity. And Eugene Dallen found a perfect abstraction of circles and half cylinders that gives not a clue to its original function.
Such images actually owe as much to reverence for the camera and for the power of the photographer's own eye as to the city itself. The urban center, like most of the world once modernism arrived and photographers decided they were artists, became a treasure trove the camera could convert to private purposes, presumably the higher ones of art and personal expression.
Except for pictures of lovers glimpsed in the streets and images of fragmentary people -- legs hurrying by, headless silhouettes -- most of these paeans to the girders, metallic gleam and reflections of the city sideline the populace. Human beings tend to be distant, blurred or merely a sort of esthetic grace note. Technology still rules. The Brooklyn Bridge looms large in both shows. Possibly the bridge is more meticulously engineered than a human being, and certainly it has lasted longer, but its beauty may well symbolize a promise it did not quite fulfill even in the 30's. Try crossing it today at 8:30 A.M.
Downtown at Howard Greenberg, Berenice Abbott too finds the city more powerful when not inconveniently cluttered with people. Abbott had personally saved Atget's negatives from destruction at the end of the 20's, and her love affair with New York was a kind of American response to his homage to Paris.
Where Atget dwelt on the past in full knowledge that old Paris was fast disappearing, she looked to the future in a city raised skyward on the foundations of industrial engineering. If Manhattan did not have a Place de la Concorde, it had its sweeping spaces and rather more perfunctory signs of majesty at the Hoboken Ferry station on 23d Street. Everywhere it had skyscrapers, and over and over they cut the sky up into intricate shapes as if to rearrange the forms of nature to suit a modern civilization.
Alexander Alland changes the discourse of these two shows by focusing often on people and indicating that their lives were more agitated than the facades of their buildings. Until Jacob Riis altered the terms of city photography, photographers had refused to take any significant note of the troubles that occurred in and were largely caused by cities, even though writers like Dickens had made the problems unmistakable 50 years earlier. Those problems must have seemed safer to read about than look at. After Riis, photographers bore witness to the shifting effects of urban life. By then, cities contained most of the population -- in 1920, the Census Bureau officially declared America an urban nation.
Alland, intrigued by the ethnic mix of Manhattan, made extensive rec ords. His pictures of gypsies are both good and informative, though perhaps a trifle too pleased with the subjects' exotic flavor, a pleasure not particularly frowned on at the time. Alland's most interesting pictures at Howard Greenberg are a few of political and economic ferment, including a robustly stylized one of a picket line, a deliberately off-kilter photograph of an anti-F.D.R. cartoon and a forlorn image of a doll hung by the neck in a storefront as a plea for the Child Labor Amendment.
Arnold Eagle was a film maker and photographer who also looked long at particular populations. ("One Third of a Nation," his document of poverty, is on view at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum; "At Home Only With God," about orthodox Jews, was published by Aperture last year.) At Greenberg there is a mix of his steady observation and sometimes dramatic lighting -- eat your heart out over the late, great interior of Penn Station -- and a few images of properly dressed lower-class children with slipping socks and untied shoes, or of tenements where sheets hang out to dry in the sooty air.
It is fascinating how much photographers (and the rest of us too) admired and still love the cities where so much misery lodges. The photographers in these two exhibitions had a stake in the urban environment, which was their own, and they partly imagined and partly invented a way to look at it. Lewis Mumford said the city was "the most precious collective invention of civilization . . . second only to language itself in the transmission of culture," though he feared that the destructive elements built into urban life would take over and the world itself would fail.
Here, as so often when cynicism or heavy irony is in order, Weegee has the last word. In "Accident," at Houk Friedman, the city's dangers strike. Cars scoot blithely down the road past a dead man sprawled beneath a sheet, his hand still clutching a torn-off steering wheel. The drivers hurry by without a glance, but we are forced to look at the soles of the victim's shoes, which are wonderfully fresh, and aimed directly at us.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Park Avenue and 39th Street," 1936, by Berenice Abbott, at Howard Greenberg. (Howard Greenberg Gallery); "Lyon Stadium," 1929, by Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, at Houk Friedman -- A world transformed into mathematics and patterns, with people as decorative shapes. (Houk Friedman)

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL VIEW;
WNCN Met The Enemy. Guess Who?

BYLINE: By Edward Rothstein

 BODY:
"We play the music you don't mind hearing" is the slogan Peter Schickele (a k a P. D. Q. Bach) dreamed up for his imaginary classical radio station, WTWP (Wall to Wall Pachelbel). No selection could be more than 11 minutes long. No vocal music during office hours. No music composed after 1912 except for works like "Bolero." And every composition played before 11 P.M. had to be in a major key.
Unfortunately, Mr. Schickele's manifesto was pretty close to the policy of WNCN in New York before the plug was pulled on its "classical" format two weeks ago. Mario Mazza, the former director of programming and operations, made his approach very clear when he began tampering with the once stable station in 1987: he wanted to make classical radio "mainstream" by "appealing to a much wider variety of people." He programmed "lighter, peppier" music and set up what he called a "power rotation" of the most "well-known, listenable, hummable pieces from classical literature." He was intent on "eliminating organ music, avant-garde, atonal, aleatoric music, waltzes, virtually all vocal music, all monaural and historical recordings." 
 Announcers never let a moment of silence pass at the beginning or end of a piece; disk jockeys imitated pop radio's chummy, insinuating patter; works were fragmented, and the music was all of a kind no one would mind hearing. WNCN called itself the "young classical-music station." In response, WQXR, the only other commercial classical station in New York, which is owned by The New York Times Company, also applied Grecian Formula to its graying broadcasts; it has managed to retain part of its identity but has just dropped flagship shows like "The Listening Room" and "First Hearing," because the management felt they had been around too long.
Variations on the WNCN prescription are still being offered to classical stations around the country by consultants brought in to increase audiences and profits. But here is a case history that should put to rest the widespread delusion that one can reach large, hip new audiences through condescension. In 1990, Arbitron ratings put WNCN's listenership at 755,000; most recently, the estimate was 650,000. Listeners' loyalty to the Wall to Wall Pachelbel format was evidently not strong. So last month, in search of new conquests and new mainstreams, WNCN became WAXQ, and exchanged Boccherini for heavy metal.
Many people are upset. But I doubt that there will be a fraction of the uproar there was in 1974, when WNCN was replaced by WQIV, also a rock station. The classical format was resurrected after extensive protests, political maneuvering, and purchase of the station by GAF, whose president had an interest in classical music. Now the company couldn't care less. "We were in a market that was limited," Randy Bongarten, the current president and general manager of GAF, sagely explained. "It was a saturated situation."
But the station had abdicated long ago. WNCN was actually killed by the now common attitude that high culture must lower its standards and tastes to reach the greatest number of people. The reasons given are either economic or political; the effect is disastrous. Of a variety of magazines concerned with classical music in the 1980's, like High Fidelity, Classical, Ovation, Keynote, Musical America and Opus, most are now extinct because their owners were not content with modest success and jettisoned them or fatally diluted their focus in a quest for larger circulation. The prescription given by the American Symphony Orchestra League is similar: dumb down the concert to bring in new audiences. The result, if the advice is followed, will be the same. A few new listeners may come; many old ones will leave.
The problem is that now, even among those with an investment in the future of the art form, a low-grade anxiety is spreading. Faced with a crisis in arts education and concerns about a tradition that seems increasingly marginal in the context of mass culture, many leaders in the arts desperately grasp at numbers and demographics. As Mr. Mazza once put it: "Trying to make classical music hip, accessible, interesting, or marketable to new audiences is impossible if you try to do it through the music alone." So the music suffers, and the emphasis is on packaging.
Of course, radio faces serious challenges. In the 1930's and 40's, it was not uncommon for dinner parties to be scheduled around unusual classical-music broadcasts. Such forms of attention have gone the way of "Fireside Chats." Classical radio seems relegated to a background role, providing sonic wallpaper. But we know from the Metropolitan Opera broadcasts, from shows like "First Hearing" and from other programs on WQXR and WNYC that different roles are possible.
The market may be limited, but it is passionate and dedicated. And perhaps -- on the radio, as elsewhere in the music business -- success may come by treating the musical tradition with seriousness and imagination. Committed new audiences will be created only if programmers take the art on its own terms, recognize that this music is not simply for entertainment and insist that listeners maintain an active relationship with broadcasts. Instead, WNCN had planned to further limit its repertory to 600 pieces, to be endlessly repeated. Its death came just in time. In classical radio, nothing should be wall-to-wall.
