HEADLINE: The B. Altman Building Goes Bookish

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
"IT was to be a store of infinite resources," declared a commemorative booklet published 80 years ago, when B. Altman & Company expanded its Fifth Avenue dry-goods palace all the way to Madison Avenue, to cover a whole city block.
Substitute "library" for "store" and you get the idea behind the Science, Business and Industry Library, now being built by the New York Public Library within the vast limestone-clad shell that was Altman's flagship until it went out of business in 1989. 
 "It will be one-stop shopping for someone looking for resources in those areas," said William D. Walker, associate director of the Public Library, which bought an eight-floor, 213,000-square-foot condominium unit in the Altman building last year. "Someone remarked the other day, 'How appropriate for a former department store.' "
Furthering that all-under-one-roof sense, the Oxford University Press expects to close tomorrow on its portion of the Altman building: a 110,000-square-foot condominium unit including five floors in the small tower that runs along the Madison Avenue side and a ground-floor lobby at 35th Street, adjacent to the library entrance.
"One of the big attractions of this building was that we'd have a symbiotic relationship with the New York Public Library," said Gerald Sussman, senior vice president at the Oxford University Press.
The executive vice president of the Public Library, John H. Masten, said: "I don't want to overstate it, but we both see each other as compatible co-residents. It has the potential for the whole site to be dedicated to the intellectual life of the city."
The $100 million Science, Industry and Business Library, designed by Gwathmey Siegel & Associates of Manhattan, is to open in 1995, as are the new offices of the Oxford University Press, a $30 million project designed by the New York office of Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum.
With these institutions in place, the general partners in the Altman project -- Morton L. Olshan, a real estate developer and owner who heads Mall Properties, and Peter L. Malkin, a lawyer who is a leading figure in mid-Manhattan real estate and business circles -- can now turn their attention to filling the remaining 600,000 square feet on the Fifth Avenue side of the building with complementary occupants.
"We're talking with other tax-exempt organizations," Mr. Malkin said, "particularly a major educational institution, for the balance of that space." He said the building would probably be divided into at least two more condominiums: one for retail on the ground floor and one or more upstairs.
"This building has uniquely high ceilings," Mr. Malkin said (22 feet on the ground floor, 18 feet on the second and third floors). "For museums that have large works of art -- which you can probably guess are contemporary museums -- this is a unique place to be able to display the works."
Richard P. Steinberg, executive vice president of Mall Properties and a longtime partner of Mr. Olshan, said that three "significant" museums had been attracted to the Altman building, as had two educational institutions, but that "we're not close to anything in terms of our next deal."
"There's a sense among institutions, which like to own, that this might be the time to buy," Mr. Steinberg said. As owners, rather than renters, nonprofit organizations can avoid paying real estate taxes (which are passed through by their landlords as part of the rent) and commercial rent taxes. That was one of the key reasons that the nonprofit Oxford University Press decided to buy, rather than lease.
"It was a big step for Mr. Olshan to sell," said an associate, Jeffrey N. Gordon. "That's not his ordinary way of doing business. But there's no rental market out there."
AS it turned out, there was no market either for a mart to serve the office furnishing industry, which is what Mr. Olshan and Mr. Malkin originally envisioned for the Fifth Avenue side of the building.
It was to be called the New York Resource Center and would have had showrooms, a theater and conference rooms.
But since office construction is at a standstill, the contract furnishing industry is "in hibernation," Mr. Malkin said. "Although they have not been happy at the International Design Center in Long Island City, they have not been in the financial position to undertake major investments or long-term commitments to move anywhere else."
Meanwhile, executives of the Oxford University Press were staring the Altman building in the face. Their office is currently in the Putnam Berkley Building, 200 Madison Avenue, which is directly across 35th Street from the old department store.
"We were running out of space and we weren't getting fair value for our money," said Mr. Sussman, of the Oxford Press.
"We decided we wanted to own our own space," he said. "We wanted finally to put stakes down in New York."
A mere 98 years ago -- quite recently, given the fact that it can trace its origins to the year 1478 -- the Oxford University Press opened a New York office. It moved to 200 Madison Avenue in 1968.
Like other Manhattan buildings acquired in the early 1980's by President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and his wife, Imelda, 200 Madison Avenue went through a difficult period during the legal battle over the Marcos properties. The 26-story tower is now owned by George Comfort and the Loeb Realty and Development Corporation. The land is owned by Alex DiLorenzo 3d.
"For a moment in time," Mr. Sussman recalled, "we were thinking of leaving the city and moving all of our operations to North Carolina" -- where Oxford already has a warehouse, distribution center and offices, in the town of Cary, near Raleigh.
However, the publisher grew convinced that if it could avoid real estate and commerical rent taxes, it could afford to stay. The city's Economic Development Corporation offered assistance, Mr. Sussman said, although financing ultimately came from the New York State Dormitory Authority.
Searching for space, Mr. Sussman said, Oxford looked at several places:
* 420 Fifth Avenue, between 37th and 38th Streets, a 30-story office tower built by the Hammerson Property Investment and Development Corporation. It is a mixture of rental space and condominium units.
* 120 Wall Street, at South Street, a 34-story tower owned by Larry A. Silverstein. Under an arrangement with the city, 20 floors have been set aside as the Association Center, where certain nonprofit organizations are exempt from real estate taxes.
* 10 Union Square East, between 14th and 15th Streets, the five-story commercial base of the Zeckendorf Towers apartment complex. The Macmillan/McGraw-Hill School Publishing Company is a tenant.
The Altman structure won out. "We loved the idea of this landmark building, with all of its character, exactly in the area where we enjoy being," Mr. Sussman said.
"Perhaps one of the most exciting things was having a building within a building," he said, referring to the fact that Oxford will occupy what amounts to its own five-story structure, with 20,000-square-foot floors and views in every direction, perched atop the massive Altman block. Oxford will also have its own entrance on Madison Avenue and a private bank of elevators that will link the lobby to the offices upstairs.
The publisher will exploit its unusual ground-floor space almost as a showroom. It will create a multipurpose room along 35th Street, parallel to the lobby, where the public can attend lectures, seminars and symposia. On the south side of the lobby, a two-level space will be created. The mezzanine will be a library for all Oxford books that are currently in print. Below that will be a waiting room and exhibition area.
"IT is going to establish our presence in the community," said Susan Rotermund, Oxford's publicity manager.
The $30 million Dormitory Authority financing for Oxford was authorized earlier this year in legislation sponsored by State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan. Despite its name, which reflects its original mission, the Dormitory Authority finances a variety of projects by private and public universities and colleges, as well as certain nonprofit organizations. It also finances schools, private hospitals, courthouses and homes for the aged.
"The thought of keeping 250 jobs in New York City while advancing a worthwhile beacon of intellectual life struck me as meritorious," Senator Goodman said.
The authority is also providing $25.5 million in long-term financing for the Science, Industry and Business Library, which is to raise $24.5 million from other government sources and $50 million in private gifts.
The largest donation so far, $7.5 million, came from Lewis B. and Dorothy Cullman. The 80,000-volume circulating library on the ground floor will be named for them.
Most of the public space will be in the basement, reached through a dramatic, two-story atrium that is to be opened up in the southeast corner of the Altman building.
On the lower level will be the main reference desk, as many as 130 computer terminals available for public use, open shelves with 60,000 volumes and more than 450 seats with power and data outlets. Also on this floor will be the area in which readers order and pick up materials from the closed stacks.
The stack core will have five levels, each 10 feet high, running from the second through fourth stories of the Altman building. Some 2 million volumes will be placed there, using compact shelving that almost doubles the capacity. New steel will be required to reinforce the structure and carry this extraordinary weight over the public areas below.
Much of the activity in the circulating library will be visible from the street. "When you look through those wonderful showroom windows, you're going to see people using a library with printed and electronic material," said Mr. Walker, the associate director.
"We expect to draw about 3,000 users daily," said Mr. Masten, the executive vice president of the Public Library. "We see ourselves as an active and visible institutional player on Madison Avenue. We're happy to bring that block back to life."
Mr. Malkin sees the rehabilitation of the Altman building, which he refers to as 361 Fifth Avenue, as part of an overall improvement in the area. He has a keen interest in saying so, as chairman of both the 34th Street Partnership and Grand Central Partnership and as the general partner in Empire State Building Associates, which holds a 114-year master lease on that skyscraper.
He said that a bill before the City Council would expand the Grand Central business improvement district down Fifth Avenue from 38th Street, at Lord & Taylor, to 35th Street, where it would adjoin the 34th Street business improvement district.
That stretch of Fifth Avenue in the mid-30's, which looks somewhat run down, will be "radically changed," Mr. Malkin said, with street cleaning and security patrols furnished by the Grand Central Partnership.
The area also stands to benefit from the revitalization of the Altman building, which has already been cleaned and is now getting enormous replacement windows.
"Not only in terms of real estate but in terms of the general character of the area, it is obviously a wonderful thing," said Charles E. Pierce Jr., director of the Pierpont Morgan Library, at Madison Avenue and 36th Street. "It's hard to imagine two better neighbors than the New York Public Library and Oxford University Press.
"It will undoubtedly improve the overall quality of the neighborhood," he said, "and may even provide us additional customers for our cafe, which opened recently."
EVEN the man who runs 200 Madison Avenue, Peter S. Duncan, executive vice president of George Comfort & Sons, said he was "very happy" with the Altman project -- although it means Oxford is moving out of his building.
"We're sorry to lose a tenant, of course, but that does happen," Mr. Duncan said. "We think, overall, that the improvements they're doing to the property will improve the neighborhood. And our property will get the benefits of it. The business and science library provides a very strong resource."
But he said the greatest impact would be people and lights filling the Altman building for the first time in six years. "That's a very large structure to be dark," Mr. Duncan said. "That's been a big problem."
Although the Manhattan flagship is the largest of the Altman properties that were acquired by Mr. Olshan, Mr. Malkin and their limited partner, Earle W. Kazis, it is not the only one. And the owners, who do business under the corporate name of KMO-361, have been busy rejuvenating the rest, with considerable success. If Altman's did one thing well,Mr. Steinberg said, it placed its branch stores impeccably.
The three-level, 170,000-square-foot store on Route 17 in Paramus, N.J., has been divided in thirds. The first floor is a Bed, Bath & Beyond store and the second is a T. J. Maxx clothing store. The third floor is not leased.
The two-level, 120,000-square-foot store on the Miracle Mile section of Northern Boulevard in Manhasset, L.I., has largely been stripped to structural steel. The owners plan to break it up into five or six stores, but the project has been delayed by legal battles.
The two-level, 170,000-square-foot store in the town of St. David's, Pa., on the Main Line west of Philadelphia, has been divided into four units: a supermarket, a drug store and two clothing stores. Two new buildings have also been added on the 24-acre site.
In White Plains, N.Y., the Altman store was razed to make way for a Nordstrom store, as part of a new mall called the Westchester, being developed by the O'Connor Group, in which KMO-361 keeps an interest.
"The other properties have moved along extremely well," Mr. Malkin said. "The key to conclude everything is the remaining 600,000 square feet in 361 Fifth Avenue."

HEADLINE: State Leads New England in Farming Production

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER 

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT has become the leading agricultural state in New England, the New England Agricultural Statistics Service reported recently.
"Agriculture is flourishing in Connecticut," the director of the Bureau of Marketing and Technology of the State Department of Agriculture in Hartford, Robert R. Pellegrino, said. 
 The professor of agricultural economics at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, Robert Leonard, said the reason is diversification.
As traditional dairy farming declined in Connecticut, as it did almost everywhere in the Northeast, farmers turned to other crops like plants in nurseries and greenhouses, Christmas trees, fruits and vegetables and shellfish.
 
'Growing Nicely'
 "The encouraging thing is that on the basis of year-to-year figures, we are growing nicely," the State Commissioner of Agriculture, John R. H. Blum, said.
The state's 4,000 farmers reported total cash receipts in 1992 of $488.7 million, 3 percent higher than the $472.2 million total in 1991. Their 1992 receipts were higher than in any other New England state, according to the Agricultural Statistics Service. Massachusetts's 6,900 farms produced receipts of $483 million; Maine's 7,100 farms, $474 million; Vermont's 6,900 farms, $452 million; New Hampshire's 2,900 farms, $143 million; and Rhode Island's 700 farms, $72 million.
In Maine, the major crop remained potatoes, which furnished 23.9 percent of the farm receipts. In Vermont, dairy farming is still the major agricultural enterprise in the state, providing 76 percent of the farm income. In Massachusetts, as in Connecticut, greenhouse and nursery crops are the big items, amounting to 33 percent of the farm receipts.
 
Higher Value of Products
 The numbers were compiled by the New England Agricultural Statistics Service, an arm of the United States Department of Agriculture, based in Concord, N.H. It defines a farm as "any establishment from which $1,000 or more of agricultural products were sold or normally would be sold during the year."
Even more encouraging in Connecticut's agriculture picture was a different measure -- the value of its farm products, compiled by the State Department of Agriculture. It is higher than the cash receipts figure because it includes an inventory of crops such as Christmas trees and nursery plants, which continued to grow and were not sold during the year.
In 1992, that total value was $710 million, up 15 percent from $619 million the year before, Mr. Blum said.
A tabulation showed Connecticut's leading agricultural products: Nurseries and greenhouses, $185 million; Eggs and poultry, $105 million; Dairy, $76 million; Livestock, $70 million; Shellfish, $54 million; Tobacco, $47 million; Fruits and vegetables, $47 million; Field crops (hay and silage), $38 million; Forestry, $40 million; Mushrooms, $35 million; Christmas trees, $10 million; Other, $3 million.
The biggest percentage increase of all Connecticut's crops was in shellfish, largely oysters grown in Long Island Sound off Norwalk and Bridgeport, the director of the State Department of Agriculture's aquaculture division, John H. Volk, said.
In 1990, shellfish operators cultivated oyster beds on 44,493 acres under water offshore, producing a crop of 380,000 bushels. Two years later, about the same number of acres produced more than twice as many oysters, 893,964 bushels.
 
'Oyster Crop Looking Good'
 The income from oysters more than doubled, too, to $46 million, up from $22.6 million in 1990, Mr. Volk said.
Although the 1993 figures are not in yet, Mr. Volk said the oyster crop was "looking good" this year.
The biggest decrease in farm income, 33 percent, was reported by tobacco farmers, who for many years were major producers in the Connecticut River valley. Their receipts were $32.9 million in 1992, down from $49.3 million the year before.
Despite that drop, Mr. Blum, a farmer who raises Angus cattle on his farm in Sharon, is optimistic about the future of agriculture in Connecticut.
"We see our agriculture as diversified and increasing," he said. "It's healthier than it has ever been."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Housing for Low-Income Elderly;
. . . 130 on 8.5 Acres in Westfield, N.J.

 BODY:
Construction began last month on a 130-unit housing project for the elderly in Westfield, N.J., on a site adjacent to an existing home, Westfield Senior Citizen Housing.
Forest City Ratner Companies is the developer of the project. The architect is Swanke Hayden Connell Ltd. of Manhattan. 
 The building, which will be owned by the Westfield Senior Citizen Urban Renewal Partnership, will be on an 8.5-acre parcel in the Manor Park neighborhood. The land is owned by the town of Westfield and leased for 33 years to the partnership.
Preliminary site-clearing work began in mid-November and foundation work is currently under way. The building is scheduled to be completed by the end of this year.
The project's design includes 130 one-bedroom apartments, two community rooms for residents, and administrative offices. The construction costs are estimated at about $10 million.
Financing will be provided by Chemical Bank of New Jersey, Transamerica Occidential Life Insurance Corporation of San Francisco and the Westfield Senior Citizens Housing Corporation.
A key part of the project was the Federal Low-Income Housing Tax Credit program. Westfield received an allocation for tax credits, which are being sold to Transamerica Occidential Life Insurance Corporation for about $4.5 million.
"Even though nobody had any idea whether the tax bill containing the tax credits would pass Congress, this team pushed ahead with the planning and the paperwork," said Westfield's Mayor, Garland "Bud" Boothe.

HEADLINE: Giving Gifts Of Talent And Time

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS

 BODY:
PAT TATE, stately and steady as a ship, is a marketing specialist at a midtown Manhattan corporate giant; Nicole Gaffney is a top-knotted sixth-grader who bounces back and forth and up and down like a Super Ball, from chair to table to floor and back again. Once a week their orbits cross over Nicole's homework in the lunchroom of Public School 198 on the Upper East Side.
Richard Milewski, a son of middle-class Queens who lost his home to heroin, toils six or seven hours a day, serving lunch and washing dishes at a soup kitchen in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. 
 Paul Freely, an expatriate Briton who works as a hairdresser in salons around Manhattan, donates 10 hours of his 70-hour workweek, cutting, coloring and combing the hair of people with AIDS.
They are part of what experts say is a growing movement here and all over America, just three of the broadly estimated one million New Yorkers, of every social and economic stripe, who volunteer their time and their talents, smoothing the city's rough edges in ways large and small.
"You go on each day and the person you're mostly thinking about is yourself," Ms. Tate said. "You get yourself up, you feed yourself, you get yourself to work. And the opportunity to volunteer, even if it's only two hours a week, gives you a chance to think about somebody other than yourself."
At the Mayor's Voluntary Action Center, the executive director, Winifred L. Brown, says inquiries about volunteering have risen 30 percent in the last year. That mirrors a nationwide surge in volunteering that many experts say is a direct result of the recession. Those who have lost jobs find purpose, new skills, simply something to do. Those who have jobs volunteer out of gratitude, heightened social awareness and, yes, guilt.
In New York, the desire to volunteer often springs from a sense of civic helplessness and anger, a feeling in many quarters that government alone cannot keep the city afloat.
"People are frustrated with 'quality of life' issues and the city's overwhelming social and environmental problems," said Kenneth Adams, executive director of New York Cares, which assigns 2,000 volunteers a month to various projects. "We have to rise up and fill that gap."
Many people, too, say that volunteering provides a sense of community in an often cold and lonely city.
"Two-thirds of the people who come in here are between the ages of 18 and 35, and most of them see this as a way to meet other people," said Nancy D. Carr, president of the Volunteer Referral Center in Manhattan, which places 2,000 volunteers every year with nonprofit agencies.
Of course, volunteering has trends. There is rarely a shortage of people who want to work with children or AIDS patients; it's much harder to get people to work with the elderly, experts say. Over all, volunteering has become more convenient. Some corporations encourage their employees to do it on company time. Many agencies keep more flexible hours than the 9-to-5 that once prevailed. Family volunteering, in which parents and children work together, is a recent innovation that balances the desire to add to the common good with the need for family time.
Most volunteers say they will commit for three months, Miss Brown said. "But if you get them for three months," she added, "you'll probably have them for three years."
Here are five of their stories.
 
Teaching on Company Time
 Gloria Buckery is the principal of Public School 198 at Third Avenue and 95th Street, where the Upper East Side overlaps East Harlem. P.S. 198, like most New York City public schools, is a place where making do on the margins has become a way of life. Which is why she is so fond of talking about how her school got its new piano.
For the last two years, the school has been linked in a partnership with Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, one of a growing number of companies that are sponsoring volunteer programs for their employees. Last year, Seagram executives attended a musical assembly featuring the old piano. "They saw a piano in five pieces and the teacher trying to play it," Ms. Buckery said. Hence the new one.
"They stand back and look," she explained, "and frankly, I think they can't believe what goes on in the public schools."
The school and the company joined forces after the Seagram chairman, Edgar Bronfman Jr., gave a speech at another public school and decided to make the experience available -- on company time -- to his employees, said Patsy Glazer, a Seagram spokeswoman.
"He almost saw it as a perk," she said. P.S. 198 was chosen based on its proximity to midtown offices and the principal's willingness to work with Seagram.
This year, about 200 Seagram employees, or a third of the Manhattan work force, are volunteering at the school. The company-time component encourages many to volunteer. The company takes no tax deduction for its contributions to the school, said Nancy Morgan, the program's coordinator.
P.S. 198 had no art program when the partnership started; now there is a weekly after-school studio, run by two Seagram volunteers. There was no music teacher; now a teacher is scheduled one day a week, her salary paid by Seagram.
"The only cry we hear is 'More,' " Ms. Buckery said. Twenty-five children are now being tutored, but hundreds more, she added, could be helped if there were more volunteers.
"Any public school is grateful for money," Ms. Buckery said. "But it's not as lasting in its effect as volunteers' coming in on a regular basis. It's like the divorced parent who gives you a very nice Christmas present, and you think, 'Where are you the other 364 days of the year?' "
Companies become involved for a mix of reasons.
"A lot of them act out of a sense of civic responsibility," said Kenneth Adams, director of New York Cares, which works on volunteer activities with 74 companies. "Others are self-serving. They want the publicity. And others look at it as a good way to boost employee morale."
For Pat Tate and Nicole Gaffney, 11 years old, tutoring is a stop-and-start session on Tuesday afternoons. It concentrates on the sixth grader's math and English homework, with interruptions to talk about current events, Nicole's boyfriend ("I know his phone number by heart," she confided), approaching holidays and other topics.
At the beginning of the year, Ms. Tate bought Nicole a desk diary that lists every tutoring session they will have.
"She's very concerned about what days we'll be together," Ms. Tate explained. Once, last year, when another volunteer showed up to substitute, Nicole burst into tears.
To Ms. Tate, tutoring is "an opportunity to share knowledge with a child, when I wouldn't normally have that opportunity, being single with no children. When I'm with her, I'm thinking about her: how can I make school make sense in those two hours?"
 
'Tired of Asking and Asking'
 Two months ago Richard Milewski was just one of the faces in the food line. Today he can be found in the kitchen at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, lifting heavy pans of chicken, scrubbing soiled trays and generally enjoying the view from the other side of the counter.
Mr. Milewski is one of the 20 volunteers who are the main reason why the St. John's Bread and Life soup kitchen can feed breakfast and lunch to as many as many as 1,000 people every weekday. Those who eat at the church on Lewis Avenue in a battered quarter of Bedford-Stuyvesant are among the poorest of the city's poor; most of those who cook and clean and serve are poor, too.
Volunteering, they say, they feel rich.
"They get tired of asking and asking," Hossein Saadat, executive director of the Bread and Life program, said of volunteers like Mr. Milewski.
"I lay back and I'm exhausted from being part of the solution, not the problem," Mr. Milewski said, his hands soft and pink from swishing through soapy water all morning. "I feel like I accomplish something throughout the day."
A recovering cocaine and heroin addict whose jaw was shattered in a recent mugging, Mr. Milewski tested positive for H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, nearly four years ago. So far, "knock on wood," he says, he remains healthy. He reports to the soup kitchen at 8 every morning, after his daily visit to a nearby methadone clinic, his long brown hair reined in beneath a baseball cap.
Mr. Milewski, who is 31 years old, grew up "middle class," he says, in Ridgewood, Queens, the fourth of five brothers. At 18 he joined the Transit Authority as an electrician, trudging through tunnels to repair signal lights and switches. He married his childhood sweetheart, and together they began using drugs. In 1986 he was suspended from his job for refusing to submit to a drug screening test, he says, but he was too high to care: "I figured drugs were a better life," he said.
He drifted across central Queens for the next six years, sleeping in parking lots and sharing needles with fellow junkies in abandoned buildings. He shoplifted from Macy's to make ends meet, and was caught and jailed twice. Last spring, no longer homeless but still addicted, he heard that there was a free lunch at St. John's.
"After six months, Sister asked me to help out," Mr. Milewski said, referring to Sister Mary Bernadette Scymczak, the nun who directs the soup kitchen. "By working, it keeps my mind occupied. And I never knew anything about a kitchen until now. I didn't know that picking up a lot of leftovers, you can make a whole meal."
He is something of a celebrity among the homeless whom he now serves, one of their own who is slowly pulling his life together. He shares a room with another formerly homeless man, and thinks he may someday look for a paying job again.
"They come up to me and say, 'How you doing, Richie?' " Mr. Milewski said. And he added, with more than a trace of pride: "I was here last Thanksgiving as a client. This year, I worked."
 
People 1, Medicare Bureaucrats 0
 Four years ago the people at Medicare picked a fight with Bella Schoenholtz of Flushing, Queens. And they had to pay. Some might say they're still paying.
It all began with Medicare's rejection of a bill that Mrs. Schoenholtz submitted after a visit to her doctor. As she recalls, Medicare refused to reimburse her, saying she had been to the doctor too many times. Mrs. Schoenholtz saw red, picked up a pen and wrote a pithy letter that she sent to her Congressman and other public officials.
She succeeded in wringing her $50 out of the bureaucracy. But along the way, a crusade was born. Mrs. Schoenholtz started "Medicare 101," based at Flushing Hospital, where she had been volunteering as an office helper for a friend who worked there. Solo most of the time, the sandy-haired, jolly Mrs. Schoenholtz advises people who are baffled by the maze of regulations governing who is paid back, when and for what under Medicare's system of health insurance for the elderly and the disabled.
She works two days a week, 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. Her clients -- about 500 a year -- hear about her service through newspaper advertisements and notices at centers for the elderly. Doctors and nurses stop in, as mystified by the regulations as everybody else.
"The elderly are confused beyond words," said the 68-year-old Mrs. Schoenholtz, whose back ailments forced her to quit her job as a bookkeeper nine years ago. "A lot of them have their spouses doing all the paperwork. Then the spouse dies, and they don't even know how to write out a check."
Others have just switched to Medicare and feel humiliated by not being able to conquer the forms. And still others are reluctant to file claims at all, embarrassed at taking what they see as a handout from the Government.
"Even though we do extensive outreach, people just don't understand," said Michael Jacoby, director of community relations for G.H.I. Medicare, which covers Queens County. Mrs. Schoenholtz calls him as many as four times a week. "Often they need someone who's familiar with the system to sit down and explain it."
Enter Mrs. Schoenholtz to set the record straight. Medicare "is not a charitable organization," she says, her voice rising and her arms waving for emphasis. "It's a form of insurance you've been paying for all your life, or your spouse has."
She has collected a folder full of letters from appreciative clients. Typical is the one from Cosmo Cavaluzzo, an elderly man from Flushing, thanking the hospital for her work "in behalf of seniors who find the complexity of Medicare benefits puzzling and beyond comprehension."
The rules may be Byzantine, but Mrs. Schoenholtz's view of her job is straightforward: "They all come here because they're not getting their money. And I am going to try to find out why they're not getting it."
 
Learning the Union Language
 Monday mornings it sounds like a really good party is going on upstairs in the light-filled town house on East 69th Street that is the headquarters of the English Speaking Union. But there is no tea or crumpets. Instead, the buzz is English in Action, 40 or so volunteers and their students, immigrants who have come to this place of flowered armchairs and fox-hunting prints to improve their English.
Most speak a little English, but have no one to talk to or answer their questions about the baffling American dialect. There is Yoneko Sawamoto, who labors hard to read the union's newsletter but can speak volumes about her 2-year-old grandson Manabu's recent visit to New York and has invited her teachers over for sushi.
There is Marian Drozdza, a maintenance man from Poland who carries an electronic Polish-English dictionary to class in its battered Styrofoam packing shell.
And there is Gilda Zapata, who left her young daughter with her mother in Paraguay to take a job as a housekeeper on Park Avenue.
The volunteers range from retired executives to office workers. Some are working to ease their boredom, others to ease their pain.
Pearle Rosenblatt, a silver-haired resident of the Upper East Side, got involved after her husband died.
"My husband several years ago discovered that they served afternoon tea here," she said, "and he thought this would be a nice thing for me. And after he died, I had to have something to do. I had kept the telephone number all that time, but I had never used it."
Call she did. Now, for two hours every Monday, she volunteers with people like Gilda Zapata.
"Gilda is naughty," Mrs. Rosenblatt teased, as her student smiled. "She doesn't speak as much as she ought to, except when we're discussing recipes."
For Miss Zapata, improving her English is essential to doing a good job and getting around New York.
"It's very important to learn English in here," she said, meaning the United States.
Since arriving two years ago, she has struggled with the language even as she mastered cooking turkey with shiitake-mushroom dressing at Thanksgiving. Her employers sent her to the English Speaking Union, and now, she and Mrs. Rosenblatt sit beneath a window, the Union Jack flapping on a staff outside, and discuss everything from the climate in Caraguatay, the town where Miss Zapata lived, to Mrs. Rosenblatt's past problems with noisy upstairs neighbors.
"I walk along the sidewalk smiling after class because Gilda makes me happy," Mrs. Rosenblatt said. "She is a lovely young girl, and she's trying so hard to perfect her English."
"I like this," said Miss Zapata, adding that she hopes, within a few years, to return to Paraguay, marry her boyfriend and open a grocery store.
 
With AIDS, and With Hope
 More than a decade into the AIDS epidemic, there is no cure; there is much despair and desperation. But as the disease reaches ever deeper into the life of the city, more and more New Yorkers are volunteering to stem its spread and to improve the lives of people with AIDS.
Some have AIDS themselves. Others have lost friends, lovers, relatives. Some work in parts of the city where, they say, they still struggle to bring the basics of prevention to the people around them.
"I have a big problem with the amount of people out here who still do not know even the little simple things, like what do the letters H.I.V. stand for," said Dennis Merrill, a 43-year-old former intravenous drug user who has AIDS and lectures at detoxification centers, schools and churches through Bronx AIDS Services, a South Bronx nonprofit agency that serves about 10,000 people a year and has about 115 volunteers, nearly all from the neighborhood.
Yolanda Emanuel, a mother of four grown children from the South Bronx, found out she had the virus five years ago and is now wheelchair-bound with peripheral neuropathy, an AIDS-related condition that has paralyzed her legs. Still, she volunteers four days a week at Bronx AIDS Services as a buddy, comforting people over the phone, and as a baby sitter for other clients.
"We were all born to die, and I just know when," said Ms. Emanuel, who is 40 years old. Volunteering helps distract her and helps others as well, she said.
"You get to meet a lot of different people from all walks of life. If I just sit down and cry, that does not accomplish anything. Let me let everybody know I was here. I can do that by touching other people and letting other people touch me."
As a mother facing death, she often counsels other fearful parents who are trying to plan for their children's care after they are gone.
"A lot of times while making a living will they realize, 'I am going to die,' " she said. As someone who has been through the same trauma, she is an especially empathetic listener. "You share your experiences with them," she said, "and let them know they are not alone."
Comfort can take many forms. Inside a storefront salon in the West Village the other day, Christopher Gerard, a former actor, was having his hair daubed with bleach, wrapped in aluminum foil and secured with bobby pins. In the end, he looked perfectly coiffed and just a little bit blonder, thanks to Paul Freely, a hairdresser who donates his craft to people like Mr. Gerard, who has had AIDS for seven years.
"I can't overemphasize how good he makes you feel," said Mr. Gerard, 47. "This is definitely not the dentist." He counts 105 close friends cut down by the disease and signs his letters, "I'm still here," after five bouts of pneumonia and Kaposi's sarcoma. If his hair is right, he believes, it helps people accept him and not think, "This is someone who's just checked out."
Mr. Freely, who is 27, never knew anyone with AIDS until he arrived in New York four years ago from England, he said. A colleague at his first job had AIDS, and out of that experience, Mr. Freely approached the Actors Fund, which runs a series of volunteer programs for theater people with AIDS.
Now Mr. Freely, who does not have H.I.V., ministers to AIDS patients at the Village storefront. He refuses to insult them, he says, by wearing gloves or a mask when he cuts their hair. Of the 50 or so people with AIDS he has served, "a good two-thirds of them have died."
"But I continue to do my work with their spirits," he added, "which helps me not to feel so sad. It's also the greatest motivational force to continue with the work."
He ran a comb through Mr. Gerard's hair and unclipped his smock. "So now you look like a California boy," he said. "The sun has kissed your hair, Christopher Gerard."
"Thank you, God," breathed Mr. Gerard. "Thank you, Paul."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JAMAICA;
A Rare Measure Of the Benefits Of Bureaucracy

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
It is hard to imagine the benefits generated from the daily crush of humanity that for years descended on the Department of Motor Vehicles office in downtown Jamaica. The jostling was unnerving. The long lines were infuriating. And the waits seemed eternal.
But the office at 165th Street evolved into a neighborhood bulwark, drawing hundreds of people from throughout the borough into local restaurants and shops each day on their way to or from renewing their driver's licenses or registering their cars. 
 The benefits are clear to business leaders and merchants, who are now facing their loss, as the state agency begins scaling down the office in Jamaica and adding two offices in Springfield Gardens and College Point. The two new offices, which will offer the normal motor vehicles services, will hold hearings on traffic summonses and be equipped to warn clients how long a wait to expect.
Reverberations from the agency's simple shift, which is meant to reduce aggravation for New York's motorists by minimizing waits, reveal the delicate economic ecology of New York City urban centers like downtown Jamaica, which have long relied on the bustle and traffic generated by public agencies.
"The decision makes a great deal of sense for their customers," said Bob Richards, the president of the Jamaica Chamber of Commerce. "But it's not going to affect this area in a positive way. It's little decisions like this that have the longest range impact on an area's economic development."
But if merchants fear the loss of customers, they understand the department's drive to keep its clients satisfied. So no one in the area is actively protesting the reduction.
But the office has been such a vital institution in the area that business leaders have in recent months been pressing officials at the state agency to maintain a "significant presence" in Jamaica.
"To completely lose an institution that has such countywide reach would certainly diminish Jamaica's role," said Carlisle Towery, the president of the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, which has for years lobbied city, state and Federal agencies to support downtown Jamaica's economic interests with public projects. "We just don't want that to happen," he added.
For years, Jamaica had the only Department of Motor Vehicles office in the borough, handling as many as 1,500 transactions a day. Officials at the agency expect that the office in Jamaica will be handling about 500 transactions a day once the two other offices are operating fully.
 RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PELHAM PARKWAY;
Fiscal Weapon To Fight Decay

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
White Plains Road in Pelham Parkway has changed very little in a generation, a modest cluster of pizza parlors, boutiques, a kosher deli and newsstands that has retained its neighborly character even as other sections of the borough have declined.
In an effort to retain that flavor, a group of landlords and merchants are seeking to establish a business improvement district -- one of those tools of self-reliance that neighborhoods throughout New York City have used to insure, among other things, safer and cleaner streets. 
 Last month, Community Board 11 approved the application by the local group, called Community Merchants of Pelham Parkway, to establish the district -- the neighborhood's first and the borough's second.
The district, financed by assessments levied on business owners within its boundaries, would be responsible for maintaining the five-block stretch along White Plains Road from Brady Avenue to Pelham Parkway South, which includes more than a hundred small shops and businesses.
The application is still awaiting review from the office of Borough President Fernando Ferrer and the Department of City Planning. If approved, the organization could begin operating as early as next summer, with a $65,000 budget in its first year.
Under state law, landlords are required to pay the improvement district an annual tax, based on the value of their property, for services that range from sanitation and security to promotion and holiday decorations.
In an area that in recent years has faced quality-of-life problems like graffiti, vandalism and illegal street vending, the proposal for establishing the new district provoked virtually no opposition.
"The merchants and property owners on White Plains Road are committed to this area," said Thomas Lucania, the district manager for Community Board 11. "There are people who have worked and made their entire lives there."
The group's major goals include luring more shoppers into the area with newspaper advertising as well as increasing sanitation along the strip with additional trash bins and private collection service.
Members have also discussed the possibility of taking over the operation and maintenance of a municipal parking lot on White Plains Road near Lydig Avenue that often goes unused because of poor security.
"We've been able to maintain a high quality of merchants and merchandise here," Mr. Lucania added. "And that's what we hope to continue to do."
 R.H.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENSONHURST/GRAVESEND -- UPDATE;
Ruling May Keep Incinerator Cold

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
An administrative law judge reviewing the city's application to upgrade and reopen the Shore Road incinerator has ruled that hearings on its potential emissions must be held before any permits are granted.
The city's Corporation Counsel has appealed the ruling, which could delay the reopening for years. 
 With the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island near capacity, New York City is desperately hunting for ways to deal with the 10,931 tons of garbage it generates on an average day. The city's only operating incinerator is in Greenpoint, but another, after a long battle, is planned for the Brooklyn Navy Yard, in Williamsburg. And recycling so far only copes with a fraction of the city's garbage.
The 20-page ruling, by Judge Daniel O'Connell for the state's Department of Environmental Conservation, determined that the city failed to consider the environmental impact of the proposed incinerator and ordered hearings on the incinerator's safety levels to be held in 1995.
The lengthy process of applying for operating permits cannot begin until after those hearings, and only after the permits are granted can work begin on upgrading the incinerator.
The incinerator, at 26th Avenue and Shore Parkway, closed three years ago and was scheduled to reopen with new equipment in 1996, to burn 750 tons of trash daily.
Residents have opposed the reopening of the incinerator, which burned up to 1,000 tons of waste a day for 31 years, saying it caused abnormally high rates of cancer and respiratory illness in the area.
"This is definitely a win on our part," said Carmine Santa Maria, chairman of the Citizens Opposing Unhealthy Gas Hazards -- known by its acronym, Cough -- which had been asking the city to conduct an environmental impact study for months.
And in a move to keep the incinerator closed, lawyers for the New York Public Interest Research Group appealed Judge O'Connell's ruling last week, saying that the economic analysis of the $75 million project was flawed.
 L.H.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:

To Lure Regular Patrons, Brewery Offers an M.B.A.
 Manhattan Brewing Company is offering an M.B.A. degree, a Master of Beer Appreciation, and 400 people have signed up for the program. The microbrewery-cum-restaurant in SoHo charges registrants $20, and they must take three of four classes, covering the history of beer and how it is brewed. One class is a tasting of 15 varieties of the company's beers; it brews and sells 25 to 28 barrels of beer a week. 
 Garrett Oliver, the brew master, said he started the M.B.A. program in November because a growing number of patrons, including many women (73 percent of those taking the course are female), were showing an interest in beer beyond drinking it. He also sees the program, he said, as a way to attract more regular patrons.

A Newcomer Takes Over At Red Hook Terminal
Since 1981, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has leased the Red Hook Container Terminal in Brooklyn from the City of New York, and then leased the site to the Universal Maritime Service Corporation to handle the day-to-day operations of the docks. Last week a new company, American Stevedoring of Elizabeth, N.J., took on that task, signing a seven-year lease with the Port Authority.
The Red Hook terminal generally serves smaller steamship lines, mainly from the Middle East, Europe and Asia. In 1992 the terminal's seven berths handled 53,000 containers.
 
At This Women's Group, Bring 2 Business Leads
Women on the Fast Track, a networking group founded in 1990, starts another year of monthly meetings on Tuesday with just under 100 members and plans to set up chapters in Dallas, Albuquerque, N.M., and Jacksonville, Fla.
Fast Track is not a support group and does not offer lectures, said Lucy Rosen, its founder and the owner of the Business Development Group, a Manhattan-based marketing and consulting firm. It is intended to meet the practical needs of women in businesses like accounting, advertising and banking. At meetings, the members discuss their particular business needs -- a company to do inexpensive binding, for example, or a new site for their organization's operations. Members are required to bring at least two tips to each session -- an answer to an earlier query, say, or the name and number of a good environmental lawyer.
The group's networking also leads to assignments for members, Ms. Rosen said, adding, "There isn't a client I have who isn't using a member." Membership costs $100 a year, and an introductory meeting is scheduled for 6 P.M. Tuesday. For information, (718) 832-0140.

Free Classes for Women In Nontraditional Fields
 Many of the first graduates of a free program that teaches women to be electronics technicians are now working as cable television installers and electricians. Applications are currently be taken for this year's classes. The program, first offered by New York City Technical College in September 1992, includes 600 hours of classroom and laboratory work as well as courses in preparing for job interviews.
The classes are underwritten by city and state grants as part of economic development programs for low-income workers or those who have been laid off. Participants must have eighth-grade reading and math skills.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Save the Neighborhood. Fix the Pudding.

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
THE day was not going well for Seymour Siegel, a food manufacturer who produces, among other things, 1 million pounds of coleslaw and 1.5 million pounds of potato salad every day.
First, the shrimp was not fresh. His son Richard, the company's chief executive, had just rejected 9,000 pounds of it, delaying by a day the preparation of thousands of shrimp salads.
Then at noon he learned that his noodle pudding, based on a heavenly recipe from his mother, Jean, was too thick, and ordered about 30 pounds of it thrown away. 
 While such problems are not uncommon in food manufacturing, Mr. Siegel, the 64-year-old head of Blue Ridge Farms, a multimillion-dollar company based in East New York, Brooklyn, takes an intense interest. Every day, he and his employees taste-test dozens of their products.
"I told the chef I wanted it to be firm," said Mr. Siegel, pushing away a plate of the yellow pudding as he sat in the company cafeteria. "Now it's too firm. If he keeps playing with my mother's recipe I'm going to have to hurt him."
Then, with a big laugh, he added, "It's so thick you can cut it with an ax."
Mr. Siegel, head of the 40-year-old, family-run operation, is known as a feisty character who gets things done with a rough-and-tumble sense of humor, a sharp business edge and a strong commitment to his 200-plus products.
But he has also been described by parents at a nearby intermediate school as a selfish mogul who will stop at nothing to earn a dollar, because he fought for years to acquire a piece of land for expansion where a new school was to be built.
Blue Ridge Farms is the third largest manufacturer in Brooklyn, home to 2,698 such companies. It is also one of the more than 12,000 manufacturers that remain in New York City even as thousands of others have either failed or moved to cities offering large plots of land, inexpensive utility rates and low taxes. The company's success is due in part to its ability to swiftly fill gaps left by food manufacturers that have disappeared.
Over the years, the company has seen revenues grow, grossing $10 million in 1980 and $70 million in 1993. Mr. Siegel's creamy potato, macaroni, shrimp and potato salads, chopped liver and knishes are sold largely to distributors; they fill the deli counters of major supermarkets and delicatessens throughout New York City, 37 states, the Caribbean, Mexico, Canada and France. Because many local supermarkets sell his products under their own labels, Mr. Siegel would not name them. But his food can be found under the Blue Ridge Farms label at Costco and other food clubs, he said.
With an annual payroll of $18 million for 600 workers -- 80 percent of whom come from the community -- Blue Ridge Farms has become a vital component in the neighborhood, which has one of the city's highest unemployment rates. The company is a certified business within the state-designated East New York enterprise zone, one of 19 such areas across the state set up to lure businesses and jobs through tax credits and other incentives.
It was not long ago, though, that Mr. Siegel was threatening to leave East New York, the very place he and his business came of age. He wanted to expand his business into the lot next door, but the site had been earmarked by the Board of Education for a replacement school.
For years, the board would not budge, even though Mr. Siegel offered in a trade a slightly larger plot of land that he uses for truck parking. Community and education leaders resisted because they thought the move would delay construction of a replacement for Intermediate School 171, which has been operating at 150 percent of capacity, with more than 1,400 students.
But the swap was approved on Oct. 29 by School Board 19 and announced by Mayor Dinkins in a flurry of last-minute campaign stops. The agreement was reached only after intervention by Mr. Dinkins, the state Urban Development Corporation and the city Economic Development Corporation, whose officers said the city could not afford to lose more major employers. Accompanying the swap was $2 million in tax credits and other incentives from the city and state for Blue Ridge Farms. The replacement school is to be built at the parking site that Mr. Siegel had offered earlier.
WHILE Mr. Siegel's image may have been marred by the land dispute, there is no question about what his business has done for the portion of East New York surrounding his business, at 3301 Atlantic Avenue. Besides bringing in badly needed jobs, Blue Ridge Farms has breathed new life into the community, with bodegas, beauty parlors, small clothing stores and restaurants springing up on once-barren landscapes. During lunch hour, neighborhood avenues are dotted with workers wearing the trademark Blue Ridge Farms uniform -- a blue doctor's jacket -- as they eat and shop.
But crime is a major problem for Mr. Siegel, who spends a total of $400,000 on security every year, $250,000 of it for guards, in this the 75th Precinct, which has had a record-setting number of homicides this year.
"This company can do well anywhere, so it's not important that I stay here for that reason," Mr. Siegel said. "My reason for wanting to stay here is because I grew up in this section of Brooklyn. This is home."
A high school dropout, Mr. Siegel sold dentures door-to-door in East New York at a time when the sidewalks were lined with neat Dutch and English row houses inhabited by Jewish immigrants from Eastern Europe. Then he landed a job in a poultry store and soon opened his own shops.
"I was up to my arms in chicken livers," said Mr. Siegel, who moved to Nassau County, L.I., soon after his business took off. "My mother chopped some up, put it on a cracker and offered it to customers to taste. It went over well."
To broaden business, Mr. Siegel incorporated many more of his mother's recipes, which had been handed down for generations and perfected as she fed a husband, who worked as a plumber, and three sons. Before long, he was making enough food and money to expand. He borrowed $1,800 from his younger brother, Martin, a doctor, and $3,200 from his father to buy a 25,000-square-foot factory on Astoria Boulevard. After operating there for a few years, he moved to his current address.
The business is run mostly by family. In addition to his son Richard, Mr. Siegel's eldest child, Jeffrey, also works for the company, as president. Martin Siegel is the company doctor.
Back in the cafeteria, Mr. Siegel was grappling with the problem of the noodle pudding, his taste buds working for him. In walked Franco Vitellozzi, the chief chef. Mr. Siegel motioned for him to come over. They hugged before sitting down.
"Franco, when it was too soft, we had to take some of the oil out and add eggs," Mr. Siegel said as the two sat there like teacher and student. "Now it's too firm and we've got to get all those eggs out of there, and start over again."
Mr. Vitellozzi nodded.

HEADLINE: Among the Dying Species Are Lost Tribes of Mankind

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

 BODY:
NINETEEN NINETY-THREE was supposed to be the International Year of the World's Indigenous People. But as it drew to a close, the vulnerabilities of aboriginal people remained as serious as ever. They hold on desperately to ancestral lands now coveted by others. They do not fit in, as the dominant others would say, and see no reason why they should, for which they are paying a dreadful price. Some are being massacred and terrorized. Many are being forced off their lands, scattered into cities and to economically and culturally impoverished lives for which they have little taste and no preparation.
These people are the endangered of the human species, survivors whose continued survival is very much in doubt. 
 Their exact number is not known, except that it must be fewer with each passing year -- now an estimated 300 million indigenous people in 70 countries. Amnesty International says they are among the "most defenseless of all the victims of human rights violations." Their plight is worldwide and becoming especially acute in places where the march of economic development and resource exploitation tramples on their once-isolated domains, leading to disease, bloodshed and despair.
Racism in the spirit of the 19th-century slogan "the only good Indian is a dead Indian" inflames the conflict. "If you can persuade yourself that people who stand in your way are savages, you can rationalize gunning them down and forcing them to adapt to your purposes," said Dr. David Maybury-Lewis, a Harvard anthropologist and founder of Cultural Survival, an advocacy group in Cambridge, Mass.
More widespread and respectable is the economic argument that a few people should not be allowed to hold up development. And it worries governments to have so many ethnic groups potentially unsettling the body politic.
The conflict is reaching crisis proportions in Brazil, which has been steadily pushing back its frontier in the vast Amazon basin. It is like watching a rerun of how the American West was won, at the expense of the Indians. Ranchers and settlers have invaded Indian lands, followed by landless rural workers. Most settlers are armed, the ranchers have hired gunmen and in many places they outnumber the Indians.
A gold rush into the remote territory of the Yanomami Indians near the Venezuelan border has brought in thousands of miners, introducing deadly malaria, destroying the rainforest, polluting streams and provoking confrontation. The Yanomami population, 10,000 in 1986, is rapidly declining, and anthropologists predict the people could be annihilated in the next 10 years. In August, miners massacred 70 Yanomami men, women and children.
A new onslaught has begun on the lands of the Awa-Guaja Indians and the supposedly protected Alto Turiacu and Caru reserves in Northern Maranhao. The human rights commission of the American Anthropological Association says the Awa-Guaja, the last forest nomads in Amazonia, face extinction from the invasion of ranchers and settlers. Their lands have just been set aside as a preserve, but often this has not stopped the invasion.
Although Brazil's Constitution guarantees Indians' rights to their traditional lands, Amnesty International says the authorities "have consistently failed to prevent the abuses or to investigate them effectively." In this century, 90 of the country's 270 Indian tribes have completely disappeared.
Elsewhere, the picture is also bleak. In Guatemala, the army's counter-insurgency campaign has claimed the lives of thousands of non-combatant Indians. In north Borneo, loggers have destroyed the forests and game of the Penan, a tribe of hunter-gatherers. In the mountains of Myanmar, formerly Burma, the Karen, Mon, Shan and Kayah are victims of relentless violence by the army, which sweeps into villages and seizes people for forced labor.
For the Tuareg, the blue-painted nomads of the Sahara who had many a fight with the French, the end of colonial rule, paradoxically, brought them less independence. When the desert was divided into several independent states, the Tuareg found themselves boxed in by new borders and hostile military regimes. Without the freedom to move their herds to faraway water holes, as many as 125,000 of the one million Tuareg starved to death in the drought of the 1970's. Out of frustration, Tuareg insurgents have attacked government forces of Niger and Mali and taken hostages, provoking the armies into bloody reprisals on hundreds of Tuareg civilians.
To many indigenous people the threat is not so much physical destruction as cultural extinction. Governments are putting increasing pressure on them to assimilate by resettling them away from lands where they were self-sufficient, teaching them in a language not their own and converting them to the dominant religion. A campaign to convert to Islam was initiated last year against the beleaguered hunter-gatherers of the Malay Peninsula, known collectively as the Orang Asli, or original people.
An unhappy fate awaits such people. "Take away their land, their trees, the Orang Asli will no longer be able to support themselves or maintain their distinctive culture," said Dr. Robert K. Dentan , an anthropologist at the State University of New York at Buffalo. "They will become either dependents of the state or a kind of landless proletariat, low-wage laborers at the very bottom of society."
Because of civil war, encroachment by ranchers and prospectors and murderous oppression, the Bushmen of southern Africa are already as close to cultural extinction as any indigenous people. Traditionally nomads of the arid plains, the Bushmen have all but lost their skills to live as hunter-gatherers and also their self-esteem.
"They are a tattered remnant clinging to the edges of the industrialized world," wrote Laurens Van der Post, a scholar who has lived among the Bushmen. "We have failed to recognize that in their own context their values have as much validity as our own. We have also failed to recognize that until we came to southern Africa they had a way of life that worked. We did not. Now neither they nor we have a way of life that truly works."
Would it matter to the world at large if some of these cultures vanished?
One argument for preserving human diversity, said Dr. Terence Turner, a University of Chicago anthropologist, is utilitarian. Many of these remote tribes possess irreplaceable knowledge of their ecosystems, including the medicinal uses of plants and the practical aspects of surviving in a difficult environment. Modern people have met disaster attempting to develop these areas, and could learn from these survivors.
On a more humanitarian level, Dr. Turner said, "People simply have a right to determine the meaning of their own lives and should not be forced to 'fit in.' "
In a few cases, indigenous people have reached satisfactory accommodations with their more powerful neighbors. The Kuna Indians of Panama, for example, are doing well controlling their own land and economy, and in Ecuador, the Shuar Federation is serving as a model for Amazonian tribes seeking greater autonomy.
Slowly, anthropologists say, public attitudes toward humans rights are changing, and with this in mind, organizations like the World Bank are setting conditions on loans for development to preserve the environment and indigenous people. "In the 20th century, you just can't ride in and shoot 'em up," Dr. Maybury-Lewis said. "If you do, the information gets around in the world quickly, and the shock and outrage can put pressure on countries to come to the defense of their people who are fighting hard to defend their traditions."

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
For Cities in Middle Age, Growing Pains Are Real

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

 BODY:
NEW YORK CITY assumed its current shape 96 years ago in a joyous consolidation of Manhattan and the Bronx with the City of Brooklyn, Staten Island and the area now called Queens. Around much of the country, cities still routinely annex neighboring areas. But for New York, such expansion is now unthinkable, and in fact city government may go the way of Yugoslavia. In November, Staten Island residents voted to secede, and Queens has a small secessionist movement too.
Why are some voices in the nation's biggest city saying, "Smaller is better"? And why is this happening even as younger places, particularly in the Sunbelt, are successfully using the grow-your-own-city technique that New York employed at the last turn of the century? 
 The short answer: New York is old and aging. For a city still growing into virgin territory, there are advantages, for the psyche and the tax rolls, in expanding its borders. But if growth stops and the municipal budget turns sour, some residents try to bail out.
Cities, it appears, can have life cycles no less dramatic than those of caterpillars or frogs, changing form as they age. If Marx had focused on the economies and politics of municipal governments rather than national ones, he might have discerned a pattern of money and politics driving each other at the local level, from expansion to stasis to, in extreme cases, breakup.
In the same month as the Staten Island referendum, Houston annexed three areas and Manchester, a small suburb west of St. Louis, moved toward doubling its size through annexation. And Everett, near Seattle, said it wanted to annex an area called Murphy's Corner. Outside the Northeast, annexations around the country are scarcely news.
But not only New York is showing strains. New Haven has a separatist movement, and Toronto's 30-year-old metropolitan government, long held up as a model of rational consolidation, is under fire.
When it was young, New York pursued growth, a popular trend around the turn of the century, in parallel with a growing economy. It worked until the city butted up against municipalities that did not want to be absorbed.
"Back when New York was doing it, some other places like Philadelphia and New Orleans and San Francisco were doing it; it was sort of the popular thing to do in the late 1800's," said Bruce D. McDowell, head of government policy research at the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations.
 
'A Tower of Strength'
 In those days, size itself was valued. "The name of a great city is a tower of strength," said a report on municipal consolidation prepared as a lobbying tool for Manhattan in the mid-1890's. "There is no good reason why this community and the country should not have the benefit of such prestige," the report went on. "Magnitude is not a thing of vapory dimensions, but a solid, substantial and determining factor, of which it would be folly to deny ourselves the advantage in important issues."
Annexation captured the increase in value that came to property where there had been improvements -- in those days, bridges. A larger city could collect taxes on both sides of the river, raising revenues from newly-valuable land. "The tax benefits of building those bridges were mostly enjoyed by the governments of Brooklyn and Queens, because land values would go up immensely once those bridges were built," said Roger Starr of the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research.
Those days are long gone. Since the early 1900's, according to Mr. McDowell, there have been fewer than 20 consolidations. And when cities lost the ability to expand, they lost the ability to rope in all the growth in their regions.
Now the older cities are in a different phase. Growth stops, and municipal budget pressures intensify, and residents look around to see if they would do better in a smaller unit, perhaps with fewer of the poor. In New Haven, residents of the prosperous East Shore section have organized under the slogan, "Secede to Survive."
 
When Needs Change
 "When economies are great, every municipality wants to build itself up, and there is very little competition because everyone is happy," said Robert M. Wright, a professor at the School of Architecture and Landscape Architecture at the University of Toronto. When money is tight, he said, "there is a notion of the need to fragment."
That is the case in Toronto, where the metropolitan government handles roads, transit and other region-wide issues, but suburbanites say they carry too much of the tax load.
Sunbelt cities still use public works to add value. New subdivisions tie into central water and sewer systems, making development feasible -- and making sure that development happens inside the city, not outside.
David P. Rusk, an author and former mayor of Albuquerque, said New Mexico had given his city a veto over construction of water and sewer systems within five miles of its borders, preventing development without the city's acquiescence. Albuquerque, founded early in the 18th century, had a long infancy. Mr. Rush said it has grown to 150 square miles today from three square miles in 1940. Ah, to be young again, municipally speaking.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Now, Home Is Where the Job Is

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IF the image of our past, whether based on myth or reality, is that the United States welcomed immigrants, we're losing our remaining illusions. Data compiled by the Federal Census Bureau and other demographers indicate that for immigrants, the welcome wagon is often flanked by a "For Sale" sign."
The figures show that, with a few notable exceptions, states that are magnets to immigrants are becoming less attractive to native-born citizens and are either losing population or not growing as fast as they once were. 
 California, as it so often is, appears to be the trendsetter.
Figures out last week from the Census Bureau (and counting only legal immigrants) show that for the year that ended July 1, 1993, California grew more slowly than the nation as a whole for the first time in 20 years. Indeed, if it were not for immigrants, the state would have had virtually no growth.
But California is not alone. According to a study by University of Michigan's Population Studies Center, New York, Texas, New Jersey, Illinois and Massachusetts, which led the nation in the numbers of immigrants in the late 1980's, have seen significant exodus, primarily of whites.
Of course, the idea of people bailing out in the face of a wave of newcomers who look and talk differently is not new. Over the years, the flavors of countless neighborhoods in old Eastern cities have shifted, say, from German to Irish to Italian to Eastern European Jews to black to Latino. But recent studies suggest that the flight is no longer merely from city to suburb, but from one state to another.
"There seems to be something about those states that attracts immigrants from abroad but does not attract people from within the United States," said Edwin Byerly, an analyst with the Census Bureau.
But the question arises whether the exodus of blue-collar whites from places like California, New York or Illinois is a reaction to immigrants or to anemic economies.
A study on internal migration patterns among whites and minorities during the late 1980's by William H. Frey, a University of Michigan researcher, indicates that states like Ohio, Oklahoma, Michigan and Louisiana, which have not drawn many immigrants, still have experienced a kind of white flight. In these cases, whites could just as easily been leaving because of the continued problems in the automobile or energy industries.
"I think the economic factors tend to be the most important," said Jeffrey Passel, director of the Program for Research on Immigration Policy at the Urban Institute. "Whether the people moving out are responding to better opportunities at the destination, or increased competition at the point of origin, I don't know. And it's tough to separate the two."
Larry Long, a demographer with the Census Bureau, also emphasized the importance of job opportunities in patterns of migration. "In the early decades of the 20th century, you had massive numbers of immigrants flowing into New York, New Jersey and other parts of the East Coast," he said. "But you had minimum numbers of outmigration from these areas, and the reason was the economy in the region was growing."
While the public perception of the current exodus is that of yuppie flight from the fast lanes of Manhattan or Century City heading for the easier pace and fresh air of the Rockies or the desert Southwest, further sifting of the data suggests that those pulling up stakes are, for the most part, working-class and middle-income whites and minorities.
But their incomes have often been achieved with with minimal education or skills -- in other words, they are among those groups that most often compete with immigrants for low-skill, low-wage jobs. The vast majority of departing whites hold no more than a high school diploma.
"The lower middle class, people making less than $35,000 a year, are squeezed out of the jobs at the lower end of the spectrum," said Mr. Frey.
 
Boom or Blip?
 For now, the number of whites moving out of these states is still small relative to the population as a whole, indicating that what is occurring may be the beginning of a trend or nothing more than a statistical blip, rather than a full-blown movement akin to America's westward expansion in the 19th century or the northward trek of Southern blacks in the 20th.
But some people, especially those pressing for immigration limits, believe that if the trend continues it portends a new kind of national segregation, one in which minorities and immigrants, who more often than not are also nonwhite, would be concentrated in a few states while places like Oregon, Washington, Utah, Arizona and Nevada become even more white.
"Places like California and New York will become even more different from the rest of the country than they already have been," said Ira Mehlman, a spokesman for the Federation for American Immigration Reform, a group that has argued for greatly reducing the numbers of immigrants.
The migration could also produce a group of sullen whites, and some blacks, who perceive that they have been forced out of a job market and compelled to uproot themselves as a result of competition by immigrants from Latin America and Asia.
In his study, Mr. Frey said a "negative reaction" of whites "to an increasingly diverse population" is a prime factor for the movement away from states with large numbers of immigrants.
As it grows such a group could become a political force that would not only be against further immigration but any Federal initiative, from foreign aid to the North American Free Trade Agreement, that smacks of helping people from beyond America's borders. And would that change what America is and how it thinks of itself?
