HEADLINE: GOLF;
The Mantra on the Pro Links Is Scores, Sponsors and Dollars

BYLINE: By LARRY DORMAN 

 BODY:
After a year in which scores were lower and stakes higher than any season in history, the major question for professional golf in 1994 is twofold: Can scores continue to drop and purses continue to rise?
The answer just might be yes, on both counts. 
 "Unless officials really start tricking up golf courses, the quality of the players today is so high that scores will keep going down, no question about it," said Greg Norman, arguably the top player in the world.
And, despite a still sluggish global economy, sponsors remain eager to throw wads of money at golfers. Purses are up on all three major United States golf tours. The PGA Tour has signed two new sponsors, Mercedes-Benz and Motorola, to long-term agreements. Last season, 23 players earned more than $1 million worldwide and that number is also expected to rise in 1994.
 
How Low Can You Go?
 Meanwhile, scoring in '93 was one giant limbo party -- how low can you go? In the four major championships, the winners were a combined 44 under par, the lowest total in history. Norman broke Tom Watson's 16-year-old scoring record at the British Open by shooting 267 at Royal St. George's; Lee Janzen shot 272 at Baltusrol in the United States Open to tie Jack Nicklaus's record set in 1980, and Paul Azinger was 1 stroke off the 72-hole record for the P.G.A. Championship with his 272, 12 under, at Inverness.
On the regular tour, Tom Kite shot 35 under par in the five rounds at the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic and Nick Price, in his five worldwide victories, was 100 under par.
All told, a working title for 1993 from the American perspective could very well be "our cups runneth over." For the first time, the United States is in simultaneous possession of the Walker Cup, the Ryder Cup, the Dunhill Cup and the World Cup.
Whether this means that American golfers have regained their dominance over European counterparts is unclear. The Ryder Cup victory was close but convincing, and Corey Pavin's victory over Nick Faldo in the World Match Play Championship provided more fuel for the argument. But the most successful player on the PGA Tour last year was Price, the native of Zimbabwe, who won four United States events. And the best player on the world stage was Norman, the Australian native who won the British Open, came within two lipped-out putts of winning the P.G.A. Championship and won three other events.
What to do with John Daly, the best player who won't be playing, at least until March 31, remains problematic. Daly is under PGA Tour suspension and has been urged to undergo counseling for his admitted alcoholism. The debate about his future, and the effectiveness of the suspension, undoubtedly will continue through the year.
Also on the horizon in 1994 is a major power struggle between the PGA Tour and International Management Group over the staging of a year-end, Ryder Cup-style competition. The PGA Tour has, for the last year, been formulating plans for a biennial competition to begin this year. Tentatively called the President's Cup and tentatively scheduled for Congressional Golf Club in Washington in September, it would match members of a United States team against players from countries not eligible for Ryder Cup competition -- Australia, New Zealand, Japan and Fiji, for example.
 
I.M.G. vs. PGA
 I.M.G. recently announced plans for a biennial year-end competition pitting the team currently in possession of the Ryder Cup against a team of players from countries in the southern hemisphere. The event would carry a purse of $2 million. Both groups say they have negotiated with various networks and cable companies for TV rights. Obviously, both events cannot take place.
The highlight of the year on the Ladies Professional Golf Association circuit is likely to be the Solheim Cup. This L.P.G.A. version of the Ryder Cup will be contested Oct. 21-23 at the Greenbrier, where the United States team will attempt to regain the Cup lost in 1992 to the Europeans at Dalmahoy in Scotland. Over all, L.P.G.A. Commissioner Charles Mechem has assembled a strong schedule, mitigated only by gaps in the third week in February and the fourth week in September.
Beth Daniel, without a victory since 1991, will be attempting to break out of her slump. Betsy King, who won player of the year honors in '93, can enter the L.P.G.A. Hall of Fame with one more victory. Brandie Burton, at the age of 21 the brightest star in women's golf and reminiscent of a young JoAnne Carner, has enough game to dominate. And Carner herself might yet become, at age 54, the oldest player, male or female, to win a professional golf tournament.
As for those truly elder belters on the Senior PGA Tour, stopping Dave Stockton will be the challenge of the year. Stockton collected five victories in his second senior season, a result of improved ball striking to go with his always deadly short game. Raymond Floyd will devote most of his time to the seniors, Lee Trevino plans to cut back, so look for a Floyd-Stockton duel for senior supremacy in '94.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The debate over John Daly's future is likely to continue. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Batting Cleanup Against the Owners for the 19th Time: Salary Arbitration

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
Look out, here it comes again.
Even as the baseball owners were welcoming in the new year, the drinks in their hands were losing their taste and the owners themselves were losing their appetites. For how can they even think about having a happy new year when they know that a few days after the new year begins, players can begin filing for salary arbitration. 
 The scourge of the owners' economic existence is back for the 19th year, and those people who bear the brunt of the process desperately hope this will be the last time they are faced with it.
If negotiations for a new labor agreement ever begin -- the old one expired uneventfully at midnight Friday -- the owners will try to put salary arbitration in a time capsule and bury it deep underground, leaving it to be discovered by someone seeking the reason for the decline and fall of the business of baseball.
The players, of course, don't share the owners' view, either of the general status of baseball financially or the specific impact salary arbitration has had on baseball's fortunes. They are in no hurry to negotiate away the process, even if the owners offer to grant free agency earlier in a player's career.
Salary arbitration gave the players leverage in salary negotiations for the first time, and when the union gave away a year of eligibility in the 1985 collective bargaining agreement, the disenfranchised players raised their angry voices.
This year's eligible players may begin filing for arbitration Wednesday, but virtually all of them will wait until the last day, Jan. 14, so they don't have to exchange salary bids with their clubs until Jan. 18.
The players who filed a year ago had their salaries increase a collective 107 percent, the second highest percentage raise the procedure has spawned. Those who negotiated contracts after filing rather than have arbitration hearings enjoyed an all-time high 110 percent increase.
Clubs have adopted a two-pronged strategy to try to beat the game. In some cases, they let players become free agents rather than go to arbitration with them. In others, they already have negotiated contracts for the 1994 season. Their efforts have reduced the list of remaining eligibles to 112, which already is 4 fewer than the number of players who filed last year. And that number was the lowest since 104 filed in 1988.
Four clubs have eight players apiece on the arbitration-eligible list. Atlanta's group includes Ron Gant, David Justice and Steve Avery; Montreal has John Wetteland, Marquis Grissom and Larry Walker; St. Louis has Gregg Jefferies, Bob Tewksbury and Bernard Gilkey and Kansas City's list includes Kevin Appier and Brian McRae.
The Yankees have six players, including Jim Abbott and Xavier Hernandez, and the Mets are tied for the smallest list with one, Pete Smith.
The start of the salary-arbitration period comes against the backdrop of Richard Ravitch's last-ditch effort to forge a new revenue-sharing agreement among the owners. It has been the owners' inability to reach an agreement that has prevented Ravitch from initiating negotiations with the players union for a new collective bargaining agreement.
The latest information emanating from the revenue-sharing negotiations is that a large group of owners is not unhappy with the latest plan that has been proposed but that extreme groups at each end don't like it, the high-revenue extreme because they don't want any kind of an agreement and the low-revenue extreme because they think their needs would not be satisfied.
The players don't feel strongly either way. They just want their share of the owners' revenue.
 
A Gift for Hibbard
 Jim Bronner, Bob Gilhooley and their associates represent Greg Hibbard, but once the pitcher signs a contract with a new team, he should consider giving Larry Himes a 5 percent agent's fee.
Declaring "I really hate to do this, but I have no choice, we're out of money," Himes, the Chicago Cubs' executive vice president for player development, let Hibbard become a free agent by not tendering him a contract by the Dec. 20 deadline. The Cubs lost their No. 1 pitcher from last season, and Hibbard gained an opportunity he would not have had for two more years, when he would have first become eligible for free agency.
More than a half-dozen clubs instantly declared their interest in the 29-year-old left-hander. One, the Boston Red Sox, was said by the general manager of another club to have offered Hibbard $7.5 million for three years. Hibbard earned $1,425,000 last season while compiling a 15-11 record and becoming the first left-hander to lead the Cubs in victories since Ken Holtzman in 1966.
"My conditioning guys did a great job with him," Himes said of Hibbard. "He was in the best condition he's ever been in. It really helped him."
 
The Long Way Home
 Jesse Barfield finally has returned home, but to get there, he had to travel from New York to Houston by way of Japan. And before he could land safely, he had to wiggle out of a potential international incident.
Several years ago, Barfield was nearly traded to the hometown Astros. He wasn't, though, so it is only now, when the Astros have signed him as a free agent, that he can play right field for them -- if he wins the job.
"Houston was ideal for him," said Arthur Rosenberg, the outfielder's agent. "It makes it exciting for him. He enjoyed playing in Japan, but he missed his family and would like to play here."
According to another agent, though, Barfield accepted the Astros' offer several days after he accepted an offer from the Yakult Swallows of the Japanese league. Ray Negron, who secured a contract for Barfield with the Tokyo Giants for the 1993 season, said he negotiated an agreement with Yakult after the Giants released Barfield, and that the veteran accepted the deal.
"There was no signed contract,"' Negron said. "You don't need one. But in principle, he had accepted the deal. Then he called me and said, 'The Astros just gave me an offer I can't refuse.' "
Yakult officials were infuriated, Negron said, but the team's representative spoke with Barfield and concluded that his family didn't want him to go to Japan. Negron said the club's officials decided that they would relinquish their rights in exchange for a letter of apology.
The Swallows would have paid the 34-year-old Barfield a guaranteed $600,000 salary and provided the chance to earn an additional $400,000. The Astros will give Barfield $100,000 for coming to camp and a $250,000 salary if he makes the club. He also can earn $640,000 in bonuses based on number of games he starts or plays. With 2 points for a start and 1 point for an appearance, Barfield would make the maximum if he gets 250 points.
In Japan last season, Barfield batted .215, hit 26 home runs and drove in 55 runs. He was playing for the first time since a wrist injury that required two operations ended his 1992 season with the Yankees on June 17.
Every time an American player returns from Japan now, he is compared to Cecil Fielder, whose return four years ago brought the major leagues one of their most fearsome hitters.
"That would be too good to be true," Bob Watson, the Astros' general manager, said when a duplication of Fielder's return was mentioned. Instead, Watson cited another player who returned from Japan: Orestes Destrade, who batted .255, hit 20 home runs and drove in 87 runs last season for the Florida Marlins.
"If he does what Destrade did, I'll be pleased," Watson said. "First I want him to make our team. If he makes it, the rest will be easier."
 
A Violation Without a Grievance
 In baseball's recent labor history, any time a violation of the collective bargaining agreement has been alleged, the Players Association more often than not has been the side raising the charge. Here is an instance, however, where the union seems to be violating the agreement, but no one has filed a grievance over it.
Since 1979, the union has used a 9 percent rate in discounting parts of players' salaries that are deferred without interest. For the last several years, though, that rate has not been the one the labor contract says should be used.
Paragraph J of Article XV of the agreement stipulates that the discount rate be the prime interest rate in effect at Chemical Bank of New York the preceding Nov. 1 plus 1 percent, rounded to the nearest full percentage point. The current rate, then, should be 7 percent, which is the rate the Player Relations Committee has been using in computing the owners' version of salaries.
In discounting deferred money to determine present-day value, a 7 percent rate produces higher figures than 9 percent. Higher figures should be to the players' benefit, but the union explains it has continued to use 9 percent for consistency's sake. There is one other reason. The union also boosts signing bonuses by 9 percent for the period of advanced payments, and in this instance, 9 percent produces higher figures than 7 percent.
Because many more contracts have signing bonuses than deferred payments, the union benefits from its continued use of 9 percent. Nevertheless, the stipulated 7 percent produces higher present-day values for the new contracts of Will Clark with Texas and Rafael Palmeiro with Baltimore than the Players Association computations.
At a 7 percent discount, Clark's $30 million becomes $27,167,294, or $5,433,459 a year, and Palmeiro's $30.35 million becomes $28,096,940, or $5,619,388 a year.

HEADLINE: BOATING;
As the Boat Show Prepares to Open, the Forecast Calls for Blue Skies and Sunshine

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

 BODY:
It has been a hard sell the last few years persuading cash-strapped consumers to spend money on boats. But the recession that struck the marine industry in 1989 appears to be lifting, a long-awaited sign for exhibitors at the annual New York National Boat Show.
In its 84th year this season, the nine-day show is scheduled to begin Saturday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. This Friday, a preview is open to anyone willing to spend $20 rather than the usual $8 for a ticket. More than 850 boats will be on display, from 50-foot motor yachts to small sailing dinghies, as well as electronic gear and boating accessories. 
 "I think the feeling we are getting from dealers is optimistic," said Michael Duffy, the boat show manager. "Consumer confidence seems to be picking up a little."
The statistics appear to support his contention. Greg Proteau, spokesman for the National Marine Manufacturers Association, said last week that the boating industry is expected to grow by 6 to 10 percent in 1994. In 1993, 487,000 new boats were sold in the United States, an increase of 7 percent from 1992.
 
Some Jobs Are Coming Back
 Manufacturers are showing signs of the increasing vigor. For example, Wellcraft Marine, a major United States boat builder, has rehired about 300 of the 1,400 employees it laid off during the last four years.
Gordon Houser, director of marketing, said that large cruising yachts are selling again with the repeal last summer of a 10 percent Federal luxury tax on boats valued at more than $100,000. "New looks have a lot to do with it, too," Houser said. "And interest rates are down."
Wellcraft plans to show its new 3600 Martinique, a 36-foot powerboat designed with a large cockpit and three separate sleeping areas. A 3600 equipped with twin 310-horsepower Mercruiser engines sells for about $130,000.
About 20 percent of the New York show's boats are sailing craft. Among the largest will be yachts from Hunter Marine and Beneteau. Buyers interested in sailboats also have the opportunity to attend another New York area boat show, the Sail Expo exhibition, Feb. 5-13 in Atlantic City, N.J.
 
Fishing Finds a Bigger Niche
 Fishing boats and accessories are being given added emphasis this year at the New York show. A 35-foot, 3,500-gallon aquarium, the Hawg Trough, will be set up at the show to demonstrate game-fish catching techniques.
Besides offering fishing seminars, show organizers have lined up exhibitors that plan to introduce new models for 1994. Century Boat, of Panama City, Fla., is expected to reveal details about its 1860 Intracoastal, an 18-foot center console motorboat designed for both fresh and saltwater fishing.
Zodiac of North America, the French inflatable boat manufacturer, plans to show its new Fish n'Hunt boats, the FH 10.2 and FH 12.6. The olive-green inflatables come equipped with swivel seats, collapsible paddles, fishing-rod storage mounts and fittings for a hunting blind. The boats, which come with 9.9-horsepower Mercury engines, vary in price from about $2,500 to $3,500.
Zodiac is also introducing its new Fastroller line, a series of small inflatables that come with new high-pressure, inflatable floorboards instead of standard marine plywood boards.
A special section at the show will feature boats of the future, such as a scale model of the Nautilus 3, which looks more like a space ship than a powerboat. It is is being developed by the Swedish engine manufacturer, Volvo Penta.
 
Buyer, Beware
 Exhibitors often come to the boat show with package deals in which buyers can save money. But Boat/U.S., a national organization for recreational boaters, warns consumers to shop carefully.
Caroline Ajootian, consumer protection director for Boat/U.S., urges buyers to specify in the purchase contract that they want the right to test their new boat in sea trials. It is also important to specify a delivery date in the contract so that dealers can't delay the transaction. "If they're hungry enough, they shouldn't argue about it," Ajootian said. "Go about it as if this is your right."
For further information about the show, which ends Jan. 16, call (212) 459-4433. Hours are from noon to 8 P.M., Monday through Friday; 10 A.M. to 9 P.M., Saturdays; and from 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., Sundays.
 
 
 
MAKING WAVES
 The 14 international challengers for the America's Cup have until the end of the banking day tomorrow in San Diego to come up with a final performance bond of $250,000. The money will be refunded to each group that shows up at the starting line of the 1995 cup trial races.

HEADLINE: THE NEW MAYOR;
Assembling an Administration: Old Friends, Seasoned Hands

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took the reins of the city government yesterday with an administration composed of several seasoned hands joined by several old friends and recent political allies who have little or no experience in city government.
In the incoming administration are three former commissioners and four midlevel aides from the Koch administration, three commissioners from the Dinkins team and three experienced commissioners from other cities who will take over agencies much larger than those they leave. 
 But in the upper echelon of deputy mayors and senior advisers, only two, Paul A. Crotty and Richard J. Schwartz, know the inner workings of the city bureaucracy from their days as officials in the Koch administration. Acting on old friendship and loyalty, Mr. Giuliani has chosen Peter J. Powers, a lawyer, to head his City Hall staff.
Mr. Giuliani has also drawn on the United States Attorney's office, which he himself headed, for talent, bringing in former prosecutors like Dennison Young Jr. and Randy M. Mastro as top aides. His other senior appointments are people with vast experience in state government: John S. Dyson, the flamboyant former head of the State Power Authority, and Abraham M. Lackman, an experienced Republican budgetmaker from the State Senate staff.
The upper echelons of the administration are dotted with critical political supporters, like Ninfa Segarra, a member of the Board of Education, and Carlos M. Rivera, a former Fire Commissioner.
And although the administration is largely complete, Mr. Giuliani must make several important appointments, including commissioners of sanitation, corrections and consumer affairs.

HEADLINE: Japan Faces the Unthinkable: A Shortage of Engineers

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
SHUTARU SHIRAHATA is in the science and engineering school at Waseda University, but he is studying to be a manager.
"I don't want to be an engineer, actually, because that has a rather dark image," the 19-year-old freshman said. He said the physics geniuses and computer whizzes at school "look very strange to me. They look like nerds." 
 The ambitions of Mr. Shirahata and other young people like him are beginning to worry Japan's Government and industry leaders.
This nation has long honored engineers as the heroes of its rise to industrial supremacy. But now, the Government says, young people are losing interest in science and technology, and that could lead to a shortage of engineers and might dull the nation's competitiveness.
One reason for the trend, the Government says, is that youths in Japan are so accustomed to video games, computers and other gadgets they have lost their sense of wonder about technology. There is also the "black-box syndrome," meaning modern machines are so complex that people cannot figure out how they work -- and this denies opportunities for would-be tinkerers.
Another reason has to do with pay. Engineers earn less money than bankers in Japan. There is also the fact that science education is boring, stressing memorization instead of creative exploration. And, finally, Japan's affluent young people are becoming too lazy for the hard work that engineering and science demand.
"There is a tendency among high school students to view university science and engineering students as preoccupied with study," the Science and Technology Agency said in a lengthy report issued last month.
It is an article of faith here that one reason Japan's industry has become so strong is because the nation's brightest students become engineers, while many top American students pursue law or business degrees. With half the population of the United States, Japan has about the same number of engineers but just a small fraction of the number of lawyers.
So the signs that engineering is losing its allure are not taken lightly. The Prime Minister's science and technology council set up a special subcommittee that is scheduled to recommend solutions by this summer. And the Science and Technology Agency devoted its annual white paper last year to that theme.
According to the agency's report, the proportion of college students applying for engineering programs has dropped steadily, to 12.7 percent in 1992 from 17.2 percent in 1986.
The number of new students enrolling in engineering -- 82,213 in 1992 -- has not decreased, however, because in some universities there are still more applicants than positions. In other cases, students end up taking engineering because they cannot get into the department that is their first choice.
THE report also said that according to opinion polls, just 41 percent of people in their 20's said they were interested in science and technology news and topics in 1991, well below the 55 percent for the same age bracket 10 years earlier. For people aged 30 and above, interest in science stayed the same or rose during the decade.
Nikkei Business, a weekly magazine, followed with a cover story last month bemoaning the state of science education and questioning whether Japan could be a technological superpower. It quoted unnamed industrial engineers and professors as saying that young engineers and engineering students nowadays cannot even repair a simple circuit or turn a screwdriver.
All this might seem to be a bit much for a country in which a high school prepares students for math and science college entrance exams that are so tough they would make an American Ph. D. candidate blanch.
Indeed, some say, the worry about the technical workforce is somewhat overblown, and is just a sign of a country that is stuck in a severe economic slump, by its own standards of booming growth, and has a colossal case of anxiety about its future. Some say a decline in engineers is to be expected as Japan evolves from a manufacturing economy to a service economy.
Skeptics say the departure from science and technology has been just a temporary phenomenon caused by Japan's bubble economy of the late 1980's, a time of quick riches and rampant financial speculation. During the bubble, many students, even those with engineering or science degrees, chose to work for banks or securities companies, making it harder for manufacturing companies to hire good people.
But now that the bubble era is over and many financial companies are tainted with scandals, the trends are starting to reverse, they say. "After the collapse of the bubble, people are coming to again recognize the value of manufacturing things," said Mitsuo Shiraishi, professor and dean of academic affairs at Tokyo Denki University, a technical college.
Moreover, at least for the present, there is no shortage of engineers. With automobile, electronics and steel companies reducing their hiring to cut costs, even engineering graduates are having trouble finding jobs, though not as much trouble as liberal arts graduates are having.
BUT Yukihiro Hirano, director of the research division of the science agency's policy bureau, said that while the bubble "is one of the triggers" of a departure from engineering careers, the long-term trend of lower interest in science and technology will remain.
Such a waning interest in technology has also been seen in the United States and Europe, Mr. Hirano said. One difference is that Japan does not seem to have the strong anti-technology feeling that exists among some people in the United States and Europe, who blame technology for pollution, the arms race and other evils. In Japan, he said, the problem is more one of apathy toward science than antipathy toward it.
Some trace the purported decline in interest in science to deterioration in science education in Japan. Kiyoshi Fujii, principal of Yotsuya Elementary School No. 6 in Tokyo, said the number of hours devoted to science classes in grade schools has been declining, leaving less time for experiments. And while at one time there were many elementary school teachers who had majored in science in college, that is less true nowadays, especially because more women are becoming teachers.
"Teachers who in their childhood never touched an insect are teaching science now," he said.
COLLEGE science education also has its problems. In contrast to Japan's usually well-endowed industrial laboratories, university labs are famous for being ill equipped and decrepit because Government research funding is so skimpy.
To increase interest, the Science and Technology Agency's report recommends exposing people to laboratory work and trying to interest more women in science and engineering. In virtually all countries, fewer women than men pursue technical careers. But in Japan, where women are limited in career opportunities in general, the disparity is greater than in the United States, Mr. Hirano said.
The number of high school students taking the entrance examination for Tokyo Denki University declined to 17,000 in 1993, from about 25,000 in the late 1980's, a drop of about a third, even as the overall number of students entering colleges rose.
The school has tried to make its entrance exam less intimidating by adding questions to which students may draw cartoons for answers. It has also begun sponsoring more lectures and programs for high school students, such as summer personal computer lessons.

HEADLINE: For Drugstores, Pushing Pills Is Much Less Profitable

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
UNTIL you talk to them, Bert Drachtman and Alexander Grass do not seem to have much in common. Mr. Drachtman and his wife run the Seventh Avenue Pharmacy in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, while Mr. Grass runs the Rite Aid Corporation, a $4 billion-a-year drugstore chain that definitely is not a Mom and Pop operation.
But increasingly, Mr. Drachtman and Mr. Grass are talking the same language. 
 "In today's marketplace, it is difficult to stay alive," Mr. Drachtman said.
Mr. Grass knows where Mr. Drachtman is coming from. "We see this from the same viewpoint because we are both being disadvantaged," he said.
Pharmacy retailing has become a bruisingly competitive world, and drugstores are being hemmed in by health maintenance organizations, hospitals and mail-order houses, all of which the druggists claim have had big advantages handed to them by major drug manufacturers. With their profit margins narrowing, rafts of retailers have closed their doors in the last two years, and others are sure to follow as cheaper forms of drug distribution gain favor.
To survive, druggists are banding together to negotiate volume discounts from drug makers. Some have even taken their cases to Washington and to the courts.
MORE than 90 percent of prescriptions are still filled by independent and chain drugstores, but pushing pills is not nearly as profitable as it once was. Net profits per prescription have fallen by about 36 percent, in 1990 dollars, since 1970, according to the 1992 annual report on the pharmaceutical industry by Lily Digest, a publication put out by Eli Lilly & Company, and the Prime Institute at the University of Minnesota.
Mr. Drachtman said that when he started his business 23 years ago, gross profit margins on prescriptions averaged between 35 percent and 40 percent. "Now you are working on 5 percent to 18 percent, and going down," he said.
Why? For one, drugstores must compete with fast-growing competitors. H.M.O.'s, hospitals and mail-order houseshave been able to get deep discounts from drug manufacturers, and independent and chain stores say these discounts have not come their way even though they formed bargaining cooperatives.
"Nitro patches cost me about $40 for a box of 30," said Dan Phillips, a co-owner of the Adobe Pharmacy in Sonoma, Calif., referring to nitroglycerine medication used by heart patients. "I have a buddy who is a hospital pharmacist who pays $1 for a box of 100."
Retail pharmacists say these rivals get favorable treatment because they can guarantee drug makers much-prized market share. By limiting their menus to a single brand of every drug, H.M.O.'s and hospitals can offer drug manufacturers exclusivity -- and play them against each other to get the steepest discounts for those rights. But retailers must offer customers a choice of brands.
While pharmacists have lowered their prices, they are not the cheapest choice for such third-party health care payers as insurance companies and employers, which are estimated to account for about 60 percent of all prescription purchases. As a result, these payers are increasingly demanding further reductions from pharmacies or are mandating that plan participants go elsewhere for their drugs.
"A lot of people don't come in anymore," said Ken Epley, who has run the South Salem Pharmacy in Salem, Ore., for 18 years. "And a lot are embarrassed because they can't come in" because their plans do not allow it.
What is more, some customers are bypassing their local pharmacies for other over-the-counter products that are cheaper elsewhere. As aggressive price-cutting competitors like grocery chains and warehouse stores cram their shelves with everything from aspirin to foot powder, pharmacists have lost health and beauty business that accounts for the 40 percent to 50 percent of revenue not derived from prescription drugs.
"Consumers have found so many outlets for these products that chains and independents have to find an answer to the question of how they are going to add value to the front end of the store," said Rick Church, an analyst who follows chain drugstores for Smith Barney Shearson Inc.
As a result, a number of pharmacies have found themselves in no position to stay in business. "Our best guess is that we have probably lost about 1,000 pharmacies over the last two years," said Todd Dankmyer, a spokesman for the National Association of Retail Druggists, a trade group that represents about 40,000 independent pharmacies.
Fred Mayer, a pharmacist in Sausalito, Calif., claims that his state has lost 600 independents in the last 18 months.
Yet competitors and analysts say that the pharmacists are crying wolf and that much of the downsizing is not unlike what is going on in retailing generally. In today's cost-conscious health-care environment, they add, value is in. That means the convenience and personalized attention that pharmacists offer may have become unaffordable luxuries.
"In the late 1960's, the independents complained that the chains had a price advantage over them," said Del Konnor, executive vice president of the American Managed Care Pharmacy Association, which represents mail-order houses like Medco Containment Services Inc. "Now, 25 years later, they have a new scapegoat. Competition is probably the keenest it has ever been in the pharmaceutical practice, and the consumer is benefiting."
Robert C. Johnson, chairman and chief executive of PCS Health Systems, a subsidiary of the McKesson Corporation and the nation's largest prescription benefits management company, said: "The theory that has worked successfully, to a degree, is forcing larger volumes of patients through fewer numbers of providers. This effort began in the mid-1980's in hospitals, was successful there, then spread to the medical profession, where group practice became commonplace. That same philosophy has spread to the pharmacy."
Mr. Johnson said that in the last five years, reimbursements to pharmacists for professional fees for dispensing drugs and counseling patients have remained "fairly constant." But in the same period, reimbursements for drugs have been cut by 10 percent to 15 percent.
"It is that reduction that has really put the squeeze on the pharmacist," he said.
With their livelihoods on the line, pharmacists big and small have waged counterattacks on several fronts. Pharmacists have spent considerable time and effort lobbying the Clinton Administration and have endorsed the President's health care legislation, which proposes to eliminate, to some degree, variances in drug prices.
"The Clinton plan would help to level the playing field, which we think will generate competition," said Jerome Sager, executive director and general counsel of the Empire State Pharmaceutical Society, which represents around 1,000 stores in New York State.
The druggists have also banded together to form buying units in hopes of increasing their bargaining clout with drug manufacturers. Last month, McKesson, the nation's largest drug wholesaler, linked 4,000 Valu-Rite pharmacies to create the nation's largest pharmacy marketing cooperative network.
But to date, alliances among independent and chain drugstores have won only grudging concessions from the manufacturers.
"On the generic drug side of the industry, we get very good prices, probably as good as anyone, and that is what has kept the independent retailers in business," said Benji Wyatt, president and chief executive of Pace Alliance Inc., a retail-pharmacy buying group with more than 3,000 retail drugstores, mostly in the Midwest.
"But on the brand-name side, we have not had much success with the bigger companies, even though some of them are beginning to negotiate with us."
To force the issue, pharmacists have taken legal action.
"If we can get more competition for drug companies for our business, then prices to consumers are going to go down for brand-name prescription drugs," Mr. Wyatt said.
In August a group of California pharmacists represented by Joseph Alioto, the former mayor of San Francisco, filed a class action against a number of major drug manufacturers, accusing them of wide-ranging violations of Federal antitrust laws, including price discrimination and illegal price fixing. That suit was followed in October by a similar action in Pennsylvania, where 10 chains, including Rite Aid, joined 10 pharmacies against seven big drug companies.
And at a November hearing of the Senate Special Committee on Aging, Mark D. Whitener, acting deputy director of the bureau of competition at the Federal Trade Commission, said the agency is investigating charges of price discrimination in prescription drug distribution.
Because of the pending lawsuits, drug manufacturers were reluctant to comment on the pricing issue.
Through a spokesman, Merck, which is being sued in California, asserted that its "pricing practices are fair and legal."
MEANWHILE, pharmacists argue that they serve a serious purpose. They see more patients each year than practicing physicians, and their services are highly valued: for the fifth year in a row last year, pharmacists were the nation's most respected group of professionals in a survey conducted by the Gallup Organization. (In the 1993 survey, doctors ranked fourth.)
"The big thing pharmacists have to sell is their service, knowledge of their patients and the ability to deliver to their patients on a timely basis," Mr. Sager said.
Mr. Johnson of PCS, a former pharmacist, suggested that retailers are caught in a market shift driven by economic forces. "The pharmaceutical industry is finally coming to the realization that the physician is no longer the influencer of the drug product decision," he said.
"What we are seeing today is manufacturers who will have to start negotiating pricing with the individual at health maintenance organizations that are putting together approved drug lists. How much opportunity the retail pharmacy will have to participate in this is still up in the air."

LENGTH: 1518 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: December 26 - 31

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
That Was the Week That Wasn't
Let's be honest about it: Nothing much happened last week -- except figuring out where to put those presents, how to pay those bills. Yes, Government numbers came out, agencies made rulings, corporations issued press releases. But we know computers were spitting out that data to maintain the illusion that solemn, sober capitalism can cruise through the holidays with barely a hiccup. It brings to mind that futuristic classroom where the teacher's voice sputters out of a tape recorder, heard only by rows of students' tape recorders. Still, the economic news that got through -- especially the word of surprising strength in the housing market -- was enough to nudge the stock market to three straight records, as the Dow industrials got within a hair of 3,800 before turning tail at week's end. 

Health Bill Rising as Fast as Ever
Yes, we've heard that prices for medical products and services are rising more slowly. But here's the catch: medical technology keeps on growing, as do the ranks of the elderly. So health spending is rising as fast as ever -- even with the prospect of an overhaul of the whole mess. Last week, in fact, the Commerce Department said the nation's health care spending would pass $1 trillion for the first time this year, rising 12.5 percent. And health spending is taking an ever-bigger bite of the gross domestic product -- an estimated 15 percent this year.
 
Chance of Life: What's It Worth?
It's easy in the abstract to say health spending should be cut, but it's harder when a life -- a special, specific life -- might be saved. Desperate people want to try anything. But who pays? When H.M.O.'s cut costs, where do you draw the line? A jury drew a line in California last week, deciding that one H.M.O., Health Net, was too frugal when it balked at paying for a bone-marrow transplant for a woman who later died of breast cancer, awarding her family $89.3 million. So does this settle anything? Of course not. Lines must, and will, be drawn if health spending is to be tamed.
 
If Only People Paid Their Taxes
The I.R.S., no doubt inspired by a bit too much holiday cheer, has had a truly fanciful vision: a world in which every American reports all income, from daylight job or moonlight, and nobody gets imaginative in figuring deductions. And last week the I.R.S. Commissioner, Margaret Milner Richardson, put a price tag on this imperfect world. Tax cheating, she said, costs the nation $150 billion a year, enough to wipe out three-fifths of the budget deficit. And just as those nasty tax forms head for mailboxes, the I.R.S. declared war, saying greater compliance was its "first major goal." (In that form, by the way, you'll notice you can now assign $3, up from $1, to Presidential campaigns. If that means the 2000 campaign is three times normal length, it will start before the 1996 election.)
 
Out With the Old (House)
The air may have been cold as the year huffed its last, but the economy was undeniably hot. The hottest spot: home sales. First came a report that November's sales of existing homes hit a record pace, followed by word that new-home sales surged to the highest rate since 1986. And that signals more good economic news, because home buyers just keep on spending -- on carpets, paint, appliances, and, of course, lawyers. That's especially true of first-time buyers, who were out in force. But there's more: the Government's index of leading indicators rose 0.5 percent, the fourth straight monthly rise, and jobless claims plunged to 291,000, the lowest in nearly five years. So as the year ended, one economist said it clearly: "All's clear on the recession watch."
 
And They Still Call It January
Now that it's Super Bowl Month, let's get one thing clear: there is nothing to the rumor that the TV folks just keep showing the same game, year after year, and no one notices because they're too busy whooping and hollering. Absolutely nothing to it. A treasonous lie, no doubt dreamed up by one of those 14 Americans (some estimates put it as high as 17) who don't watch the game. Advertisers clearly don't believe it, for they're paying NBC a record $900,000 to pitch sneakers or colas or beers for 30 seconds. That's $30,000 a second, about what many people make in a year. How must they feel, having a year's sweat and toil valued the same as a fleeting televised moment amid a helmeted blur? "That," said one marketing official, "is a sobering way to dimensionalize it." And if you've got an extra million in your ad budget, better hurry: as of last week, most of the 56 half-minute spots had been sold.
 
COMPANIES
 
New Wings for an Old Name?
In the end, nothing was left of Pan Am but its name. Already bankrupt, it stopped flying two years ago, and its assets were sold. But what a name it is! It evokes a whole era of aviation history, back to 1927. So just that mighty trademark -- which couldn't get you on the subway, much less around the world -- sold recently for $1.325 million. And the buyer, Charles Cobb, now says he might even start an airline.
 
4-Letter Words, 8-Figure Profits
Today's topic, class, is the economics of obscenity. Let's see: Infinity Broadcasting, Howard Stern's employer, earned about $90 million last year, and Mr. Stern's very public parts had a lot to do with that. The F.C.C. has fined Infinity $1.2 million because of Mr. Stern's mouth, of which Infinity has paid nothing. The bottom line (as Mr. Stern might say): obscenity pays. Now the F.C.C., which has gotten thousands of complaints about Mr. Stern's radio show, wants to change that. Last week it raised the stakes, delaying deals worth $170 million in which Infinity planned to buy three radio stations, and that could cost Infinity millions. In the end, the Supreme Court will probably decide how free speech can be.
 
A Top Prudential Casualty
Scandal reaches ever higher at Prudential Securities. Last week Loren Schechter, the top current executive being investigated by Federal prosecutors, resigned as general counsel. He is said to have come under scrutiny for his failure to stop misrepresentations of the safety of limited partnerships sold in the 80's.
 
Brutes in Toyland
The world's really a simple place. Women dream of weddings, men of guns. Don't believe it? Look at today's dolls -- Barbies that chirp, "Let's go shopping!"; G.I. Joes that snarl, "Eat lead, Cobra!" A group of Manhattan performance artists decided that such toys "encourage negative behavior in children" -- and came up with a novel way to make its point. It simply swapped the voice boxes in some dolls so that a G.I. Joe will whimper, "Will we ever have enough clothes?" and Barbie snaps, "Attack!"
 
Death of an I.B.M. Pioneer
A generation ago, Thomas J. Watson Jr. guided a mighty I.B.M. into the computer age. On the last day of a year that I.B.M. would love to forget, Mr. Watson died at 79.
 
Sign of Strength for Railroads
You don't hear much about the railroad industry, but it's quietly building strength. The latest of many signs: last week CSX ordered 300 high-efficiency locomotives from G.E. And for CSX, it's proof of a return to basics.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
A Ford in Mazda's Present
Remember the days when it seemed that Japan was putting America in its shopping cart and wheeling it calmly away? Gone, long gone. American auto makers have roared back, while the Japanese have sputtered. Mazda has been especially hard hit, after expanding too fast when times were flush; last year, in fact, it may have lost $300 million. Last week, Mazda all but fell on its sword, suddenly ceding more control to Ford, which with a 25 percent stake was already its largest shareholder. And it's more than an investment for Ford: the American company will now have a lot to say about Mazda's future, and a Ford executive will become a top Mazda manager. So, what next? Will the cycle come round again, with Japan calling the shots at the Big Three a decade from now?
 
China Updates Its Currency
A big question mark as a new world order takes shape is the role the huge Chinese economy will play. Last week, China took a clear step toward becoming part of that world order, ending a two-tier exchange rate for its currency. This is not full convertibility -- something it has promised GATT within five years, and something it must have to truly join the outer world. But by ending a system that allowed a black market on which the yuan was worth far less than it was officially, it will ease the flow of exports and imports and help to establish a market economy.
 
Troubles in Spanish Banking
Spain's banking industry was in turmoil last week after central bankers took over the nation's third-largest bank, Banco Espanol de Credito, and replaced its chairman, Mario Conde. There were signs of trouble at the bank, known as Banesto, which had expanded aggressively under Mr. Conde, and regulators badly wanted to protect the credibility of the nation's banking system. But bank stocks quickly took a beating.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 500 words

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
After a Boring 1993, Let's Hope For a Repeat

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
THIS bull market is the dullest in a generation. While major stock indexes were setting records as 1993 ended, the really amazing fact was just how little action there had been. Had you bought the Standard & Poor's 500 at its lowest close of last year, and sold it at the high reached last week, you would have made a profit of 9.8 percent.
Never in the previous six decades of the S.&P. had the swing from annual bottom to top been so flat. But that low volatility should not have come as a shock. The old record for smallest annual swing was set in 1992, at 11.9 percent. 
 And it isn't just big stock indexes that show a lack of vigor. The Nasdaq composite was more than twice as volatile as the S.&P. 500 last year, with a swing of 21.9 percent. But that is the third-smallest Nasdaq move in the past 20 years.
To be sure, there are owners of many stocks who found last year anything but dull. Philip Morris shares plunged along with cigarette prices and General Motors stock soared as the weak dollar forced Japanese car makers to raise their prices. "The volatility of individual stocks has not collapsed," says Philip Smyth, an analyst at Birinyi Associates in Greenwich, Conn. "But when you look at the indices, it just keeps getting smoother."
It is possible to have violent swings within a narrow range, but that did not happen either. Last year saw just 17 occasions when the S.&P. ended the day up or down at least 1 percent from the prior session. That was down from 75 such days in 1990.
Why so quiet? Partly, it is the lack of surprises on the economic front. No doubt it also reflects the way Wall Street has adjusted to program trading, as it adjusted years ago to the trading of big blocks. At first, both produced heavy volatility. Now, notwithstanding Friday's late slip caused by some options expiring, complaints are rarely heard about either.
But mutual funds and low interest rates have also played a role. The prevailing sentiment among mutual fund managers is that they are paid to pick winning stocks, not to hold cash at these puny rates. So even when fund managers bail out of the latest disappointment, they tend to plow the money back into other stocks, and index moves are mild.
The time most comparable to the present, the only other one in which the S.&P. had two consecutive years with annual moves of less than 15 percent, was 1964-65. The following year saw the return of volatility, and share prices fell as both inflation and the Viet Cong proved stronger than Washington expected.
Peace and quiet is not everyone's idea of heaven. Those who crave action inevitably have begun to look elsewhere. It took the S.&P. 500 a whole year to move less than 10 percent. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index managed more action than that in the last five trading days of the year. Investors chasing performance are buying funds that invest in emerging markets.
Let them. Our New Year's wish is for a 1994 market just as boring, and as profitable, as 1993's.

HEADLINE: Lawyers, Class Actions and Fees

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your article understates the damage done to individual investors when a firm such as Beigel & Sandler files class actions on their behalf and then agrees to a pathetically small settlement. 
 If Herbert Beigel truly advised individuals that "No one should be in a class action who has a strong individual claim except for a person whose claim is of such small monetary value that it would be economically unfeasible to bring a claim any other way," his business would disappear.
In the recent JMB Realty/Merrill Lynch case, where his firm received more than $1 million for negotiating and recommending a settlement paying the investors less than two cents on the dollar, this advice did not appear in any press statements or in the mailing to investors. The reason this sort of settlement is accepted by the investors is that investors have to act to exclude themselves, and act within a short time. In the JMB/Merrill case, less than a month was available. If the investor doesn't receive notice, or needs an explanation of the complicated choices involved, he or she is out of luck.
Our firm represents individual investors with claims starting at $5,000 in securities arbitration, primarily on a contingency basis. We have not seen investors in arbitration, even after the payment of fees and costs, wind up with as little as they would have in class actions. If, as Mr. Beigel says, the cases he settles so cheaply are weak, why do investors recover so much more on an individual basis?
 
 MITCHELL L. PERLSTEIN Boca Raton, Fla., Dec. 20
 
The author is a partner at Parker Perlstein & Company.

HEADLINE: Africa, Out in the Cold

 BODY:
In a burst of compassion and amid loud applause, the United States a year ago rushed to the rescue of the sick and starving in Somalia. But for Africans, this holiday season is even bleaker, and not just for Somalis. When the humanitarian mission in Somalia went sour, most of Africa below the Sahara also seemed to drop from sight. Every bit of bad news -- civil wars, military coups, drought and disease -- has sadly reinforced a mood of fatalism or still worse, callous unconcern.
Yet it is one thing to recognize Africa's economic and political ills, and quite another to let them become the pretext for doing little or nothing. Much that has gone wrong in Africa springs from causes beyond African control; that, too, needs to be recognized. First and most grievous is the steady drop over a decade in the world prices for African exports, which in turn has shrunk the private investment flow to sub-Saharan states from $10 billion in 1982 to $4.7 billion in 1990. 
 The dismaying results are underscored by Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the first U.N. Secretary General from Africa. For countries below the Sahara, foreign debts, described by Mr. Boutros-Ghali as a "millstone around the neck," have risen to the equivalent of 106 percent of gross domestic product, compared with 37 percent for another debtor region, Latin America.
This has cruelly coincided with a decline in development loans from multilateral banks. New lending commitments to sub-Saharan Africa by the World Bank in its last financial year fell by $1.2 billion, or 30 percent. That in part reflects sharper competition for all foreign aid. The World Bank's commitments to Eastern Europe, for example, rose in the same year to $3.8 billion from $1.7 billion.
Doubtless, as the World Bank says, Africa's political volatility helps explain this contrast. But it is also true that sub-Saharan Africa has been the biggest loser as the cold war has ended. A decade ago, the Reagan Administration expatiated on Africa's vital maritime "choke-points," its wealth of natural resources and the presence of 37,000 Communist economic technicians below the Sahara. Now the technicians have disappeared, along with Soviet-bloc aid, and so has Africa's cold war leverage.
What this also implies was spelled out at a conference in Namibia by a British parliamentarian, Sir David Steel: "We in the West cheerfully supported appalling dictatorships because they were on the 'right' side in the cold war. Now that this shadow is lifted, we demand instant standards of good governance. This is not good enough."
So what is good enough? A little more aid and debt forgiveness in extreme cases would make a difference. So would incentives for political and market reforms. But what might achieve more, at negligible cost, would be a concerted diplomatic initiative to bring an end to wars that beggar and uproot so many peoples in Angola and Mozambique, in Liberia and the Sudan, in Somalia and Rwanda.
Remarkably, Africa has witnessed real gains in the past year. South Africa has repudiated apartheid. Peace, however tenuous, prevails in Ethiopia; Eritrea has won its right to independence. Armies have demobilized in Uganda, and its economy is percolating. In a broad swath of countries, from Kenya to Zambia, from Malawi to Gabon, ordinary people are clamoring for human and political rights. Gains like these merit a more generous -- and attentive -- response from richer nations.

HEADLINE: Clear Today; Tomorrow, Who Knows?;
Catch '94

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
IT'S a new year and therefore -- admit it and face it bravely -- time to look ahead. The good news (or maybe not) is that the future may not be quite the yawning void of which Marcus Aurelius wrote. That's only if the past is indeed prologue. But it may not be. It does, however, allow some educated guesses at what's coming. Herewith a handful: 
 Will you be better off in 1994 than in 1993?
That's the sort of question that got George Bush and Jimmy Carter into a peck of trouble. But there is a whole cottage industry of economic prognosticators out there who are happy to answer, provided you promise to forget which ones were dead wrong. And for better or worse, most are mildly bullish on America.
The forecasts of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development are among the most cautious and, by no coincidence, the most copied. Its computer jockeys expect 3 percent growth in output next year, enough to clip half a percentage point off the unemployment rate by the end of '94 but not enough to kindle even a spark of inflation.
The catch, of course, is what the catch has long been: the American economy is so big and so diverse that the averages mask much of what you'd really like to know. As of November, for example, the national unemployment rate was 6.3 percent. But it was twice as high for blacks and three times as high for 16-to-19 year-olds unlucky enough to be out of school.
Nor do the averages have much to say about the diverging fortunes of regions and industries. While the heartland is chugging right along, the economies of Southern California and New England are still taking on water. And although DRI/McGraw-Hill is forecasting a zippy 9 percent increase in office equipment output next year, weapons makers are staring at a 5 percent fall.
Perhaps the most elusive part of the economic equation is also the most important: how the bounty of the recovery-in-progress will be divided. It's been tough -- much too tough -- being young, unskilled or a single parent heading a household for a very long time. From 1974 to 1991 the percentage of children in poverty rose from 15 percent to 22, while during the same period the percentage of elderly who were poor fell from 15 percent to 12.
Predicting what will happen to this and related measures of income distribution requires a suspension of disbelief, since the causes of the divergence are still a mystery. But there are straws in the wind suggesting that the later 1990's will not be as hard on the have-littles. PETER PASSELL

HEADLINE: Welfare and Social Work Both Need Reform

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Welfare Recipients Are Victims, Not Criminals" (letter, Dec. 20) by Jennifer E. Baity, a graduate student at the Columbia University School of Social Work, states she is alarmed by the "frightening implications" of President Clinton's proposed welfare reform. 
 To illustrate, she describes a client she is working with "who speaks of nothing but getting a job and getting off welfare."
Her client is a single mother with three children younger than 6, who lives in subsidized housing and receives assistance from the aid to families with dependent children program, food stamps and Medicaid. She says her client had been working but lost her job because her day-care arrangements "fell apart" with the birth of her third child.
Why is it that Ms. Baity thinks that a client who talks of getting a job and getting off welfare is an indication of responsibility? She would be serving her client more effectively if she were to advocate family planning.
In my role as parent I see the choices my stepson and his wife have had to make. They have one child younger than 6 and know that their economic condition, and the expense and complications of child care, do not allow them to have more children now. They both work at full-time jobs so they can have a dependable income, decent housing, food, medical benefits and affordable child care.
What's alarming to me is that a respected university is producing social workers with Ms. Baity's hypothesis, which is that their clients are "victims" of society.
It's very simple why President Clinton needs to reform welfare -- our country can no longer afford to support single mothers who do not practice birth control.
Ms. Baity's concerns sound like a voice from the 1960's. With our country's economic climate what it is, it's frightening that our future social workers are stuck in a decades-old ideology. Our economy has changed, and social work education needs to be reformed. Otherwise, many needy clients are going to be left out in the cold because of inadequate human services.
 
KAY POWELL
New York, Dec. 22, 1993

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living in/Newtown;
Big Town With a Small-Town Ambiance

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
FROM its incorporation in 1711 until the 1930's, Newtown's population, mostly farmers and artisans, never went past 3,000. Cotton mill and Goodyear rubber factory workers swelled the ranks in the 19th century and a trickle of commuters and affluent professionals followed in the 1900's.
During the postwar exodus to the suburbs Newtown remained a quiet outpost on the northeastern border of Fairfield County, too remote for the hordes of city folk who settled into southern Fairfield's bountiful array of new subdivisions. But that was before the cost of living in lower Fairfield County zoomed and traveling a bit farther to work became less onerous if the right house could be found at the right price. 
 In Newtown it could, and in the last 20 years this archetypically New England community in Connecticut has been discovered, its population increasing not only in numbers but also in diversity.
Heavily oriented toward families, it has no condominiums, few rentals, residential zoning of 1 to 5 acres and a handful of restaurants. But there are some 60 arts, service and social organizations, including the Town Players, Friends of Music, Ballet Miniatures, Historical Society, garden clubs and animal welfare and conservation groups.
Newtown is geographically the largest community in the county, with three exits on Interstate 84. There is shopping at four local centers, along Route 25 and at the nearby Danbury Fair Mall.
Still, Main Street is little changed from the 18th century, its fine old churches, Meeting House and homesteads carefully preserved and in constant use. The flagpole, on the site of the first Meeting House, sits in the middle of the road, protected by state statute after it was declared a traffic hazard by the Connecticut Transportation Department. The town fought its removal and had it declared a National Landmark.
Up the street, the wooden floors of the 200-year-old General Store creak underfoot, and squeezed between counters is an upright piano, played by Donna Spanner, the proprietress, and many customers. On summer nights people stop by after the movies for sodas and homemade ice cream, and year round they come in from 5 A.M. to 11 P.M. for breakfast, lunch and snacks. Self-serve coffee patrons leave their money near the coffemaker.
"They always pay," said Ms. Spanner.
The movies, a block away at the Edmond Town Hall, cost $2 for adults, $1 at matinees and $1 for children. There is free parking in the rear.
In 1992 the recession gave Kim Danziger, a developer, an opportunity to buy 65 bargain-priced acres at Old Farm Hill Road from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. He began selling lots and building four-bedroom homes on 2-plus acres for $319,000 to $359,000. Within a year he sold 22 houses of 8 to 10 rooms in 6 styles in a development called Lantern Ridge. Included in the base price are landscaping, most appliances, decks, a two- or three-car garage, cedar clapboard siding and screened thermopane windows. Six lots are left.
Some 300 houses of the 7,194 in town are for sale, and Irene Schwartz of Flagpole Realty said "indications are that the median price has tilted upward to around $209,000, but homes can still be found in the $128,000 to $138,000 range on 2- and 3-acre lots."
Elizabeth Myers of William Raveis Real Estate said that homes were selling "in 100 days instead of 6 months to a year" but that those priced above $500,000 still lingered.
"We're in a building boom here," said Jean St. Jean, Newtown's Building Department Administrator. Permits for 30 new houses priced from $250,000 to almost $1 million were issued in November. In the first week of December, 14 were issued, bringing the 1993 total to around 200.
That's about as many new houses as there were new elementary school pupils enrolled in 1993. In 1992 there were 100 new children and 164 new homes. Applications for 17 more subdivisions with a total of 84 lots covering an aggregate of 596 acres have been approved by the Planning and Zoning Commission.
To accommodate the new students, two of the four elementary schools were expanded in 1992 and an addition to the high school is planned.
S.A.T. scores are higher by about 30 points than state averages, which are in turn higher than national averages, and 80 percent of the 3,711 public school children went on to higher education last June.
GIFTED students and those with special needs are placed in appropriately tailored programs, and advanced college credits may be earned in high school. An enrichment program in the middle school and high school brings together people in the arts and professions with small groups of students to explore mutual interests.
"We have assembled a professional staff that understands there is always a significant potential for improvement," said Dr. John Reed, Superintendent of Schools for 12 years. "We don't wait for lightning to strike with some new program or technique. It's a day-by-day effort, with no laurels to rest on. Education is a very complex undertaking, which may be why I prefer a system like this, of manageable size."
A private Montessori School enrolls 100 pupils from 3 years of age through Grade 6. Its preschool division operates five days a week, three hours a day. Tuition is $3,000 to $5,000. St. Rose parochial school has 193 students from kindergarten through 8th grade and charges $1,680 to $4,000.
THE town has more than 4,000 acres of parkland, including the two sections of the 1,874-acre Paugusset State Forest. In summer, Lake Lillinonah and Lake Zoar -- actually bellied-out stretches of the Housatonic River -- churn with boaters, swimmers and water-skiiers. A seasonal boat launch permit at Lake Lillinonah costs $25.
Residents get free permits for several parks and preserves, including Dickinson Park, where there is an ice-skating pond, annual fishing derbies and Halloween extravaganzas, and Treadwell Park, which has an 8-lane pool. Swimming permits there or at the high school's indoor pool cost $50.
Charges for a variety of other town-run programs range from $14 for four tennis lessons for a child to $149 for eight horseback-riding lessons.
"Our horse editor says there are close to 2,500 horses in town," said R. Scudder Smith, the third generation of Smiths to edit The Newtown Bee, a paper founded in 1877. He also edits the Bee's companion, Antiques and the Arts Weekly, and a new publication, "Horses of Connecticut."
The only regulation governing the keeping of horses is that they must be housed at least 100 feet from the owner's property line. Some 28 miles of trails are maintained by the private Bridle Lanes Association, open to bird-watchers, cross-country skiiers and hikers as well as equestrians. Membership costs $35 for a family.
The town also has a Fish and Game Club, the Newtown Country Club and Rock Ridge Country Club, all private.
At the center of town is the original community of Newtown, a square mile of land that was incorporated as a borough in 1824 so that it could preserve its identity as outlying areas grew. While it is part of Newtown, the borough has its own government, and its 800 taxpayers pay an additional $1.35 for each $1,000 of assessment to maintain their street lights, public landscaping and fire hydrants.
Through 20 years and four votes a contingent of Boroughites has sought to establish a portion of Main Street from Currituck Road to Glover Avenue as a Historic District, to preserve its pristine early-American elegance.
"We lost by one vote last time, but we will try again," said Joan Crick, Warden of The Borough and one of its nearly two dozen officials.
SOON the borough will have Newtown's first sewers, mandated by the state because of septic tank overflows. The $34 million sewer system and treatment plant, financed by state and local bonds, will extend into parts of the Sandy Hook section, and construction is expected to begin this year, said Elizabeth Stocker, Newtown's Community Development Director.
In Sandy Hook, Lou Bastos, owner of the 1857 Red Brick General Store, takes pride in the distinctive little business center and surrounding homes.
"We have descendants of 18th- and 19th-century mill workers still living in the original houses," he said.
The Pootatuck River runs through Sandy Hook and on its banks is a handsome office building converted from an old firehose factory. More offices and light industry are being sought to keep residential taxes down. Newtown's Business Park has about 20 companies, with six lots, totaling 13 acres, still available. There also are 400 acres of open land zoned for commerce.
Office and light industrial development is being considered now for part of the 900 acres at the state's Fairfield Hills Correctional Center by a task force headed by Julia R. Wasserman, Newtown's State Representative. More than 60 buildings, erected in the 1930's as a mental hospital, have been gradually emptied over several years. Some are now occupied by the Second Company Governor's Horse Guard, part of the state militia. And a new 400-bed state jail was built on the grounds in 1992, to the dismay of the town.
The Bridle Lanes Association wants to use 300 of the 900 acres for a major $35 million horse show facility that could be used for antiques shows and other events, drawing from the entire Northeast. "Now the shows have to go to other states," said Kim Connolly, association vice president.
"We will report on both plans to the legislature in April," said Representative Wasserman.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Lawyers, Class Actions and Fees

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Kurt Eichenwald's article is a work of demonizing. The demon is attorney Herbert Beigel of Chicago. Herb, a former Justice Department prosecutor with the organized-crime task force, founded the firm Beigel & Sandler (which now bears the sesquipedalian moniker of Beigel Schy Lasky Rifkind & Hennessey). Herb Beigel is also, I should disclose, my law partner and friend. 
 If the whole truth could be told, the real harm done by Mr. Eichenwald's piece would be clear: the misdiagnosis of the problem. Investors in limited partnerships have been victimized, first by the sellers of securities and then by legislators and judges who have shaped and applied the law in ways that enable the wrongdoers to escape the consequences of their misconduct. As a result, investors have sometimes had to settle for less than they deserve.
Settlement of lawsuits is an area ripe for analysis, as under 10 percent of filed class actions go to trial. Mr. Eichenwald's article is misleading, however, in its generalization that lawyers representing investors in class actions "don't need their approval of a settlement." Indeed, the settlement of a class action (and the awarding of class counsel's fees) must be approved by the court after notice to all the investors and an open hearing. Investors dissatisfied with the proposed settlement can also opt out of the case by sticking a 29-cent stamp on an envelope, enclosing an informal one-sentence note, and dropping it in the mail. Neither settlements nor fee awards are ramrodded through and rubber-stamped by the courts.
Apparently without conscious irony, Mr. Eichenwald contends both that our firm recommends "low" settlements in some cases and aggressively prosecutes "frivolous" claims in others. But in the VMS Realty case, his prime example of a "low" settlement, all defendants moved to dismiss the case. Some (including Prudential Securities) settled before the motions were decided, paying $25 million in cash. But others (including Cigna Securities) refused to settle and the court granted their motions to dismiss. It is absurd for Mr. Eichenwald to criticize our firm for extracting a substantial sum to settle claims the judge would otherwise have thrown out.
There is no basis for Mr. Eichenwald's criticism of our firm's settlements in non-class actions. In such cases settlement recommendations are subject to the client's affirmative approval (as opposed to the "opt-out" or negative enrollment procedure of class actions). The key point is that the combination of a contingent fee with a modest upfront retainer, with no additional payments of either fees or expenses except out of a recovery, has enabled investors to pursue claims that they might not otherwise have been able economically to bring. Jane Bryant Quinn praised this very fee structure in Newsweek several years ago.
As for "frivolous" claims, it is simply a fact that when a law firm agrees to bring some of the most novel, risky and difficult cases on behalf of aggrieved investors, some claims will be rejected. In the Kushner v. D.B.G. case, the judge imposed a sanction of $25,000 on Beigel & Sandler. Yet these allegedly "frivolous" claims were settled by the defendants for a substantial sum. Would our clients have been better served by getting nothing?
In short, Mr. Eichenwald is wrong to blame the victim's lawyers for the problems caused by others. There is nothing we or other class-action/contingent-fee firms desire more than better recoveries for our clients.
 
RONALD A. SCHY
Chicago, Dec. 30

CORRECTION-DATE: January 16, 1994, Sunday

HEADLINE: Small Steps to a Greater New York;
Awards for Courage

BYLINE: By STANLEY CROUCH; Stanley Crouch, author of "Notes of a Hanging Judge," a collection of essays, and a forthcoming biography of Charlie Parker.

 BODY:
New Yorkers argue about everything. But as the campaign for City Hall showed, they don't disagree that the quality of life here has declined. With Rudolph W. Giuliani installed as Mayor, how can the social climate be improved? The Op-Ed page invited recommendations and proposals.
 What this city needs most is freedom from the idea that democracy is nothing more than special-interest groups moving toward positions of power. Morale is the real medicine -- the spiritual fuel that will enable us to take on challenges together. 
 So besides moving against crime, poverty, inadequate public education, unemployment and bureaucratic hanky-panky, Mayor Giuliani would do well to create a symbol that speaks to the perpetual expression of human empathy. He should establish a monthly award for citizens and public servants who reach across race and all other lines to express their courage and commitment to urban civilization. They do these sorts of things daily, in every borough. The Mayor should constantly remind us of that; and he should remind the hysterical press, which hucksters so much alienation.
Appropriate fanfare recognizing this sort of heroism could give New York a badly needed second wind of morale.
