HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: G. Michael Brown;
Planning Ahead at the Foxwoods Casino

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
INDIAN gaming enterprises started 14 years ago with a bingo hall on a Florida reservation and have expanded to 68 casinos and 170 high-stakes bingo games in 24 states today, with more in the planning stages. About half of the nation's 318 federally recognized tribes are attempting to open gaming halls. The most successful Indian casino in the nation is Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo & Casino on the Mashantucket Pequot Indian reservation off Route 2 in Ledyard, with an estimated net operating profit of more than $20 million a month. G. Michael Brown, 51, is the chief executive officer of Foxwoods.
Mr. Brown, a graduate of Seton Hall Law School, was an assistant prosecutor in Essex County, N.J., worked in the New Jersey Attorney General's office and in 1979, when New Jersey legalized casinos, he was appointed the director of gaming enforcement. He started an Atlantic City law firm in 1982, Brown and Michael, which specializes in gambling regulation. 
 He was introduced to the Mashantuckets in 1990 when the tribe was considering entering the casino business. He advised the Mashantuckets on how to set up the casino and helped to obtain financing. When the casino opened in February 1992 he helped the tribe set up its own gaming commission, and served as its first chairman. He became chief executive of Foxwoods in January.
Although he presides over a luxurious casino with flourishes such as an indoor waterfall, his own office is in a construction trailer. In a recent interview, Mr. Brown talked about Foxwoods and the future of gambling in Connecticut. Here are some excerpts from that conversation:
Q. Foxwoods has captured the world's attention because of its incredibly fast growth. How long can it be sustained?
A. I think it will level off when we complete Phase 5 and Phase 6. Phase 5 is a new bingo hall that will be completed in May of 1994. It will seat 3,000 for bingo and 5,000 for events such as boxing, and we'll take the old bingo hall and put another 1,500 slot machines in there, which will put us close to 5,000 slot machines. Phase 6 will be a garage with 1,500 parking spaces. Beyond that, the Foxwoods development will probably level off for a while. With the opening of the new hotel this month we'll have 610 hotel rooms, and we'll be able to accommodate most of the people who want to stay with us. We'll have 139,000 square feet of gaming space, 233 table games, keno, bingo, 3,150 slot machines -- I think we have enough to keep the market active. The new parking garage will be designed to withstand construction of an eight-story hotel on top of it. That is not going to commence at this time, but it's there if and when the market demands it.
Q. How does Foxwoods manage a 50-percent profit margin, compared to 30 percent at most other casinos?
A. Atlantic City casinos, which I'm most familiar with, compete for customers. They spend exorbitant amounts of money on complimentary services and promotions and advertising, because there's 12 of them, and they're all looking for the same body coming off the bus. There's only one of us, so we can advertise the resort in a subdued way, and we are not involved in major giveaways. Secondly, we don't cater to real high-level play. The largest bet you can place here is $2,500 on a table game. Also, our cost of operation is less because we pay close attention to overhead.
Q. What is happening to all the money that the tribe is earning from the casino?
A. Most of it is being spent on the expansion now. But they also just broke ground for a Native American museum, the largest Native American museum ever built. The tribe has an educational fund so that any tribal member can go to any college in the world and they'll pay the costs, and pay them a salary while they go. They have a health care center that treats not only tribal members but any Native American. They're developing housing for tribal members and senior citizens. They have a community center that's going to open in a month or two.
Q. You are seeing larger crowds almost every month. Is your limiting factor going to be the market, or the capacity of the roads?
A. I don't think it's the roads. I think right now it's the lack of parking. We're having offsite parking for employees and turning employee lots into patron lots. I think we're just starting to scratch the market. We're up to about 40,000 people on the weekends, and our average day is probably 18,000 or 20,000 people. But we were strictly a day trip until July 2 when we opened the Two Trees Inn. Now we're getting into heavy marketing efforts in Boston, Toronto, New York City, northern New Jersey, and we'll start to draw people in from there now that they know they can come and stay overnight.
Q. Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. blocked expanded casino gambling in Connecticut this year. Since he has decided not to seek a second term, do you expect a major push this year to legalize gambling?
A. I'm really not very politically astute. I'm sure there's going to be a push to legalize, and we will try to convince people that one casino is enough for the state, but it's a state political decision. If someone else comes into the market, if they change the law, hopefully we're going to be the better Connecticut casino.
Q. Gambling is described as the fastest growing industry in the United States. Why now?
A. Until 1978 gambling was illegal everyplace in the United States except Nevada. New Jersey legalized casinos, and we spent a lot of time trying to create not only a clean operation, but the appearance of integrity in casino investigation, regulation and operation. When people saw you could do it and you could regulate it and you could use it to draw visitors to your state, everyone started to jump on the bandwagon.
Q. There continue to be occasional problems with corruption, though. What do you do at Foxwoods to prevent that?
A. I have on our surveillance department staff some former F.B.I. guys and some former state police organized crime guys, whose job it is to make sure we don't do business with the wrong type of people. They do a review of every person we're going to do business with. If a guy comes in and wants to sell us tapes, he fills out a vendor application form. My in-house people do a background check. Every person we do business with has to get an vendor license from the state, so there's an independent background check done by the state. Every employee, including me, has to have a background check done by the Connecticut State Police before they can work here. We stay in touch with the local F.B.I. and the Secret Service out of Boston. We stay in touch with the other casino surveillance and security departments.
Q. Then why do you face so much opposition from residents of Ledyard, North Stonington and Preston?
A. Some people don't want to see change. Quite frankly, if I bought a farm on Route 2 10 years ago, and now I saw one of the major entertainment resorts in the world being built down the road, I probably wouldn't like it. There's a traffic increase, too, which is an inconvenience. But I think you also have to consider we're not going anywhere, and we're going to do what we can to ease the inconvenience and the pain for the surrounding community. We paid for all the traffic lights and road improvements that are being done in the area, all of it done voluntarily on the tribe's part to ease the impact of this major development.
Q. What do you do about compulsive gamblers?
A. We've sponsored one conference on the subject, and we give $100,000 a year to a compulsive gambling association to do program development and assistance. Our supervisors take courses in how to recognize compulsive gamblers, and if they spot one they're supposed to move them off the floor. Usually a floor person will go over, ask them to go have a cup of coffee in the grill, then talk to them and try to get them to go home. It probably happens once a day, or 10 times a week, when there's an incident where people appear to be over their head.
Q. What about the criticism that Indians have an unfair advantage over casinos on non-Indian land?
A. No casino in the United States guarantees the state in which it's located $113 million a year, which we do to Connecticut. Secondly, the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act was passed with the support of the Nevada Resort Association, to contain and set up some regulatory system over gaming on Indian land, and we're complying with that law. If you look at the impact that Indian tribes have had on the local economies, that we've had here and that the 13 tribes that run casinos in Minnesota have had on the Minnesota economy, there's an enormous contribution to the local economies.
Q. How long will the construction continue?
A. At least until next summer. We'll always be building new parking lots, and we have our own waste-water treatment plant that is being expanded continually, so we'll have construction going on through at least the year 2000. But I think the major, heavy construction -- once we get the Phase 5 bingo hall and the Phase 6 garage open -- will subside substantially.

GRAPHIC: Photo: G. Michael Brown, chief executive of the Foxwoods casino. (Gale Zucker for The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 1; Column 1; Westchester Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 1444 words

HEADLINE: Hopes for '94: Faster Rebound Than in '93

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
REPORTS of renewed vigor in some sectors of Westchester's economy notwithstanding, bottom-line figures showed that the county during 1993 lagged behind other sections of the New York City area in rebounding from the recession.
The slowness in Westchester was due mainly to "the continuing saga of large corporations laying off workers in efforts to downsize," said Noreen L. Preston, an economist with the County Department of Commerce and Economic Development. The corporate restructurings -- by I.B.M., Nynex and Reader's Digest, among others -- counteracted job gains realized by other small and medium-size companies, she said.
Weaker Labor Force Participation 
 Although monthly figures for Westchester's jobless rate were lower this year than last -- 5.1 percent for October 1993 compared with 6.2 percent a year earlier, for example -- the figures did not reflect a job market that was growing stronger.
Rather, the jobless rates -- evaluated in context with other statistics -- indicated that fewer workers were looking for jobs, said Frank M. Surdey, a regional economist for the State Department of Labor.
"The lower unemployment figures were not an indication of economic health," Mr. Surdey said. "What we saw was weaker labor force participation, more discouraged workers and on the whole 1993 was the softest year job-wise since 1982."
Mr. Surdey cited a 6 percent loss of manufacturing jobs in Westchester this year -- 45,600 in October compared to 48,300 for the same month a year ago. The wholesale and retail sector also saw job losses -- from 82,000 in October 1992 to 80,000 in October this year.
Construction Jobs Picking Up
And despite a late-year pickup in construction, overall 1993 was not a healthy one for the industry, Mr. Surdey said. Figures showed there were 15,800 construction jobs during October 1993, compared with 16,200 during the same month a year ago.
Nevertheless, some healthy indicators for the future are being seen for construction workers, said Ross J. Pepe, president of the Construction Industry Council of Westchester and Hudson Valley, a professional and trade group representing 500 businesses. Mr. Pepe called 1993 "something of a turnaround year for the industry."
He said that construction workers in the building sector, who were "devastated with a 40 to 50 percent unemployment rate in 1992," experienced relief late this year, mainly due to new shopping mall construction in White Plains, where the Westchester, an 830,000-square-foot mall, is under construction.
And although the unemployment rate for construction workers is still between 25 and 30 percent, Mr. Pepe said that "the outlook is that things will be getting better."
He said a new Federal courthouse in White Plains, a parking garage and new terminal at the Westchester County Airport and a $102 million, 489,000-square-foot processing and distribution center for the United States Postal Service in Harrison will generate yet more jobs for the construction industry this year.
But competition for construction jobs continues to be keen, and contractors from outside the area are bidding hard for the relatively few jobs that are available here. In response, local union leaders are softening demands in their efforts to win jobs for their rank and file, often granting no-strike clauses and other concessions.
 
High Commercial Vacancy Rates
 "Even though there are real signs for the short term, I can't make any projections for the long term," Mr. Pepe said. "A lot of that will depend on the Clinton Administration and whether Congress will find ways to stimulate the economy with infrastructure improvements."
Like other sectors of the economy, the commercial real estate market was also dogged by the slow local economy. Vacancy rates for commercial buildings soared to 26 percent, from 22 percent a year ago, and new building was nonexistent. Employment cutbacks by large corporations played a major role in the high vacancy rates, as some companies sought smaller quarters for their leaner work forces.
But John H. Rostenberg, a principal with the Rostenberg-Doern Company, a corporate real estate broker, said there were signs of life stirring in what until recently appeared to be a moribund sector of the economy.
"We are still putting more space on the market than we are renting," said Mr. Rostenberg, whose company has offices in Purchase and Stamford. "Yet we are hopeful things will be getting better soon. We don't have a crystal ball, but we believe that maybe the worst is finally over."
 
Portfolio Refinanced
 One indicator of a pickup is that owners of corporate properties have recently begun to upgrade industrial parks and the lobbies of major buildings, Mr. Rostenberg said.
"A year ago, these properties needed work," he said. "Now we are seeing the owners repositioning themselves for 1994. It's a sign of optimism."
Mr. Rostenberg also said that the Robert Martin Company, the largest owner of corporate properties in Westchester, was recently able to refinance its portfolio. "It's a bellwether," he said. "The lenders haven't given up on us."
But Kenneth H. Thorn, executive vice president of First Fidelity Bancorp, one of the largest banking operations in Westchester, said that although banks were once again more aggressive about lending, they remained cautious when it came to the commercial real estate market because of corporate restructurings.
Mr. Thorn said that early in the recession, banks "turned inward" to resolve problem loans, but last year they took a more optimistic attitude toward lending, reflecting a general feeling that the economy was rebounding.
Whereas banks were still "pretty cautious and saw real weaknesses in some sectors," they are now "actively courting" loans for multifamily housing, retail space and warehouses, Mr. Thorn said.
 
No Bank Failures in '93
 In 1992, Federal regulators seized three county-based banks; last year, no local lending institution failed, indicating a stronger economic climate. But First Fidelity, which is based in Lawrenceville, N.J., recently acquired the Hawthorne-based Peoples Westchester Savings Bank and Village Bank in Port Chester, and Mr. Thorn said the acquisitions "reflected national trends toward consolidation in banking."
Also, Mr. Thorn said that because of low interest rates, banks had become more interested in the sale of mutual funds and annuities.
The low interest rates, while not generating much activity in traditional passbook savings, did have a salutary effect on the real estate market. Looking back over economic trends in 1993, P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, reported that the real estate market fared very well.
"It was better than a good year for us," said Mr. Mercurio, who predicted that the final tally of single-family home sales for 1993 -- about 6,000 by year's end -- would be the highest since 1988. He added that although single-family home sales dominated the market, sales of condominiums also rebounded.
 
Decreased Inventories
 The uptick in the real estate market was fueled by interest rates that hovered around 7.125 percent for a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, Mr. Mercurio said. Interest rates for adjustable-rate mortgages were even lower.
The median price of a single-family home in Westchester during 1993 was between $275,000 and $300,000, compared with the "go-go years of the mid and late 80's when it was $325,000," he said, adding that the most difficult homes to sell were in the $700,000 to $900,000 range.
Another indicator of strength in the real estate market was that inventories decreased for the first time in four years although the average time that a home stayed on the market from its listing to closing remained at 200 days. In the 1980, that figure was about 150 days.
In another sign of better economic times to come, Westchester last year saw new discount chain stores moving to the county. Among the new discounters catering to budget-conscious shoppers were Pace Membership Warehouse in Elmsford, Bradlees Inc. in Yonkers, T. J. Maxx in Yorktown and Tops Appliance City in Hawthorne.
Also, 34 small- and medium-size companies set up shop in Westchester during 1993 -- among them telecommunications, advertising, marketing, consulting, accounting and service companies, said Ms. Preston of the Department of Commerce and Economic Development.
Despite the gains in some sectors, Ms. Preston described the county's economy as "still bouncing around the bottom."
She said, "We're not sinking any deeper, but we're not making tremendous headway either."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 5; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 910 words

HEADLINE: All the Presidents' Man

BYLINE: By James Chace; James Chace is the Henry Luce Professor in Freedom of Inquiry and Expression at Bard College and the editor of World Policy Journal.

 BODY:

TENSION BETWEEN OPPOSITES
Reflections on the Practice
and Theory of Politics.
By Paul H. Nitze.
Illustrated. 212 pp. New York:
Charles Scribner's Sons.
$22. 
 YOU want Paul Nitze on your side. Inside the Government -- and he has worked for Presidents from Franklin Delano Roosevelt to Ronald Reagan -- he strives to implement the policies of the Administration he is serving, whether Democratic or Republican. Outside, he becomes a deadly critic, a no-holds-barred tough guy who can bring down the foreign policy of the party in power. That is what he did when he helped organize the hawkish Committee on the Present Danger during the Carter years. He warned one and all -- convincingly -- that the United States was entering "a dangerous period of strategic disadvantage vis-a-vis the Soviet Union." Although Mr. Nitze overstated the case, he persuaded enough people of its merits to cast doubts on Jimmy Carter's toughness. He was rewarded by being appointed chief negotiator in arms control talks with the Soviet Union, an important role in the Reagan Administration. Once back in office, he worked with characteristic vigor to help negotiate an agreement banning medium-range missiles.
Now in his 80's, Mr. Nitze, along with Clark Clifford and George F. Kennan, is one of the surviving members of the so-called Old Establishment of Washington insiders. Like so many of the other "Wise Men" who designed American foreign policy in the postwar period, Mr. Nitze came to Washington already a member of an establishment: educated at Hotchkiss and Harvard and married into wealth, he was a banker at the investment house of Dillon, Read & Company. He arrived in the capital in 1940 at the behest of his former boss at the firm, James V. Forrestal, later to become the first Secretary of Defense, to work with him for the Army Chief of Staff, Gen. George C. Marshall, on the draft of the Selective Service Act. "Be in Washington Monday morning. Forrestal," read Mr. Forrestal's telegram to Mr. Nitze. He obeyed, and is there still.
Mr. Nitze's positions in Government are too numerous to list, among the most notable being George F. Kennan's heir as head of the policy planning staff in 1950, when he drafted national security memorandum NSC-68. The call of NSC-68 for a military buildup "to check and roll back the Kremlin's drive for world domination" shaped the cold war world.
Mr. Nitze spent much of the rest of his public life urging this policy upon subsequent administrations, while showing himself willing to negotiate arms control agreements with the men in Moscow. Why, then, did he never attain the higher offices he so craved? In "Tension Between Opposites," an arresting meditation on power, he writes: "In government, I found it hard to be wholly loyal to the principles of either the Democratic Party or the Republican Party. I, therefore, never achieved appointment to the highest political offices." But it was perhaps not so much his principles as his methods that prevented his achieving his goal. Clark Clifford, who headed the Pentagon in the late 60's when Mr. Nitze was Deputy Secretary, recalls that Mr. Nitze was denied the positions of Secretary of Defense and Secretary of State because his "ambition and impatient intellect often manifested themselves in irritable peevishness and flashes of unveiled contempt for people whom he felt did not deserve the high government positions they held."
Mr. Nitze may have permanently read himself out of such a job when he attacked Paul Warnke, his old colleague in the Defense Department in the Johnson years, at Senate confirmation hearings for Mr. Warnke's position as arms control negotiator in the Carter Administration. After characterizing Mr. Warnke's views of foreign policy as "asinine" and "screwball," he replied to a senator who asked him if he thought he was "a better American" than Mr. Warnke by saying, "I really do."
In his new book, Mr. Nitze pays homage by writing flattering and often revealing profiles of many of the men he worked with, almost all quintessential men of action: James V. Forrestal; Will Clayton, a key economic policy maker in the Truman Administration; General Marshall; and Secretaries of State Dean Acheson and George P. Shultz. All, he suggests, derived their energy and accomplishments from "striving for a harmony" in the tension between what needs to be done (theory) and how to do it (practice). He perfectly expresses who he is when he lays out the principles he says one should follow "to become a participant and molder of history -- not merely an object of history." "Strive for both the general and the concrete," he suggests, and have "pride in oneself, in one's background and in one's country."
For all his admiration for men of action, Mr. Nitze reserves his warmest words for George Kennan, with whom he disagreed mightily and publicly over the need to contain the Soviet Union with military power. When he was asked how he could remain Mr. Kennan's devoted friend, he replied that they never had any differences "except on matters of substance."
Like Mr. Kennan, Mr. Nitze would like to see "the creation of a council of state whose task would be confined to telling the country what ought to be done in the long-term interest of the United States. It would then be up to the politicians to see what would be politically possible." But what if the members of the council disagree? We are given no answer.

HEADLINE: Outlook '94;
A Policy Compass Points East and South

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
REMEMBER the G7, the group of major industrialized nations that gathers every year in circumstances of considerable pomp to dream up new inspiration for the world economy? It's now clear that the institution, and the view of the world that went with it, are fast going out of fashion.
The reasons are simple. The bulk of the G7 -- that is Western Europe and Japan -- is in an economic trough deep enough to preclude rapid recovery in 1994 or even 1995. Areas of growth and real economic opportunity increasingly lie in Latin America and Asia outside Japan. 
 The United States, the one major Western nation showing fairly robust growth, has already drawn its conclusions. The Clinton Administration shifted America's traditional foreign policy focus in 1993, southward to Mexico through the North American Free Trade Agreement and eastward to the Pacific through a summit meeting of the 15-nation Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum.
These trends will continue in 1994. They will offer businesses and investors who are not risk-averse, opportunities in Asia, particularly China, and in Latin America; and they will provide cynics with more evidence of the growing supremacy of trade interests in global diplomacy.
One in every six Boeings built is now bought by China: President Clinton will, therefore, probably find a way to renew China's most-favored-nation trading status in June, despite qualms about human rights. Somalia, Bosnia and Haiti do not buy many jets or semiconductors: They will be quietly forgotten if possible.
The policy is known as economic security -- that is harnessing America's diplomacy to the creation of jobs and turning a blind eye to certain wars. It's a significant shift, and the implications are just beginning to unfold.
One is already clear: No major economic or political initiatives are to be expected in Eastern Europe, where fudging will remain the order of the day, as wary eyes are fixed on Russia. That is bad news for Western Europe, still struggling to emerge from recession and desperately needing a spur from its under-developed eastern hinterland.
Growth of no more than 1 percent in Western Europe is to be expected in 1994, and that thanks only to Britain, where growth will reach 2.5 percent. Soaring unemployment and the growing cost of the welfare state seem likely to penalize the rest of Europe. "These are going to be the nasty nineties for Europe," said Christopher Potts, chief economist at Banque Indosuez. "From a European point of view, the United States looks like an economic paradise."
If Europe needs solace for its doldrums, it should look to Japan. The nation that had seemed unstoppable in the late 1980's now looks as vulnerable and unpredictable as its Nikkei stock market index. The price of wild over-confidence in stock market and property speculation is being paid.
Deep adjustments seem necessary. They include some modification of Japanese companies' traditional commitment to lifetime employment and tax cuts to spur consumer spending and perhaps demand for American goods. But these changes will take time. The Paris-based Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development predicts growth of 0.5 percent for Japan in 1994. The yen may have to depreciate to spur a recovery, but that will be resisted in Washington, where the view is that Japan should import more and use a strong yen to do so.
Alan Stoga, the managing director of Kissinger Associates said, "The big risk in the world economy in 1994 is Japan. The machine is no longer working, and its markets look increasingly fragile. A significant collapse cannot be ruled out."
The Asian mantle has been taken up by China, with 1.2 billion potential customers, a double-digit growth rate and a seemingly irrevocable embrace of a market economy that has business people from Detroit to Dusseldorf excited, despite the severe illness of Deng Xiaoping.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany went to Beijing in November and came back with contracts worth $4 billion. In the airline industry alone, China needs 40 aircraft a year for the next two decades: That is manna from heaven for Boeing, Airbus Industrie and McDonnell Douglas.
David D. Glass, president and chief executive of Wal-Mart Stores, foresees the day when Chinese people will feel as at home in Wal-Mart stores as Americans. To realize such ambitions foreign corporations will have to overcome the distrust of outsiders that is deep-rooted in a 4,000-year-old society and still fed by the rhetoric of a closed political system.
Outside China, growth and investment prospects still look strong in the rest of Asia, although after an 80 percent gain in these equity markets in 1993 in dollar terms, some correction may be due.
Similar forces will continue to push money into Latin America, where the economies of Chile, Argentina, Peru and Mexico are beginning to reap the benefits of market reform. Capital flowed out of Latin America in the 1980's, but is now returning. The North American Free Trade Agreement has tied not just Mexico, but by optimistic implication the whole area, to the United States.
"Even after gains of 45 percent in 1993 in dollar terms, the outlook is very attractive, and stocks in Latin America remain cheaper than in Asian markets," said Jay Pelosky, director of Latin American strategy at Morgan Stanley in New York. There are risks, and elections in Brazil and Mexico in 1994, but Chile's elections suggest that market reform can, in the end, be popular.
If, however, Latin American and other emerging markets look too volatile, the United States' economy -- with a predicted 1994 growth rate of over 3 percent -- is worth pondering. Although Wall Street has had a long bull market, growth with low inflation is likely to mean continued low interest rates -- and that's good for shares. "The U.S. is the bright spot in the world economy," said Mr. Potts of Banque Indosuez.
So, President Clinton should be able to hold his head high when he arrives at the G7 summit in Naples in July. If he's ready to take account of economic reality, he might suggest an expansion to a G11 -- adding, say, Mexico, Brazil, China and, to keep President Boris Yeltsin happy, Russia.
What used to be called North-South trade, and might now be better termed inter-developmental symbiosis, has become the crucial issue for growth. The symbiosis is between the cheap labor and fast-growing markets of the "South" and the technology and new job-creating exports of the "North." Such an expansion of the G7 would take account of America's new doctrine of economic security, which entails directing foreign policy less to such traditional partners as NATO and more to the developing nations growing fast enough to create jobs and wealth in America.

HEADLINE: With More Flops Than Hits, No Wonder Hollywood Is Jittery

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD

 BODY:
Forget comedy sequels. Worry about westerns. Focus on hiring A-list movie stars, but only if they play predictable roles: Robin Williams as a nanny, Julia Roberts as a woman on the run, Tom Cruise as a vacuous yuppie lawyer in danger.
With movie studios planning to release at least 150 films in 1994, the economic lessons of 1993 have made Hollywood jittery. The average cost of a film is about $25 million, there were more duds than hits, and some of the biggest studios endured financial flops in a generally bleak year. 
 The good news for Hollywood in 1994 is that on Wall Street, studios are generally deemed valuable properties. The bitter fight over Paramount Communications underlined the value of movie studios. With the advent of more cable television channels, the need for "product" from the studios and independent producers is expected to accelerate.
The bad news for Hollywood is that the films remain, by and large, financially costly and esthetically impoverished.
Even Universal Pictures, which is Japanese-owned and should be swimming in money, faced some disappointments. Universal produced Steven Spielberg's "Jurassic Park," the No. 1 movie of the year and the highest-grossing film in history. It has grossed $350 million in the United States.
Despite that success, Universal is expected to wind up third in market share after Warner Brothers and Buena Vista, the distributing arm of the Walt Disney studios. Details of the market share are incomplete for the entire year, but according to Daily Variety, an industry publication, the market share of Warner Brothers as of mid-December was 18.1 percent, compared with Buena Vista's 16.1 percent and Universal's 13.8 percent. Behind Universal was Columbia Pictures, 20th Century Fox, Paramount and Tristar.
The reason for Universal's third-place finish is a spate of generally dismal films like "Hard Target," "Heart and Souls," "The Real McCoy," and "Judgement Night." (The studio's newest releases, "Schindler's List," and "In the Name of the Father," are critical successes, but they have opened at relatively few theaters and it is too soon to gauge their national box office appeal.)
For 1994, Hollywood executives have come to a none-too-startling conclusion. "It'll be more of the same," said Joe Roth, the former chairman of 20th Century Fox. "There were seven movies in 1993 that did $100 million. Each of them could have been picked by a kid in the fourth grade. There were big stars doing exactly what the audience wanted them to do."
To be specific, there were Steven Spielberg playing with dinosaurs, Harrison Ford in "The Fugitive," Tom Cruise as a lawyer in "The Firm," Clint Eastwood as an aging Secret Service agent in "In the Line of Fire," Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan in the romantic "Sleepless in Seattle," and, according to Mr. Roth and others, Robin Williams in "Mrs. Doubtfire," and Julia Roberts and Denzel Washington in "The Pelican Brief."
The predictions of big hits for 1994 are, well, perfectly predictable. These include two Warner Brothers films, "Maverick," starring Mel Gibson and Jodie Foster, opening in May, and "Wyatt Earp," an epic starring Kevin Costner, Gene Hackman and Dennis Quaid, opening in July.
Yet Warner Brothers and other studios are nervous about the westerns. These films were given the green light after the success in recent years of "Dances with Wolves," and "Unforgiven." This year, however, "Geronimo," produced by Columbia, fared poorly. And Warner Brothers' "A Perfect World" proved disappointing.
Comedy sequels in 1993, such as "Sister Act 2: Back in the Habit," and "Addams Family Values," also did less business than expected. But several sequels have been completed, including Paramount's "Beverly Hills Cop 3," starring Eddie Murphy, Billy Crystal's "City Slickers 2," a Castle Rock-Columbia project opening on Memorial Day. Those two films and Universal's "Flintstones" are due to open around Memorial Day. Other high-profile films that Hollywood executives see as potentially hitting the $100 million mark are Walt Disney's animated "Lion King," opening in June, and a comedy with Julia Roberts and Nick Nolte, "I Love Trouble." Warner Brothers is also releasing "Interview With the Vampire," starring Tom Cruise, at Thanksgiving.
Paramount is making an adaptation of the Tom Clancy novel "Clear and Present Danger," starring Harrison Ford.
Columbia has its early hopes set on two expensive and risky films. The first is James L. Brooks's "I'll Do Anything," and "Wolf," a romantic thriller directed by Mike Nichols and starring Jack Nicholson and Michelle Pfeiffer, which opens in the spring.
And 20th Century Fox is depending on, among others, an action film, "True Lies," starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, who returns to standard action fare, and directed by James Cameron.
For all the predictions, the most common piece of wisdom in Hollywood is the one expressed several years ago by the screenwriter and novelist William Goldman. It is repeated like a mantra this time of year: "No one knows anything."

HEADLINE: Patents

BYLINE: By Sabra Chartrand

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE Patent and Trademark Office will be the focus of a fundamental debate this year, as the Clinton Administration examines the patent system's role in the development of economically competitive technologies.
Right off the bat, the office will tackle a dispute over software patents sparked by the sweepingly broad patent awarded to Compton's New Media for multimedia search systems. So harsh has been the outcry that the Patent Commissioner, Bruce Lehman, has said the award will be re-examined. 
 Debate over "harmonization" of Federal patent law will intensify, too. That dispute centers on whether the United States should modify laws to conform with those in Europe and Japan. Last fall, the agency heard arguments over whether it should abandon its tradition of awarding patents to the first inventor and replace it with a system of issuing a patent to the first person to file a claim. Discussion will also focus on whether the 17-year exclusivity of United States patents should be lengthened and whether patent applications should be published.
This year will probably see a continued decline in the number of United States patents issued to foreign inventors, now that the Japanese seem to be filing fewer applications. Patent experts attribute the falloff to the downturn in Japan's economy.
For several years, foreign inventors were receiving nearly half of all patents issued by the Patent Office. In 1992, the most recent year for which data are available, Japanese inventors continued to lead the way among foreign applicants by receiving 23,000 of 109,000 patents issued. And yet, 54 percent of patents awarded in 1992 went to Americans -- the highest percentage in six years.
Meanwhile, most inventors still wait 18 months on average for a patent -- and no changes are seen to speed up the process. One consolation for the little guy: powerful corporations are forced to cool their heels as long as loners tinkering in their garages.
 
A Paddle-Wheel Airplane
For Travel to the Airport
 The headache of traveling from La Guardia or Kennedy airports into Manhattan might be alleviated someday by an inexpensive air shuttle. An engineer at the Northrop Corporation proposes just such a system for all big airports. His newly patented airplane uses paddle wheels in place of wings to take off and land vertically.
Travelers who live or work in big cities often must drive a half-hour or more to airports outside metropolitan areas. While many major airports have helicopter shuttles, the aircraft can carry so few people that the service is too expensive for the average person.
The "rotorcraft" designed by Heinz A. Gerhardt looks as if someone attached paddle wheels from a Mississippi riverboat to the sides of an airplane fuselage, right where the wings should protrude. But the paddles are actually blades, and a pilot can tilt each one independently to give the aircraft lift, thrust, roll and yaw.
"By the fact that the blades rotate, they develop lift," Mr. Gerhardt said. "By adjusting the pitch of the blades you can achieve lift or thrust or a combination thereof."
The plane has the passenger and cargo capacity of a fixed-wing aircraft with the lift of a helicopter. Mr. Gerhardt said it could travel up to 300 miles per hour, and might be as large as a Boeing 747 jet.
"In principle, there is no limit, but I was thinking in terms of carrying 10 passengers," he added.
Mr. Gerhardt won patent 5,265,827.
 
 
A New Way for Surgeons
To Keep Gloves Sterile
 Health professionals rely on rubber gloves to protect against the spread of disease. Nonsterile gloves are sufficient for most. But surgeons must use sterile gloves, and they often require help to put them on without touching anything. To get around that, an engineer in Medford, L.I., invented a cartridge that allows surgeons to stick a bare hand in and pull a gloved hand out.
Frederick Wood's cartridge is designed to hang on a wall or be mounted onto a cart. Inside the cartridge is another container shaped like a hand. Gloves, fitted one inside the other, are placed inside the hand-shaped container. Each glove has a tab interwoven around its cuff, and between it and the adjacent glove. All the air is removed from inside the hand-shaped container, causing the gloves to be sucked up against one wall.
When a user sticks his hand inside the container, he puts on the innermost glove. He then pulls the tab, breaking the vacuum around that glove and releasing it.
He said his patent also covers a condom applicator. He received patent 5,269,405.
 Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

HEADLINE: In America, an Economic Upswing Cheers the Forecasters

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
To Thomas H. O'Brien, chairman of the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, the proof that business was feeling more bullish about the economy and intended to spend more was unmistakable: a $5 billion surge in the credit lines his bank extended to companies the last three months.
The revival of business borrowing at PNC is just one of many signs the economy, now in its 34th month of stop-and-go expansion, has gotten back on a moderate growth track. Among the other indications: falling joblessness, consumers' improving mood, solid gains in spending on cars and other big-ticket items, rising industrial production and growing order backlogs. 
 "We now have an expansion that's broad and deep enough so that I think we'll now see a sustained period of growth," said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, President Clinton's chief economist.
Growth will probably not stay as strong as the 4 percent to 5 percent rate forecasters expect for the final quarter of 1993. Economists, in an unusually tight consensus, predict growth will average about 3 percent this year.
They say there are too many negatives still facing the economy to make a boom probable: a hefty tax rise, more military cuts, a soggy world economy and a very low household savings rate. The plus is that most economists say they do not detect the kinds of imbalances -- creeping inflation, production bottlenecks or over leveraging -- that could short-circuit the recovery.
"It's the well-rested economy phenomenon," said Laurence H. Meyers, president of Laurence H. Meyers & Associates in St. Louis and winner of the Sterling award for best predictions in 1993. "We saved our strength, and some of it is coming out now."
Moderate growth has its virtues. Forecasters almost uniformly expect inflation to remain well behaved this year, citing an impressive array of forces -- from plenty of capacity to lively productivity growth to a vigilant Federal Reserve -- that are apt to keep it that way. Most see a repeat of last year's rise of about 3 percent in consumer prices. But some forecasters, including Larry Kimbell of the University of California at Los Angeles, think things will be even better than that.
Economists also expect long-term interest rates, which determine the cost of buying a house or investing in new plant and equipment, to remain low by historical standards.
Forecasters say a 3 percent growth rate is sufficiently solid to lift Americans' after-tax income in real terms and to whittle the unemployment rate. If the economy adds two million jobs, as the economists expect, the unemployment rate, now 6.4 percent, should edge down near 6 percent. In effect, that would mean full employment -- or something close to it -- in most states outside California and New York.
Forecasters are rarely right on the money, though the blue-chip consensus only missed by a tenth of a percentage point on growth last year. This year most economists predict that any surprises are likely to be on the upside.
"Since there was such weak economic growth from 1988 to 1992 and such limited job creation, Ms. Tyson said, "there may be a fair amount of pent-up demand," which combined with low rates could lift consumer spending.

HEADLINE: Federated Acquires Stake in Macy In Bold Move Toward Expansion

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM

 BODY:
Federated Department Stores, in a bold move to create the largest department store company in America, announced yesterday that it had bought a stake in a leading rival, R. H. Macy & Company.
If Federated should succeed in taking control of Macy, which some analysts said yesterday that they doubted, it would bring together some of the best-known department stores in the country: Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Burdines of Federated, and Macy's, Bullock's and I. Magnin, owned by Macy. 
 Federated paid $449.3 million for half of a secured claim against Macy -- which is operating under bankruptcy protection -- held by the Prudential Insurance Company of America and has an option to buy the other half. The claim represents $832.5 million, plus interest, that Macy owes to Prudential. Federated, which operates nine department store chains, paid $109.3 million in cash for the stake, with the balance to be paid in three years at a floating interest rate.
 
 
'Very Shrewd Move'
 Should it exercise its option to buy the remainder of Prudential's stake, Federated would become Macy's largest creditor and would have a voice in the outcome of its bankruptcy reorganization. Even with the half it now owns, Federated, which emerged from bankruptcy itself in 1992, is likely to play a far more active role in Macy's bankruptcy proceedings than other creditors have so far.
"It was a very shrewd move on Federated's part," said David H. Ford, an analyst who follows distressed securities at the Delaware Bay Company. "Federated has beneficial ownership of all of the piece they bought, but they didn't have to pay for it all at once."
But Mr. Ford and other bankruptcy experts cautioned yesterday that becoming a creditor, even a large and powerful one, is a far riskier way for Federated to attempt a marriage with Macy than a more conventional merger agreement would be.
"Buying the debt does not guarantee them in any way that they will come out with control in the end," said Robert Miller, the lawyer who represents Macy bondholders. "This is a very curious move on the part of Federated, and I do not have any idea whether it portends favorably or unfavorably for the Macy's case."
 
 
'No Guarantee'
 Allen I. Questrom, the chairman and chief executive of Federated, said in a statement that the company was aware that the attempted merger was contingent upon what happens during Macy's bankruptcy proceedings.
"None know better than we that this will be a challenging process, with no guarantee that we will be successful in accomplishing anything more than having made a sound business investment for Federated and its shareholders," he said. "But if, as we get further into the process, we continue to believe that it will be in everyone's best interests, and if ultimately it can be accomplished, then the end result of a combined Federated and Macy's department store operation will be well worth whatever effort is required."
Federated did not tell Macy of its negotiations with Prudential, which transpired rapidly, until yesterday morning. But Mr. Questrom has told several people that he may be interested in acquiring all or part of Macy. Many in the retail industry said they thought he was particularly interested in Bullock's, which Macy owns and which Mr. Questrom built into one of the leading department store franchises when it was part of the Federated empire.
 
 
Surprise Over Timing
 Myron E. Ullman 3d, the chairman and chief executive of Macy, said Federated's new role as a Macy creditor would have little if any impact on the company. "We're a little surprised about the timing, although not about their interest," he said. "Obviously, the reorganization is going well, and there are reasons for people to be interested."
Analysts applauded Federated's acquisition for its sheer daring, although they were uncertain how it would ultimately shake out. For those who were on the scene in 1988, when Macy tried to buy Federated, the announcement brought an eerie wave of nostalgia. That purchase was thwarted by Robert Campeau, the Canadian real estate developer, who bought Federated and saddled it with the debt that ultimately led to its bankruptcy.
 
 
'Crowning Glory'
 "It's a very bold move on the part of Federated, which I applaud, and if it goes through will be the crowning glory of Allen Questrom's career," said Walter F. Loeb, president of Loeb Associates Inc., a retail consulting firm.
The combination of the two companies, which is contingent on a number of factors including the bankruptcy process, would create a department store behemoth with more than $13 billion in sales and operations in almost all areas of the country. The May Department Stores Company, with $10.5 billion in sales, is currently the largest.
 
 
Number of Ties
 The two retailers already have a number of ties, and a merger would create opportunities for more efficient operation and much greater buying power.
Mr. Ullman used to work for Federated and knows Mr. Questrom and James M. Zimmerman, Federated's president and chief operating officer, well. But those relationships soured over the summer, when Macy hired one of Federated's senior merchants to fill its No. 2 position. Federated already handles Macy's information management systems and data processing under contract.
Federated would benefit from Macy's expertise in product development and its extensive network of contractors overseas. And while there is some overlap between the two companies, the number of places where the two chains have stores in the same malls is not significant, a Federated spokeswoman said.
Macy would benefit from Federated's knowledge of the bankruptcy process and its access to capital.
"A lot of what Questrom is trying to push through at Federated is similar to what's happening at Macy's, too -- the effort to build business at moderate prices, the effort to be strong in home furnishings," said Isaac Lagnado, of Tactical Retail Solutions Inc., a retail consulting and research firm. "It could potentially be, unless egos get in the way, a win-win situation."
A combination of Federated and Macy would also prevent other companies from acquiring all or part of Macy.
"This pre-empts anyone else from buying a piece of Macy and presenting Federated with a different kind of competition," Mr. Loeb said.
But what is puzzling is how Federated expects to translate its stake into control. Macy has several ways to dispense with the claims against it in bankruptcy. Analysts have assumed that the Prudential debt, which is the most senior, would be paid in full, and that Macy could elect to simply pay it off.
 
 
Alliances Needed
 To gain control in the bankruptcy proceeding and insure the completion of the merger attempt it has embarked upon, Federated would have to gain the alliance of other creditors like Fidelity Investments and Trust Company of the West, two big holders of Macy's secured debt. Fidelity and Trust Company are known for buying big enough stakes in bankrupt companies' debt that in alliance they can control the outcome of a reorganization.
Fidelity has already begun taking a more vocal role in Macy's bankruptcy proceedings, and some say it has sought to attract Dillard Department Stores Inc. and other department store chains to take part in Macy.
Daniel Harmetz, who manages the Fidelity fund that owns a chunk of Macy's secured debt, could not be reached last night.
In many cases, Fidelity buys the debt of a company in bankruptcy proceedings in the hope of gaining an equity stake in the company when it emerges from bankruptcy. To receive equity in exchange for the debt it holds, however, it must push the company out of bankruptcy early in the proceedings, before the company has accumulated enough cash and value to pay it off outright. Should Federated ally itself with Fidelity and others to pursue such a strategy, it could win an equity stake in Macy that might help it in its quest to combine.
 
 
'Different Game'
 "Now it's totally a different game," Mr. Ford of Delaware Bay said. "No longer are you talking about people getting equity in Macy's, but instead they'd probably be getting equity in a combined company."
Carol Sanger, a spokeswoman for Federated, emphasized that the company had not acquired its stake with hostile intentions and said repeatedly that Federated would seek to work "cooperatively and constructively" with Macy to combine the companies.
But she also said Federated would seek to work with other creditors as well. "It definitely gives us a great deal of flexibility to work with other creditors, and it does in fact open up a number of possibilities in terms of coming up with a plan of reorganization," Ms. Sanger said. "We think the potential is there for an expedited emergence from Chapter 11 because its something that stands to benefit everyone."

SECTION: Section B; Page 11; Column 4; Cultural Desk

HEADLINE: The Play Is Just Not the Thing

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
When Lynn Redgrave's one-woman show, "Shakespeare for My Father," closed last night at the Helen Hayes Theater, it left only three commercial plays running on Broadway: "Laughter on the 23d Floor," "The Sisters Rosensweig" and the two-part "Angels in America." This might seem a record dearth, but it isn't: last year at this time there were only two nonmusicals, "Conversations With My Father" and "Someone Who'll Watch Over Me." But since seven commercial plays started their runs this fall and only two opened in the fall of 1992, this season's void suggests a far sharper collapse.
Among the failures was Brian Friel's eagerly anticipated "Wonderful Tennessee," which lasted all of one week despite respectful reviews. Its early demise was all the more disappointing in light of Mr. Friel's considerable success with "Dancing at Lughnasa" two seasons ago. Also quick to close were the works of two Pulitzer Prize winners, "Any Given Day," by Frank Gilroy, and the two-part "Kentucky Cycle," by Robert Schenkkan, as well as "The Twilight of the Golds," by Jonathan Tolins, and "Mixed Emotions," by Harold Baer. 
 The straight play was once, of course, the foundation of Broadway. No fewer than 188 were produced during the 1927 season, and 36 opened in a single season as recently as 1980. Last season's tally was 18, though 10 of them were produced by Broadway's nonprofit institutional companies, among them Lincoln Center Theater, Circle in the Square, the National Actors Theater and the Roundabout Theater.
If it were not for these institutions, said the veteran producer Robert Whitehead, "the theater, as a force, would cease to exist."
"I felt a real sense of hope because the volume of commercial plays went up this fall," Mr. Whitehead said. "But the failures certainly have been disconcerting." Not disconcerting enough, though, to deter him from planning to bring Arthur Miller's next play to Broadway in April.
The most serious problem is cost. "The $600,000 play of five years ago now costs $1.2 million," said James B. Freydberg, the lead producer of last season's hit "Fool Moon." "The same production would cost $400,000 off Broadway."
 
'Making It Broadway'
 Even elaborate plays on the scale of "Angels in America" and "The Kentucky Cycle," both of which originated at regional theaters, cost less in the past because the major elements of the production -- actors, director and creative team -- came to Broadway as a package. The trend now, Mr. Freydburg said, "is to enhance them for Broadway: remounting them, recasting them and redoing them. They call it 'making it Broadway.' And that costs a lot of money."
Inflation and the costs of contracts with theatrical unions are frequently given as prime reasons for the escalation of production costs. But not everyone thinks they are the only reasons. "I don't blame the unions," Mr. Freydberg said. "I think it's mismanagement on the part of the producers. They pay everyone too much and don't design the shows specifically to make a weekly profit."
The number of successful plays will not increase, Mr. Freydberg said, until producers are better schooled in the intricacies of production to insure that plays can turn a weekly profit when a show is running at considerably less than capacity. "There are a lot of hobby producers out there, who don't need the money and produce plays as a sideline," he added.
In part, the scarcity of qualified play producers is the result of "a producers' brain drain, because there's no money in it," said Frederick Zollo, one of the producers of "Angels in America." "It's dangerous on Broadway. But in Hollywood, you get paid a producer's fee whether the movie runs or not. So why slave away in New York City for no money?"
In the view of many producers and theater managers, the traditional audience for Broadway plays is declining, although there are no hard statistics. At the same time, the audience for straight plays at institutional theaters has been increasing. George Wachtel, the director of research for the League of American Theaters and Producers, says the audience for straight plays is not declining so much as it is evolving. "They're looking for a more contemporary idiom, so they're finding their way to shows like 'Angels in America' on Broadway or 'Oleanna' off Broadway, plays that more closely reflect the society in which they exist," Mr. Wachtel said.
 
The Flight to Film
 Another factor in the decline of the Broadway play is the flight of talented, committed theater writers to film and television. Even though, as Mr. Zollo said: "In some ways, the talent pool among writers is vastly increased, because we now have women's voices, gay voices, black voices. But they're just not bringing their work to Broadway."
In fact, the trend is in the other direction. When David Mamet was looking for a theater for "Oleanna" last season, Mr. Zollo said, "He was slightly tempted to come to Broadway, but I warned him off it. 'Oleanna' was an intimate two-character play, much better suited for downtown than to a cavernous Broadway theater with a proscenium." The show became a long-running hit at the Orpheum Theater on Second Avenue and made money.
Mr. Freydberg said he never considered bringing David Rabe's new play, "Those the River Keeps," to Broadway because of the cost, and that it would open off Broadway at the Promenade this season. And although Paul Rudnick's "I Hate Hamlet" ran on Broadway in the 1991-92 season, he turned to Off Broadway this year with his successful comedy "Jeffrey."
The producer Arthur Cantor, who has shunned Broadway since 1986, thinks audiences rejected Mr. Tolins's "Twilight of the Golds" because of its troubling theme. The play posited the existence of genetic testing of the unborn for homosexuality and examined its impact on a pregnant wife and her family. "There used to be a niche on Broadway for the interesting topical play on a social issue that provoked debate," Mr. Cantor said. "No more. We'll probably lose writers like him, and themes like this, to Hollywood and to television."
Another inhibiting factor, Mr. Zollo said, is that fewer and fewer tourists want to see straight plays. "They all ask for the big musicals," he said. Indeed, most Broadway shows count on tourists to sustain them during summers and holiday periods.
 
'Special Event Status'
 "Perestroika," the long-awaited second half of "Angels in America," met one of the new requirements for the survival of dramas on Broadway: "You'd better have special-event status or pack your bags," was the way Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, put it.
"The Kentucky Cycle," with its Pulitzer pedigree, multi-generational sweep, double-play length, budget of $2.5 million and cast of 21, qualified on that score. But mixed reviews failed to ignite the kind of excitement that could overcome the daunting barriers of price (a $100 top) and playing time of six hours, which the show's producer, David G. Richenthal, acknowledged were problems from the start.
Reviews that focused on its darker, melancholic scenes may explain why "Any Given Day," Mr. Gilroy's 1993 prequel to his 1964 Pulitzer Prize-winning "Subject Was Roses," failed to attract as much of an audience.
Despite the pessimism of their comments, few theater people expect the straight play to completely disappear. "Broadway will increasingly become a marketing tool; not so much a creative environment, but rather a marketing environment," said Lewis Allen, who intended to bring Sam Shepard's latest play, "Simpatico," to Broadway until the financing dropped out.
Mr. Allen said that producers will still seek out the cachet of a Broadway run to make money from touring and subsidiary rights. Others look with hope to the Broadway Alliance, a coalition of Broadway producers, theater owners and unions that was formed in an effort to reduce theater costs and ticket prices. Hope persists even though the fall season's failures included two alliance productions, "Mixed Emotions" and "Any Given Day." "In lowering the cost of production, the alliance is still the best hope to increase the number of straight plays on Broadway," Mr. Whitehead said.
 
'Between Life and Death'
 Another hope is to increase subsidies for plays in the crucial phase of a theatrical run, before word of mouth attracts an audience. "For 'Fool Moon,' T.D.F. was the difference between life and death," Mr. Freydberg said, referring to the Theater Development Fund, the Manhattan-based nonprofit organization that subsidized the show before and after its opening. The fund doubled its budget to $360,000 this season to support new plays, buying tickets from producers and selling them at a $4 reduction to a mailing list of 90,000 theatergoers.
Other groups, including the American Theater Wing and Early Stages, provide low-cost tickets to schoolchildren, and theater owners participate in such programs as well. Nevertheless, Mr. Zollo said he and other producers believe that "we need a major national program to rebuild theater audiences from the ground up."
"If kids could see plays regularly, from the first grade on," he said, "we could create an entirely new audience, not just for Broadway, but for all theater."

HEADLINE: A Smart Buy, or Too Smart by Half?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
The same kind of huge mistake, made years ago, sent Federated Department Stores and R. H. Macy plummeting toward bankruptcy. But Federated's blunder was much bigger. As a result, it now may be in a position to take control of Macy.
But in arranging the deal that was announced yesterday, in which Federated paid $449.3 million for half a secured claim against Macy, Federated's chairman and chief executive, Allen I. Questrom, may have purchased debt that is too good to enable such a bid to succeed. 
 If much of the above sounds nonsensical, welcome to the wonderful world of bankruptcy -- where it is unclear who owns a company, where the influence of management may be great or insignificant, and where the owner of low-level debt can be the one who winds up in the driver's seat.
 
Who Will Hold What?
 The deal leaves Macy owing Federated about $1 billion. In terms of power, Federated may have miscalculated this time by buying secured mortgage debt. If managers of Macy and lower-level creditors want to do so, they can probably come up with a plan of reorganization that would make the mortgage debt good, either by paying it off or by issuing new securities worth as much as is owed. That would leave Federated with no stock in the reorganized company. In such a case, Federated would show a profit, but have no influence on a post-bankruptcy Macy.
But by jumping into the reorganization with both feet, Federated has become a player, one that might be able to go around management and cut its own deals.
"It gives us the flexibility to work with other creditors and gives us a number of possibilities in formulating a plan of reorganization," said Carol Sanger, a Federated spokeswoman.
A big part of Macy's problems can be traced to the 1988 takeover battle for control of Federated, set off when Robert Campeau, the Canadian real estate speculator, put in a bid for Federated. Macy made its own bid, and the stock price rose and rose. In the end, Macy and the Campeau Corporation cut a deal, giving Federated's two California-based chains, Bullock's and I. Magnin, to Macy -- shortly before a recession started to take hold that was to prove especially bad in California.
The deal was a disaster for all involved. Mr. Campeau turned out to have grossly overpaid, and to not have much idea about how to operate department stores. Federated soon went broke. Macy managed to hang on for several years more before it entered Chapter 11.
Federated is out of bankruptcy now. Macy, having survived longer, is in it and thus potentially vulnerable to a would-be acquirer gaining control by purchasing debt.
In bankruptcy, the goal is to submit a plan to a bankruptcy judge that treats creditors fairly and allows the company to continue operating. If possible, senior and secured creditors are paid or receive new securities that are equal in value to what they were owed.
More junior creditors often end up with stock in a new company, and creditors who rank below them, not to mention existing stockholders, may get little if anything. Management normally submits the plan, but in some circumstances creditors can offer their own plan and get it approved.
Investors seeking to take control of a company that is in bankruptcy proceedings thus strive to buy the securities that will get the new stock. Which securities those are depend on how much the company being reorganized is really worth. Buy too good a security and you may wind up as a continuing creditor. Buy too bad a security and you may get virtually nothing.
An experienced speculator in such securities, who is not involved in Macy and who spoke on condition that he not be identified by name, expressed surprise at Federated's move to buy secured debt, the type most likely to be made whole, and thus not get stock.
"It mystifies me," he said yesterday. "I don't know why you would put that much money into that level, if your objective is to get control of the company." He added that "unless things at Macy are a lot worse than I think they are," the stock is likely to go to more junior creditors.
Of course, that assumes that Mr. Questrom is not able to cut a deal with the junior creditors. With his stake, he can try to block any management plan, although a judge could rule that the plan treats Federated fairly and override any objections. And Mr. Questrom may be able to push Macy to act sooner, a move that some think would benefit secured debt holders at the expense of junior creditors.
In any case, other kinds of debt might have been impossible to acquire in the quantity that would make Federated a player in the Macy transaction. Federated has taken effective control of about $1 billion in debt with a cash outlay of $109.3 million. Conceivably, it could still buy other Macy securities if it felt it needed to do so to put together a deal.
 
A Mortgage Deal
 Under Federated's deal with Prudential Insurance, which held mortgages on 70 of Macy's 110 department-store properties, it agreed to pay $449.3 million for 50 percent of the mortgage with $109.3 million down and the rest due in three years, plus interest. It also has an option to buy the remaining 50 percent of the mortgage for undisclosed terms.
Under that mortgage, Macy owes $832.5 million, plus accrued interest at 12 percent that brings the total to more than $1 billion.
It is possible, of course, that Federated's assertion that it wants to take over Macy is not completely accurate. Assuming that Macy management wants to avoid control by Federated, it becomes all the more important to come up with a plan that makes the debt good, simply because Federated, with stock, is more to be feared than an institutional investor like Prudential would have been.
If so, Federated will wind up with a handsome profit in what could become known as "bankruptcy greenmail."

HEADLINE: '93 Donations Increased For Most Area Charities

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
With some notable exceptions, charities report that they received more donations this holiday season than last, as changes in tax laws and a bullish stock market encouraged end-of-the-year giving.
A large number of organizations in the New York region estimate that contributions will be about 10 percent higher than a year ago. Charities largely credit the increase in donations to a revision in the tax law that allows donors to write off the current market price of a gift -- instead of a lower purchase price -- without increasing their tax liability under the alternative minimum tax law. That way, wealthy donors are not penalized for deducting the full value of assets that have appreciated over time. 
 "The new law should encourage donors to give art works to museums, land to conservation groups and stocks or securities to any number of organizations," said Ann E. Kaplan, a research analyst for the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel.
At least 20 percent of all gifts come at year's end, estimates Brian O'Connell, an analyst of philanthropy trends and the president of the Independent Sector, a coalition of 850 of the nation's leading foundations, corporations and nonprofit associations.
"Contributors tend to be more generous at this season, which is why so many appeals are mailed in December, asking donors for a second or supplemental gift," he said. "People give for all the right reasons -- like wanting to support good causes -- but taxes are a critical consideration, and taxpayers tend to wait until year's end."
A bullish stock market is encouraging gifts of larger value, as people who have seen their stock appreciate are more willing to make donations, fund-raisers say.
"We're seeing more giving from the very wealthy, but also more gifts from those who make contributions under $5,000," said Patricia F. Lewis, president of the National Society of Fund Raising Executives, which represents 15,000 professionals working for charitable organizations.
The Salvation Army's headquarters in Manhattan received a surge of telephone calls from brokers in late December saying the charity was getting electronic transfers of stocks.
"We had about six such calls within 72 hours, and it was a little bright spot for us because donations to the Army's kettles and replies to its direct-mail appeals have been disappointing," said Patricia M. Foster, director of development for the greater New York area.
The campaign of United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York is running slightly ahead of the previous year's drive, said Stephen D. Solender, executive vice president, and gifts of appreciated stock have risen sharply. "We had 186 gifts of stock in 1992 and a hundred more this year. We've received 20 gifts of real estate since July 1, double the number given in 1992."
The Children's Aid Society anticipates that it will raise about $1 million in its current campaign in gifts from individual donors, an increase of 10 percent, said Philip Coltoff, the executive director. The 140-year-old society, which operates in the five boroughs, is one of the country's largest organizations serving children and families. While individual giving has increased, support from foundations and corporations has leveled off, he said.
Other charities have also noticed a decline in corporate support and attribute it to the lingering weakness of the region's economy.
United Ways of Tri-State, which includes 31 local United Ways in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey, has been hit hard by corporate cutbacks because most of its money comes from employee payroll deductions.
"We have pledges of $81.8 million from the 164 companies we cover," $2.9 million less than 1992, said Betty Beene, Tri-State's president.
International Business Machines, which customarily accounts for 10 percent of all giving to Tri-State, reduced its work force by 13,000 employees, causing a loss of $3.8 million in donations from that source alone.
Ms. Beene said that the charges of lavish spending and financial mismanagement on the part of William Aramony, who was the national president then, were "past history" and said the losses were mainly a result of the weak economy.
Contributions this winter to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund reached $2.4 million yesterday, down from $2.5 million a year earlier, said Arthur Gelb, president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the fund.
He said it was too early to estimate final results because the current campaign would continue until the end of February and the drive usually gained momentum in its final weeks. A year ago, more than $4.4 million was raised, the second largest total in the campaign's 82-year history but still 12 percent behind the $5 million collected during 1991-92, a record year.
 
Hospital Nears Record
 The Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, on the other hand, is headed for its best year in its 109-year history, said Mortimer H. Chute Jr., a senior vice president. In 1993, it raised more than $73 million, a 24 percent increase compared with the previous year. The gifts included cash, stocks and securities, and some property.
"These gifts came from donors in the 50 states and 35 countries abroad," he said. "In general, charities are doing better for a variety of reasons. People feel better about the economy. Some charities are doing a better job getting out their message. For example, we're putting renewed emphasis on our advanced cancer research."
The Archdiocese of New York, which includes Catholic Charities, has raised its 1994 fund-raising goal to $10 million for the Cardinal's Appeal, up from $7 million last year, said Joseph G. Zwilling, the director of communication. The Archdiocese said it had exceeded its 1993 goal by more than $1 million.
"A raise to $10 million seems like a large increase, but our experience tells us people will respond more generously when we show them where their money is going," he said. "We are putting 25 percent of our funds into education, for example, and increasing our Inner-City Scholarship Fund."
Columbia University, in the middle of a five-year fund drive, anticipates a 10 percent increase in contributions over the previous year and is receiving many more gifts of appreciated stocks, said Emmett Watson, the director of gift-planning.

HEADLINE: Whether It's Bluejeans or Mini-Motors or Power Plants . . .: Levi Straus;
American Symbol With a Cause

BYLINE: By Michael Janofsky

 BODY:
Think globally . . . Think globally . . . Think globally. This is the corporate executive's mantra for the new year. With the North American Free Trade Agreement in place and a new world trade agreement moving smartly forward, companies are aggressively expanding beyond national borders and innovating at every turn to snare new business. Caterpillar, for example, elbowed Japanese companies aside in China's coal fields by agreeing to establish a parts warehouse and fly in mechanics. In Silicon Valley, Applied Materials came from behind by spending 15 percent of sales each year on research and development. ABB Asea Brown Boveri is consolidating manufacturing and shifting production of components to take advantage of the free trade accord. In Latin America, Bunge & Born is betting that the region's rate of consumption will grow faster than its overall economies. Levi Strauss, long a global visionary, sounds a sobering note. It continues to turn its back on China's vast market for bluejeans because of human rights concerns. Here, then, six companies and their global strategies:
For all the companies that are marketing products globally, few sell items that better represent American culture than Levi Strauss Associates. Not only has the privately held company become the world's largest brand-name apparel manufacturer, its cornerstone product, Levi's, has virtually become the generic name for bluejeans. 
 In markets worldwide, a pair of Levi's has come to represent "freedom, originality, youthfulness and the spirit of America," said David Schmidt, the company's vice president for corporate marketing. That kind of cachet enabled the 140-year-old San Francisco company to generate an average of $2 billion in international sales in 1991 and 1992, the last years for which figures were tabulated. Those figures represent about 40 percent of total sales. Levi Strauss is now in more than 60 countries outside the United States.
But symbols sometimes carry additional responsibilities, and when they fall upon a company with an already strong social conscience, the results can be somewhat surprising for a progrowth business.
For example, in late 1992, amid its global expansion, Levi Strauss decided against establishing a widespread operation in China because of concerns about the lack of human rights in the country.
What that meant was simple: after a nine-month study by a company task force, Levi Strauss chose to forgo the chance to outfit more than a billion people in Levi's jeans in deference to its strong feeling that China had not progressed far enough in improving its record on human rights, never mind if the United States continued to grant China most-favored-nation trading status.
"There are wonderful commercial opportunities in China," Mr. Schmidt said. "But when ethical issues collide with commercial appeal, we try to insure ethics as the trump card. For us, ethical issues precede all others."
Levi Strauss's social conscience grew out of another task force that worked three years ago to develop what the company regards as standard practices for doing business abroad. In essence, they are guidelines that take into account issues like working conditions, the environment and human rights in the host nation. They are considered in all the company's business relationships, from company-owned stores in Europe to new operations in South Korea and Taiwan.
Based on those principles, Levi Strauss also chose not to expand into Myanmar, formerly Burma, in 1992.
"We look upon building and maintaining the brand as critically important," Mr. Schmidt said. "But the brand represents something. We try to make sure it represents something consistent, wherever we are. To do that, we have chosen not to participate in China for now. I can't say the book is closed forever. We would very much like to be in China. We'll just continue to monitor it and hope the human rights condition becomes more favorable." MICHAEL JANOFSKY
