HEADLINE: For the Nations of the Western Hemisphere, Renewed Growth: Latin America;
Strong Growth Draws Investors

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil

 BODY:
In a sluggish world economy, Latin America is expected to maintain its position in 1994 as the fastest-growing region after Southeast Asia.
Building on three years of economic growth of more than 3 percent, Latin America is expected to grow by 3.5 percent this year. 
 The 1980's, Latin America's lost decade, is quickly fading into memory. Foreign debt payments have been rescheduled, easing a crisis. And government privatizations and budget austerity -- except in Brazil -- have reduced the region's inflation rate to 16 percent from 700 percent in 1990. Single-digit inflation is expected this year for several major economies: Argentina, Chile and Mexico.
All this is good news for United States investors and exporters.
So far this decade, 70 percent of all new United States foreign investment has gone to Latin American and the Caribbean, according to the World Bank. Of all international foreign investment in 1993, 60 percent went to China, Malaysia, Thailand, Mexico and Argentina, the bank reported in December.
Latin America has also emerged as the fastest-growing area in the world for American exports. Stock markets in the region were strong last year. Brazil's surged to a record. In Argentina share prices advanced in the last quarter but were still below the peak reached in May 1992.
The United States trade surplus with Latin America should continue in 1994 as many South American economies are expected to grow in the range of 4 percent to 5 percent: Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Peru and Paraguay.
"My concerns are a slowdown of Latin exports and less competitive exchange rates," Sebastian Edwards, the World Bank's chief economist for Latin America, said. "Regional trade has increased dramatically, but demand for Latin products in the industrialized world is not very strong."
Venezuela, the region's nation most dependent on oil exports, is expected to experience low growth and high inflation if oil prices continue to fall, as predicted.
As usual, Latin America's wild card is Brazil, a huge nation that accounts for one-third of the region's economic activity.
Flying in the face of regional trends, Brazil's foundering Government presided over an inflation rate of 2,500 percent in 1993. Despite monthly inflation of 32 percent, Brazil's businesses managed to make the economy grow by about 4 percent in real terms.
But economists predict that growth will slow to 2 percent in 1994. Not only is inflation expected to remain high, but uncertainty over presidential elections in October are keeping investors skittish. In opinion polls, the strongest candidate, Luis Inacio (Lula) da Silva, is a socialist whose Workers' Party is hostile to privatization and cuts in government spending. JAMES BROOKE

HEADLINE: For the Nations of the Western Hemisphere, Renewed Growth: Mexico;
Despite Advances, A Nervous Market

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

DATELINE: Mexico City

 BODY:
Although Mexico's economy enters 1994 with three of the uncertainties of last year behind it, there still is likely to be a great deal of nervousness in the Mexican market next year.
In the space of a few weeks at the end of 1993, the United States approved the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mexico's legislature approved a new foreign investment law, and the ruling party selected as its 1994 presidential candidate -- and overwhelming favorite to win the August 1994 election -- Luis Donaldo Colosio Murrieta, who immediately vowed to continue the economic policies of the current president, Carlos Salinas de Gortari. 
 Foreign investors, especially those in the United States, rejoiced over the enormous impact the three acts would have on the stability and long-term growth of Mexico's economy.
But just beneath the euphoria lie distressing signs that 1994 could be a difficult economic year.
The Mexican economy, which has been dragging, has one foot in a classic recession. Government figures show that Mexico's gross domestic product fell by 1.2 percent during the third quarter of 1993, the biggest drop since President Salinas took office in 1988.
Economists consider two consecutive quarters of decline to be a recession, and there is little hope that the fourth quarter of 1993 will see much improvement.
The Government has plans to stimulate the economy in 1994, an election year. These include spending a $6 billion budget surplus, cutting corporate and individual tax rates, and holding prices on electricity, airport fees and other goods and services that are controlled by the Government.
Economic officials like Undersecretary for Foreign Investment Pedro Noyola, say Mexico would need to match the current $10 billion in foreign investment it received this year to maintain economic stability, but foreign investors are uncertain whether that level can be sustained.
There are some who say that many investments related to the new trade agreement have already been made and that there will not necessarily be a post-agreement boom.
The leading index of the Mexican stock exchange has surged by 40 percent this year, but many bargains that once attracted investors from the United States have disappeared.
During 1994, interest rates on Government treasury notes, called Cetes, are expected to drop, as are domestic interest rates for loans. The biggest question may be what happens to the Mexican peso, which some economists and analysts say is overvalued.
Mr. Colosio has not said how the peso should be handled. The finance minister, Pedro Aspe, is said to support a strong peso, and there is talk that he may be named to head the new independent central bank when the president retires.
Officially, the Government projects 5 percent inflation for 1994 and 3 percent growth in the economy. Inflation in 1993 could end at below 8 percent, and growth about 1 percent, depending on how the last quarter's figures come in. ANTHONY DePALMA

HEADLINE: For the Nations of the Western Hemisphere, Renewed Growth: Canada;
Strong Growth But Weak on Jobs

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

DATELINE: TORONTO

 BODY:
Canada is struggling to get back on its feet economically after heavy-duty structural changes the last half-dozen years, including the painful redirection of resources in response to freer trade, disinflation, new technology and changes in the nation's tax laws.
The convalescence demonstrates how closely linked the patient is to its huge southern neighbor. The economy is growing again but not because of any quickening in the pace of domestic consumption. The engine is exports, chiefly to the United States, which are setting new monthly records. 
 Steel, lumber, automotive parts, lead and zinc and other industrial products are in demand to support the economic expansion in the United States, which takes 80 percent of Canada's exports. In turn, exports are a quarter of Canada's gross domestic product.
Cuts in inflation, now below 2 percent, and gains in productivity in most industries have sharpened competitiveness and led most forecasters to see steady improvement in growth over the next couple of years.
The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the Paris-based agency that periodically rates industrialized countries' economic performance, predicts Canada will outpace every member but Turkey over the next two years, with a 3.7 percent expansion in 1994 and a 4.1 percent gain in 1995 -- up from 2.5 percent in 1993.
Yet because of continued corporate downsizing and increasing use of labor-saving technology, no significant drops are foreseen in unemployment, which has hovered around 11 percent over the past three years.
Many economists believe that growth must climb nearer 5 percent before unemployment starts falling; yet forecasts by the O.E.C.D. and others suggest there is not much chance of this any time soon.
So, while the economy strengthens, the mood here is still morose. "Company downsizing spooks consumer spending," said Ranga Chand, senior economist at Burns Fry Ltd., Canada's leading investment house.
Another problem is the huge Government deficit, forcing interest payments and debt ever higher. The new Liberal Government vows to do something about it, but people will not know what it has up its sleeve until the February budget.
Room for maneuver is relatively tight. The Federal deficit is 6 percent of the gross domestic product, double the 3 percent level in the United States. About 40 percent of Canada's debt is held abroad, meaning that unless a deficit-cutting program has credibility, foreigners are likely to dump Canadian securities and the Canadian dollar, which at around 75 cents to the United States dollar is already near its lowest levels in six years.
The question is whether the Government will cut spending or raise taxes. Either way will be a drag on economic growth, further postponing the end of double-digit joblessness.
On bright spot has been the stock market, which enjoyed a record 1993. The Toronto Stock Exchange 300-share index surged 29 percent to 4321.40, and many analysts foresee further advances of 10 percent to 20 percent this year, given the strength in both the economy and corporate earnings. CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH

HEADLINE: Whether It's Bluejeans or Mini-Motors or Power Plants . . .: Applied Materials;
A Big Comeback In Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Think globally . . . Think globally . . . Think globally. This is the corporate executive's mantra for the new year. With the North American Free Trade Agreement in place and a new world trade agreement moving smartly forward, companies are aggressively expanding beyond national borders and innovating at every turn to snare new business. Caterpillar, for example, elbowed Japanese companies aside in China's coal fields by agreeing to establish a parts warehouse and fly in mechanics. In Silicon Valley, Applied Materials came from behind by spending 15 percent of sales each year on research and development. ABB Asea Brown Boveri is consolidating manufacturing and shifting production of components to take advantage of the free trade accord. In Latin America, Bunge & Born is betting that the region's rate of consumption will grow faster than its overall economies. Levi Strauss, long a global visionary, sounds a sobering note. It continues to turn its back on China's vast market for bluejeans because of human rights concerns. Here, then, six companies and their global strategies:
A decade ago, Silicon Valley semiconductor chip equipment companies said they were being overrun by Japanese competitors. Now, with Japanese high-tech companies in a deep slump, some American manufacturers are again in good shape. Among American revival stories, Applied Materials Inc., since last year the world's largest maker of semiconductor manufacturing equipment, is the most compelling example of a company that has beaten its Japanese competition internationally by relying on traditional Silicon Valley principles. 
 It appears that underlying Applied Materials' remarkable rebound, from $174.5 million in revenue in 1985 to $1.08 billion this year, is a commitment to pushing entrepreneurial rewards deep into the organization.
Applied Materials, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has surpassed Japanese rivals Advantest, Canon, Tokyo Electron and Nikon to take the lead in the industry. The company makes a variety of machines used in manufacturing chips.
Its special expertise is in a class of exotic systems that deposit ultra-thin and ultra-pure materials on silicon wafers. Other machines that Applied Materials makes etch the tiny circuit lines of semiconductors.
Concern that the United States could lose the chip wars led to the creation in 1987 of Sematech, the Government and industry consortium that focused on revitalizing the country's manufacturing expertise.
According to G. Dan Hutcheson, president of VLSI Research, Applied Materials gained its position by focusing on customer satisfaction when the Japanese were becoming complacent and arrogant, by having higher reliability and by spending significantly on research, development and engineering, averaging 15 percent of sales annually.
But there may be a deeper reason for Applied Materials' success. "What's innovative about Applied Materials compared to others is the way in which the structure of the management was altered to drive the business in terms of incentives," Mr. Hutcheson said.
The best traditions of Silicon Valley are based on entrepreneurial engineers who struck out with venture capital to create new technologies and companies. But as companies grew, the incentive structure tended to reward managers, not engineers.
But James C. Morgan, Applied's chairman, created compensation plans that motivated rank-and-file engineers as well as top managers. "By not being greedy at the top, he enabled tremendous success in the organization," Mr. Hutcheson said.
Today, about 55 percent of Applied's sales are international -- mostly in Japan despite sales' recently dipping there because of recession. When the Japanese chip makers begin spending significantly to upgrade their equipment technology, it will only strengthen Applied Materials.
Mr. Morgan, author of the book "Cracking the Japanese Market," set up the company's first Japanese subsidiary in 1979, and in 1992, the Japanese market accounted for 35 percent of the company's sales, among the greatest percentages for any company in the Fortune 500. JOHN MARKOFF

HEADLINE: Whether It's Bluejeans or Mini-Motors or Power Plants . . .: Caterpillar;
Worldwide Watch For Opportunities

BYLINE: By ALISON LEIGH COWAN

 BODY:
Think globally . . . Think globally . . . Think globally. This is the corporate executive's mantra for the new year. With the North American Free Trade Agreement in place and a new world trade agreement moving smartly forward, companies are aggressively expanding beyond national borders and innovating at every turn to snare new business. Caterpillar, for example, elbowed Japanese companies aside in China's coal fields by agreeing to establish a parts warehouse and fly in mechanics. In Silicon Valley, Applied Materials came from behind by spending 15 percent of sales each year on research and development. ABB Asea Brown Boveri is consolidating manufacturing and shifting production of components to take advantage of the free trade accord. In Latin America, Bunge & Born is betting that the region's rate of consumption will grow faster than its overall economies. Levi Strauss, long a global visionary, sounds a sobering note. It continues to turn its back on China's vast market for bluejeans because of human rights concerns. Here, then, six companies and their global strategies:
 To Siegfried R. Ramseyer, crossing borders is second nature. Growing up in Geneva, he never thought twice about choosing say, a French restaurant for dinner -- in France. "They were the best restaurants," said Mr. Ramseyer, who lived half an hour from the French border. 
 Caterpillar Inc., based in Peoria, Ill., is equally adept at going where opportunity beckons. "Wherever we're allowed to do business, we like to do business," said Mr. Ramseyer, vice president of Caterpillar's Asia-Pacific and Latin American division. That included South Africa when such investments were highly unpopular at home, and, Mr. Ramseyer hopes, Vietnam, as the United States eases limits on trading there.
As a result of such perseverance, the roster of competitors has changed markedly. In the 1960's and 1970's, the companies to beat were International Harvester, Euclid and Allis-Chalmers. Today, those American names have been displaced by Komatsu, Hitachi and Kobelco of Japan. "We survived because we always had an international approach," Mr. Ramseyer said.
Doing so much business overseas, means, of course, responding to the vicissitudes of foreign markets with a flexibility that many American managers cannot muster.
Mr. Ramseyer, for example, was expected to toast his new friendship with a Saudi sheik by eating the choicest part of a lamb-and-rice banquet: the sheep's eyes. "You just swallow hard and do it," he said.
The results seem worth the effort. In 1992, Caterpillar exported $3.3 billion -- one-third of its sales -- and imported only $1.4 billion of components and other materials. That trade surplus of $1.9 billion kept 17,000 Caterpillar employees and another 34,000 people who work for Caterpillar's suppliers employed, the company estimates.
These days, Caterpillar sees its biggest opportunities in the Pacific Rim. Growth in that part of the world is expected to increase 6 percent to 14 percent a year, compared with 2.5 percent in the United States, spurring investment in the types of construction equipment that Caterpillar sells.
Even without a dealer network acting as its emissary in China, Caterpillar recently won a $20 million contract to supply 18 190-ton trucks to China's coal fields. It elbowed aside Wabco, a unit of Komatsu, essentially by offering to open a parts warehouse near the coal fields and to fly in enough mechanics to keep the machines humming.
"When you have a new customer like this, they just don't buy the product, they buy the company," Mr. Ramseyer said.
The North American Free Trade Agreement and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade mean that Caterpillar may reassess its strategy of locating plants all over to be near customers and to scale trade barriers. For instance, it still sells enough medium-size, D6 tractors to justify making them in the United States, France and Japan. But a drop in volume and the fall of trade barriers could lead the company to think harder about consolidating production in its two most efficient plants.
Until then, Mr. Ramseyer will urge policy makers to do more for free trade. And he will continue to carry two passports -- a trick he learned while heading Caterpillar's Middle East business -- just in case he finds himself shuttling between hostile countries. ALISON LEIGH COWAN

LENGTH: 493 words

HEADLINE: ...Today's Corporate Game Plans Know No Boundaries: ABB Asea Brown Boveri;
Global Arms, Regional Muscle

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
A lot of companies like to call themselves global. Few can do so with as much justification as ABB Asea Brown Boveri, the Zurich-based industrial giant, which operates 1,300 companies in 140 countries.
Operating worldwide is not a plus by definition. With most big markets in recession for the past two years, profits have stagnated at ABB after doubling from 1988 to 1992. Demand has shrunk in its core business of supplying the electric-power generation and distribution industries. 
 A global reach, however, gives the company a chance to take full advantage of the opportunities created by worldwide political and economic changes. And under its hyperkinetic chief executive, Percy Barnevik, ABB is moving to seize the advantage on on all fronts.
The company has become one of the most active investors in Eastern Europe, taking major stakes in companies in Poland and the Czech Republic and moving more slowly into Russia. It is investing heavily in Asia, which it sees as the fastest-growing market in coming years.
To take advantage of the North American Free Trade Agreement, ABB is consolidating manufacturing operations by moving production of some components from the United States to Canada and others from Canada to the United States, while stepping up efforts to sell them in Mexico.
And it anticipates using the same strategy on a bigger scale now that the protracted negotiations on liberalizing world trade have been completed.
"The more free trade, the better for us," Mr. Barnevik said. "We can optimize our production globally."
ABB already plays to its regional strengths. When it bids to build a power plant in Asia, for example, it may include components manufactured in Poland, where low labor costs allow the company to keep prices low, Mr. Barnevik said.
The trick for ABB as it continues to grow in size and ambition will be to maintain the company's famously strict cost control and ability to run each business unit locally while taking advantage of the economies inherent in its scale.
In August, Mr. Barnevik announced that the company would close 15 plants in Europe and North America at a cost of $500 million. He also reorganized the company's management to pay greater attention to the three main markets: the Americas, Europe and Asia.
And Mr. Barnevik has consolidated industrial products segments to four from six, partly to encourage more cooperation among ABB's far-flung businesses in the growing market for turnkey power plants, which are plants purchased by customers as a complete package rather than component by component.
The biggest change for ABB for this year may be an increasing shift away from the growth through acquisition that characterized its activities in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
"In western Europe and America, we pretty much have the presence we want," Mr. Barnevik said.
"Now it's a matter of reaping the full benefits of what we have." RICHARD W. STEVENSON

HEADLINE: ...Today's Corporate Game Plans Know No Boundaries: Bunge & Born;
More Mindful Of Latin America

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
With low inflation and economic growth proving remarkably enduring in much of Latin America, there are new pressures for consumer manufacturers to pay more attention to their customers.
"Stability has made the consumer much more demanding and given him more time to shop around and make the spending decisions," said Ricardo Esteves, a director of Bunge & Born S.A., South America's largest consumer products company. 
 "During high inflation, the fear was simply to be able to get the products, and you didn't worry about quality or price," he said. "Now the shopper is comparing local goods with imported goods, with other brands. So we have to produce better products at more competitive prices."
Of all of the companies with a finger on the pulse of Latin American consumers, Bunge & Born should have as acute an awareness as any. Known in the United States principally as a grain trader, the privately held conglomerate, with worldwide sales of $20 billion, operates processed-foods, paint, textile and cement operations in Argentina, Brazil, Uruguay, Paraguay, Peru and Venezuela.
After years of accumulating an array of businesses, experiencing deep losses and struggling with a disorderly management structure, the company has forced itself to modernize and become more competitive. Over the last two years, with the help of McKinsey & Company, it has sold a number of businesses and concentrated its expertise on a handful of industries that mainly answer local consumer demands in Latin America. For companies that can increase quality, there should be a payoff. Bunge & Born's research sees consumption growing faster than the overall economy.
That means different things for different parts of the company's business. Although Molinos Rio de la Plata S.A., Bunge & Born's food subsidiary, is the largest food marketer in Argentina, it is trying to improve the image of its cold cuts, mayonnaise and cooking oils and build strong, recognizable brands.
"Before, people would buy whatever pasta was on the shelves, even though they did not know what little company made it," Mr. Esteves said. "But people want to feed themselves better; they are looking for better taste, more purity, as well as a company that will stand behind the product."
With greater spending power, consumers are buying more prepared foods, instead of basic foods like oil and flour, he noted. So the company is moving more into prepared cake mixes to meet that demand.
Another business with great potential for Bunge & Born is paints. With stable prices, Argentina and other countries are beginning to develop long-term consumer credit industries, which should cause an explosion in home mortgages.
Bunge & Born expects that once mortgage credit is more widely available, its Alba S.A. paint subsidiary in Argentina, its Inca S.A. unit in Uruguay and its Pinturas Carol unit in Brazil will take off.
The company is also using advertising to promote more do-it-yourself home painting, which it hopes will increase paint sales even more, without undermining the traditional professional painter.
But Bunge & Born may have to wait longer for a boom in Brazil to develop because the country of 150 million still has high inflation -- more than 1,200 percent in 1993.
"Brazil inevitably will reduce inflation, and once it does, the market will be so explosive you won't be able to meet the demand," Mr. Esteves said. "So we are already preparing for that stage, working on quality." NATHANIEL C. NASH

HEADLINE: ...While a Sluggish Japan Sighs Amid Asia's Roaring Tigers: Southeast Asia;
Dynamic Markets But Growing Pains

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand

 BODY:
Among the dazzling economies of Southeast Asia, what has gone up seems likely to keep going up in 1994.
Southeast Asia remains the most economically dynamic region on earth, and regional forecasts suggest that economic growth will continue to hum along at up to 7 percent next year, much more than double the pace expected in the United States. 
 Even laggards like the Philippines and long-time basket cases like Cambodia and Laos are poised for better growth.
Not only are Southeast Asian nations producing what the industrialized world buys in good times and bad -- shoes, clothes and small electronics -- but they are also creating vast consumer markets.
More than a third of all the goods exported in Southeast Asia finish up in other countries in the region, and the portion keeps growing. Street markets are being replaced by shopping malls.
The key problems of the past generation -- hunger and grinding poverty -- are being replaced in some countries with the problems that come with economic success: pollution and urban congestion. Some of the nations of Southeast Asia have so damaged their environments, in fact, that they risk driving away foreign investors and tourists.
Large multinational companies say that in the last two years it has become difficult to attract talented expatriate workers to Thailand and Indonesia, where boom times have created filthy air and water and round-the-clock traffic jams. Hotels in Bangkok, where tourism is the most important source of hard currency, are empty much of the year.
The most interesting economic news in the new year may come from the nations that have long been burdened with the most backward economies: Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos and Myanmar, formerly known as Burma. To varying degrees, all are giving up central economic planning in favor of free markets.
Despite its atrocious record on human rights, Myanmar, with a population of nearly 60 million and vast natural resources, has suddenly begun to attract significant interest from savvy investors from Singapore, who have set up a new Myanmar airline. Despite growing corruption and a crumbling infrastructure, Vietnam continues to stir up so much enthusiasm among investors that the American trade embargo is increasingly seen as toothless. PHILIP SHENON

HEADLINE: Mr. Giuliani's Dreams

 BODY:
Rudolph Giuliani took office on the steps of City Hall yesterday promising a return to New York City's halcyon days of hope, promise and achievement -- a time that may never have existed quite as he describes it, but has a place in the heart of New York's 107th Mayor, and in the dreams of millions of New Yorkers.
"The era of fear has had a long enough reign," Mr. Giuliani said, with his 7-year-old son, Andrew, standing happily at his side. "The period of doubt has run its course. As of this moment, the expressions of cynicism -- that New York is not governable, New York is not manageable, New York is not worth it -- all of these I declare politically incorrect." 
 Harking back nearly a century, to when his grandfather Rodolfo came to New York in pursuit of a better life, Mr. Giuliani urged New Yorkers to overcome their fears and doubts.
As he did during his campaign, the new Mayor described the New York of today in terms bleaker than reality -- as a city characterized by crime, guns, cynicism and fear. And he described the city of the future as a place of renewal and productivity, celebrated for what has long made New York distinctive, from the theater and great museums to the United Nations.
Mr. Giuliani was short on details, and made only passing reference to the city's looming budget deficit of at least $2.2 billion. Controlling the budget will be a priority, said the new Mayor, along with restoring public safety, improving education, creating jobs and enhancing the quality of life. He offered little insight into how he will address those matters.
But inaugural ceremonies are always long on symbolism and short on substance and the symbolic message of this inauguration was clear. Time and again Mr. Giuliani appealed to New Yorkers (especially secessionist Staten Islanders) to stick around, work hard and put their faith in a change-oriented leader who is the first Republican Mayor in a generation. "Problems are challenges to do better and we will do better," he told his audience.
The spectators at City Hall yesterday provided a marked contrast to the audience assembled four years ago to celebrate the inauguration of David Dinkins, the city's first black Mayor. That jubilant crowd was heavily black and yesterday's included just a smattering of African-Americans. Mr. Giuliani reiterated his commitment to diversity in his speech. But reaching out to blacks disappointed in Mr. Dinkins's defeat is, as a black Giuliani supporter said after the ceremony, something the new Mayor "will have to work on."
It is one of many difficult matters Mr. Giuliani will have to work on as he adjusts to the daunting job of running a complex, often troubled and economically fragile city. Mindful of the problems before him, the new Mayor nonetheless promised that change would bring improvement: "Dream with me," he said, "of a city that can be better than the way it is now."

HEADLINE: Olympic Park Will Give Downtown Atlanta Growth and Jobs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Billy's Olympic Dream Park" (Op-Ed, Dec. 20) by John Huey, on the proposal by Billy Payne to build a $100 million Centennial Olympic Park in Atlanta for the 1996 Olympics: It annoys me as an African-American when white people think they are speaking on my behalf. John Huey makes many of the classic mistakes of which so many pseudoliberals are often guilty, beginning with the presumption that the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games and Billy Payne are racially insensitive. 
 Mr. Huey obviously has no idea what the role of the Olympic Committee is and how it is trying to be responsive to the entire community.
Had he got in touch with our Committee for the Olympic Games, he might have learned that we take our civic responsibility seriously.
We have invested $50 million in building projects that will benefit the predominately African-American Atlanta University Center; initiated a partnership with Clark Atlanta University to train 1,200 Georgia students in broadcast and telecommunications technology; created in the stadium-impacted neighborhoods a jobs-training program that has already graduated and employed 24 residents; employed a diversified work force, which exceeds virtually any corporation of its size and scope in the country, and worked daily with more than a dozen community groups and civic leaders, black and white, to insure that the Olympic experience benefits as many people as possible.
Can the Olympic Committee cure hunger, poverty and homelessness? No. That is the duty and the mission of elected leaders. Our job is to stage the best Olympic Games in history. We believe that the Centennial Olympic Park will not only contribute to that effort, but will also leave behind a lot more than "grass seed for a two-week festival."
What will remain is an economic development opportunity in Atlanta's downtown, which will spur growth and bring jobs to an area that residents, black and white, will be able to reach by public transportation.
Mr. Huey has fallen back on the old stereotype of the big white corporate gorilla sitting on the poor downtrodden colored folks, in this case, a tiresome and inaccurate image.
The Centennial Olympic Park is not about race. It is about change and about the frustration of unrealistic expectations from this giant sports event. The Games will come and go, and like the aftermath of any party, the memories of it will differ, based on what those involved feel they got out of it.
 
LYN MAY
Director of Communications for Operations, Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games
Atlanta, Dec. 23, 1993

HEADLINE: Low Rates May Keep 1994 Bond Sales Sluggish

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasuries were everything in 1993, but in 1994 they won't be. And reversals of that stripe will keep heads spinning and returns down in 1994.
Mortgage-backed securities, which took a beating last year, may be back in vogue, as fewer people refinance higher-rate mortgages. Municipal bonds, underperforming last year because of the oversupply of issues as cities took advantage of low rates, should also shine. And if 1993 was the year of capital gains -- of double-digit total returns -- this will be the year of the coupon -- single-digit payoffs mostly from interest earned. 
 The reason: while long-term rates are likely to stay low, they are not favored to dip below 1993's lows. And that steadiness means less chance for the kind of capital gains that, for example, helped bring returns of over 18 percent on the 30-year bond last year.
"We're trying to lower expectations," said A. Keith Brodkin, the chairman of Massachusetts Financial Services in Boston.
Plunge in Interest Rates
With a new President and a surprisingly weak economy in the first six months, long-term interest rates plunged, propping up the stock and bond markets and giving investors huge capital gains. This decline, beginning in January, gained force in the summer and fall when it appeared that inflation might end the year lower. With slow growth and declining inflation, the yield on the 30-year bond fell to a 25-year low of 5.78 percent in mid-October.
The decline in interest rates produced a record $290 billion of new issues in the tax-exempt municipal bond market as state and local governments rushed to pay off older, higher interest rate borrowings. The junk bond market also thrived, setting its own record of $60 billion in new issues as investors set aside credit concerns to seek higher yields in a low-interest environment.
The scramble for yield will be a prominent theme again this year. With interest rates expected to remain low, picking up higher yields will mean taking on more risk, either by buying securities with longer maturities or by trying corporate or municipal bonds with credit ratings below the top grade or junk bonds below investment grade.
The 1994 outlook hinges on economic growth and inflation in the United States and the performance of the economies in Europe and Asia that market American exports.
If the outlook on moderate growth and inflation here and sluggish growth abroad proves correct, long-term interest rates will bounce around in a narrow range between 6 percent and 7 percent. If inflation, with the help of weak oil prices, surprises and winds up at 2 percent instead of 3 percent, long-term rates could fall below last year's 25-year low. The yield on the 30-year bond finished 1993 at 6.34 percent.
Much of the forecast depends on whether the Federal Reserve raises its short-term interest-rate target, which has been three percent for over a year. Short-term interest rates have already moved higher on this expectation and could continue to rise, depending on the Fed. The six-month Treasury bill finished 1993 with a discount rate of 3.19 percent and a jump of a quarter to half a percentage point is expected.
If traders and investors think the Fed is not being tough enough in fighting inflation, long-term rates could rise. But, if the Fed is decisive and punctures any burst of inflationary worries, as it did with its subtle shift in monetary policy last May, then long-term rates could fall.
In either case, rates are likely to remain low. That means that corporate bonds, which offer higher yields than Treasuries, should be more attractive. Junk bonds should be sought out for their yields -- averaging possibly 9 to 11 percent. And steady economic growth with low interest rates will make some of the below investment grade companies selling junk healthier and eligible for credit upgrades -- adding price increases to yields.
Mortgage-backed securities should rebound this year if long-term interest rates remain stable or inch higher. Last year's rush of home mortgage refinancings, set off by the sharp drop in long-term interest rates, forced the early payoff of many higher interest mortgage-backed securities, undermining their performance. And some refinancing risk will linger this year in the higher yielding mortgage-backed securities because millions of homeowners have yet to take advantage of lower interest rates. So mortgage-backed securities with coupons around 7 percent are safer.
But municipal bonds may be the most attractive, underappreciated play for investors in 1994, even those who are not in the new top tax bracket, which, with the so-called millionaire's surcharge, is 39.6 percent.
The reason is that forecasters are predicting a steep decline in new bond issues because stable interest rates will stifle Government refinancing of higher interest rate debt. The record refinancing last year held down prices by swamping investors. But with projected new issues falling almost 40 percent this year that downward pressure on municipal bond prices will disappear.

HEADLINE: Markets Around the World Set Records in '93

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
From Wall Street to Kuala Lumpur, the world's stock markets finished the year higher, and some reached records on the last day of trading in 1993.
As the world economy rebounded and showed signs of growing stronger in 1994, stocks have gone along for the ride. 
 Foreign stock prices have also been bid higher by U.S. investors scouring the globe for better returns than the 2 or 3 percent offered at the local bank. Americans have also shopped for promising foreign issues because of concerns that the stock markets in the United States are overvalued.
 
Money Flows In
 "With the amount of money flowing in and the small capitalization of foreign markets, it's no surprise they had huge moves," said Michael Metz, investment strategist for Oppenheimer & Co. in New York. "The question for 1994 is: What if those flows don't continue?"
Higher interest rates, which could result from higher inflation, stand to entice many investors to bring their money back home and send a wave of selling rippling around the world, Mr. Metz said.
From Britain to even the long-slumping Japanese market, stocks finished the year higher. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index in London finished Friday 20 percent above the end of 1992 at 3,418.4. In Tokyo, where markets were closed Friday, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 issues had finished at 17,417.24, 2.9 percent higher on the year.
The annual gain for the Nikkei came because of a three-day rally at year's end. If not for the 597-point surge, the index would have finished lower for the year. Japan's worst recession since World War II persisted in the past year, despite Government stimulus efforts worth $174 billion.
Elsewhere, sometimes on little-heard of stock exchanges, markets soared.
In Manila, the composite market index finished the year 150 percent higher, and the index on the Kuala Lumpur stock exchange nearly doubled to finish the year at a record.
As Hong Kong moved another year closer to Chinese rule, its stocks soared to records.

HEADLINE: A High-Technology Outcry Against the U.S. Patent System

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The nation's 203-year-old patent system is on a collision course with new technology.
 Framing a crucial public-policy issue for 1994, a growing number of software publishers and patent experts are calling for fundamental changes in the way the Government assigns ownership to computer hardware and software inventions. Failure to revise the system, these critics say, will stifle creativity in crucial high-technology areas. 
Although many software companies, including the Microsoft Corporation, continue to support the idea of patent protection for original ideas in software and computing, the critics complain that the process too often awards patents in fields already plowed by others. And they fault the Patent and Trademark Office for issuing what patent lawyers call "land mine" awards -- patents that explode onto the scene a decade or more after an established industry has broadly deployed the technology.
 Then there are the absolutists, like the Oracle Corporation, a big software publisher, which argues that patents are totally inappropriate in the computer software industry.
 The issue reached a crisis point last month over the Patent Office's award of a wide-ranging patent to a small San Diego software company, Compton's New Media, a subsidiary of the Chicago-based Tribune Publishing Company. The patent seems to give Compton's control over the most popular techniques for searching for information in multimedia data bases -- software that combines computer information and text with color pictures, compact-disk-quality sound, animation and video clips.
 The award alarmed many industry executives, who said they feared that Compton's had been given a virtual stranglehold over a crucial kind of software that computer, telephone, entertainment, publishing and cable companies are counting on as the basis for a vast new information economy. Compton's created a further stir by indicating it planned to seek royalties from multimedia hardware and software companies.
 Responding to the industry outcry, the Patent Commissioner, Bruce Lehman, took the unusual action in late December of announcing that his office had new information and would re-examine the patent.
 Despite the move, there has been a chorus of calls for fundamentally revamping the patents system, which was originally intended to promote innovative research by protecting inventors and entrepreneurs. But critics now say the system is creating a public-policy contradiction: on one hand, the Clinton Administration is eager to foster competition in telecommunications; on the other, the agency continues to grant 17-year monopolies, just as it did when technologies evolved at century-long intervals.
 "The Patent Office has no sensitivity to its economic impact," said Brian Kahin, director of the intellectual property project for the Interactive Multimedia Association, a trade group representing software developers. "We have the Patent Office regulating from the bottom up by controlling innovation."
 Mr. Lehman, in an interview, defended his office, saying that the Clinton Administration is the first to recognize the relationship between the patent system and economic and technical development. "The patent system has a great influence on the economy and the development of technology," he said. "There has to be a delicate balance between over-protection and under-protection."
 Still, Mr. Lehman conceded that it was impossible to foresee the policy impact of each patent. "We issue 90,000 patents a year, and I'm not able to read every one," he said. "One of the frustrations I have is in the difficulty in identifying policy-oriented and other problem patents."
 Mr. Lehman has announced that his office will hold hearings in Silicon Valley on Jan. 26 and 27, at which software industry executives may air their complaints about the system.
 Software was not even considered a patentable technology until a United States Supreme Court ruling in 1980. That put the Patent Office in the awkward position of having to review filings without having historical data against which to check the originality of the ideas.
 Today, as a result, critics of the patent system argue that there are obvious "bad" software patents, which disregard development work by others that predate the patent applications. But the bigger problem, critics say, involves other patents that are valid under current rules but threaten the development of important new systems.
 A group of leading computer scientists and software developers, for example, is considering a challenge to a longstanding patent held by Stanford University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and two private groups. The patent covers a fundamental approach to encrypting computer data to keep it private. The challengers say the patent is so broad that it is stifling widespread development of new mathematical coding algorithms essential to providing security for electronic communications.
 The industry is also upset by what it refers to as land mine or "submarine" patents -- ones awarded a decade or two after inventors' applications. Roger Billings won a 1987 patent for the concept of "file server" computer networks and Gilbert Hyatt was awarded one in 1990 for the computer-on-a-chip microprocessor that lies at the heart of today's personal computers. Both were issued after thriving industries emerged.
 To many computer scientists, Mr. Billings's claim -- the basis for his suit against one of the nation's largest software publishers, the Novell Corporation -- is an outrage.
 "I've read his patent, and I feel like I've watched the tapes of the Rodney King beating," said Robert Metcalfe, the publisher of the computer newspaper Infoworld and a pioneering computer scientist who invented the modern office network while at Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center. Mr. Metcalfe argues that there are numerous prior examples of the types of networks to which Mr. Billings is claiming exclusivity.
 Several large software companies are questioning whether it is appropriate to continue using a patent system designed in a era before computing and computer networks.
 "The software industry in the United States grew up dramatically and made a lot of millionaires before anyone thought we should patent any of this," said Michael Kurtz, vice president and legal counsel of Oracle, which is based in Redwood Shores, Calif., and is one of the nation's largest software companies.
 Earlier this year Oracle took the unusual step of announcing its opposition to all software patents. The company argued that existing copyright law and available trade-secret protections were better suited to safeguarding new ideas in software.
 "Of course they don't like patents," John Shoch, a venture capitalist at Asset Management in Palo Alto, Calif., said of Oracle. "They built their whole company around ideas that I.B.M. invented but was not able to protect."
 Oracle grew rapidly during the 1980's on the strength of database management software invented at I.B.M. during the 1970's, before software came under patent law.
 To be sure, many large software companies, like I.B.M., support the current patent system. And companies that in the past have not aggressively pursued an intellectual-property business strategy are now building arsenals of patents. But Mr. Kurtz argues that the patent process itself has made it increasingly necessary to build these libraries, and he blames the phenomenon for sapping the software industry of its innovation.
 "When our engineers are helping us write patents, they're not writing software," he said, and filing a single patent can cost $20,000 or more, including lawyers' time. "Companies like Apple, which grew from two guys in a garage," Mr. Kurtz said, "would never have happened if they had to spend a bunch of money on patents."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 3, 1994, Monday

 CORRECTION:
An article on May 19 reported that child welfare and police officials in Chicago had concluded that a group of fourth graders seeking to retaliate against a strict substitute teacher had concocted a tale accusing him of molestation. The article added that parents, unhappy with the conclusion, were threatening to file charges against the teacher, Albert Thompson.
While the article quoted parents and two school officials extensively in support of the children, there was no comment from Mr. Thompson about the findings, or about the parents' threats. The article should have noted that attempts to reach Mr. Thompson through the union were unsuccessful, and that calls to the Albert Thompsons in the Chicago telephone directory failed.
Mr. Thompson has since approached The Times to emphasize his exoneration by all the investigating agencies and his reinstatement as a substitute teacher. "The parents should not have had the last word," he said.
In addition, the article's headline misstated the result of the official exoneration. It did not "fail to end" the case; it failed to silence the debate.

HEADLINE: Stocks Drop Sharply With Mexico Strife

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Mexican stocks fell sharply today after armed peasants began an uprising in southern Mexico.
The IPC index of 36 companies dropped 100.4 points, or 3.86 percent, to close at 2,502.23. It was the biggest one-day drop in four months. 
 Starting on New Year's Day, when the North American Free Trade Agreement took effect, about 600 armed peasants, many of Mayan descent, declared war on the Mexican Government, saying they were fighting for the future of native people. Dozens were killed, and the rebels took over at least four towns, later abandoning three of them, calling for land reform and a new Government.
Some financial analysts, though, said today that the conflict was unlikely to weigh on the market for long. "This gives investors the perfect opportunity to do what people have been expecting -- to take profits," said Geoffrey Dennis, emerging markets research chief at Bear, Stearns.
The Mexican stock market has sharply risen on hopes for economic expansion with application of the North American trade pact.
 
Profit Taking Seen
 Susana Ornelas, an analyst at Baring Research, also called the drop an overdue correction. "This is mostly profit taking on the huge rise in the past two weeks by investors coming back from vacation," she said.
Given the favorable long-term economic prospects in Mexico, some analysts said a market retreat was likely to attract buyers. "We may have a quite significant or quite prolonged move sideways to downward, possibly for a couple of weeks," Mr. Dennis said. "Then you have an enormous buying opportunity."
Ernest Brown, senior economist for Latin America at Morgan Stanley & Company, said the fighting reflected the problem of income distribution in Mexico. He said that one danger would be if, as a result of the uprising, the administration of President Carlos Salinas de Gortari decided to increase spending and created deficits.
American investors also took profits in Mexican stocks trading in the United States. Those declining included the American depository shares of Telefonos de Mexico, down $2, to $65.50, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, and of the glassmaker Vitro,, which lost 50 cents to close at $18.625, also on the Big Board. Three large closed-end funds in Mexican equities fell: the Mexico Fund down $2 to close at $37, the Mexican Equity and Income Fund down $1.625, to $23, and the Emerging Mexico Fund down $2, to $23.75.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Macy's Future
Macy reacted coolly to efforts by Federated to add Macy to its stable of stores. Allen I. Questrom, Federated's chairman, met with Myron E. Ullman 3d, Macy's chairman. But Macy said its plan to emerge from bankruptcy would not be altered by Federated's purchase of some of its debt and its possible new role as the largest Macy creditor. [Page A1.] 
 Federated's attempt to seek a merger with Macy bears the hallmarks of a grand merchant, a marketing wizard and a shrewd strategist -- in short, an Allen I. Questrom. [D4.]
 
The Economy
Consumers, rather than business or government, are fueling economic growth, and most forecasters say their spending should help sustain the economic expansion in 1994. Little has dampened this eagerness in recent months to spend, and retailers are stretching their resources to accommodate the demand. [D1.]
Spending on construction projects rose 1.8 percent in November and the manufacturing sector continued to expand in December, more evidence of a stronger economy. [D3.]
 
Companies
Toys "R" Us said that Christmas sales had exceeded most analysts' expectations and that it was giving more responsibility to two senior executives as part of a long-term succession plan. Charles Lazarus, its 70-year-old founder, remains chairman. [D1.]
General Motors is working to improve efficiency in its parts-making operations, a painful but essential move considered critical to restoring profitability throughout the corporation. [D1.]
Coopers & Lybrand adopted Lotus for its personal computers, a significant endorsement for Notes software. [D5.]
Reynolds Metals will cut aluminum-sheet output, take a fourth-quarter charge and post a yearly loss amid falling demand. [D5.]
The Well, a computer on-line service, is being bought by Bruce Katz, a businessman who already owns half of it. [D5.]
MCI will make a "significant" announcement expected to relate to reports it plans to build local telephone networks. [D6.]
Walgreen reported record first-quarter sales and profits and said it planned to open 175 drugstores in the fiscal year. [D6.]
An 84-year-old grandmother won the right to buy an American Stock Exchange seat over objections by the exchange. [D6.]
Walt Disney's chairman, Michael Eisner, will not get a bonus because of the company's troubles with Euro Disneyland. [D16.]
 
International
On Nafta's first day, there was no surge in shipping activity on the U.S.-Mexico border. With most manufacturers just reopening after the holidays, there was little ready to be shipped. [A6.]
Mexican stocks fell sharply amid a peasant uprising. The Bolsa's 3.86 percent drop was the biggest in four months. [D3.]
 
Markets
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply as the economy's continued firm recovery heightened inflation fears. The Treasury bond yield rose to 6.41 percent, the highest since August. [D1.]
Stocks ended mostly lower as interest rates rose. But the Dow industrials gained 2.51 points to 3,756.60. [D8.]
Orange juice futures jumped 8 percent on forecasts of a freeze in Florida. [D18.] The dollar and gold rose. [D18.]
 
Today's Columns
More companies raised their dividends last month than in any month since 1983, a possible indication of confidence that the higher profits of 1993 will continue. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D1.]
The advertising and media implications of a merger of Macy and Federated would be significant. But the reaction of agency executives was mixed. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Whitman Picks Outsider to Fill Treasurer Post

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
Governor-elect Christine Todd Whitman today picked Brian W. Clymer, a Bush Administration official who mailed in his resume with hundreds of others, as her state treasurer, the post most critical to keeping her campaign promises to shrink state government and cut state income taxes by nearly a third.
Mr. Clymer, 46, is a Pennsylvanian with no ties to New Jersey politics, no friends in the political labyrinths of the statehouse. He is the first of Mrs. Whitman's appointees to come without either years of experience in the state's government or a background of personal and professional kinship with the Governor-elect.
 
Calls Whitman's Plan 'Doable'
 Instead, Mr. Clymer sought the job along with hundreds of other applicants after Mrs. Whitman was elected, and he was selected after a series of interviews, said Carl Golden, Mrs. Whitman's spokesman. Mrs. Whitman said today that she met Mr. Clymer for the first time two weeks ago, and that he was the only person offered the treasurer's job. At Mr. Clymer's first public appearance, Mrs. Whitman reaffirmed her determination to cut the state government and Mr. Clymer several times called the Governor-elect's plan "doable." 
 He joins a cabinet whose appointees have so far come from either within state government, as in the case of Mrs. Whitman's choice for Education Commissioner, Dr. Leo Klagholz, or else as members of Mrs. Whitman's personal and professional circle when she was chairman of the Board of Public Utilities in the administration of Thomas H. Kean, such as Deborah T. Poritz, the nominee for Attorney General, and Lonna R. Hooks, her choice for Secretary of State.
In accomplishing his task for Mrs. Whitman, Mr. Clymer will need the cooperation of legislative Republicans who control the budget-writing committees in both houses, and who have have expressed the worry that budget cuts at the state level may leave them exposed to voter anger at the local level, where dependence on state aid is high.
Today, Mr. Clymer met the Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, for the first time, and the nominee does not have any friends in the legislature who will smooth his way through the budget thicket.
Mr. Clymer will assume primary responsibility for the most politically arduous task facing the Whitman administration, that of cutting income taxes for most taxpayers by 30 percent over three years, while limiting the growth of the state budget to the rate of inflation. Mrs. Whitman has said she would accomplish this without forcing tax increases on local governments, which receive two-thirds of the New Jersey state budget, or forced layoffs of state employees.
Mr. Clymer is currently head of a Media, Pa., transportation engineering company, Railway System Design Inc. From 1989 to 1993 he was the Bush-appointed head of the Federal Urban Mass Transit Administration, dispensing nearly $4 billion a year in aid to the country's 1,100 mass-transit systems.
He has therefore been a more openhanded administrator than a tightfisted one as Mrs. Whitman has commanded him to be, and Mr. Clymer made it clear today that he was aware how his job as the Whitman administration's chief budget, staff and tax cutter would differ from the work he did in Washington.
"I am certainly aware that the closer you get to the taxpayers, the hotter the seat gets," he said at a news conference with the Governor-elect today. "It is always difficult to cut back and to make tough decisions that affect people's lives, but the long and the short of it is that the Governor is committed to making the state government more efficient, we think we can carry out that commitment, and that's what we're going to do."
Assuming he is confirmed, Mr. Clymer will preside over an annual budget of nearly $16 billion that will be burdened with a built-in deficit of upward of $1.5 billion beginning in July. Moreover, income-tax receipts are lagging behind projections made by the administration of Jim Florio, the incumbent Mrs. Whitman defeated.
The transit agency Mr. Clymer headed actually grew slightly during his tenure in Washington, where he was remembered today as an adept fighter for mass-transit aid against White House budget cutters.
When he was asked to weigh the prospect of presiding over a shrinking budget and staff instead of a growing one, Mrs. Whitman stepped to the microphone to make sure everyone understood that it was not just the Treasurer's 5,300 employees, but an entire state government that was going into the shrinker.
"We're looking at not only seeing one department end up smaller than the one he took over, but an entire government," she said. "That is what the commitment is going to be, and we have had no problems so far on agreeing on that as a result."
 
Series of High-Level Jobs
 Mrs. Whitman praised Mr. Clymer's administrative skills and the prospect of marrying his business experience with public service. Before joining the Bush Administration, he held a succession of high-level positions with the Philadelphia area's publicly owned rail and bus commuter system, the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority. He is a certified public accountant.
Mr. Golden, meanwhile, said there was nothing unusual in a governor picking an unfamiliar face to head her cabinet's most critically important department. Half of Mr. Kean's cabinet were strangers to him at the outset of his administration in 1981, said Mr. Golden, who was Mr. Kean's spokesman. Mr. Florio, for his part, reached to Texas and Washington state to fill some cabinet slots.
Throughout his meeting with news organizations today, Mr. Clymer said he believed the Whitman plan is "doable." He said that he has gleaned some ideas from members of the transition staff, and that he has seen some figures on state tax receipts that will be crucial to the success of the new governor's plans. No New Jersey governor since the 1960's, Republican or Democrat, has left office with overall state tax rates lower than when he took office.

HEADLINE: Dow Ekes Out a Slight Rise as Most Stocks Slip

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stocks ended mostly lower in quiet trading yesterday as good news on the economy prompted inflation fears and pushed interest rates higher. Blue-chip issues, however, managed a late advance.
Stocks of smaller companies and technology stocks were among the hardest hit. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.51 points, to 3,756.60. Declining issues outnumbered advances, 1,318 to 902, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Volume on the Big Board totaled 279.3 million shares, up from 171.4 million on New Year's Eve.
Stocks spent much of the session firmly lower, but recovered slightly late in the day, when the Dow skipped to its narrow advance. Oil shares helped buoy blue-chip stocks.
 
Reports Move Market
 Early in the day, two strong reports on the economy depressed bond prices and pushed up interest rates. Bond investors dislike word of strong growth because it brings the threat of inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income investments.
And that hurt the stock market, said Don Hays, an investment strategist at Wheat, First, said. Stocks and bonds have often moved in tandem recently because low interest rates make shares more appealing and cut the cost of money to companies.
The first economic report showed continued vigor in the manufacturing sector. The National Association of Purchasing Management said its December index rose to 57.9 percent from the previous month's reading of 55.7 percent.
A reading above 50 percent is generally indicative of growth in manufacturing.
The Commerce Department said construction spending rose 1.8 percent in November. That was higher than the 1.0 percent advance private economists had forecast.
Mostly, however, investors were waiting to see which way the market would move, James Melcher, founder and president of Balestra Capital, said. "There's always a lot of uncertainty at the beginning of the year," he said.
Among other leading market indicators, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 1.01 points, to 465.44, the New York Stock Exchange's composite index lost 0.81 point, to 258.27, while the Nasdaq index slipped 6.04 points, to 770.76. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index rose 0.09 point, to 477.24.
Concern about inflation pushed gold prices and gold-mining stocks higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery gained $2.80, to $394.70 an ounce. Meanwhile, Sunshine Mining led the Big Board's most-active list, rising 1/2, to 3 1/8, while ASA jumped 3 5/8, to 52 7/8.
 
Oil Stocks Rise
 Oil stocks moved higher after news that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is considering bringing forward its scheduled March 25 meeting. Chevron rose 7/8, to 88, while Exxon gained 5/8, to 63 3/4.
Among other actively traded issues, Federated Department Stores rose 2, to 22 3/4, after the company bought a stake in R. H. Macy & Company for $449.3 million.
American depository receipts for shares in Telefonos de Mexico lost 2, to 65 1/2, on the New York Stock Exchange, amid reports that dozens of people had been killed in a peasant uprising in southern Mexico.
Technology shares led the Nasdaq index lower. Oracle Systems lost 1/4, to 28 1/2. Intel fell 3/4, to 61 1/4; Microsoft dropped1/2, to 80 1/8; Lotus Development shed 1 1/2, to 53 1/2, and Cisco Systems lost 3/8, to 64 1/4.
Shares ended higher abroad, although markets were closed in Tokyo and London. Stocks rose 0.1 percent in Frankfurt and 1.0 percent in Paris.

HEADLINE: Prolonged Lyme Treatments Posing Risks, Experts Warn

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

 BODY:
Almost two decades after Lyme disease was detected in Old Lyme, Conn., health experts and officials are warning that overdiagnosis of the disease and complications from long-term antibiotic treatments may pose as great a danger to public health as the disease itself.
In one instance cited by the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, 14 children had to have their gallbladders removed, and 22 suffered bloodstream infections because of complications from long-term treatment with intravenous antibiotics at the Jersey Shore Medical Center. Though the children's doctor defends their treatment, the centers found no evidence that most of the children had Lyme disease.
 
'Obsessively Diagnosing'
 In another case, a New Jersey doctor's license was suspended for "obsessively diagnosing late-stage Lyme disease" in patients lacking clinical evidence of the disease, falsifying records and collecting fees for referring patients to companies that provide intravenous antibiotics in the home. The Board of Medical Examiners says it is investigating links between other physicians and such companies as well. 
 Diagnosed early, Lyme disease is often remedied by a single course of oral antibiotics. The controversy involves the prolonged use of intravenous antibiotics, sometimes for several years, to treat chronic infections. That use can cost as much as $17,000 a month and has been reported to cause life-threatening complications in some patients.
Health experts in the New York region say overdiagnosis stems largely from the lack of any simple conclusive test for Lyme disease and the lack of agreement over how frequently the infection persists or recurs. For example, in the early stages, only 40 percent of infected patients will show signs of the disease in blood tests.
Another factor, they say, is greed: Some Lyme-disease hot lines refer patients to a network of doctors and clinics that will readily, and often wrongly, diagnose Lyme disease in return for payments from companies that sell in-home treatment.
"The bulk of the evidence suggests that Lyme disease is overdiagnosed and that many of those given the diagnosis do not have the disease and will not benefit from antibiotic treatment," said a committee of medical experts appointed by the New Jersey Health Department after a report last February on problems at the Jersey Shore Medical Center.
While the committee acknowledged that in individual cases, "underdiagnosis can be just as serious a problem as overdiagnosis," it said the greater number of patients risk hazardous side effects of "antibiotics given for a disease they do not have."
The issue has become public and political. On one side are patient advocates, drug companies and a small number of practicing doctors who favor long-term antibiotic treatment for chronic infections. On the other are physicians and research scientists and insurance companies that generally stop paying for intravenous antibiotics after 28 days; all point out the absence of any published research on such treatments.
In New Jersey, a bill requiring insurers to cover intravenous antibiotic treatment of Lyme disease indefinitely passed the State Assembly, despite warnings by the State Health Commissioner that the law would encourage potentially damaging treatment. The bill, which has not reached the Senate, is expected to be reintroduced in amended form next session.
The bacteria that cause Lyme disease are carried by deer ticks that bite humans, leading to a bull's-eye rash and flu-like symptoms, like fatigue and muscle aches. Oral antibiotics usually clear up the infection. Ignored, it can produce cardiac and neurological problems, including facial paralysis, and later, arthritis or inflammation of the brain or nerves. Eventually, some doctors say, the disease can cause permanent tissue damage and weaken the immune system.
Even at this late stage, many doctors stress, the disease can be detected through an examination of spinal fluid and other tests and often can be cured by a month of intravenous antibiotics, and this is the generally recommended approach. Most doctors now say, however, that this treatment may fail in rare instances where Lyme disease has infected the central nervous system.
In 1992, 9,677 cases of Lyme were reported to the Centers for Disease Control, mostly in East Coast states north of Pennsylvania.
 
Near-Fatal Complications
 Dr. Allen C. Steere of Tufts University, who first identified Lyme disease in 1975, wrote recently that more than three quarters of the patients referred to his Lyme Disease Clinic at the New England Medical Center and the majority of 100 patients at a New Jersey Lyme referral center were misdiagnosed and given unnecessary antibiotics.
"Lyme disease has become an overdiagnosed and overtreated illness," he wrote in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
Dr. Gary P. Wormser, director of the Lyme Disease Diagnostic Center at the Westchester County Medical Center, wrote in The Southern Medical Journal about a patient who was convinced he had Lyme disease. He nearly died of complications from intravenous antibiotics, including a sharp drop in white blood cells, ulcers and inflammation of the colon. Later tests showed a brain tumor, Dr. Wormser said in an interview.
The most dramatic misdiagnosis, Federal officials said, was at the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune.
Epidemiologists at the Centers for Disease Control visited the hospital after noticing an unusual number of students in Monmouth and Ocean counties were receiving home instruction. They say they discovered a preponderance of children, most of them girls, in whom Lyme disease had been diagnosed without supporting evidence and who were out of school receiving intravenous antibiotics. State Senator John O. Bennett, visiting the hospital's pediatric unit near that time, said that "every pediatric patient was a Lyme patient."
The Centers for Disease Control's report described the consequences of the doctors' frequent recourse to intravenous antibiotics: 14 gallbladder removals and 29 bloodstream infections in 22 children. Hospital records showed that only 2 to 3 percent of the children under care met the standards of confirmed criteria for Lyme disease, David T. Dennis, the report's author, said in an interview.
Patient advocates and parents of some of the children who lost their gallbladders defended the hospital and criticized the centers. In letters to the Governor's Lyme Disease Advisory Council, an advocacy group for Lyme-disease patients, parents spoke of their children's suffering. They said the hospital's pediatric neurologist had warned that gallstones can be a side effect of ceftriaxone, the intravenous antibiotic that some children took for almost six months.
Lorraine Garvilla, whose daughter Meghan lost her gallbladder, wrote, "The discomfort from the gallbladder surgery was minor compared to what Meghan has suffered from Lyme disease."
 
Defending the Treatment
 The pediatrician, Dr. Dorothy N. Pietrucha, defended the diagnoses and treatment. She said that the documentation of Lyme disease was often in her office records rather than at the hospital, and she said the gallbladder removals and bloodstream infections were not numerous, given the 1,352 treated for Lyme disease during the period reviewed. "I have a lot of patients who have done well with long-term treatment," she said.
And Ken Fordyce, the father and husband of Lyme-disease patients and the chairman of the Governor's Lyme Disease Advisory Council, criticized the Centers for Disease Control's report. Though Dr. Elliott Frank, chief of infectious diseases at the hospital, said he believed the study had followed standard guidelines, Mr. Fordyce called the research "slipshod" and said "the C.D.C. owes the people of New Jersey an apology."
"In most cases, the parents made the decisions and said they were pleased with the quality of care they received," he said.
Dr. Frank said the hospital has begun urging patients to seek second opinions before beginning long-term intravenous treatment.
Health officials are also concerned by what they say is profiteering among certain physicians who may have a financial stake in prescribing home intravenous therapy.
Before his license was suspended in September, Dr. Vithaldis Shah, who has offices in West Milford and Pompton Plains, N.J., received $150 to $175 a week for each patient he referred for treatment to at least five companies that provide in-home treatment, according to the findings of a State Board of Medical Examiners administrative hearing.
Accounts of the 22 cases reviewed at the hearing show repeated instances of falsifying records to make a case for Lyme-disease treatment. They also show instances of diagnosing Lyme disease from symptoms as vague as swollen glands, neck stiffness and fatigue, or headaches and pelvic pain.
 
'Room for Disagreement'
 The board rejected Dr. Shah's contention that he was simply treating patients with a controversial, yet valid, approach to the disease. "Just because we have identified an area of medicine where there is room for disagreement does not mean that all manners of approach are acceptable," it said.
Chris Hyde, a lawyer for Dr. Shah, said the physician was "following an accepted medical school of thought" and planned a "vigorous defense" at his coming trial.
The New Jersey bill would double to 56 days the period insurance companies must pay for the antibiotic treatment. After that, it would require a second opinion to continue treatment. Patient-advocate groups say a new law is needed to stop the financial devastation Lyme patients face because of the cost of home intravenous treatment.
"The insurance companies are making an economic decision," Mr. Fordyce said. "They have rejected IV care beyond 28 days, but they will allow oral care beyond 28 days. Let's get our science straight -- either the bug is eliminated or it's not."
Charles M. Cutler, vice president of medical services for the Prudential Insurance Company, acknowledged that oral antibiotics, more commonly prescribed and inexpensive, tend not to come under the same scrutiny as intravenous medications. He pointed to the absence of published studies showing benefits from the use of long-term antibiotics in large numbers by Lyme patients.
The outgoing New Jersey Health Commissioner, Bruce Siegel, warned that the legislative cure may create new maladies. Dr. Siegel, who has joined the Giuliani administration as head of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, noted the complications of long-term treatment at the Jersey Shore Medical Center. "If we just give it a green light I don't think we're helping anyone," he said.
