HEADLINE: Rates Rise As Inflation Fears Grow

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday and interest rates rose as continuing evidence that the economy was recovering at a firm pace heightened fears of resurgent inflation.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond fell $10 for each $1,000 of face value and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose from 6.34 percent on Friday to 6.41 percent, the highest yield since mid-August. 
 With a crop of recent data indicating that economic growth in the fourth quarter might exceed the 2.9 percent recorded in the third, and that the current inflation rate of about 3 percent might also rise, the bond market has caught a case of the jitters lately. The uncertainty has been heightened by the impending release of significant year-end economic data, including December employment figures on Friday.
 
Market 'Ready to React'
 "After being in the doldrums for a couple of weeks, the market is ready to react to the economic data we get this week," Darwin Beck, an economist with First Boston, said.
He said that the market's expectation was for further signs of economic strength, a possibility that could prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates as a pre-emptive strike against higher inflation.
"The market will be looking for some reaction from the Federal Reserve Bank sooner, rather than later," Mr. Beck said. "However, the Fed will have to have pretty clear evidence on the economy's first-quarter performance before it takes any steps to change monetary policy. And that evidence will not come until late in the first quarter."
Analysts cautioned that yesterday's moves came on a day still affected by slow holiday-related trading. Traders said the selling began when bonds futures broke below a technical support level.
Two reports of economic strength yesterday affected trading. The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its survey of manufacturing activity in December rose for the third straight month. But some market participants had expected a stronger rise, which had weakened Treasury prices before the survey's release.
Prices bounced slightly higher when the weaker-than-expected manufacturing numbers were released, but retreated after the Commerce Department reported that construction spending rose 1.8 percent in November, more than expected.
 
Construction Spending Up Again

 
 Analysts at MMS International noted that the gain in construction spending was the seventh straight advance. They pointed to significant acceleration in both residential and nonresidential spending since the middle of 1993.
The market also came under pressure from the Commodity Research Bureau's report that its daily index of commodity prices continued to tick higher over the last few sessions, aided by hefty gains in precious metals and energy components. Yesterday, gold prices rose $2.80, to $394.70 an ounce, and crude oil for February delivery was up 39 cents, to $14.56 a barrel.
Analysts said data within the purchasing managers' report might provide clues to Friday's employment data. The employment component of the purchasing managers' report rose in December to 49.2 percent from 46.1 percent in November. A reading above 48 percent over time generally translates into a rise in the Government's manufacturing employment data.
Matthew F. Alexy, a Government trading specialist with First Boston, cautioned that yesterday's market might not have provided a true indication of its general direction. He said the activity might be a continuation of last week's selloff and that it came on a day of less than total participation.
"We did not see a significant number of buyers or sellers," he said. "This market is running only on 40 percent power; last week it was 20 percent."
Treasury Auctions
 The weekly Treasury bill auctions of three- and six-month maturities drew decent demand at the average rate of 3.10 percent and 3.29 percent, respectively. The level of noncompetitive bids was slightly better than at recent auctions, at $1.322 billion for the three-month issue and $960 million for the six-month issue.
Analysts said the smaller volume of bills being sold this week, down $800 million from last week, helped demand at the auctions. They also said investors might be taking a defensive posture, buying more short-term maturities and selling long-term issues until the direction of interest rates becomes clearer.

The fringe of what the National Weather Service said was a major winter storm moved into the New York metropolitan region from the south with a mixture of snow and rain. Communities throughout the region were sanding and salting highways as the service predicted a few inches of snow turning to rain along the shore and from six inches to a foot north of the city. HEADLINE: Frustrating Fight for Acceptance;
For Older Job Seekers, a Sad Refrain: 'I'd Love to Hire You, but You Just Won't Fit In'

BYLINE: By ESTHER B. FEIN

 BODY:
Despite a decade-long push by private and government organizations to market older people as reliable and mature workers, advocates for people 55 and older say their efforts have largely failed. They say that employers continue to view age not in terms of experience or stability but as deterioration and staleness.
People who have worked to promote the older labor force say that 10 years ago they were confident that, through intensive public relations and educational efforts, American businesses would recognize and harness what they argued are the skills of older workers. Although it is impossible to tally how much money went toward that end, people who work in the field estimated that tens of millions of dollars were spent nationwide on studies, job fairs, seminars for executives and advertising. 
 Libby Mandel is 69 years old and has been looking for a job for two years. She has taken advantage of many of these programs, going to computer classes, resume writing workshops and job fairs, and thrusting herself forward as an experienced secretary who had, for 25 years, skillfully handled the paper, telephone and student traffic at Seward Park High School in Manhattan.
"These senior programs were all supposed to show people that age doesn't matter," said Mrs. Mandel, in a voice more resigned than hopeful. "But it does. It still does. It's like a handicap. Really."
 
Anger and Frustration
 Now people running these programs, as well as older workers themselves, say they are frustrated and angry at how little headway they have made in changing attitudes and hiring practices.
To be sure, all agree, the recession has not helped. But in many cases, they say, the burden of age in the job market is as profound as those of race and gender.
The Federal Age Discrimination in Employment Act, which was enacted in 1967 and amended several times since, prohibits any form of discrimination in the workplace due to a person's age. The law now eliminates mandatory retirement ages for all but very select positions, including top-level executives.
Employers may not ask a job applicant's age or consider it when making a hiring decision, except where it is a so-called "bona fide occupational qualification." An example of that would be a job like construction, where physical strength is an issue, but even then a fit and robust older worker would be protected. The fact that a job is entry-level or that a company envisions training someone for a longterm career track would be irrelevant to the law.
But it is too often relevant to employers, complain advocates for older workers, although proving age discrimination in employment is very difficult.
People like Mrs. Mandel who have journeyed futilely about the job market say that they can actually feel themselves dissolve from vital individuals into antique stereotypes as they sit before interviewers who, careful not to run afoul of discrimination laws, try surreptitiously to find out applicants' ages and couch their biases in the most deferential terms.
"When I look at myself, I see a funny person basically, a helper; I'm enthusiastic," Mrs. Mandel said. "But when I talk to these recruiters or go on interviews, I know what they see is an old lady. They don't have to see my date of birth. They see the gray hair, they see the wrinkles, and they think, 'Old.' "
The job market, while showing some recent signs of recovery, is still a grim odyssey for most unemployed people, but it is particularly so for older people.
Statistically, the situation for older workers in the New York region is significantly worse than the country as a whole. Nationwide in 1992, about 738,000 people age 55 and older were unemployed and actively looking for jobs, a rise of about 51 percent in five years, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. In the New York area, those ranks swelled nearly 2 1/2 times in the same period -- from 28,000 to 67,000 -- due, in large measure, to the corporate reorganization that took place here in the 1980's and the subsequent recession.
Still, the jobless rate for older workers -- 4.8 percent in the United States and 6.8 percent in the New York region in 1992 -- is lower than that of the general work force. But experts say those figures reflect the stability of workers who have had steady jobs and have not been forced back into the marketplace. The numbers also don't reflect older workers who, put off by dismal prospects, have stopped looking for jobs.
 
'Untapped Resource'
 There are, to be sure, some companies that have responded and have reached out to aging workers. But experts say that the "untapped resource," as one report referred to workers 55 years and older, remains largely that -- untapped.
"I wish I could say that because of all these case studies, companies are running out in droves to hire older workers," said Michael Barth, a labor economist and senior vice president for ICF, a Washington consulting firm that specializes in labor market studies. "But if anything, they are finding more ways to get rid of them and the reason is because there is a lot of pure bias, of behaving toward older workers totally in the context of their age, not their ability."
People 55 and older are increasingly looking for jobs for many reasons. People are living longer and healthier and have a desire and ability to keep active professionally for longer.
In addition, in a period of massive corporate layoffs and downsizing, older workers are frequently induced into taking early retirement, afraid that if they don't accept severance packages one year, they will be let go without any safety net the following year. But the money is usually not enough for them to live on, considering average life expectancy and a troubled economy.
 
Studies Offer Praise
 A variety of studies -- some of which surveyed human resources executives at hundreds of firms, others of which focused on particular companies -- have found that workers age 55 and older are more reliable, have lower rates of absenteeism, higher productivity and were just as easy to retrain as their younger colleagues.
But the prejudices against older workers are so ingrained, people who have studied the issue say, they defy logic and hard data.
"In the beginning, I was more optimistic that if we corrected the stereotype, if we could document productivity, that it would help change attitudes," said Karen Davis, the executive vice president of the Commonwealth Fund, a private foundation based in New York that recently completed a five-year, $4 million study of workers over 55.
"I really thought the reports would have had more of a positive impact. But we are running against the economic trends and some deep-rooted bias. I still think it may turn around, but it's clearly going to be an uphill struggle to make it happen."
At a recent job fair for older workers at the Roosevelt Hotel in Manhattan -- promisingly named "Ability is Ageless" -- participants walked from booth to booth, leaving their resumes with recruiters and commiserating with each other about the indignities of job-hunting at their age.
 
Handling the Age Question
 "I'm ashamed to admit it, but I dye my hair, like a lady, to give myself a more youthful appearance," said one man, a 62-year-old former salesman from Flushing who declined to give his name. "And I wear bright ties. They should think I'm with it, and not stuffy." He fingered a yellow swath of silk with aqua crests and sighed, "So far, it hasn't helped."
Similar laments are repeated at job fairs in other cities and at workshops and training programs designed to make aging workers more competitive. At AgeWorks, a 16-week skills-improvement course run by the New York City Department for the Aging, several women compared euphemisms for "you're too old" that they had encountered in their job quests.
"They say that you're overqualified, even if you're willing to take a lower-level job," said Sara Lerner, a former bookkeeper from Riverdale, who, like many people interviewed, would give her name, but not her age.
"That's the main one they use," said Karen Halpern, who was given early retirement recently from her job at I.B.M.
"There's also, 'I'd love to hire you, but you just won't fit in,' " said Helen Miller, of Ridgewood, Queens, who was candid about her 66 years and is looking for clerical work. "They also get around asking you your age by asking what year you graduated, or asking to see your driver's license."
If they do get hired, many older workers find that it is for a job that is far lower in pay and stature than their previous position.
For 25 years, Cecil Frazier was a chef at the Gloucester House, a pricey midtown restaurant where he was known for his lobster bisque. Now he grills burgers and fries chicken for a T.G.I. Friday's restaurant in Manhattan, and in spite of that drop in status, he is grateful.
Most of the people he worked with before the Gloucester House closed in 1992 are still looking for work, their years of experience proving no lure to potential employers. "They're working 20 years and more and can't get no jobs," said Mr. Frazier, who is 60 and searched nearly a year before finding work. "But the younger guys, now they got the jobs. They've got no experience, but they got the jobs."

 
Signs of Change
 There are some in the field who say they are optimistic that the trend is beginning to turn. But those voices are all but drowned out by the once hopeful -- and now befuddled -- advocates in the field, who say they are at a loss trying to figure out how to translate their information into jobs.
In a study issued last year, the American Association of Retired Persons and the Society for Human Resource Management surveyed about 1,000 managers in a range of businesses and found that even though "workers over the age of 50 are admired for their skills and their work habits" they are nonetheless "underutilized and undervalued."
"Everybody saw them as reliable, like a Saint Bernard," said Dr. Martin Sicker, director of Work Force Programs for A.A.R.P. "They love them, but they won't hire them and we really couldn't get at why. None of the negative stereotypes show up in the answers, but even positive stereotypes cause pigeonholing.
"They use words like 'mature' and 'dependable' but they don't look at individual skills and characters. They lump older workers together in a way that they don't younger ones, and any buzz words set off alarms for me. It does just come down to 'ageism' and we haven't found a way to crack it."

HEADLINE: Rebels Determined 'to Build Socialism' in Mexico

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALTAMIRANO, Mexico, Jan. 3

 BODY:
As Government spotter planes buzzed circles in the gray sky and young policemen shivered in the local jail, soldiers of the peasant army that captured Altamirano and three other towns on Saturday morning swarmed over the squat concrete town hall today, smashing it apart with sledgehammers.
"The orders we have are to knock it down," said a leader of the rebels holding this rural town in southern Mexico, a thin 20-year-old who identified himself only as Jesus. "Our thinking is that we have to build socialism." 
 That the cold war had ended seemed to mean nothing to the hundreds of insurgents who stunned their countrymen Saturday by announcing themselves as the Zapatista Army of National Liberation and declaring war on the Government. The struggle they describe is the timeless one of poor Indians against "the rich," the new world they envision being one where things would simply be better.
 
Confusion Replaces Muscle
 Government forces appeared mostly to avoid any offensive against the rebels today after at least 84 people were reported killed in the seizures of the four towns and the fighting that ensued as the rebels retreated from three of them -- Las Margaritas, Ocosingo and San Cristobal de las Casas -- on Sunday.
The guerrillas' military weakness was obvious today along a 30-mile stretch of rural highway that remained more or less under their control. From quiet conversations with townspeople and villagers, the rebels' sway seemed a product less of any considered support than of confusion and fear.
Yet the mere sight of scores of Indian men and women, staked out along the road with assault rifles, was a remarkable measure of the despair that has taken root in this land since Spaniards began to conquer the Maya almost five centuries ago.
"There is no longer any way to survive the situation in Mexico," said Jesus, who described himself as the child of poor peasants from another part of Chiapas state, near the border with Guatemala.
 
'This Is Where We Live'
 "There is no work, no land, no education," Jesus said. "There is no way to change that in elections," he added, echoing the proclamations of his superiors without seeming to mimic them. "This is not going to be a war of two or three years. This could be a war of 25 or 30 years."
When a reporter asked the dozen men clustered around Jesus whether they were prepared for such a sacrifice, no one spoke up. Asked whether they wanted to go home, one said, "This is where we live."
Physically beautiful and dismally poor, Chiapas is known for the lush jungle ruins left by the Maya, the Baroque colonial churches left by the Spaniards and the deep inequities that have prevailed since the cultures met.
 
Near Servitude
 Even after the 1910 revolution, the Indians often continued to live in almost feudal servitude to the landowners. The state's riches, from pine forests and tropical farmlands to vast cattle ranches, were controlled by a small clique of European and mixed blood.
The Indians were controlled politically by village bosses, called caciques, who were fully integrated into the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has governed Mexico for 65 years.
It has since become a standard photo opportunity for candidates and Presidents of the governing party to appear in the brilliantly colored ponchos that Indians in many villages still wear over their jeans or skirts.
But even as President after President have declared their deep commitments to the Indians, the social and economic problems have eased only somewhat, and fights over scarce arable land have kept poor peasants and farmers in perpetual conflict, often with the Catholic Church and the Government as their respective proxies.
Chiapas ranks last among Mexican states in households with electricity (66.9 percent), last in the number of children under 14 who attend school (71.3 percent) and last in the number of people over 14 who can read (69.6 percent). It is fourth from the bottom in the percentage of households with access to sewers (41.2 percent) or running water (58.4 percent).
The state has also consistently earned one of the country's worst records of human rights abuse, and advocates for the Indians, most notably the outspoken Bishop of San Cristobal, Samuel Ruiz, have accused the Government frequently of torture. Such assertions emerged again last April after hundreds of soldiers swept through Indian villages seeking the killers of two officers, touching off initial rumors of guerrilla activity.
In an interview in San Cristobal, Bishop Ruiz's spokesman, the Rev. Gonzalo Ituarte, said the poverty and political domination of Indians had eased in recent years. But he argued that the situation had also grown more volatile as a new concentration of the region's wealth grew more apparent.
 
In Rebellion Since 1712
 "Any Indian who has a tiny little hovel and one change of clothes comes to the city now and sees new cars and beautiful hotels and all of these fine things, and they are not insensitive to that," Father Ituarte said. "The control of the caciques has been reduced. The big landholdings have been reduced. The problem is, these things continue to exist at the door of the 21st century."
Periodic rebellions date to 1712, when Tzeltal Indians rose up after being forced to pay taxes to build a church and hospital in San Cristobal. But despite some rumors earlier this year of guerrilla activity in the sparsely populated pine forests around Ocosingo, another of the towns seized by the Zapatista army, the new war seemed unfathomable even for many of the people who found themselves surrounded by the rebels today.
"Look at this," said Francisco Gomez Sanchez, 53, a teacher in the farming town of Oxchuc, sweeping his hand toward a spontaneous gathering of hundreds of townspeople who seemed to have been stranded by the fighting. "There are no big landholders here, no rich people. How do you explain that they burned down the town hall?"
In their proclamation of war, the Zapatista army, named for the peasant hero of the 1910 Revolution, Emiliano Zapata, offered any number of reasons.
Their struggle, they wrote, was "for work, land, housing, food, health care, education, independence, freedom, democracy, justice and peace." They also decried environmental degradation and the North American Free Trade Agreement, which they called a "death sentence" for Indians handed down by President Carlos Salinas de Gortari.
 
'The People Must Rule'
 A 20-year-old rebel leader who gave his nom de guerre as Eliseo said the goals could only be achieved by the fall of Mr. Salinas and his party. "The people must rule Mexico," he said.
Another guerrilla, in a ski mask, with a semi-automatic rifle and a walkie-talkie, who would identify himself only as a 28-year-old captain, insisted vehemently that the rebels had received no outside support, as some Government officials have suggested, but were fighting "for socialism like the Cubans have, but better."
Some peasants, like Romeo Jimenez, said the act of rebellion was enough to bring their sympathy.
"We Indians are the conquered ones," said Mr. Jimenez, 32, a farmer in San Cristobal. "The Government always says they will help us, and they never pay attention. We don't know those men," he said of the rebels. "But we understand them."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
U.S. Says Americans Safe
 WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (Reuters) -- The United States Ambassador to Mexico has sent five aides to southern Mexico to assess the situation, the State Department said today.
"We understand that all Americans who have wanted to leave that area have been able to do so recently, and we have had some direct contact with American citizens who indicate that they are safe," said the State Department spokesman, Michael McCurry.

HEADLINE: Free Trade Era Begins, Uneventfully, at Border

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTAY MESA, Calif., Jan. 3

 BODY:
He was only dimly aware of it, but Tomas Estrada helped make trade history this morning.
The young truck driver from Tijuana, Mexico, wheeled up to the United States Customs dock here with a white truck filled with 6,368 women's blouses, 1,657 pants, 3,910 shorts and 3,974 girls' head bands -- all assembled in Mexico and destined for Los Angeles. They were among the first cargoes of merchandise to enter the United States at reduced tariffs under the North American Free Trade Agreement. 
 But for Mr. Estrada and many others whose livelihood is rooted in border traffic and commerce, this day was not notably different than any other, and if anyone expected a rush to take advantage of the new, lowered duties, that did not happen.
With most manufacturers just reopening after the holidays, there was little ready to be shipped. And experts predicted that the free-trade accord would not produce sudden changes. Trade was liberalized over the last six years, and red tape already was reduced by other means, said Liliana Ferrer, consul for economic affairs and special assistant to the Consul General of Mexico in Los Angeles.
 
A Slow Day
 The port of entry here, on a sunny, dusty mesa 23 miles east of San Diego, is normally the second-busiest commercial port of entry on the Mexican border, after Laredo, Tex. An average of 1,033 trucks from Mexico enter it daily, laden with vegetables, textiles and electronic products made or assembled in Mexico, often from American components. And it was equally slow today eight miles west, at the border crossing between San Ysidro, Calif., and Tijuana, the Mexican port of entry for exports from the United States, where 1,100 trucks a day normally cross.
Nonetheless, this first business day after the agreement formally took effect on Jan. 1 marked a milestone for relations between the United States and Mexico. Though critics say the agreement will destroy American jobs and the environment, backers hail it as a great experiment that will prove an economic boon for Mexico, the United States and Canada.
The warming of trade relations is welcomed on both sides of the border, though tensions remain high over the current crackdown by the United States on illegal immigration.
Even as trade barriers came down, American authorities were continuing to raise barriers against illegal aliens along the Mexican border from Texas to California. In the last few months, American workers have been erecting a 10-foot-high iron border fence north of Tijuana that will stretch 14 miles inland from Imperial Beach, south of San Diego. They are also installing steel pilings 340 feet into the Pacific Ocean to thwart illegal immigrants arriving by boat.
 
The Proponents' Hope
 In retaliation for these actions and for what they call immigrant bashing by politicians in California, Mexican groups in Tijuana organized a boycott of businesses on the American side during the weekend of Nov. 20-21. That caused a drop of 7 percent in legal border crossings and several million dollars in lost business in San Diego, Chula Vista and other American cities where shopkeepers depend heavily on customers from south of the border.
The hope of backers of the trade accord in both countries is that it will create enough jobs in Mexico, which has large areas of high unemployment, to reduce pressures to emigrate. Jorge Bustamante, president of the Colegio de la Frontera Norte in Tijuana, estimated that illegal emigration to the United States would be reduced by 15 to 25 percent after the trade pact has been in force for five years.
Under the trade agreement, Mexican tariffs, which have ranged from about 5 to 20 percent on 4,500 American-made goods like computers and telecommunications equipment, are eliminated immediately; others are to be reduced gradually until nearly all trade barriers come down by the year 2004. Similarly, the lower American duties on Mexican goods like textiles and apparel are to be cut or eliminated.
Rudy M. Camacho, the district director for United States Customs in San Diego, said that even without the trade agreement, Mexican-American trade in the last six to eight years grew 5 to 7 percent a year. That is expected to increase, and Customs is building a large truck-inspection station here.
The trade agreement means no relaxation of Customs inspections, either entering or leaving the United States, Mr. Camacho said, to deter the use of commercial imports to conceal drugs and exports to conceal protected high-tech goods and large amounts of currency.
 
Searching for Contraband
 Inspectors made Mr. Estrada, the Mexican truck driver, go through the arduous process of unloading his entire shipment of women's clothing from their racks and spreading them on a loading dock -- not so much to count the goods for duty purposes as to see if anything was concealed in the load.
The inspectors could not say what duty would be levied on Mr. Estrada's cargo because the duty is not calculated until 10 days later by customs accountants; the shipper is then billed.
One way life may change for Mr. Estrada and other truckers on both sides of the border is that with proper paperwork they will now be able to drive deeper into each other's countries; previously, they had to unload their cargoes near the border for transfer to a domestic carrier.
There was also confusion among those wanting to ship to Mexico. In a small, trailer-like hut in San Ysidro, where trucks bound for Mexico pass through a small opening in the high metal fence that marks the border, Jorge Lopez, who works for the T. J. Serrano customs brokerage firm, sat at a cluttered desk and pondered hundreds of pages of rules that he had just received from Mexico City. Mr. Lopez helps Mexican buyers of American goods cut through the red tape.
"There's a lot of confusion," he said, slapping his forehead in dismay. "They don't know nothing on the Mexican side." What would be the effect of the trade pact on imports into Mexico? "Everybody is waiting," he said. "It's too soon to know."

It was one of the first cargoes of merchandise to enter at reduced tariffs under the North American Free Trade Agreement. (Lee Dodds for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Says Deal With North Korea On Atomic Site Inspections Is Near

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3

 BODY:
American officials said today that the United States was close to reaching a deal that would allow international monitors to inspect seven nuclear sites in North Korea and end a tense standoff.
Building on progress made in talks last week, the two sides may complete an agreement by the end of this week if North Korea and the International Atomic Energy Agency settle a few remaining details, said a State Department official who insisted on anonymity. 
 American officials said the two sides still had to work out the inspection procedures. In addition, the officials said Washington wanted North Korea to resume a dialogue with South Korea and wanted the two Governments to exchange envoys, with the goal of insuring that the Korean peninsula remained free of nuclear weapons.
 
'Hopefully Soon'
 At a White House news briefing, Dee Dee Myers, the President's spokeswoman, declined to say whether an agreement was possible this week. "I would be very reluctant to set any kind of deadline on that," she said. "We're making progress, and we'll have an announcement when we have an announcement, hopefully soon."
If North Korea meets Washington's demands, then the United States in return will suspend a joint military exercise that is intended to reinforce South Korea's defenses.
In addition to demanding the one-time inspection of the seven sites, the international atomic agency and the United States are eager for North Korea to agree to let the agency's cameras continuously monitor North Korea's nuclear sites.
Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman, said at a daily briefing today that "we do expect to have contacts in coming days," and that "there may be more to say somewhat shortly on the subject."
An agreement would be expected to lead to high-level talks in which American officials would press the North Koreans to let international inspectors visit two nuclear waste sites that are off limits to the International Atomic Energy Agency. Those two sites, which are not among the seven under negotiation, could furnish evidence of how much weapons-grade nuclear material North Korea has.
 
Improved Ties Possible
 Washington has proffered improved political and economic ties if North Korea consents to such inspections.
The dispute has divided American officials: the Central Intelligence Agency has concluded that North Korea has probably developed one or more bombs, while State Department intelligence experts are not convinced.
Last March, North Korea said it would withdraw from the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons. This made American officials worry that North Korea might rush ahead with building nuclear warheads.
One of the sticking points in the dispute is that the United States wants the inspections to be carried out under the aegis of the treaty, but North Korea, insisting that it has withdrawn from the treaty, is demanding that any inspections be performed ad hoc and outside the treaty.
 On Saturday, optimism about an accord increased when North Korea's leader, Kim Il Sung, said Pyongyang and Washington had agreed to a joint statement, which he said indicated that the dispute might be "settled fairly."

HEADLINE: New Haven Mayor Pushes Property-Tax Issue

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Jan. 2

 BODY:
John DeStefano admits to having had qualms about campaigning for mayor last fall on a promise to sue the state.
He would sue, he told voters in New Haven, one of the nation's poorest cities, to overturn the property-tax system that pays for local government in Connecticut. The system, he said, unfairly saddled the city with high taxes that were driving jobs and the middle class to the suburbs. 
 "My initial concern was 'Would it be perceived as pandering to people's miseries in the city by blaming someone else?' " he said.
But now that Mr. DeStefano has taken office, his doubts seem gone. He has become a leading spokesman for a growing number of people who believe Connecticut's reliance on the property tax is harming not just the state's cities, but its entire economy. They are pushing the General Assembly toward a debate on the property tax -- how to make it fairer, how to lighten it for everyone.
Other mayors, legislators, business organizations and municipal lobbying groups are all calling for changes in the local tax that generates nearly 30 percent of all tax revenue in Connecticut. That is more than the state's income tax and sales tax combined and 50 percent more than the national average.
 
Regional Solutions
 "The re-examination of the property tax will take place," said Nicholas Carbone, a former Hartford deputy mayor who heads a state-sponsored institute studying the issue. "The outcome of that is much harder to predict."
Revising the property tax could prove even more controversial than Connecticut's income tax, enacted despite a public uproar three years ago. 
The debate is likely to focus on regional and statewide solutions in a state with no county government, where cities and suburbs often view each other with suspicion. And it would also mean examining how the overall tax burden should be redistributed, when nearly everyone already complains that taxes are too high.
Mr. DeStefano says he would support a statewide property tax, which would equalize the tax among all communities, or regional plans that would share among several communities the tax revenue from new development in all.
 
No Legal Precedent
 Officials in many suburbs have vowed to fight plans that would add any part of their residents' property taxes to the income tax and sales tax they already send to Hartford, for redistribution as aid to the state's cities.
Even filing a lawsuit as a catalyst for serious discussion is daunting. While many courts have overturned property taxes in cases challenging the fairness of a state's school-financing system, the lawyers putting together the New Haven suit say they have no precedent for a case attacking the fundamental fairness of a state's reliance on the local tax.
The state government is also limited in what it can afford in terms of tax relief. "The administration is examining a number of different approaches to the question of how to restructure the property-tax system," said Avice Meehan, spokeswoman for Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. "Having said that, no one believes there is the financial wherewithal to undertake any major overhaul."
Experts like Mr. Carbone, who heads the Connecticut Institute for Municipal Studies, say the need for change is driven by the collapse of the Northeast's real-estate market in the late 1980's. The property tax's burden has increasingly shifted to homeowners as commercial construction has halted and as the value of office buildings and other commercial property has fallen.
"Property wealth is rapidly dissipating in Connecticut," Mr. Carbone said. "To have the major source of revenue be the property tax is insane when it's in a state of deterioration."
In New Haven, Mr. DeStefano announced last May that he was preparing a suit to challenge the property tax on the ground that it violated the principle of equal protection under the law. New Haven's municipal services and tax-exempt universities, hospitals and public housing projects serve the entire region, he said, but the reliance on local property taxes make the city's tax rate two to three times as high as its suburbs'.
Mr. DeStefano, a 38-year-old New Haven native who has spent most of his career in city government, has since developed an analysis of the property tax's failings that extends beyond his city to the economic welfare of the metropolitan region and the state. More equitable tax rates, he said, would make the state more competitive and would attract more jobs for everyone.
"This isn't about compensating New Haven at the expense of other towns," he said, perched in a chair in the office on Whalley Avenue where he was piecing together his new administration. "It doesn't have to be a zero-sum game where someone is going to benefit at the expense of somebody else."
His starting point, however, remains the starkly different tax rates among the state's cities and suburbs. In New Haven, the annual tax on a home with a market value of $150,000 is $3,570, while in neighboring North Haven the tax is $2,295.
The owner of a new $15,000 car would pay a $642 tax on it in New Haven, $241 in North Haven. A business with $1 million worth of computers would pay a $42,800 tax on them in New Haven, but only $16,100 in North Haven.
Those differences, Mr. DeStefano said, contribute to the growing segregation and poverty of cities by giving employers and the middle class an incentive to leave. But as the deterioration of cities threatens the vitality of the regions around them, he said, Connecticut will become less able to compete with other parts of the country unless it finds a basis for cooperation among its cities and suburbs.
"When people talked about metropolitan government in the 60's," he said, "the thrust was more efficient delivery of services through economies of scale. I think regionalism now is founded on the fact that for the core city and the towns surrounding it to survive and thrive, they need to work together."
An ally, State Senator Martin M. Looney of New Haven, has proposed a statewide property-tax rate on motor vehicles. The effective annual tax rate on vehicles, according to the Connecticut Conference of Municipalities, ranges from 5.01 percent in Waterbury to 0.74 percent in Lyme, so that a $15,000 car is taxed at $751 in Waterbury and at $111 in Lyme.
"It seemed that the equity of property-tax reform beginning with the motor-vehicle tax would be clear," Mr. Looney said. "While you might be able to argue that the value of homes might vary greatly depending on location, it seems clear that a car is a car wherever it is."
Mr. DeStefano said he hopes that legislators will begin a serious discussion of tax revision in 1994. If they do not, he said, a lawsuit against the state will be filed in both state and Federal courts. But he would prefer to make the case to his suburban neighbors that equalizing tax rates would unlock the door to new jobs for the entire region.
The region needs a new industry, he argues, and the most promising is biotechnology, nourished by the research going on at the Yale School of Medicine. But the city's high property taxes discourage investment.
"There are some businesses that should be in Branford, or North Haven or Wallingford," he said, naming three suburbs. "But if a business needs a harbor or a rail system or to be next to the School of Medicine, then it needs to be here, and it shouldn't have a disincentive to come because of the property-tax structure."
Suburban officials are leery of any New Haven initiative that would affect their property taxes. In his own election campaign, Anthony Rescigno, the North Haven First Selectman, vowed to fight a city lawsuit.
 
View From Suburbs
 "The people of North Haven already pay more than their fair share to the state in terms of income tax and sales tax that then gets funneled back to the cities," Mr. Rescigno said.
"I think that's O.K.," he continued, "but to suggest that we should be paying more is not O.K. We would fight it legally, and that's unfortunate, because we want to see New Haven thrive."
In Hamden, where the tax rate is nearly as high as New Haven's, Mayor Lillian D. Clayman won re-election over an opponent who campaigned against regional taxes, but she is cautious about talk of regionalism. "It's become a catch-all phrase, and it means a lot of different things," she said.
Hamden's taxes are high in part, she said, because residents are willing to pay for good schools, parks and other services. "If you're going to use regionalization to have other people use our services without paying for them, we don't want that burden," she said.
"Regionalization is something legislators have to grapple with in this session," she said. "I'm not sure they will, because it's an election year. But someone has to define what it is."

He spoke in December to students at Hillhouse High School. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: U.S. Approves Plan To Reduce Fishing Off of New England

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 3

 BODY:
Hoping to stem the collapse of fish stocks off New England, Federal officials today approved a plan to reduce fishing of some species by 50 percent over the next five to seven years.
The fishing management plan will impose a moratorium on new commercial fishing licenses, limit the amount of time boats can spend at sea and prohibit two boats from working together to pull a single large net. 
 Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, who approved the plan, said in Washington that he would also propose $2.5 million in economic aid for Northeastern communities that depend on the fishing industry.
 
Hurting Fishermen
 Fishermen and dealers will also be required to buy electronic equipment to help report catches. The data will be used for enforcement and scientific research.
The new rules, many of which take effect immediately, cover boats that fish in American-controlled waters off New England. The rules are expected to have a major impact on coastal communities in Massachusetts, Rhode Island and Maine, officials said.
The National Marine Fisheries director, Rolland A. Schmitten, acknowledged that the restrictions would hurt New England fishermen but warned that further steps might be needed to protect dwindling groundfish stocks.
Stocks of cod, yellowtail flounder and haddock -- the principal groundfish species -- have been hit hard by overfishing.
"This plan calls for measures that impose significant restrictions, but if we fail to act now the resource will be lost and the future economic base of many New England communities will be undermined," Mr. Schmitten said in a statement.
The groundfish management plan was approved by Secretary Brown the same day that an emergency ban went into effect on haddock fishing in the United States-controlled portion of the Georges Bank in the Atlantic Ocean off the New England coast.
That ban, imposed a month earlier than usual, is intended to give greater protection to spawning haddock by increasing the area, to 2,600 square miles from 800 square miles, historically designated off limits to fishing.

HEADLINE: Duncan Ballantine, Educator, Historian And Consultant, 81

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Dr. Duncan Smith Ballantine, an educator and historian, died last Tuesday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 81.
He had a brief illness, his family said. 
 A former college president in Portland, Ore., and Istanbul, Turkey, Dr. Ballantine retired in 1979 as director of finance for education projects at the World Bank in Washington. He continued to serve as a consultant for several more years.
He was born in Garden City, L.I., and graduated from Deerfield Academy and Amherst College. He received a Ph.D. from Harvard University in 1947. In World War II he served as a commander in the Navy.
Dr. Ballantine started his teaching career at the Gow School in South Wales, N.Y., in 1936. After the war he was an associate professor of history at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. In 1953 he was named president of Reed College in Portland. He left in 1955.
From 1955 to 1961 he was president of both Robert College and the American College for Girls in Istanbul, which merged during his tenure and were turned over to the Turkish Government. Robert College, founded in 1863 primarily for Turkish students, taught young people from many countries.
He joined the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development in 1962 and was responsible for evaluating educational projects in developing countries and providing low-interest loans for building and improving those countries' educational institutions and programs.
Dr. Ballantine's first marriage to Margarette Torbert of Chevy Chase, Md., ended in divorce.
He is survived by his wife, Saffeti Acele of Bethesda; two daughters, Katherine Davy of Manhattan Beach, Calif., and Andrea S. Ballantine of Silver Spring, Md.; a son, Duncan A., of Bethesda, and two granddaughters.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
Federated's move on Macy's raises more questions than answers about the retailers' media buying.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
FOR decades, New Yorkers had a catch phrase they delighted in using when asked to share a secret: "Does Macy's tell Gimbels?"
Gimbels, sad to say, has been closed since 1986. Yet now Macy's might be telling Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Stern's. 
 That could be the result of an agreement announced by the parent of those retail chains, Federated Department Stores, to pay $449.3 million to acquire a stake in R. H. Macy & Company. Federated's goal in buying half of a secured claim against Macy, which has been operating under Federal bankruptcy protection, is to take control of its Macy's, Bullock's and I. Magnin units and create the nation's biggest department store retailer.
If such a merger comes to pass -- and that is, of course, a rather large if -- the advertising and media implications would be enormous. Executives at agencies, as well as executives at the print and broadcast media organizations that carry department store advertising, cautioned yesterday that it was far too soon for definitive conclusions. Their initial reactions, though, were decidedly mixed.
"I'm not sure what it means," said a leading media executive in New York, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. "But you always get nervous when there's a concentration of power."
Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst who follows media stocks for Paine Webber in New York, disagreed.
"Having a healthy retailer is a good thing, no matter what else happens," he said. "If I'm a newspaper-space salesman, or calling on Macy's from a radio or TV station, I'd rather be talking to people who are planning for the future and not worried about being out of a job next week."
As a result, Mr. Gottesman asserted, the media could offset any losses suffered if a combined Federated-Macy "qualified for additional discounts" by buying larger amounts of advertising space and time.
There could be additional positive consequences of a financially stronger Macy's, he said: "If Macy's is better capitalized, it becomes a stronger competitor. That could very likely evoke or trigger a competitive response from stores outside the Federated orbit." Thus, retailers like Lord & Taylor might also increase ad spending.
But an important media executive intimately familiar with New York retailing, who spoke only on the condition of anonymity, disputed that.
Bloomingdale's and Macy's "are the two goliaths who drive each other," the executive said. "To the extent a single corporate entity would lower the temperature, it's not good."
"You'd have enormous economic clout concentrated with a very shrewd retailer," the executive added, "and it would use that clout to squeeze vendors, whether they sell clothing or advertising."
Kenneth T. Berents, who follows media stocks for Wheat, First Securities in Richmond, agreed. "Every time department stores merge, it reverberates into shudders in the newspaper industry," he said. "When you take two competitors and combine them into one, they still do advertising, though not at the breakneck pace they did before."
The crucial issue for media organizations in local markets where both Federated and Macy are strong, he added, like Atlanta and New York, "is that if Federated gets control of Macy's, how many stores will get shut to get profits up?"

 Richard N. Costello, president and chief operating officer at TBWA Advertising in New York, the agency for Bloomingdale's, was far more sanguine.
Plans to merge Macy's into Federated's holdings are "splendiferous," he said, likening the challenges faced by Macy's to those confronting Bloomingdale's, which awarded his agency its account in March.
"This is a store that's an institution," he said, "but needs to redefine itself and what it wants to become. You want a statement that captures that it's something quite terrific but that people ought to take another look at it if they haven't shopped there in the last few days, weeks, months."
TBWA is working on a campaign for Bloomingdale's, which could begin running in the spring, that Mr. Costello described as "an image repositioning, redefining Bloomingdale's, while still being very careful to sell merchandise."
The agency for Macy's is Lintas New York, which introduced a huge campaign in April 1991 carrying the theme "The magic of Macy's. We're a part of your life." Macy's, which spent about $30 million on advertising in 1990, said at the time that it would raise that figure fivefold to promote the image-burnishing message of the Lintas campaign. But its bankruptcy proceedings forced Macy to drastically curtail image-oriented ads in favor of those intended to quickly move merchandise, which are being created in-house.
"The account is inactive," said F. Stone Roberts, president and chief operating officer at Lintas New York. "But if retail sales pick up, and real estate improves, and Federated gets involved, it could become a good opportunity for us."
He paused, then added, "There's a lot of 'ifs' there."

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Cold Forecast for Florida Pushes Orange Juice Up 8%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

 BODY:
Orange juice futures jumped 8 percent yesterday, the largest single-day gain in more than two years, on forecasts for a crop-damaging freeze in Florida.
Gains in orange juice and crude oil led the Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities to its highest level in three years. The index, a gauge for inflation, was a point higher at 227.34. 
 Meteorologists said two cold fronts were headed south and could bring freezing temperatures to Florida's orange groves as soon as tomorrow.
 
'A Little Enthusiastic'
 "Temperatures could fall as low as 28 degrees," said Peter Leavitt, executive vice president at the Weather Services Corporation in Bedford, Mass. "That's not damaging unless it stays that cold for a few days. There's always that potential, but I think the market may have been a little enthusiastic."
Orange juice for March delivery closed 8.5 cents higher at 115.75 cents a pound on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Not all weather services agree about the severity of the temperatures, said Court Turner, an analyst with A. G. Edwards & Sons in Winter Haven, Fla., making the rise mainly speculative.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil prices soared on improved demand for gasoline and heating oil and on speculation that the members of OPEC would hold an emergency meeting to try to halt the 32 percent plunge in crude prices since March.
With Gulf Coast refineries shutting for annual maintenance, inventories should start to fall and prices rise, traders said. With gasoline at its lowest price in real terms since the end of World War II, traders rushed to buy contracts yesterday.
The Dow Jones News Service, citing an unnamed senior official at the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, said the group would consider moving its meeting scheduled for March 25 to late January or early February.
Crude oil for delivery in February settled 39 cents higher at $14.56 a barrel; unleaded gasoline for February jumped 1.20 cents, to 41.20 cents a gallon. Heating oil for February rose 0.69 cent, to 45.21 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Signs of Stronger Economy Help to Send Dollar Higher

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against most currencies yesterday in response to more positive American economic news, including a national purchasing managers' survey that indicated the manufacturing sector was growing.
Gold prices also ended higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery, the most actively traded futures contract, gained $2.80 to settle at $394.70 an ounce. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management said its monthly index rose to 57.9 percent in December from 55.7 in November. A continual reading of more than 50 percent indicates the manufacturing sector is expanding.
"There's a spreading understanding that the U.S. economy is going to be stronger than previously thought," William Arnold, chief foreign exchange dealer at Chemical Bank, said.
A growing economy helps the dollar in two ways: Investors buy dollars to invest in expanding American businesses, and investors believe the stronger economy will push up interest rates, providing a better return on some investments.
In contrast, many traders are guessing that the Bundesbank of Germany will lower interest rates at its meeting on Thursday. In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.7434 German marks, from 1.7388 marks on Friday.
The dollar continued to rise against the Japanese yen, ending at 112.73 yen in New York, up from 111.85 yen on Friday. Traders said part of the continuing rise was a result of the bleak short-term outlook for the Japanese economy.
The dollar retreated, however, against the Canadian dollar. In New York, the dollar was quoted at 1.3138 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3218. Fund managers bought the Canadian currency for technical reasons, judging it undervalued, Lisa Finstrom, a currency analyst at Smith Barney Shearson, said.
Markets in Tokyo, London and Canada were closed yesterday for holidays.
The British pound fell in New York to $1.4750, from $1.4778 on Friday.
On the Comex, silver for current delivery jumped 13.3 cents, closing at $5.220 an ounce.

HEADLINE: Consumers Let Good Times Roll

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
As the American economy heads into the new year, it is consumers -- rather than business or government -- who are fueling growth. But while most economists expect consumers to slow down at least a little this year, most forecasters say their spending should help sustain the economic expansion in 1994.
Despite white-collar layoffs, higher taxes and cuts in military spending, little has dampened Americans' eagerness in recent months to buy everything from washers to wall units -- as well as the houses to put them in. 
 And retailers are stretching to accommodate their demand.
In Raleigh, N.C., Frank R. Anderson Jr. kept the doors of the Sir Walter Chevrolet Company open all day on New Year's Eve, New Year's Day and Sunday, too, so that the pickups, four-wheel drives and Camaros could keep heading for customers' driveways. "When the good times roll," Mr. Anderson said, "you've got to roll with them."
In Irvington, N.Y., Pamela O'Keefe, a realtor at the William B. May Company, had customers asking to see co-ops on the afternoon of New Year's Eve. "December is usually a slow month," she said, "but clients are hearing that other people are buying homes and they don't want to be left behind."
And in San Francisco, Ruth Owades, chief executive of Calyx & Corolla, a fresh-flower catalogue company, said the holiday season was more frantic than usual. "Everything kind of happened at the last minute," she said, estimating that her company sent 30 percent more flowers than in the previous Christmas season.
"Everybody was waiting for some positive signs from the economy," she said. "Once they saw them, they pulled out all the stops and felt good about the spending."
Recent upbeat reports show that confidence, retail spending, home buying and hiring are all up. In fact, consumers, who were expected to be full of angst and relatively subdued in 1993, accounted for most of the economy's growth in the second half of the year. Their spending has been rising at about a 4 percent annual rate in the last two quarters, while their outlays on new housing have zoomed up at roughly a 15 percent rate, economists now figure.
Although last year's spending spurt was stronger than expected, it was not as strong as the consumer rebounds in the expansions of the 1960's, 1970's and 1980's, when 5 percent annual spending growth was typical.
Still, while forecasters had predicted some pickup in spending in the second half, they did not expect households to play the leading role in carrying the expansion.
"You had people selling the idea that Americans were going to stop spending and go back to sitting on Goodwill furniture in their hand-knit sweaters," David Wyss, an economist at DRI/McGraw Hill, said.
The surprising strength of consumer spending -- November home sales, for example, far exceeded expectations -- has also prompted many companies to gear up production, hire more workers and restock inventories. Of course, not all retailers have shared equally, and department stores and apparel manufacturers have had less stellar sales as consumers concentrate on more costly items -- from computers and cars to houses and home furnishings.
With an eye on their latest orders and sales figures, large and small companies alike are telling pollsters that they plan more hiring and capital spending.
Dan Grow, president of Drexel Heritage Furnishings Inc. in Drexel, N.C., said his company would likely keep the second shifts it had added at various plants to meet the holiday rush.
And Ms. Owades said she intended to send out more catalogues this spring and add salespeople. "We're planning for a very strong Valentine's," she said.
There are subtle signs, however, that even as the dollars flow, consumers are not really going back to their free-spending ways of the 1980's. They are still determined to get more for less, to ferret out the bargains.
These days, sales clerks at the Saks Fifth Avenue store in Boca Raton, Fla., squirrel away a half-million dollars in jewelry before private-sale night so that favored customers can get their desired baubles at a hefty discount. The blue-collar crowd that is buying pickup trucks may want them equipped with air-conditioning, stereos and other frills, but they "are still price shopping," car dealers say. And more furniture buyers are heading to lower-cost stores, like Ikea, than to more expensive stores like Drexel Heritage.
At the Ikea store in Elizabeth, N.J., last week, Tom Dickinson, a plant manager, and his wife, Marie, a homemaker, and their two children were among the throngs of shoppers. This Christmas, the Hackettstown, N.J., couple made their first big-ticket purchase in several years -- a computer for their children, ages 5 and 8. And last Friday, they drove to Ikea to hunt for a computer work station and a dinette set. By spring or summer, they expect to be shopping for a mini-van to replace Mrs. Dickinson's 1985 Pontiac station wagon.
"When you get to the point of thinking, 'Maybe it won't be me next,' you can spend a couple of dollars," said Mr. Dickinson, who survived the downsizing of his company.
 
Slower Spending Growth
 Most economists, from the Keynesians in the Clinton camp to pin-striped supply siders on Wall Street, are convinced that consumer spending growth is likely to cool to a more sustainable pace. They also see a cooling in the economy, which they think grew at a rate of 4 or 5 percent in the last few months of 1993.
"The numbers are very, very good," said Larry Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns & Company. "But the current boomlet is not a forever story."
Consumers seem to share these somewhat diminished expectations. At the University of Michigan, Richard Curtin, who conducts a widely followed monthly consumer poll, pointed out that Americans are not nearly as giddy as they were a year ago. Just a quarter of the families polled, compared with half a year earlier, believe economic growth will keep accelerating.
There are other reasons for thinking that spending growth will ease this year. A key reason: people are spending more than they are earning. "They have to slow down and let income catch up with spending," said Mr. Wyss of DRI/McGraw Hill.
Taxes could also squeeze the purchasing power of some pretty big spenders. "I'm not so sure everybody's thought about how big their tax liability is going to be," Mr. Grow of Drexel Heritage said. "I'm concerned that we could see a little slowdown in spending as we get into the tax season."
And there is always the possibility of a bigger chill -- something that could foil even the most reasonable forecasts. Mr. Curtin, for example, expressed concern that "we're still vulnerable to setbacks in confidence if the job market stops improving."
That said, economists have erred lately more on the side of underestimating consumer spending. Most of them did not anticipate how fast confidence and the job market would revive and how powerful a punch low interest rates would provide.
The lowest interest rates in a generation are offering a strong incentive for consumers to buy houses or fix them up. And getting into the market before rates go up is a compelling reason for moving quickly.
"It's an excellent time to buy," said Richard Miles, who works for a Manhattan television production company and just made a successful bid for a four-bedroom Cape Cod bungalow in Nyack, N.Y. "Mortgage rates are unbelievable. Our monthly payments are going to be less than what we're paying in rent."
But even if the housing rebound slows, home sales have been so strong lately that consumers will almost certainly be spending more on furniture and appliances in the next few months.
Robert Kay, the general manager of Ikea in Elizabeth, said his biggest problem was that the store's floors were so jammed he had trouble keeping everything from beds to home-entertainment units in stock. The Dickinsons, for example, could not buy the dinette set they wanted because the chair cushions were sold out. They plan to revisit the store next week.
 
Trade-In Fever
 Consumers will keep buying cars and trucks, economists predict, because the urge to replace aging vehicles may not have run its course yet. "We've sold a lot of cars this December," said Roger Hoover, finance manager at Dresing Chevrolet Buick Pontiac Inc. in Jacksonville, Ill. "There seems to be a real super buying attitude."
At Dresing, farmers and factory workers at the local Capitol Records plant are driving off in Chevrolet pickups that cost $20,000 or so, as much as an entry-level BMW in the mid-1980's. "We can't get enough," Mr. Hoover said.
Whether spending keeps growing at a respectable pace depends mostly on income growth, and that, in turn, depends mostly on job growth. The additional spending in 1993 came in part because the economy added 190,000 new jobs a month, many factories paid overtime and wages held their own against inflation.
There are some signs of continued hiring. Weekly jobless claims are at a five-year low, an upbeat indicator at least for December. The workweek is longer than at any time since World War II, so employers have little room to increase production through overtime. And, though post-Christmas reports have not come in, all indications are that inventories are fairly lean.
 
 
A Question of Savings
 But consumers have been saving less in order to spend more -- and whenever consumer spending outpaces earnings, economists get concerned. While income should grow as fast as in 1993, or even faster, the savings rate, which hovered above 5 percent a couple of years ago, has been squeezed down to 4 percent or so. To keep spending at recent rates, consumers would have to be willing to reduce their savings even further. To most economists, that seems unlikely at a time when baby boomers are facing college bills and retirement.
Besides, consumers may not be able to keep tapping sources of extra cash. The bull market in stocks and bonds, which swelled the financial wealth of households to an all-time high last year, may not produce another big wave of capital gains for the 55 million Americans who are active investors. Unless interest rates fall further, which most economists are not predicting, the extra cash from refinancing mortgages or lower payments on floating-rate loans will not be available this year.
While there is no evidence that consumers are prepared to increase their debt at a faster pace than their incomes are growing, many consumers have become less skittish about borrowing.
"I'm not sure it's a good sign or a bad sign," said Mr. Wyss of DRI. "The good side is that it suggests confidence. The bad side is that it means consumers are living a bit beyond their means."

HEADLINE: Pop Ballet Propels Joffrey's Recovery

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Just five months ago, it looked as if the financially hard-pressed Joffrey Ballet might not be able to perform in April at the New York State Theater as planned. But now the long-awaited engagement, the company's first appearance in Manhattan in more than two years, is a sure thing. The reason can be stated in one word: "Billboards."
The full-evening ballet -- a suite of dances set to music by Prince and choreographed by Laura Dean, Charles Moulton, Peter Pucci and Margo Sappington -- opened in Iowa City last January and has been packing in audiences ever since. The most recent performances, part of the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in November, were sold out. 
 The audiences are young, too, at a time when major arts institutions are glumly facing the fact that their patrons are aging with them. But is "Billboards" art? And does that matter? The ballet has given the Joffrey, known always as a youthful pop company, a new lease on life, enabling it to pay off longstanding debts and restructure and expand its board.
Gerald Arpino, the artistic director and resident choreographer of the Joffrey, said in an interview that he had long had a fondness for billboards and that his dream of seeing the Joffrey name emblazoned over a huge sign on Sunset Strip in Los Angeles helped inspire the creation of the new piece. He admitted that Robert Joffrey, the company's founder, thought his dream crass. Mr. Arpino said he was thrilled when the ballet was advertised last summer on a billboard towering over the Strip. "There we were, opposite Schwarzenegger," he crowed.
He admitted, too, that presenters of dance groaned when they heard that the company was planning a Prince ballet. The murmurs were on the order of "Ugh, Arpino's going to ruin the Joffrey," Mr. Arpino said. "Now, they're asking me to advise them on how we've increased audiences for dance."
 
Saved From Merger
 Ticket sales soared, he said. In Chicago, the Joffrey sold three times as many tickets as the dance company that preceded it at the same theater. In Washington, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts added seats for the ballet. At the University of Iowa in Iowa City, whose Hancher Auditorium presented the premiere, student attendance climbed from a high of 27 percent of the audience at dance, music and theater performances to 46 percent for "Billboards." "Sales for dance companies coming in after 'Billboards' went up, too," Mr. Arpino added.
Not so long ago, however, it seemed possible that the company might not survive long enough to present "Billboards." Faced with severe financial problems that threatened their existence, the Joffrey and American Ballet Theater briefly contemplated a merger in July 1992.
Soon after, Ballet Theater chose a former principal dancer, Kevin McKenzie, and a young financial hotshot from the Houston Ballet, Gary Dunning, as new directors. That May, Mr. Arpino had quietly brought in a mild-mannered mystery man named Cecil C. Conner Jr., an international business lawyer and a partner in the Manhattan firm of Mandelbaum, Schweiger & Conner. A serious amateur musician and a balletomane, the 51-year-old Mr. Conner, now the executive director of the Joffrey, had done a good deal of volunteer legal work for nonprofit arts organizations. But he had never helped run a major dance company.
 
Cash and Work Flow Again
 As part of its stabilization plan, the Joffrey decided not to perform unless it had a sponsor. "The economic risks of self-producing are so great and the cash flow pressure so great," Mr. Conner said in an interview. "That's why our only New York season in 1993 was at the Brooklyn Academy, where they presented 'Billboards' in the Next Wave Festival."
"The success of 'Billboards' has given us a lot of bookings around the country," he went on. "It has given us constant work -- and constant cash flow -- in the 1993-94 season. In some locations we made more than the sponsor's guaranteed fee, and traditionally we get a split of the box office."
The Joffrey performed in Milwaukee for the first time in 17 years and added eight cities to the customary seven where the company regularly performs. It will perform about 40 weeks during fiscal year 1994, which starts on July 1, four weeks over its contractual obligation to the dancers. The dancers worked 30 weeks in 1991 and 32 in 1993. "We worked out an arrangement to take care of lost weeks in long-range payments to the dancers," Mr. Conner said, adding that the company would perform about 40 weeks, more than its contractual obligations to its performers, in fiscal 1994.
The Joffrey, which has 40 dancers and a $9 million budget, has also reduced its deficit by $1.1 million, about half of what it owes in loans from individuals and in unpaid vendor fees. It has expanded its board both numerically and geographically, enlarging it by 13 members to 53. The company has also created a new board structure with more levels of donations, starting at $5,000. And board committees have been reformulated so that board officers have more individual responsibility.
 
Classics of the Future
 All of this can be attributed at least in part to the revitalizing effects of "Billboards." It is to be performed at the State Theater with a repertory of familiar and new works, including the company's long-awaited production of "Les Presages." The Joffrey is the first American company to present the 1933 ballet, choreographed by Leonide Massine to Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony. Though plotless, the piece deals with man's struggle against fate and has been seen as a presentiment of World War II.
"If we hadn't done it, if I hadn't conceived, produced and directed 'Billboards,' we wouldn't be doing 'Les Presages' or presenting a new piece by Randy Duncan or reviving Kylian's 'Return to a Strange Land' and Ashton's 'Patineurs' in New York," Mr. Arpino said. "Of course, change is hard to take. 'Billboards' is a 'now' piece that reflects its era. In a few years it will be a classic, probably like Jerome Robbins's 'New York Export, Opus Jazz.'
"I created a billboard for American dance and I spread it all over the United States. Elitists draw a circle that keeps people out. I'm drawing a circle and saying, 'Come in,' to people who would never go to the ballet."
