HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Interest Rates Fall in Thin Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Interest rates on Government securities fell yesterday during a session that traders said was notable for its lack of liquidity.
Thin trading conditions often lead to big swings in prices, and yesterday was no exception. 
 After moving higher early in the day, prices of Treasury securities gave back all of their gains around midday on rumors that someone was selling a large block of intermediate-term notes.
But those rumors never materialized, and prices subsequently recovered. Bond yields, which reached their highest level since mid-August on Monday, fell back.
 
Yield Falls to 6.35%
 By late in the day, the Treasury's 6 1/4 percent 30-year bonds were offered at a price of 9822/32 , up 7/8 point, to yield 6.35 percent, down from 6.41 percent late Monday.
"There are not a lot of positions around, and there does not seem to be a willingness to take on new positions either," said John Costas, head of the government trading department at Credit Suisse First Boston. "Until we get the employment numbers on Friday I don't think we will see people willing to commit much money to the market."
The Labor Department is scheduled to report on December's employment conditions on Friday.
Some credit market analysts also pointed to weaker-than-expected 10-day car sales as a more fundamental reason for the turnaround in prices, although such sales are reported by only General Motors and Ford. Analysts had expected auto sales to increase in the final 10-day period of 1993 from already-strong levels recorded earlier last month. Still, auto sales for all of December were up roughly 5 percent from a year earlier.
The car sales numbers, along with a Johnson Redbook survey of retailers that showed sales slowed in December from November, means that December retail sales data expected next week are likely to show a rise of about four-tenths of a percent, said Steven Slifer, an executive vice president and financial market economist at Lehman Brothers.
That figure "is consistent with the idea that the economy will grow at a somewhat slower rate in the first quarter," Mr. Slifer said, "somewhere around 2.5 percent to 3 percent" from the 4.5 percent rate of growth he projects for the fourth quarter.
Despite the one-day rise in Treasury prices and drop in yields, many market participants remain wary. To a number of traders, stronger economic growth and a move by the Federal Reserve Board to raise short-term interest rates appear almost inevitable.
"I think what we have seen for the last three or four months is likely to continue this year," one government-securities trader said. "Since August or early September, yields on the five year have moved from around 4.60 percent to close to 5.30 percent. That retracement has been fairly orderly. And I think that over the next year you will see a continuing trend toward higher rates and lower prices."
If not halted, the upward movement in yields on Treasury notes was delayed a bit yesterday.
 
Secondary Market Offerings
 In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 5 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered in late trading at a price of 99 1/2, up 19/32 , to yield 5.82 percent. Meanwhile, the Treasury's 5 1/8 percent five-year notes were offered at a price of 9918/32 , up 10/32 , to yield 5.22 percent. And the 4 1/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 9931/32 , up 2/32 , to yield 4.26 percent.
Elsewhere, the first new issues of the year were priced in the corporate bond market. Three deals totaling $525 million in debt were priced.
The largest new issue was offered by the Bear Stearns Companies. The parent of the investment banking firm sold $250 million of 10-year, 6 5/8 percent notes through its principal subsidiary, Bear, Stearns & Company.
The notes, which mature in 2004, were priced at $99.55 to yield 6.687 percent, 85 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 5 3/4 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing. The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
The other two new issues were a $150 million five-year note offering from the International Lease Finance Corporation and a $125 million high-yield note offering from ICF Kaiser International.
The quest by Federated Department Stores to take over R. H. Macy & Company continued to have a positive effect on the price of Macy's debt securities outstanding.
In the secondary market for high-yield junk bonds, the 14 1/2 percent Macy bonds due in 1998 were offered yesterday at $522.50 for each $1,000 face amount of securities. A week ago those bonds were trading at around $400 per thousand.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Snow Shuts Building Sites In East, Depressing Lumber

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Lumber futures prices fell sharply yesterday as heavy snow in the East shut down construction sites and stifled demand for building materials.
Spruce two-by-fours for January delivery fell $10.50 on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange to $453.10 for 1,000 board feet. 
 January deliveries have tumbled nearly $35 since peaking Friday at a nine-month high of $488. The record high is $493.50, reached last March 15.
Cash lumber prices have remained between $460 and $465 since Christmas.
The futures market rocketed last week in response to strong housing sales figures, but the snowy weather that hit the East Coast Monday and yesterday cooled the speculative fever, analysts said.
"We got way ahead of ourselves," said Curt Cunningham, president of Pacific Futures Trading Company in Seattle. "As long as the wood's not moving to the job site, the buyers can put off their inventory acquisition."
 
New Orders Scarce
 New orders were scarce yesterday at sawmills, but most mills have order files stretching to Jan. 17, so immediate price cuts are not likely on the cash market, said Bud Merrill, an analyst for Smith Barney Shearson in Eugene, Ore.
Meanwhile, weather worries eased in the market for frozen concentrated orange juice, where the January contract gained 8.25 cents a pound Monday on fears of freezing temperatures in the Florida Citrus Belt. January deliveries fell 3.7 cents Tuesday on the New York Cotton Exchange to $1.0895 a pound.
"You had panic buying yesterday and the trade took profits today," said Judy Ganes, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. "The forecast seems to have moderated. People took a step back and realized that maybe the more conservative temperatures estimates were more in line with what was happening."
Forecasts for biting cold weather in the Northeast and Midwest also drove heating-oil futures higher and helped lift crude oil prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Light sweet crude for February delivery rose 11 cents, to $14.67 a barrel; January heating oil rose 0.20 cent, to 50.50 cents a gallon; February unleaded gasoline jumped 0.93 cent, to 42.09 cents a gallon, and February natural gas rose 3.5 cents, to $1.964 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: AT LUNCH WITH: Michael Crichton;
Scarier Than Dinosaurs: Men vs. Women

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 4

 BODY:
The waitresses and the owner of Takanawa welcome Michael Crichton enthusiastically as he walks in with a nod and a smile. It's his favorite luncheon spot in town -- a small, unfancy Japanese restaurant less than a mile from his office in Santa Monica, Calif.
"In this restaurant, the then owner came up to me with a review of 'Rising Sun,' and said, 'Is this you?' and I said, 'Yeah,' and he said, 'People are saying I shouldn't be your friend,' and I said, 'I'd like you to read it,' " recalled the author of such best sellers as "Jurassic Park" and "The Andromeda Strain." 
 Mr. Crichton settled into a seat. "So I got on the horn to Tokyo to get him an early Japanese copy," he said. "And when I came back he said two things that were characteristic of almost all Japanese readers. They say, 'The book is true, and I understand why you're being criticized.' And that's that."
The 51-year-old writer, bespectacled and buttoned-down, speaks slowly, firmly and laconically. Although charming and usually articulate, he always seems to be on guard.
The critical reaction to "Rising Sun" stunned him, he said, because reviewers mostly saw the book as a shocking polemic, wrapped in a murder mystery, about Japan economically crushing the United States.
"I was astounded at the reaction," Mr. Crichton said. "I was really trying to describe the cultural chasm. The memory of my book tour was I spent most of my time defending Japan. It was weird."
Mr. Crichton looked up and smiled. He said he wouldn't be astounded by the reaction to his new book, "Disclosure." The book is being published this week by Alfred A. Knopf, which is shipping out an extraordinary 900,000 copies to bookstores. In this case, with a book about what he calls "gender relations," Mr. Crichton seems to be courting controversy.
The novel turns the sexual politics of the 1980's and 90's upside down, and raises questions about everything from the contemporary balancing act between men and women at home and at work to, most explosively, sexual harassment.
The heart of the book, which is taken from a real incident, focuses on a successful, married, 40-ish male executive at a computer company in Seattle who rejects the sexual advances of his new boss, a woman. The fact that the woman was his lover 10 years before complicates the relationship. And what turns the situation even more treacherous is that the woman falsely accuses the man of sexual harassment.
The woman is, of course, beautiful and manipulative and has a pattern of trying to seduce men who work for her. (Picture a combination of Glenn Close in "Fatal Attraction" and Faye Dunaway in "Network.") The man is, well, a perfectly nice guy from the Tom Hanks school. The book has been sold to Warner Brothers for $3.5 million.
So, as feminist critics might ask, what can a multimillionaire from a privileged Long Island family, married four times, contribute to the often-ferocious debate about men, women and sex, circa 1994? Mr. Crichton anticipates that the main criticism of the book will be that sexual harassment of men by women is rare. He insists he is not obligated to write about typical situations.
He has done homework on the issue, as he habitually does before he writes. He interviewed the participants in the case. He read books about feminism, visited computer companies to talk to employees about sexual relationships between co-workers and spoke to lawyers about sexual harassment.
"Statistically," he said, "25 percent of harassment cases are brought by men, and the majority of those are against other men. Five percent of all harassment cases are brought by men against women.
"I think we live in a society in which it's perceived that if a man is coming on to a woman she's being stressed, but if a woman comes on to a man he's lucky. The reality is not necessarily that way.
"On all sides here there are unexamined issues and unstated feelings, feelings that people don't even know they have," he said. "You bring this out by reversing the ordinary roles. Let everybody see what the other side feels like. The goal, really, is to do something about harassment."
The goal is most certainly also to push a societal hot button and churn out another best seller. Although Mr. Crichton has been writing since his days at Harvard Medical School, and had his first best seller, "The Andromeda Strain," in 1969, he ascended to superstardom with the success of the movie "Jurassic Park."
Although he is not the darling of the literary critics, his books have sold more than 100 million copies worldwide. They are often viewed as a thinking person's escapism, chockablock with technical information.
In the restaurant, Mr. Crichton knows the menu by heart. He orders tea. He's solicitous and, essentially, a private man. "Do you like sushi?" he asks. "Do you prefer that or something cooked?" His interviewer pauses. "I detect some hesitation," he says. A compromise is reached: sushi and chicken teriyaki.
He works nearby in a bungalow that resembles a doctor's office. Although he graduated from medical school, he never practiced medicine, choosing to write instead, to the horror of his family -- even though his father was a journalist. ("I saw writing as a normal thing to do," he said. "My father would sit at a typewriter and pound out a story.")
Mr. Crichton also lives in Santa Monica with his wife, Anne-Marie Martin, an actress, and their daughter, Taylor, 4. Although married three times previously, he has no other children. Mr. Crichton is not fond of talking about his personal life, and barely smiles about the comment once made to him by the comedian Steve Martin: "Haven't you ever heard of pre-marital sex?"
He shrugs. "All those times I just wanted to get married," he said, grasping for words. "It was very emotional, you know. I was just trying to get it . . . right." He bursts into nervous laughter.
What propelled him to write "Disclosure" was, he said, the evolving relations between men and women. And beyond this, his ambition has always centered on questioning "the reigning dogma."
"What you're really seeing here is a protected area, a kind of intellectual protectionism where things aren't debated or fully discussed," he said. "And certainly many people have commented that feminism has not been very tolerant of internal dissent." He cited authors like Katie Roiphe and Naomi Wolf, whose books on rape and women's issues have stirred some angry comments among feminists.
As for him? His book, unlike theirs, is a novel, but a novel that he insists is a reflection of what's happening.
Mr. Crichton said his research at computer companies startled him.
"For one thing, there's a lot of sex in these companies," he said. "More and more people draw their social life from their work environment. And the human-resources people kind of throw up their hands. A lot of companies have a rule that if you're having a private relationship with someone who works for the company you have to report it. You can do it but it can't be secret. Well, of course it's secret.
"People are naturally concerned that their boss may have a special relationship with someone and that person will receive favored treatment. And women basically felt that they didn't have any problems with harassment or even unpleasant situations, except with men over 40."
But as more women rise to senior levels, Mr. Crichton said, the situations are bound to become complicated. Or reversed.
"I asked women how they arranged their social lives, and they said they sometimes pick stud muffins for their subordinates," he said. "And I'd say, 'Are you sure this man is free to turn you down?' It seemed to me almost classic."
Having finished his meal, he relaxed a bit as he chatted about less weighty matters. At 6 feet 9 inches, Mr. Crichton rose from the table, bid farewell to the restaurant staff, and slouched beneath the door to leave. "People always say to me, 'You play basketball?' and I say, 'No," and they say, 'You should.' " He laughed and walked along Wilshire Boulevard to his white Ford Explorer.
"It would be a refreshing change to write something where I'm not attacked," Mr. Crichton said. "When the movie 'Jurassic Park' came out, public-relations flacks for biotechnology companies began writing Op-Ed pieces saying how damaging and anti-science it was."
"Give me a break," he said with a laugh. "Life is too short. It's only a dinosaur movie."

LENGTH: 1167 words

HEADLINE: Wine Talk

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

DATELINE: MASHATU GAME RESERVE, Botswana

 BODY:
DOES zinfandel go well with kudu? Or leopard? Elephant? And baboon, what about baboon?
Here in the far southwest corner of Botswana, in Southern Africa, zinfandel goes with any of a hundred different wild creatures 
 Not, to be sure, while eating these exotic birds and beasts, because in this game reserve, no one is allowed to harm them, much less eat them. Let's just say, they don't seem to object to anyone drinking wine in their company.
This fact became vividly clear at a "wine weekend" held at Mashatu recently, during which this correspondent conducted, if that's the word, a tasting of American wines deep in the African bush.
Mashatu, named after a tree native to this part of Africa, is the largest privately owned game reserve in Southern Africa, comprising 90,000 acres, twice the size of Brooklyn. Located about 300 miles north of Johannesburg, it is bordered on the northeast by Zimbabwe and on the south and southwest by South Africa.
Although privately owned, by Rattray Reserves, a South African company, Mashatu is part of the 17 percent of Botswana's land devoted to wildlife preserves. Landlocked Botswana is supported by a substantial income derived from diamonds. Larger than France but with a smaller population than Dallas, Botswana is sometimes called the Switzerland of Africa because of its political stability and relatively strong economy.
Tourism is a growing business in Botswana. Travelers from around the world come here, though still in small numbers, to catch a glimpse of what many ecologists fear is a disappearing Africa.
Visits of any length can be arranged, but at a remote reserve like Mashatu, the schedule is attuned to long weekends. Guests, almost all of them from South Africa, arrive Thursday or Friday and leave Sunday. Some drive to the South Africa-Botswana border and make the trip into the reserve in Land Rovers; most fly into the Mashatu airstrip in private planes or on charter flights.
From 5 to 9 A.M. and again from 4 to 8 or 9 P.M., guests spend their time crashing through the bush in four-wheel-drive vehicles, tracking leopards, giraffes, cheetahs, impalas, kudus, baboons and the herds of elephants, which trudge tirelessly through the park in search of food.
Animals and visitors tend to lie low in the midday heat, making it a good time for the pool -- or for a wine tasting. On the first full day, the group went through a batch of interesting South African wines.
The next day, a steady breeze prompted the rangers to suggest taking the American wines outdoors. Carrying them gently, in ice buckets, over the rough, often nonexistent trails though the bush, we did, to an idyllic spot on the bank of the dry Limpopo River, a victim of southern Africa's decade-long drought. The Limpopo forms the border between Botswana and South Africa.
Onerous import duties combined with the now-lifted sanctions have effectively kept all but a minute quantity of foreign wine out of South Africa. So the 25 or 30 guests, all of them South Africans, were as eager to try a California chardonnay as they had been to see a kori bustard or lesser kudu earlier in the day.
What wines to show? Good wines, widely available in this country at reasonable prices. Chosen were:
* Edna Valley Vineyards, chardonnay, 1991.
* Bonny Doon Vineyard, Vin Gris de Cigare, 1991.
* Sanford Winery, pinot noir, 1990.
* Ridge, zinfandel, Sonoma, 1991.
* Fetzer Vineyards, Barrel Select cabernet sauvignon, 1989.
* Robert Mondavi Vineyards, Reserve cabernet sauvignon, 1989.
Except for the Mondavi cabernet, which sells for more than $20, all the wines sell for about $15 or less and are nationally distributed in the United States.
Burgundy-style wines are much in vogue in South Africa. Both new wine makers and older wineries are working to improve the quality of their pinot noirs and chardonnays. The Sanford Winery and Edna Valley wines were judged to be the equal of anything currently produced in South Africa, but even more impressive to the professionals in the group was the fact that thousands of cases of both wines are produced annually.
Most in the group felt the Bonny Doon Vin Gris, a rose, was excellent but not much different from some of the better roses produced in South Africa. The Mondavi reserve cabernet, though still closed-in, was greeted with something akin to awe; not so much for its intensity but for its elegance and breed, qualities sought after but not always achieved to such a degree in wines of the Western Cape.
The popular favorites of the day were clearly the Fetzer cabernet and the Ridge zinfandel. Cabernet is not uncommon in South Africa but tends to be austere. The plummy richness and sheer accessibility of the Fetzer wine came as a revelation to the tasters. Even more astonishing was the price, usually under $10.
The zinfandel got much the same reception. A small amount of zinfandel is produced in South Africa, but it's still considered rather exotic. The tasters were intrigued by the fact that a wine could be so intense and so drinkable at the same time.
Peter Devereux, a Johannesburg writer and wine expert, who presided over the wine weekend, told his assembled countrymen that the tasting, even though limited to half a dozen wines, indicated to him that South African wine makers were 15 years behind their Californian counterparts.
He spoke of South Africa's long isolation and need to catch up in order to share in the world market. "When South Africa can make wines like these consistently and at similar prices, we can be said to have arrived," he said.
Among other things, the tasting in the bush showed that good California wines can stand up under some unusual conditions. Before the jaunt into the bush, Mr. Devereux banned smoking and suggested that no one wear any strong scent.
He forgot to tell the elephants. Fortunately the breeze held up for most of the afternoon.
 
TASTINGS Rodney Strong Zinfandel 1990, Old Vines, Russian River, Sonoma; about $14.
 
 These gnarled vines, which Rodney Strong estimates to be at least 90 years old, are hardly prolific, but the fruit they produce is deeply colored and intensely flavored. And so is the wine he and his wine makers make from them. From the days when the winery was called Sonoma Vineyards, it has been known for full, rich zinfandels at reasonable prices. This particular wine spent 18 months in oak and is about 14 percent alcohol, which is high, except for a rich, full-bodied wine like this. Rhone wines are the latest thing in California -- wines made from the hot-climate grapes of the Rhone Valley in France, like sirah, mourvedre, cinsault and grenache. Luckily a few farsighted wine makers are focusing on the old-fashioned zinfandel, an American grape with many of the properties so admired in the Rhone varieties. The best zins, as Californians call them, are more than a match for most California versions of Chateauneuf and Hermitage. This estate-bottled wine is one of those zins.

HEADLINE: Review/Opera;
Lush French Rarity, Via Shakespeare

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
The sensitivity and gentle exoticism of Reynaldo Hahn's art songs have made them centerpieces of the modern recital literature. But the operas, operettas and musical theater works he composed for the French stage in the first decades of this century have become footnotes in operatic history, scarcely mentioned in reference works and virtually never performed.
Hahn died only 47 years ago, so perhaps history's verdict is not final. Granted, a real reconsideration would require full-scale productions and recordings of works that have been collecting dust, and given the costs involved in presenting opera these days, few major companies (or singers) are likely to commit their resources to uncertain payoffs. 
 Small companies, on the other hand, thrive on taking chances, and perhaps their efforts should have greater reach. Opera Manhattan, a six-year-old company dedicated to presenting rarities, is making an eloquent case for Hahn with "Le Marchand de Venise." The production runs through tonight at St. Peter's Church (Lexington Avenue at 54th Street).
Hahn composed this setting of Shakespeare's "Merchant of Venice," with a French libretto by Miguel Zamacois, for the Paris Opera in 1935. Zamacois and Hahn took some interesting liberties with the Shakespeare text. Minor characters are dropped and the play's many changes of setting are compressed into five scenes in three acts. Shylock is also conceived differently. In some ways, the verbal abuse he suffers from the Venetians is more direct than in Shakespeare, but instead of the "Hath not a Jew eyes" speech, Zamacois and Hahn give him a dramatic aria in which he delivers a more historically pointed denunciation of centuries of Christian anti-Semitism.
Hahn's musical characterizations are magnificent. Offsetting the bitterness and drama of Shylock's music are the shapely, supple melodies assigned to the three pairs of lovers: Portia and Bassanio, Jessica and Lorenzo, Nerissa and Gratiano. There are touches of tone painting, the most vivid being the gently bobbing music that underlies the discussion of the gondola that will spirit away Jessica and Lorenzo. Holding everything together is a musical language that combines Mozartean gracefulness, a distinctly French sense of harmony and pastel coloration, and even a touch of French folk song in the choruses.
Since 1992, Opera Manhattan has donated the box-office receipts from all of its productions to the Community Research Initiative on AIDS, and in the interest of keeping its production costs low, it resorts to some inventive economies. The company's director, Gabriel Guimaraes, reduced the orchestration to wind quintet, harp and piano, and took the work's Mozartean character as a cue to accompany the recitative sections with piano only. Yet the arrangement offered a vivid impression of the work's lushness and beauty, and on Monday evening the musicians, directed from the keyboard by Mr. Guimaraes, gave the score an energetic, nicely balanced reading.
There is no scenery to speak of, but Marc J. Reiss's stage direction made good use of the church's resources, and suggested the settings and action reasonably. The attractive costumes, by Anthony Muto, also abetted the illusion of a more ambitious staging. Unusual for a production this small, there were English supertitles, which were helpful.
Vocally, the company was hobbled by throat infections on Monday evening, but the singers persevered and generally did themselves credit.
Peter Becker took the role of Shylock on two days' notice, and sang it from the score. Yet he endowed his reading with power and coloration.
Among the better-rehearsed singers, the strongest were Robert Sapolsky, whose smooth, firmly produced baritone made him an appealing Bassanio, and Rosemary Barenz, who brought a bright, steady soprano to Portia's often challenging music.
Keren Bernbaum, a mezzo-soprano with a warm, rich tone, was an effective Nerissa, and Marion Capriotti, also a mezzo, gave lively performances of some smaller roles. The cast included Michael Alhonte (Antonio), Robert Hancock (Gratiano), Richard Slade (Lorenzo), Erin Langston (Jessica) and Eric Owens (Tubal).

HEADLINE: Economy Dampens Ardor of Brazilians

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 3

 BODY:
In a tropical land soaked with sensuality, economic anxieties are tarnishing a point of Brazilian national pride: bedroom performance.
Harried by annual inflation of 2,500 percent, a national record, sexually active Brazilians are now having sexual relations 1.6 times a week, according to a survey of 2,631 adults conducted by the Brasmarket polling group. 
 This is almost half the rate of three times a week registered by pollsters five years ago and dangerously near the once-a-week frequency recorded in polls of American adults.
"You can't be a victim in the street and a hero in bed," Moacir Costa, a Sao Paulo psychotherapist, told Isto E, a newsweekly that commissioned the poll.
Two-thirds of the adults surveyed complained that the economic crisis was dampening their libido.
"What is happening in Brazil was recorded in Argentina during the 1980's when that country went through a great economic crisis," said Gerson Lopes, an author of books on Brazilian sexual mores. Surveys indicated that Argentine sexual encounters dropped sharply with economic hard times: from four a week to one a week.
A non-economic worry may be affecting Brazilians' sex habits, too. Roughly one million Brazilians are infected with the virus that causes AIDS. So far, about 45,000 Brazilians have developed AIDS, a toll that, outside Africa, is second only to that in the United States.
Brazil's sex crisis is manifested at the dilapidated motels that line Rio's access roads. These establishments charge by the hour, feature mirrors on the ceilings and carry suggestive names like Lipstick, Pussycat and L'Amour. Opened up like beer bottles in the economic go-go years of the 1970's, many of Rio's 225 motels are now deteriorating from a lack of maintenance.
Once discreet, the motels now fight to survive by advertising on television and by offering promotions like discount lottery tickets or a free lunch for two. Even so, Rio's motel industry trade association estimates that motels are renting their rooms at discounts averaging 40 percent.
This decline in leisure spending is seen throughout Brazil's economy, including video rentals, record sales and movie ticket sales. Since 1991, Brazil's cigarette consumption has dropped by one-third, to about a billion cigarettes this year.
"Economic constraints have a big impact on casual sexual relations," said Richard G. Parker, an American anthropologist here who wrote "Bodies, Pleasures and Passions: Sexual Culture in Contemporary Brazil" (Beacon Press 1991). "There are an awful lot of heterosexual encounters that require a fair amount of money: a bar bill, a dinner, a motel room."
Contributing to sexual frustration, weddings dropped sharply during Brazil's recessionary years. From 1988 to 1990, the number of weddings in Brazil dropped 18 percent, to 777,000. Census data show that the favorite month for Brazilian weddings shifted from May to December, the month when workers receive year-end bonuses mandated by law.
Brazil's sex crisis has tormented Valdomiro Ferreira in more ways than one. In 1992, Mr. Ferreira owned six shops selling sexual aids. With the economic squeeze, his clientele dried up, and he closed four shops.
"I got to the point of going without sex for one month, I was so worried about my work," the Rio businessman complained to Isto E. "Before, I used to have relations every day, even without being any kind of superman."
In descending order of importance, respondents to the Brasmarket poll listed the following reasons for flagging sex drive: insecurity; lack of money for a date; criminality, which may discourage people from going out, and lack of money for a motel.
In a country traditionally known for optimism and self-confidence, male self-doubt has reached such a point that a prime-time soap opera, "Fera Ferida," featured an impotent athlete in its plot this season. Once a rake, the character started to encounter bedroom trouble after he broke his leg on the eve of his debut on Brazil's national soccer team.

HEADLINE: In America;
Balance, Mr. Mayor

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
It's a good thing Andrew Giuliani was on hand throughout his father's inaugural address on Sunday. The sustained antics of the uninhibited 7-year-old -- who made faces and parroted his father, and offered such unsolicited observations as "He's right, you know" -- provided the only real warmth and exuberance during the speech.
It'll be awhile before we see another successful politician as stiff and as chilly as New York's new Mayor. By comparison, Vice President Al Gore is a regular vaudevillian. 
 Andrew also gave his dad, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the opening for a rare display of humor. Mr. Giuliani said the city's corporation counsel had expressed concern that Andrew, having helped his father recite the oath of office, might in fact have become co-Mayor.
"We're trying to figure out what's the legal effect of what he did yesterday," said Mr. Giuliani. "Paul Crotty is concerned that not only did he take the oath, he gave an inaugural address."
New Yorkers may need Andrew before this whole thing is over. He's the lighter side of his cold and calculating, technocratic and potentially ruthless old man.
In essence, Rudolph Giuliani is a cop. What the city hopes to get from him is a crackdown on crime. Anything else is a bonus. Anything less is a failure.
Toward the end of Sunday's speech, Mr. Giuliani said, "American cities can't survive as we know them if they remain so violent. Our priority must be to reduce the violence.
"I'll place a much greater emphasis on stricter enforcement of the law to reverse the growing trend of ever-increasing tolerance for lawless behavior. I'll work for changes in policing and in criminal justice that will redress the balance that I believe is now out of balance. Guns, the handguns, will be a particular source of our efforts."
The Mayor made a good start when he ordered the deployment of 15 cops to patrol the area around Taft High School in the Bronx. The administration described the deployment as the first step in fulfilling Mr. Giuliani's promise to create safety zones around the city's schools.
The Mayor also spoke in his inaugural address about the need to get at "the underlying causes of crime."
"This," he said, "will be as important a part of my administration as respect for the law."
Don't count on it. This is the same man who threatened during the campaign to throw homeless people out of the shelters after 90 days; the same man who vowed to sweep the streets of drug dealers without explaining how he would pay for prosecuting or incarcerating them; the same man who said initially that gun licensing would be a good idea even if it put guns into the hands of more people.
Rudolph Giuliani is not a root-causes kind of guy. He's much more likely to say "Stop doing that!" than "Why are you doing that?"
Compassion, even apart from the crime issue, has not been Mr. Giuliani's strong suit. And it's not likely to be a hallmark of his regime.
Last week's flap over funding of the arts provided a revealing glimpse of the cold heart of this administration. John Dyson, Mr. Giuliani's Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, suggested that more support be given to the city's elite cultural institutions, like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, by reducing the funding to smaller and less renowned cultural groups.
The reason: The elite institutions bring in more tourist dollars, thus boosting the city's economy.
This caused a furor and Mr. Dyson subsequently backed off. But his proposal is exactly the kind you can expect from an excessively technical and pragmatic approach to city government.
The city needs some balance. There's more to life in a great metropolis than budgets and badges.
By inclination, and with the public's blessing, Mr. Giuliani will be focused on law enforcement.
Co-Mayor Andrew will be available to provide us with a chuckle from time to time.
The many other aspects of life in the city -- including the joyful, the magical and the humane -- will have to be watched over by the rest of us, both in and out of government, who understand that while safe streets are essential, they're only the beginning.

HEADLINE: Foreign Policy Nears a Peril Point

BYLINE: By Brent Scowcroft and Richard Haass; Brent Scowcroft, president of the Forum for International Policy, a foreign affairs foundation, was national security adviser under George Bush and Gerald R. Ford. Richard Haass, a National Security Council staff member in the Bush Administration, is a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The foreign policy debate during the Clinton Administration's first year focused almost totally on secondary issues. The country can ill afford such a luxury this year.
The only first-magnitude issue to get large-scale public attention and sustained Presidential focus (at the eleventh hour) was the North American Free Trade Agreement. Other such issues -- Russia, the Middle East, North Korea, China, Japan, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade -- drew episodic high-level attention from an Administration preoccupied with domestic concerns. 
 Three of the four most debated policies were Bosnia, Somalia and Haiti -- all areas of actual or potential military intervention where American interests were less than vital.
Despite progress on trade and in the Middle East, the lack of focus on the big issues has led to weakened relationships with our allies and a loss of support at home for continued U.S. leadership in the world.
The outlook is approaching a point of peril for shaping a coherent foreign policy. To reverse this trend, President Clinton needs to choose a few priority issues for 1994 and act on them. Here are five candidates -- all matters where important U.S. interests are at stake and where our actions can make a difference.
Dealing with Russia, Ukraine and the rest of the former Soviet Union.
The Administration has established American support for Boris Yeltsin as a leading force for political and economic reform. With the parliamentary elections over and the new Constitution approved, we have to broaden U.S.-Russian relations.
Besides expanding our contacts with all responsible elements of the political spectrum and emphasizing support not for individuals but for democratic institutions and market reforms, we should spend more time on such emerging features of Russia's foreign policy as its more menacing positions on nuclear weapons and the former Soviet empire.
If Russia can object to the expansion of NATO, the West should be able to make the expansion of Russian influence no less an issue. We have to make clear that our long-term support is not unconditional and will depend on Russia's adherence to political and economic reforms and restraint toward its neighbors.
U.S. relations with Russia cannot be the sole avenue through which U.S. relations with Ukraine are conducted. Our policy toward Ukraine has been confrontational and one-dimensional, linking our willingness to provide assistance and normalize relations to Ukraine's willingness to give up its nuclear weapons. But the more we push this approach, the more the Ukrainians conclude that the weapons are valuable.
Given Ukraine's collapsing economy and Russia's uncertain intentions toward an independent Ukraine, we could end up with the worst of all worlds: an unstable and isolated Ukraine with nuclear weapons. We should seek to promote Ukrainian stability, with support tied only to needed economic and political reforms; with this approach, the nuclear question can be addressed more productively.
Consolidating European security.
Too much of the U.S.-European dialogue has been consumed by squabbles over trade, finger-pointing over Bosnia and counterproductive suggestions that Asia is more important to us than Europe, as if the two regions were mutually exclusive. We need to resume a serious dialogue on possible external threats to European stability.
The issue of expanding NATO will top the agenda at the NATO summit meeting next week. But it does not need formal expansion to deal with former Warsaw Pact countries. Our goal in Eastern Europe should be to provide security and to consolidate political and economic progress (on which our help has been stingy), not to encourage governments to devote scarce resources to defense in order to earn admission to NATO.
Nor should our goal be to make NATO so large that it becomes unwieldy. We can promote European stability by developing less formal military ties to Eastern Europe and making it clear that we will extend security guarantees if Moscow threatens its neighbors' security. This approach should reassure Eastern Europe, avoid unduly provoking Moscow and give us leverage over Russia's external behavior.
Pacifying North Korea.
We have a clear interest in avoiding conflict on the Korean peninsula. We have an equally clear interest in making sure North Korea does not provoke an Asian arms race and does not add a nuclear dimension to the threat it poses to regional stability.
The Administration said yesterday it was close to a compromise with Pyongyang. It is making a crucial error. Any arrangements for inspections must provide for not onetime but regular and full access to all sites -- not merely the seven apparently agreed upon -- that are known or suspected of having nuclear-weapons activities. If the North takes concrete steps to reduce the threat to the peninsula and the region, we should open meaningful political and economic relations. But whatever happens, the U.S. and South Korea should continue joint military exercises and strengthen the defenses of the South against attack from the North, whether nuclear or conventional.
Fostering strategic dialogue with the Asia-Pacific powers.
The North Korean issue demonstrates how important political-military relations remain in the Pacific.
China's negative attitude on sanctions against North Korea, its aggressive and dangerous policy on arms exports, Japan's hints about rethinking its non-nuclear-weapons policy, the conventional military buildup among members of the Association of Southeast Asian states -- all suggest strongly that we cannot allow our diplomacy with the world's most vibrant economies to be dominated by trade disputes.
Instead, we need broader consultations on national priorities and changing national relationships in a dynamic Asia.
Strengthening the sinews of foreign policy.
Chief among the requisites for successful foreign policy is a credible military able to give weight and support to policy. The Administration has cut the already much reduced defense budget it inherited from George Bush. The cuts are even larger than often realized, considering that the defense budget includes a range of international activities that do not contribute directly to U.S. forces.
We cannot allow the U.S. military to become a hollow instrument in which the sizes and composition of our forces and their readiness are not supported by necessary training, maintenance, personnel and spare parts. The Defense Secretary-designate, Bobby Ray Inman, faces a tough job. He must convince President Clinton to finance the Pentagon's possible budget request of $255 billion for the 1995 fiscal year and fight for it on Capitol Hill.
President Clinton, who has shown his ability to exploit the power of his office to shape the nation's political agenda -- on the budget, health care, crime -- must do no less on issues of foreign and defense policy.
There are, of course, other national security matters deserving high-level attention. A short list includes consolidating and where possible expanding gains in trade liberalization, continuing Iraq's isolation, maintaining vigilance toward Iran, promoting democratic change in Cuba, normalizing ties with Vietnam, coping with continuing instability in the former Yugoslavia and rethinking our relationship to peacekeeping, peacemaking and the United Nations.
These or other issues may turn out to require sustained, high-level involvement -- say, if the Middle East peace process falters of if the war in Bosnia spreads. But what is certain is that the big issues require special attention in the Oval Office. They offer the areas of greatest opportunity if the U.S. takes the lead -- and the greatest risk if we do not.

HEADLINE: Raise in Rent Aid Would Curb Homelessness

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 In these recessionary times, when even people with substantial work histories and job skills face reduced job security and people with few skills or handicaps are virtually barred from the work force, New York State must maintain its safety net for people unable to work. County public assistance grants are often the last resort to which people with no income can turn. 
 The majority of public assistance recipients in this state are children, and the vast majority of grants are given to families. A critical part of the grant is the shelter allowance, an amount issued to pay rental expenses, which is supposed to allow these families to secure and remain in stable housing. However, the allowance is inadequate.
The level of the shelter allowance has not been raised since 1988, despite almost universal increases in housing costs. The public assistance grant for a household of three brings that household, on average, to only 58 percent of the poverty level. The disparity between income and cost leads directly to homelessness, as families who rely on public assistance cannot pay their rent, are evicted and cannot obtain new housing.
It also contributes to hunger and poor health, as these families try to juggle their income to meet expenses and must choose between a roof over their heads or enough to eat.
This low shelter allowance is also a false economy for the state. Emergency assistance to homeless families, whether as huge shelters in urban areas or welfare motels in rural areas, costs more per family than paying the rent on an apartment. Those adults who have employment often lose it in periods of homelessness because of the disruption in their lives, loss of transportation to their jobs, if the emergency shelter takes them out of the area, and the overwhelming time demands of the bureaucracy involved.
This inevitably increases the need for public assistance. There is an additional human cost in psychological trauma, especially to children, which is difficult to measure but is ultimately borne not only by the victim of homelessness but also by society when that child has difficulty adjusting to school, integrating into the work force or interacting with peers.
New York State should increase the shelter allowance in the 1994-95 budget year to meet these needs. This requires political courage on the part of government officials. However, such courage and compassion for those excluded from the economic benefits of society can justifiably be expected and demanded from those who lead.
 
PATRICIA CROOP
Albany, Dec. 24, 1993
The writer is executive director, Statewide Emergency Network for Social and Economic Security.

HEADLINE: Cuba Embargo Has Had Desired Effect

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"U.S. Companies Use Affiliates Abroad to Skirt Sanctions," your Dec. 27 front-page report on Cuba and Libya, misleads your readers to believe that the case regarding Cargill Inc.'s sale of Cuban sugar shows how American corporations seize on "porous laws" to use foreign subsidiaries and circumvent the United States embargo on Cuba. This is not the case. 
 The 1988-89 Cargill case involves the Trading With the Enemy Act and took place three years before enactment of the Cuban Democracy Act, which I sponsored and which became law on Oct. 23, 1992.
The Cuban Democracy Act prohibited such trade. The results speak for themselves: United States trade through foreign subsidiaries fell from $718 million in 1991 to only $1.6 million last year. What remains covers contracts in effect when the Cuban Democracy Act became law because United States laws are not applied retroactively. The Cargill case discussed in the article involves the possible involvement by Cargill United States in the 1989 financing of sugar, which had already been sold by Cuba to Venezuela. The case is an enforcement action under the Trading With the Enemy Act, and it is continuing.
I have expressed my outrage about this case to Attorney General Janet Reno and underscored that if the allegations are true and if Cargill is found guilty, both the corporate officers involved and the company should be prosecuted.
Contrary, however, to your article's assertion that "the trading involved here raises questions about the effectiveness of one of the most visible tools of United States foreign policy," the Cuban Democracy Act, passed four years after this case, definitely answers questions about the effectiveness of the embargo. United States trade through foreign subsidiaries has ground to a halt.
While your article's investigative reporting is valuable, your analysis of the United States embargo must be put into context. The Cuban economy, particularly without its Soviet benefactor, is crumbling; Fidel Castro's own family wants out, and the final period of President Castro's dictatorship is here.
The embargo has had its effect, and the day when the United States will trade with a free Cuba is near.
In the meantime, it is important to correct the impression that is given by the article, that United States laws regarding trade with Cuba are lax. That is simply wrong, and it is a dangerous impression because United States trade with Cuba, directly or indirectly, without a license is illegal, and violators will surely be prosecuted to the full extent of the law.
 
(Rep.) ROBERT G. TORRICELLI
Chairman, Subommittee
on Western Hemisphere Affairs
Washington, Dec. 28, 1993

HEADLINE: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. Dies at 81; A Power in the House for Decades

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

 BODY:
Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr., an unreconstructed New Deal liberal from Massachusetts who rose to become Speaker of the House for 10 years, died last night at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 81 and lived in Washington and Harwich Port, Mass.
The cause of death was cardiac arrest, said a statement released by his family. 
 Mr. O'Neill was an old-style politician and proud of it, a House Speaker comfortable with power, who clung to his brand of liberalism long after it ceased to be fashionable, even among his fellow Democrats.
An early opponent of the Vietnam War, Mr. O'Neill took strong positions on many controversial issues. He was the Congressional leader who pushed hardest for the impeachment of President Richard M. Nixon and later, as Speaker, put his prestige on the line for Congressional reform.
Mr. O'Neill was the Speaker from 1977 to 1987, during the Presidencies of Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, both of whom ran against entrenched Washington officials and considered Mr. O'Neill the ultimate insider.
But although he reached the heights of political power and mingled easily with national and world leaders, Mr. O'Neill was perhaps best known for his advice to colleagues to attend carefully to their constituents, because, as he put it, "All politics is local."
He was a large, joyous, generous-spirited man with a bulbous nose, yellowed white hair that flopped over his forehead and an ever-present cigar. He was a rabid sports fan, frequently attending baseball games and boxing matches, a skilled poker player and a devoted but struggling golfer.
To Mr. O'Neill, who spoke of the Democratic Party with near-religious fervor, the party was the one of the cities, the working people, the poor, the needy, the unemployed, the sick and the disinherited. "And no way are we ever going to let them down," he would insist. He opposed a balanced budget because, he said, it would "dismantle the programs that I've been working for as an old liberal."
When President Reagan persuaded Congress to curtail many of Mr. O'Neill's favorite social programs, the Speaker lamented that the Democrats had been too successful at their work. He said the Democratic programs had created a broad middle class whose members had forgotten the many benefits they had received from government -- in education and housing, for example -- and wanted to pull up the ladder behind them.
Republicans made Mr. O'Neill a target of their 1980 and 1982 campaigns, portraying him as a bloated old pol with outdated liberal ideas. They produced a television commercial that featured an actor who resembled the Speaker laughing off warnings that his car was low on fuel, until the vehicle finally ground to a halt. The announcer then proclaimed, "The Democrats have run out of gas."
Mr. O'Neill remained steadfast. "I haven't changed my philosophy," he frequently told reporters, with whom he met daily.
He made no apologies for the kind of politics he had mastered in Boston. As Speaker, he rewarded friends and punished enemies with the help of a long memory but few grudges.
 
Carter and O'Neill: Different Democrats
 Mr. O'Neill's became Speaker the year Mr. Carter took office as President. About all they had in common was their political party. Mr. Carter, an emotionally taut Georgian with a scant power base among Democrats, had reached the White House as an anti-politician, an outsider who publicly disdained Washington insiders personified by the gregarious Speaker, who had worked his way up from ward politics.
"Our first conversation," the Speaker recalled, "he told me how he had handled the Georgia Legislature, by going over their heads directly to the people."
Mr. O'Neill said he responded by referring to the 289 House Democrats in the majority. "I said: 'Hey, wait a minute. You have 289 guys up there who know their districts pretty well. They ran against the Administration, and they wouldn't hesitate to run against you.
"He said, 'Oh, really?' "
The two men did not speak the same language. Mr. O'Neill said he had once told the President, "Keep your left hand high." But the Speaker found that Mr. Carter was no boxing fan and was unfamiliar with the boxer's classic defensive posture. "He didn't know what I was talking about," Mr. O'Neill said.
But as a loyal Democrat Mr. O'Neill felt morally bound to help Mr. Carter whenever possible. An autographed photograph from the President was inscribed, "To my friend Tip O'Neill, thanks for another lesson in good politics, Jimmy Carter, June 1977."
But in 1980, when the Republicans won the White House and the Senate and cut deeply into the House Democratic majority, the Speaker privately blamed the President, believing him inept.
 
O'Neill and Reagan: Different Irishmen
 Mr. O'Neill never shied from wielding power, although he frequently lamented that the power of the Speaker had declined since the days of Sam Rayburn, the Texas Democrat whose word became law during his 17 years in the post, ending in 1961. That was when a Speaker could get binding commitments from committee chairmen; it was before the diffusion of power that Mr. O'Neill himself worked to bring about.
From 1981 to 1987, Mr. O'Neill led the loyal opposition to President Reagan, a man with whom he shared an Irish heritage, an interest in sports and an outgoing personality. But the two men had a profound philosophical disagreement about government: the Speaker regarded government as the solution to many social problems, as an agent of social change; Mr. Reagan regarded it as a problem in itself, interfering in the lives of Americans and impeding economic and social progress.
The Speaker also found Mr. Reagan to be appallingly ignorant of the intricacies of government; indeed, he called him the most ignorant man who had ever occupied the White House. Publicly, Mr. O'Neill called Mr. Reagan "Herbert Hoover with a smile" and "a cheerleader for selfishness."
Early in his time as Speaker, when his bill for a new House code of ethics was in trouble, he lumbered to the well of the House and cut through the debate on the key provision, a limitation on outside income. The speech was vintage O'Neill.
Sure, he said, he knew what it was to be strapped. Wasn't he the one who had fought for a raise of $12,900 a year in Congressional pay? But in exchange he had promised the American people "the strongest code of ethics that this country has ever seen." The issue, after Watergate, he thundered, was "restoring public confidence in this Congress as an institution, restoring confidence in its membership."
He looked out at an audience that included the 80 Democrats for whom he had campaigned the previous fall, the scores of members he had appointed to the nine select and special committees over which he had jurisdiction, and the more than 200 beneficiaries of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Fund, for which he had been the chairman.
His listeners knew that the Speaker had a great voice in their committee assignments, the scheduling of floor action on bills, the disbursing of campaign money and the small favors that can make or break a Congressional career. Mr. O'Neill called in his chits. The result was a foregone conclusion. The vote was 344 to 79.
Four years later, when 44 Democrats joined in voting to overturn a ruling of the chair, the kind of parliamentary decision that is the lifeblood of the House, Mr. O'Neill wrote them a letter that he was "extremely disappointed" and obliquely warned that "disciplinary measures" were under consideration.
Such measures could affect a member's committee assignments. He added that he felt that such measures were unnecessary. No future Democratic votes against the judgment of the chair were noted.
Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. was born on Dec. 9, 1912, in working-class area of Cambridge, Mass., which later became part of his Congressional district. His father was a member of the Cambridge City Council. His mother died when he was a child, and his father remarried.
He picked up the nickname "Tip" from a baseball player, James Edward O'Neill of the old St. Louis Browns, who had the knack of hitting foul tips until the pitcher walked him. So Mr. O'Neill's boyhood friends gave him the name. The Speaker was an inveterate fan of the Boston Red Sox.
Educated in Roman Catholic schools, he broke into politics at 15, campaigning for Al Smith in his 1928 Presidential campaign against Herbert C. Hoover. "All I knew was that Al Smith was an Irish Catholic and we had been suppressed all our lives," he said.
Four years later, he helped get out the vote for Franklin D. Roosevelt. "You'd have Mrs. Murphy ready to get into an automobile to take her to the polls," he recalled. "And then you'd go to the next house, Mrs. Sweeney, and you'd have the car come for Mrs. Sweeney. We walked the streets to get the votes out."
As a senior at Boston College, Mr. O'Neill lost his first campaign, for the Cambridge City Council, by 150 votes. But he was elected to the Massachusetts House of Representatives in 1936, where he rose to Speaker, and where he remained until 1952 when, he was elected to the United States House.
He won the seat vacated by John F. Kennedy on Kennedy's election to the Senate. It was also the seat once held by James M. Curley, the Boston politician whose career was the basis of the Edwin O'Connor novel "The Last Hurrah."
 
 
Avoiding a Move To Washington
 Mr. O'Neill and his wife, Mildred, decided not to move their family to Washington when Mr. O'Neill was first elected, and they did not go back on this agreement until Mr. O'Neill became Speaker, a quarter century later.
Until then, Mr. O'Neill roomed with Representative Edward P. Boland, Democrat of Massachussetts, his closest friend. Their refrigerator was said to be stocked almost exclusively with beer.
In Washington, Mr. O'Neill became a protege of Representative John McCormack of Massachusetts, then the Democratic whip, who introduced him to the House power structure as part of the informal "board of education" meetings that Speaker Rayburn held after hours for Congressional leaders and friends. By his second term in the House, Mr. O'Neill had won a coveted seat on the Rules Committee.
 
War and Conscience
 Mr. O'Neill's opposition to the Vietnam War in 1967, when he was a leader of the Rules Committee, was a decision affected by the anti-war feelings of his own children (three boys and two girls) as well as among the intellectual communities at Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in his own district. His blue-collar constituents, who made up the bulk of his support, were overwhelmingly in favor of the American role in the war.
But Mr. O'Neill wrote in his autobiography, "Man of the House" (Random House, 1987), that he had come to the conclusion that the conflict was a civil war and that American involvement in it was morally wrong. When President Lyndon B. Johnson called him to the White House to explain his change of position, Mr. O'Neill recalled, he told the President, "In my heart and in my conscience I believe your policy is wrong." Johnson accepted his position, Mr. O'Neill said, when he found out that the Congressman had not changed it for political reasons.
But his opposition to the war did eventually reap some political dividends: he won the trust and support of younger House members who shared his position on Vietnam, and they became important allies as Mr. O'Neill rose in power.
In 1971, having supported Hale Boggs of Louisiana as majority leader, Mr. O'Neill was selected by Mr. Boggs to be majority whip, an appointive post. After Mr. Boggs died in a plane crash in Alaska in 1972, Mr. O'Neill was elected majority leader.
Mr. O'Neill, as the whip under Speaker Carl Albert of Oklahoma, was the Democrats' strong man; he did the difficult things. He was instrumental in bringing changes that stripped the committee chairmen of their autocratic power, and he was the Democratic leader who pushed hardest for the investigation and impeachment of President Richard M. Nixon, who resigned before a vote on impeachment was held.
 
At 64, Speaker, by Acclamation
 Mr. O'Neill was elected Speaker by acclamation in December 1976, when he was 64, and took office the next month. "The wonder of it is that such a decent, compassionate man could rise to the top of a place like this," said Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens.
But Mr. O'Neill was not without lapses of judgment.He was among many House members who accepted favors from Tongsun Park, the South Korean lobbyist and intelligence agent. In 1973 and '74, Mr. O'Neill permitted Mr. Park to sponsor two lavish birthday parties in his honor, thereby bolstering Mr. Park's prestige.
Similarly, Some questioned Mr. O'Neill's judgment when he intervened in an application for Federal money made by James P. Wilmot, who had been chairman of the Democratic Party's Finance Committee.
The Speaker telephoned the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Carla A. Hills, asking when there would be a decision on Mr. Wilmot's request for $2.2 million in annual rent subsidies for a housing project. Such inquiries tend to be viewed as requests for special consideration. In any event, Mr. Wilmot got his subsidies.
 
 
Remaining Neutral As a Kennedy Ran
 Although he had close ties to the Kennedy family, Mr. O'Neill remained neutral in the party's Presidential nomination fight between Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and President Carter in 1980. He played a role behind the scenes at the Democratic National Convention, however, negotiating an agreement that led to Mr. Kennedy's reluctant endorsement of the President.
Until his retirement, the O'Neills maintained their home in Cambridge, enabling the Speaker to keep in touch with the city's intellectual community as well as its neighborhoods. A Saturday morning ritual when Mr. O'Neill was in Cambridge consisted of stops at the Chinese laundry, the Italian food store and the Star Market in Porter Square.
In retirement, Mr. O'Neill divided his time between a house in Harwichport on Cape Cod and an apartment in Washington and spent some holidays at a condominium in Florida.
The Speaker's oldest son and namesake, Thomas P. O'Neill 3d, a former lieutenant governor of Massachusetts, is in public relations. Another son, Christopher, is a Washington lawyer, and a third, Michael, is in business in Cambridge. One daughter, Susan, has her own business in Washington, and another, Rosemary, is a political officer for the State Department.
After suffering colon cancer, which led to a colostomy, Mr. O'Neill made public service advertisements in which he joined athletes and movie stars in talking candidly about having cancer.
Unlike some politicians who amassed a fortune, Mr. O'Neill retired from the Speakership in relatively modest circumstances. His book, "Man of the House," however, written with William Novak, became a best seller that made him financially secure. Mr. O'Neill also made commercials for a credit card company and a motel chain.
Mr. O'Neill's book was a treasure trove of stories, including some about his political campaign for the Cambridge City Council while he was a senior at Boston College. He finished ninth in a field of 60 candidates, of whom the top eight were elected.
The race taught him a lifelong lesson. He had not campaigned in his own neighborhood, which he had taken for granted and where he made a poor showing. In a post-mortem on the campaign, Mr. O'Neill's father told him what he had learned in a lifetime of politics: "All politics is local."
In addition to his children, he is survived by his wife, Mildred, and eight grandchildren.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1182 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON TO PRESS RUSSIA TO USE AID TO ASSIST JOBLESS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
After a long internal debate on Russian policy, President Clinton plans to go to Moscow next week urging continued tough economic reforms, officials said today.
But they added that he will also offer some new ideas about how Western aid can be used to retrain Russian workers and cushion those left unemployed by economic change. 
 Administration officials said they are still thrashing out what sort of programs to propose, as well as whether Washington should lead by example and add more money to the aid pot.
But at a White House lunch today with newspaper columnists, Mr. Clinton left little doubt about where he stood on whether the strong showing by ultranationalists in last month's elections meant the West should urge a slower pace of reform. He said he would tell President Boris N. Yeltsin that Russia needs more reform -- not less -- and more Western help to reduce the political fallout.
 
Thoughts for a Bumper Sticker
 "I am going to Russia to reaffirm the support of the United States, both for democracy and for reform," said Mr. Clinton, who spoke to the journalists after a two-hour meeting with his top advisers. "We were thinking of a slogan today. We were trying to think of what our bumper sticker would be about. Because in reaction to the last election there, there were some people who were questioning whether, well, has reform gone too fast or not fast enough? Or whatever.
"I think our slogan would be, there needs to be more reform and more social service support," he added, "more attempts to build a safety net to deal with the consequences of reform, but not an attempt to slow down the reform effort. More reform, more support."
At the lunch, three days before he embarks on his first European mission, a 10-day journey, Mr. Clinton spoke in detail not only about Russian aid but also about the future of the Atlantic alliance and relations with Eastern Europe.
 
Issue of NATO Expansion
 Mr. Clinton devoted his opening statement to an attempt to assure Eastern Europe of continued support, despite Washington's opposition to immediate NATO membership for Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. He defended Washington's plan for only limited military partnerships between those countries and NATO. And he hinted that Washington was acting at least in part in response to an appeal by Mr. Yeltsin not to isolate Russia with an expanded Western alliance.
"The signal that Yeltsin sent me is, he did not want to feel that Russia was being isolated, was being sort of moved back into a potential enemy status," Mr. Clinton said.
The President said NATO was "reaching out" in a limited way to Eastern European countries because "we don't want them to feel threatened by an eastward pull anymore, but neither do we want to prejudge the future intentions and policies of Russia and other countries in the newly independent states, and especially Ukraine."
He said he believed that Russia and the other former Soviet republics appreciated this cautious approach because they do not want to be condemned to the status of enemies.
 
Integration Into Europe
 "It recognizes that they should be given the opportunity to develop a new sense of their national purpose that is not aggressive and permits them to be a part of an integrated European political economic and strategic system," Mr. Clinton said. "I think strategically that is very important. How do these options that are before us affect Ukraine? How do they affect Kazakhstan? They matter too, and they don't want to be pushed back into some pattern that reflects what was in their past, but may not be what they wish for their future."
Mr. Clinton said he would also use his talks with Western European allies at NATO summit talks to press them to open up their markets more to Eastern European exporters, whose industries are withering for lack of customers right next door.
Since militant nationalists and Communists made a surprisingly strong showing in last month's elections, Administration officials have been reconsidering their approach to Russian aid, with some seeming to hint that maybe the West should ease up on its demands for economic reform.
 
More Harsh Medicine
 In recent days, though, economic experts, particularly Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, have argued that what Russia needs now is to intensify its reform efforts. But, they add, that reform must be better cushioned -- to avoid the sort of political reaction seen in the elections -- by better helping pensioners and Government workers.
In a speech Monday to economists in Boston, Lawrence Summers, Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, alluded to this evolving strategy.
He said it would be "a grave mistake, and not one that anyone in the United States Government intends to make," to think there was some sort of "third way" for dealing with Russian aid -- a way that would make for painless reforms.
Mr. Summers said "there is no viable alternative to the hard work of economic stabilization." He added, though, that while encouraging that hard work, the United States and the West had to insure that their aid dealt "with the dislocations that are inevitably associated with reforms."
 
Talks With Wealthy Allies
 But how will the Administration go about this? In part, Mr. Clinton will offer some new ideas still being thrashed out; in part he will want to hear from Mr. Yeltsin; in part the President and Treasury officials plan intensive discussions with other members of the Group of Seven industrial nations on whether they should give new directives, and possibly new money, to the international institutions working with Russia.
"The first thing to do is actually get the money flowing again," said Jeffrey Sachs, the Harvard University economist, who is advising the Russian Government. "The fact is that, of the $28 billion promised last year by the Group of Seven countries, only about $3 billion of real program support has been delivered. We have to reinvigorate the whole aid process, and begin with a discussion with the Russian Government about how they feel the money should be targeted."
For example, Mr. Sachs said, in order to reduce the deficit, Russia needs to close down many of its inefficient coal mines. One approach would be to offer severance payments and money for relocation or even job retraining, and to pay for it either with aid from the West earmarked for the miners or by rewriting the Russian budget to address the workers' needs and then financing the budget with direct foreign aid.
"To do this without creating a social crisis requires a major job of coordinating, to pull all the pieces together so everyone has an interest in going forward," Mr. Sachs said. "I would compare it to something like the job that Lee Iaccoca did with Chrysler when it was on the verge of bankruptcy. Someone has to coordinate the creditors, the industrialists, the unions, the board of directors -- which in Russia is the Parliament. That is what has been missing.
"That is our role," he added. "The I.M.F. is not Lee Iaccoca."

HEADLINE: IN MESSAGE, CUOMO ECHOES G.O.P. IDEAS

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 5

 BODY:
Sounding election-year themes for a state recovering from a lingering recession, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed today an array of incentives to encourage job growth, including cutting taxes on real-estate developers, corporations and hotels.
In his 12th State of the State Message, Mr. Cuomo made three long-standing Republican themes -- improving the state's business climate, fighting crime and reforming welfare -- the centerpieces of his legislative blueprint for 1994, a year in which he and all 211 members of the state Legislature are up for re-election. Mr. Cuomo has said he will announce by the end of the week whether he will seek a fourth term, and he used his speech today to systematically shore up each of his most distinct political vulnerabilities. [News analysis, page B6.]
 
Allies and Skeptics Switch
 In a political role reversal, Mr. Cuomo's tax-cutting and welfare proposals got a frosty reception from his fellow Democrats who control the Assembly, particularly the Speaker, Saul Weprin, while receiving support from his usual nemesis, the Republican-controlled Senate. Today, Senate Republican leaders praised Mr. Cuomo's speech for embracing ideas they have proposed, even as they chided him for not going far enough. 
 Though Mr. Cuomo offered relatively detailed information about his tax-cutting and anti-crime proposals, his plan to encourage more welfare recipents to work is more long term and is not fully developed.
Departing from the dire economic forecasts of recent State of the State speeches, Mr. Cuomo said today that the improving economy had provided enough tax revenue to justify phasing out or reducing several taxes, many of which had been established over the past four years to plug budget gaps.
Though details about the tax cuts remain unclear, aides to Mr. Cuomo said they could cost the state $500 million or more when fully carried out. However, because some cuts would be phased in, their greatest impact would be after the elections. And in the long run, the aides said, the cuts could lead to increased tax revenues by encouraging business expansion.
As an inducement to development, Mr. Cuomo proposed exempting commercial construction and renovation on property worth more than $1 million that is started before 1996 from the state's real estate gains tax. The 10 percent tax is charged on profits from the sale of commercial property. He also proposed phasing out the state's 5 percent portion of the tax on hotel rooms costing over $100 a night, possibly by the end of 1995.
A third cut proposed by Mr. Cuomo, in the corporate surcharge, would simply reduce a tax that the state was scheduled to eliminate last year but couldn't because of a looming gap in the budget. Mr. Cuomo is considering cutting the tax, which is tacked onto a variety of other state corporate taxes, from 15 to 12.5 percent.
"Here's the message," Mr. Cuomo said. "New York State believes in business; we want the jobs you produce, we want you to do well. And if you're prepared to create jobs for our people, we'll do everything we can to make it worth your while. We need you. We want you."
In his notably cool reaction, Mr. Weprin said the Assembly Democrats are concerned that business tax cuts could lead to a reduction in social services. "The Assembly will not abandon people who need help," Mr. Weprin, a Queens Democrat, said.
While praising many of Mr. Cuomo's proposals, Republican legislative leaders questioned his sincerity, derisively describing his speech as a death-row conversion to conservatism by a liberal Democrat fearful of voters' wrath.
"After 11 years, the Governor has finally embraced much of the Senate Republican agenda to combat crime, revitalize our economy and restore the pride and productivenss that earned New York its reputation as the Empire State," said the Senate majority leader Ralph J. Marino, an Oyster Bay Republican. "The failed policies of the past are now clear to everyone."
 
Change in Welfare Offices
 Mr. Cuomo, hammering at the theme that work can solve many social ills, said he will seek to increase job training and counseling for welfare recipients. And he said he would ask his Commissioner of Social Services to restructure local welfare offices so that they provide job counseling to welfare applicants before approving them for welfare grants.
"Jobs should come first, not welfare," Mr. Cuomo said. "Welfare should be only a last resort."
Mr. Cuomo also proposed a pilot program that would increase welfare grants for parents who keep their children in school and reduce grants to parents whose children drop out. And he called for increasing programs to detect welfare fraud, including expanding a program that requires the fingerprinting of state welfare recipients, most of whom are single males. Currently, the program is being tried in Rockland and Onondaga counties.
In a proposal designed to help the working poor, Mr. Cuomo called for a state income tax credit for an estimated 820,000 low-income families. By 1995, the credit would reduce state taxes to a family with two children and an annual income of $26,000 or less by a maximum of about $300.
At the outset of the 45-minute speech, Mr. Cuomo said crime should be the lawmakers' first priority. He said he will seek legislation mandating life sentences without parole for three-time violent offenders, longer sentences for most violent crimes and "sharp" limitations on parole for sexual offenders. He said he will include $10 million for prison construction in his budget, which he will introduce on Jan. 18.
Mr. Cuomo also proposed several gun-control initiatives, including banning assault weapons, creating special task forces to prosecute gun and drug traffickers and raising the legal age for purchasing a gun from 16 to 18. Following the speech, Mr. Cuomo met with legislative leaders to discuss common ground on crime proposals, particularly a ban on assault weapons, but nothing conclusive resulted from the talks, legislative aides said.
Though Republicans said they support Mr. Cuomo's proposal for limiting parole, they said no anti-crime package can be complete without the death sentence. Mr. Cuomo has vetoed death sentence bills for 11 consecutive years. He did not discuss the death penalty in this year's speech.
Though he usually bridles when called a tax-and-spend liberal, Mr. Cuomo today poked fun at his and the Legislature's taxing proclivities. Referring to a $25 fee that businesses have to pay so they can give their employees their wages in checks, Mr. Cuomo said, "Even for us, that was obnoxious."
