HEADLINE: Bentsen Foresees Rate Rise

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
After a year of touting lower interest rates as an Administration accomplishment that has stimulated the economy, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen predicted today that short-term rates would rise modestly.
Mr. Bentsen refused to say how soon he expected an increase. And he would not say whether he expected the Federal Reserve to move actively to raise them or simply allow the market to push them up, as it has already begun to do. 
 Mr. Bentsen also made an unusually blunt, but unsuccessful, effort to halt the Japanese yen's steady slide against the dollar, which has improved the competitiveness of Japanese exporters at the expense of their American rivals. In a speech at the Brookings Institution here today, the Treasury Secretary called for "exchange rates that will reflect the underlying cost competitiveness of Japan and its trading partners."
 
Reaction to Japanese Economy?
 The yen climbed briefly after his remarks but then resumed its slide. Traders attributed the decline to a lack of investor confidence in Japan's weak economy. [Page D16.]
Most economists have attributed improvement in the United States economy in considerable measure to the current low interest rates, particularly long-term rates. Mr. Bentsen repeated in his Brookings speech his contention that the Administration deserved the credit for the low rates because it had tried to bring down the budget deficit.
Short-term rates have already risen slightly in the last few weeks. The emerging consensus of private economists has been that a further slight increase is likely soon, but would do little damage to the economy.
Asked this morning before his speech whether there was any need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates during the first quarter, Mr. Bentsen responded, "I must say that in our projections we assume that there would be a modest increase in short-term rates, but I must say on the other side of it that inflation has been even better contained than anticipated."
A minute later, he sought to amend his remarks to make clear that the increase might not come in the first quarter. "I said, 'we anticipated a modest increase in short-term rates over a period of time' -- we did not get definitive, I'm not that good on my crystal ball," Mr. Bentsen said.
Officials at the Federal Reserve declined to comment.
 
Stating a Perceived Reality
 The Treasury Secretary was acknowledging the likelihood of higher rates -- which many economists believe to be the natural accompaniment to strong economic growth -- but not advocating them. Nonetheless, he allowed for the first time the possibility that short-term rates would rise this quarter.
On Dec. 19, Mr. Bentsen said that the Administration foresaw a modest increase in short-term rates, but not until after the first quarter of 1994, His remarks were not widely reported. Four days earlier, President Clinton had said "it would be inappropriate" for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.
When Mr. Bentsen predicted last Thursday that the United States economy would grow at a steady and sustainable rate in 1994, he said, "This should allow interest rates to remain relatively low and reduce further the rate of unemployment."
A Treasury Department official who insisted on anonymity said that the Administration was still discouraging the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates. But the department believes that some increase is inevitable anyway.
The Treasury Department has very little direct influence over interest rates. The Federal Reserve guides rates by buying and selling Government securities.
 
Rises Seen in Other Forecasts
 The latest Blue Chip Financial Forecasts, a survey of economists' predictions, estimated that the yield on three-month Treasury bills would edge up to 3.3 percent in the first quarter from 3.15 percent in the previous quarter. The President's Council of Economic Advisers forecast in August that short-term interest rates would average 3.6 percent in 1994, up from 3.1 percent in 1993.
The Treasury Department aide said late this afternoon that Mr. Bentsen's predictions were based on internal department forecasts of interest rates and that the Secretary was anticipating further increases in addition to the slight upward creep of short-term rates in recent weeks.
Mr. Bentsen spoke at Brookings as part of the the Administration's effort to claim much of the credit for economic growth.
"The Administration doesn't believe that it, by itself, was able to bring it all off, but the Administration has certainly had a major influence," he said.

HEADLINE: A.M.A. Found to Donate More to Foes of Its Views

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
The political arm of the American Medical Association gives more money, on average, to Congressional candidates who oppose the doctors' positions on important public health issues than to those who support such positions, a new report says.
The report, published Thursday in The New England Journal of Medicine, concludes that the political action committee affiliated with the association "contributed more frequently and more heavily" to conservative lawmakers, despite the fact that they often opposed the association's positions on issues like tobacco exports and Federal restrictions on abortion counseling. 
 In an interview today, Dr. Steven S. Sharfstein, an author of the report, said the committee, known as Ampac, "inadvertently undermines the public health agenda of the A.M.A." In giving money to members of Congress, Dr. Sharfstein said, "Ampac emphasizes the economic concerns of physicians more than the excellent public health stands of the A.M.A. itself."
 
Comparison of Contributions
 From 1989 to 1992, the study said, the political arm of the association contributed an average of $13,270 to members of the House of Representatives who opposed the association on three major votes, while "members who sided with the A.M.A. on all three votes received an average contribution of $8,800."
The report was written by Dr. Sharfstein and his son, Joshua M. Sharfstein. Dr. Sharfstein is president of a psychiatric hospital in Baltimore, the Sheppard and Enoch Pratt Hospital, and is secretary of the American Psychiatric Association. He has been a member of the medical association for 10 years, but has not given money to Ampac. Joshua Sharfstein, who is a student at Harvard Medical School and has done political work for several Congressional candidates, said he and his father were "progressive Democrats."
Dr. James S. Todd, executive vice president of the association, said that while the findings were interesting, "no credible conclusions" could be drawn because the study was too narrowly focused and did not consider the full range of the association's lobbying and public affairs activities.
Brenda Laukaitis Craine, a spokeswoman for the association, refused to say how Ampac decided on campaign contributions. "It's complicated," she said. "The process involves all state medical societies. The Ampac board has the final say. The board of the A.M.A. is not directly involved."
In an interview, Joshua Sharfstein said: "Ampac's campaign contributions go preferentially to members of Congress who are more conservative, as measured by the ratings of their voting records by the American Conservative Union. Those conservative members are significantly more likely to oppose the A.M.A.'s positions on public health issues."
Joshua Sharfstein said Ampac spread its money broadly, typically donating to more than 80 percent of House members seeking re-election.
The study focused on money given in the campaigns of 1989-90 and 1991-92. It examined votes on three issues: handgun control, use of Federal money to promote foreign sales of tobacco products and a Federal rule banning abortion counseling at family planning clinics that got Federal money.
Campaign contributions by the health care industry have increased sharply, with the likelihood that Congress will pass legislation to revamp the nation's health care system.

The Economy
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said he foresaw an increase in short-term interest rates. But he refused to say when or whether the Fed or market forces would raise them. [Page D1.]
The Administration wants to create a Government-owned corporation like Amtrak to operate the nation's air traffic control system. It will also seek to increase to 49 percent the amount of voting stock that a foreign carrier can own in a U.S. airline. [A16.] 
 Factory orders rose 1.4 percent in November, helped by sales of aircraft, cars, computers and metalworking machinery. [D2.]
 
Companies
A small software developer will introduce a new computer software that acts like a microorganism that can find its own way through the nation's computer networks to carry out useful tasks like booking a flight on an airline's computer system. [D1.]
Fidelity's Capital and Income Fund is the Macy creditor with the most influence, so its manager is being courted by Federated and Dillard in their attempts to gain control of Macy. [D1.]

HEADLINE: Whitman Says Tax Reduction Will Hurt

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY, N.J., Jan. 5

 BODY:
Governor-elect Christine Todd Whitman began talking tonight for the first time about the pain as well as the promise of her campaign pledge to cut taxes and state government.
In the third of her appearances with voter groups the Governor-elect answered questions and took suggestions for an hour on ways to cut income taxes by nearly a third over three years. 
 Tonight she began to note that making good her tax-cut pledge will have its costs. In earlier appearances she had more to say about auditing state performance, freeing local governments and supporting innovation than about the nuts and bolts of cutting spending. Asked when she would be specific, she gave as an answer her inauguration date, Jan. 18, and the date of her first budget message, March 15.
"Well, there is always going to be pain," she said in response to a question from Maggie Benoit, 16, a high school junior from Hillsboro, N.J., about the prospect of state financing cuts forcing local taxes higher. "The state is going to have to impose some discipline on itself, and local government is going to have to do that, too."
Despite this muted warning, Mrs. Whitman maintained the posture of student of government more than governor that she had established in the two earlier sessions. A fourth program will be held in New York City at the studios of WABC radio and will be broadcast as a one-hour call-in session on "The Bob Grant Show" on Thursday after she visits Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City.
 
Criticized During Campaign
 During the campaign, her Democratic opponent, Gov. Jim Florio, frequently criticized Mrs. Whitman for a lack of specifics in her broad tax-cutting program, but each time Mrs. Whitman maintained that she would listen to the people before deciding where the cuts would be made.
A 10 percent cut in the state income tax for each of three years would cost the state about $1.4 billion out of its nearly $16 billion budget. In addition, she has pledged to limit the increase in the state budget to less than the inflation rate.
Throughout the campaign and during the early weeks of her transition, however, Mrs. Whitman refrained from preparing the public for the logic of those numbers. Nearly 10 percent taken out of a budget burdened with a built-in deficit that Mrs. Whitman herself has estimated at $1 billion will require large-scale reordering of state spending, Republican legislators have been warning privately.
Tonight's session was broadcast on Rutgers University's Wednesday night "Caucus: New Jersey" television program.
"Right now we are in a learning process, trying to put the budget together," Mrs. Whitman said. "There are not always going to be popular decisions."
Mrs. Whitman offered her prediction of fiscal stringency early in the one-hour show, but then she showed herself willing to embrace a wide range of popular but budget-draining programs that members of the audience mentioned for her protection.
For example, Mrs. Whitman lamented the lack of adequate financing for the state's community colleges, suggested that students at the state college system be charged on the basis of their ability to pay, promised to maintain the state's Lyme disease prevention program and implicitly called for more money for the state's social programs as a deterrent to crime.
 
Endorses Clinic Program
 Soon afterward, she endorsed a Federal-state program of neighborhood clinics to reduce the use of expensive emergency room services and seemed to urge the state to create a new program:
"Not only do we want to build on that kind of health care, we want to take it further, taking doctors to the people where they work," she said.
Mrs. Whitman made two other ideas more specific: she said she would endorse a law to allow communities to exempt themselves from state-mandated services, like providing 911 emergency telephone service, for which no state funds are appropriated. And she called on the Legislature to attach both a price tag and a source of funds for each spending proposal that it passes.
Mrs. Whitman won general praise from an audience that included high school students, educators, union leaders and a contingent from the Ross Perot grass-roots group, United We Stand, whose spokeswoman, Beverly Kidder, attempted to elicit the Governor-elect's public support for initiative, which allows residents to place measures on the ballot through petition drives, and referendum, which allows citizens to directly vote in laws.
Mrs. Whitman said tonight that she supported the idea, but with some restrictions -- that the ballot questions be limited to three, that full financial disclosures be required to show who is behind the initiatives and that no issue that was defeated could be brought back the next year.

HEADLINE: NATO CLEARS PLAN FOR TASK FORCES

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
NATO officials removed the final barriers today to an American-backed proposal that would change the military alliance's command structure to make it easier for NATO and former Warsaw Pact troops to combine forces to defuse crises both inside and outside Europe.
The plan calls for establishing multinational task forces of NATO and non-NATO troops that would conduct joint military exercises and be ready to rush into action on peacekeeping or relief missions. 
 In interviews today, NATO officials said France had abandoned its last objections to the plan, paving the way for President Clinton and other NATO leaders to approve it when they meet in Brussels early next week.
The Clinton Administration has supported the plan because it furthers its goal of shifting some of the alliance's defense burden to Europe. Also, it will give European nations more flexibility and resources to police their own backyard.
 
Europe Could Act Along
 Under the plan, European nations in NATO could use European troops and NATO resources, like radar and intelligence reports, to try to defuse conflicts in the region while American troops remained out of the mission.
An American official at NATO headquarters said the plan "provides a vehicle that enhances burden sharing by allowing the European members of the alliance to make use of existing NATO command structures and assets to conduct operations in which the United States would not choose to be involved."
The Clinton Administration supports the plan because it discourages the Europeans from setting up a separate multinational force outside the NATO structure -- an idea that made Washington uneasy because it would reduce American influence in Europe. The Bush Administration opposed the plan, believing that it would reduce the American role in NATO.
NATO officials said today that the new strucutre would create "combined joint task forces" involving troops from different branches of the armed services and from different countries. For example, a joint task force might inlclude six Western European NATO members along with Poland and Hungary -- and some officials said that Russia might also be able to take part.
NATO officials said that if the proposal is approved at the summit meeting next week, alliance planners will begin drawing up its details.
 
Warsaw Pact May Join
 American and NATO officials see these forces as a way for former Warsaw Pact nations to cooperate more closely with NATO as part of the Partnership for Peace plan that President Clinton has pushed to tie Eastern European nations closer to NATO. President Lech Walesa of Poland and other Eastern European leaders have urged instead that NATO members grant them immediate membership in the alliance.
In many ways, the plan caps off efforts begun by the Bush Administration two years ago to develop ways to make NATO more responsive to crises.
"The plan institutionalizes a more flexible way of employing allied forces," one official said, adding that the alliance's slow, clumsy response in Bosnia was due in part to NATO's inflexible structure.
Even though some NATO countries might not take part in a specific task force action, the North Atlantic Council, with 16 member countries, would have to approve such an action before it was carried out.
"It will mean less dependence on U.S. involvement all the time, but will do so without diminishing the core functions of the alliance in maintaining the collective defense of its members," one Pentagon official said.
The plan helps satisfy a desire among France and other European nations for Europe to establish a more independent defense identity.
Nonetheless, French officials were at first uncomfortable with the plan because they were eager to set up a large separate military force under the command of the Western European Union. France, Germany and Belgium have already set up a small Eurocorps, based in Strasbourg.
But Western officials said France was forced to abandon its vision of a much larger force because of the tremendous cost at a time it is weighed down by recession and budget deficits.

HEADLINE: Mayors in Florida Demand More State Help on Crime

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 5

 BODY:
Alarmed at what they described as the "explosive growth" of violent crime throughout Florida and the damage to the state's reputation, mayors and police chiefs from six of Florida's seven largest cities met here today for a "safe city summit" and called on the state government to mete out harsher punishment to habitual criminals.
"We have reached a point of exhaustion," said Mayor Ed Austin of Jacksonville, the host of the one-day conference that was also attended by officials from Fort Lauderdale, Miami, Orlando, St. Petersburg and Tampa. 
 Speaking for the group, Mr. Austin demanded that the state increase its prison capacity by at least 50 percent. Failure to do so, he said, would mean that "we are aiding and abetting criminals."
 
Plan for Legislature
 The meeting came after a recent series of widely publicized crimes, especially against visitors, that have given Florida an image of danger and lawlessness. In little more than a year, the state has been shaken by sniper attacks on motorists in Jacksonville, the racially motivated burning of a black tourist outside Tampa and the killings of 10 foreign tourists in locations as far apart as South Florida and the Panhandle.
At the end of today's session, the officials drew up a joint resolution to take to the Legislature. It said construction of 25,000 new prison beds would prevent criminals from being released early to ease prison crowding, which has become a severe problem here. It said the cost would be a maximum of $375 million but did not address where the money was to come from. Mayor Austin suggested shifting monies in the existing budget and said taxpayers would gladly pay extra if they knew the money was going to build prisons.
The resolution also called for legislation to "grant a broader range of sentencing discretion" to juvenile-court judges and to eliminate all sentencing guidelines for adult offenses, with the result that sentences over all would be tougher.
"We can't be bluffing," said Mr. Austin, a former prosecutor. "We are now bluffing. We have got to have enough prison and juvenile beds to return integrity to the criminal justice system" and convince habitual offenders that they will indeed be punished for crimes they commit.
 
Promise of Lobbying
 The Legislature met in November for a special session that was devoted in large part to the crime problem, especially among juveniles, but lawmakers made little headway in their discussions of constitutionality, cost and efficiency. The Legislature's regular session is scheduled to begin next month, with many of the same issues expected to dominate the agenda.
"We're personally going to attend the session of the Legislature" to push the package agreed upon today, Mayor Steve Clark of Miami said. The mayors will be able to exert more influence on lawmakers and hold them accountable to voters, Mr. Clark said, because they are, for the first time, united on how to fight crime.
Although mayors in Florida meet periodically to discuss common problems, the conference today was the first time officials of largest cities have gathered solely to discuss crime. Their joint initiative is also unusual by national standards, even though city officials in states as far afield as Massachusetts and California have made tentative efforts to speak collectively to their state legislatures.
Though national crime statistics for 1993 are not yet available, Florida has in recent years had the highest crime rate of the 50 states. In addition, according to 1992 statistics of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Dade County, which includes Miami, had the highest crime rate among all metropolitan areas nationwide of more than 500,000 people, with a total of 12,336 serious crimes per 100,000 residents, more than twice the national average.
Two other counties immediately north of Dade, Broward and Palm Beach, also rank in the top 10 of serious crimes in urban areas. New York City is 10th, with a crime rate of 8,491 serious crimes per 100,000 people.
 
'Bleeding to Death'
 "When you have a state that leads the country in crime rates, you're hemorrhaging," Mayor David Fischer of St. Petersburg said in explaining the stimulus for today's meeting. "When you're bleeding to death, you have to put a tourniquet on it, and that's what we're doing today."
The mayors openly acknowledged that another reason for their meeting was the need to fight the public relations disaster their state has suffered as a result of its high crime rate. Both in this country and abroad, magazine, television and newspaper reports have portrayed Florida as "a state of fear," even though the number of visitors slightly increased in 1993.
"We're in the business of image management for our cities and our state," said Mayor Glenda Hood of Orlando, which brags that it is the world's most popular tourist destination. "There's a perception problem that's become reality."
Mayor Austin of Jacksonville added that Florida's economic well-being depended on its ability to be seen as "a good place to come to and visit and trade with." And, he added, "you can't do that if you are a crime center."

Fighting Crime in California
 SACRAMENTO, Calif. Jan. 5 (AP) -- In his annual address to a joint session of the State Legislature, Gov. Pete Wilson today proposed several anti-crime measures, including a $2 billion bond issue to build six new state prisons.
Mr. Wilson, a Republican, also requested mandatory life sentences for rapists, child molesters, arsonists and felons caught with a gun. In addition, he proposed doubling prison terms for two-time felons and putting three-time felons behind bars for life.

HEADLINE: Admiral to Visit Hanoi, as Relations Improve

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5

 BODY:
In another sign of improving ties between Hanoi and Washington, Adm. Charles R. Larson, commander of United States forces in the Pacific, will visit Hanoi this month, the highest-ranking American military officer on active duty to go to Vietnam since the war in Southeast Asia ended in 1975.
Admiral Larson, a four-star officer based in Hawaii, is to go to Vietnam on Jan. 16 for three days to review the work of American and Vietnamese specialists investigating the fate of missing Americans. Admiral Larson is also expected to meet with high-ranking officials in the Foreign Ministry. 
 The Administration is moving toward easing the trade embargo against Hanoi, and has conditioned a relaxation of the embargo on resolving the fate of more than 2,000 servicemen who did not return from the Vietnam War.
An upbeat assessment from a senior commander like Admiral Larson that Vietnam is cooperating fully would provide the Administration with a defense against complaints that could come from veterans' groups that oppose closer ties to Hanoi.
As a candidate, Bill Clinton promised that he would not lift the embargo until Hanoi made a "full accounting" of missing Americans. But Mr. Clinton eased the sanctions slightly last September when he allowed American companies to bid for projects in Vietnam financed by international lending institutions.
The admiral's visit will come a month after Winston Lord, the Assistant Secretary of State for Asia, returned from a trip to Southeast Asia. Mr. Lord argued in favor of immediate action to ease the embargo to reward Hanoi for its help in resolving the M.I.A. issue.
Admiral Larson, a former submarine captain who served as President Richard M. Nixon's naval aide during the Vietnam War, will meet with American civilian and military investigators in Hanoi and with specialists excavating crash sites and pouring over archives in various parts of the country.
His visit coincides with the largest field inquiry the United States and Vietnam have conducted together since Washington began sending investigators to Vietnam in 1988. The American team of 84 specialists, including archeologists and linguists, intends to investigate as many as 89 cases and excavate as many as 13 sites, the Pentagon said in a statement.
There are 2,239 Americans unaccounted for in Southeast Asia. Of those, 1,648 were lost in Vietnam.

HEADLINE: A New Bradhurst;
Harlem Trades Symbols of Decay for Symbols of Renewal

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
On West 145th Street, opposite an uneven commercial row of boarded-up stores, a gas station and a thriving burger shop, four sand-colored buildings stand waiting for new occupants. Their bricks are scrubbed clean, six stories of brand-new windows sparkle underneath sculpted moldings and green marble glows around the lobby entrances.
The buildings, vacant for years, are at the heart of Bradhurst, a 40-square-block neighborhood in north Harlem. The neighborhood became a symbol of the decay that has blighted Harlem for decades, with some areas looking as if they were reduced to rubble by shelling. 
 But the rehabilitated buildings are signs of a new Bradhurst. Families will be moving into the 236 apartments this month, completing the first phase of the largest neighborhood redevelopment project in the city's history. The plan calls for more than 2,200 units of mixed-income housing, a community center and a new commercial base -- and, eventually, a use for every vacant building and lot in the area.
For decades much of the bustle and vitality that made Harlem a center of black America was lost, as people left and buildings fell apart, but it is slowly returning with a burst of construction in Bradhurst and elsewhere.
 
Making Comebacks
 "In 26 years of working here, this is the first time I feel we have gotten a little bit ahead of the deterioration," said Wyatt Tee Walker, pastor of Canaan Baptist Church, which has almost 600 units of housing built or under construction in Harlem.
Many projects like Bradhurst have been on the drawing boards for years, taking shape in the Koch administration but becoming reality under Mayor David N. Dinkins. Neighborhoods in the South Bronx, East Brooklyn and southern Queens, as well as Harlem, have been revitalized with new housing and new residents, families bringing life to long-silent streets.
But there is uncertainty about the future of such projects under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who comes to office facing a budget gap of more than $2 billion in the fiscal year that begins July 1.
"Koch and his people were not unsupportive," said Canon Frederick B. Williams, chairman of the board of Harlem Churches for Community Improvement. "They were supportive, just at a minimal level. They said, 'Here's a little crumb.' David Dinkins came in and said, 'I know you can serve a banquet.'
"Now, if I'm to continue the metaphor, we would like for the new Mayor to let us serve coffee and dessert."
 
Vacant City-Owned Buildings
 More than 6,000 units of housing have been completed in Harlem since 1989 or are under construction, most of them rehabilitated tenements or walk-ups. In Harlem, as in many of the other neighborhoods, the revitalization has extended to a web of community organizations, which have come together and strengthened in their pursuit of a reborn community.
The Bradhurst plan, for instance, is being overseen by the Consortium for Central Harlem Development, a group of 11 community organizations representing religious, development, real estate and business interests.
Harlem has the highest concentration of vacant city-owned buildings in the city, buildings whose owners defaulted on taxes after the migration out of Harlem in the 1960's and 70's. About 3,000 units in central Harlem are scheduled for development. Another 2,800 units in city-owned vacant buildings are not yet committed for rehabilitation. And those numbers do not take into account the hundreds of privately owned vacant or substandard buildings or the vacant lots, which comprise 12 percent of the land in central Harlem. The potential for growth is high, but so is its cost.
With the new wave of building, Harlem began to chip away at the trends it has been mired in since the 1970's, the declining population and the shrinking housing stock. One by one, and even in large chunks, abandoned buildings are being rehabilitated and filled with families, most of them poor but more and more working and earning moderate incomes.
 
Rebirth in the 80's
 Harlem's rebirth began in the last years of the Koch administration, when the Department of Housing Preservation and Development initiated a 10-year, $5.1 billion capital plan for revitalizing neighborhoods in 1986. By the late 1980's, construction began on what were perhaps the first housing units created with city money in Harlem in a generation.
Mayor Dinkins and his administration accelerated the housing boom, spending more than $200 million in central Harlem over four years, and brought more community groups into the process. Under Mr. Dinkins and his Housing Preservation and Development Commissioner, Felice L. Michetti, the city began a variety of new programs citywide that allowed community-based organizations to build more easily, either by developing projects themselves or by acting as community sponsor, with substantial say in the final product.
The city also opened the planning process, working with community organizations and the local community boards to develop zoning and development plans that they felt would help their neighborhoods.
"The efforts, particularly in a couple of areas, started back in the Borough President's office," when Mr. Dinkins held that position, said Bill Lynch, a former Deputy Mayor and campaign manager for Mayor Dinkins. "It is all part of what I would call a comprehensive effort to bring community development up there."
 
Extra Effort
 Bradhurst is the largest but by no means the only project being developed in Harlem. The Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce has finished the first phase of Strivers Center, named after the historic Striver's Row district, which is nearby. The mixed residential and commercial project will include a row of nightclubs, restaurants and a Jazz Hall of Fame. A Third World Trade Center, which would combine a hotel with offices for African and Caribbean countries, is being planned for 125th Street and Lenox Avenue.
But Bradhurst exemplifies the community effort that has gone into rebuilding Harlem. The Consortium and its executive director, Todd Jones, have tried to include the community in their planning, making sure that services are available for those who need them and that the buildings' designs are attractive and convenient. They fought for extra city money to install elevators, for instance, because they realized how difficult it was for a mother to climb up four or five floors with a few children and a load of groceries.
The first apartments are for low- and moderate-income families, as well as 16 studios for artists. Rents will range from $350 a month for a one-bedroom apartment for a low-income tenant or family to $675 for a three-bedroom apartment for a moderate-income family. The tenants will be chosen by city lottery, with 30 percent of the apartments reserved for Harlem residents.
They also used the project to bring jobs to the area. Most of the architects, engineers, contractors and their workers are black or Hispanic. Some are local untrained workers whose training the groups provided.
 
'Protect Investment'
 But the outlook for plans like Bradhurst is uncertain, at least according to Kathy Wylde, who served on one of Mr. Giuliani's housing transition panels. Although the future phases of the plan call for home-ownership opportunities and more private investment, the first phase alone cost the city more than $24 million. One estimated the ultimate cost to the city at $163 million. And with a multibillion-dollar budget shortfall, that type of city investment will be hard to come by.
"The city budget was going to be severely constrained no matter who was mayor, and there is every indication that the capital budget programs are likely to suffer," said Ms. Wylde, the president of the New York City Housing Partnership. "The kind of model that was used in Bradhurst is not going to be continued or replicated on any large scale."
Deborah Wright, the Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, said the new administration was considering its role in Harlem. "The Harlem community is important to the city," she said. "Obviously the city has made a huge commitment there. We will be looking at ways to do everything we can to protect that investment."
As a sort of insurance policy against severe budget cuts or indifference from City Hall, many Harlem leaders are looking to Washington, both to the Clinton Administration and to their most powerful political force, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Harlem.
 
Urban Empowerment Zone
 Some community leaders are applying for the area to be designated an urban empowerment zone, under legislation that Congressman Rangel wrote and with his strong support. If Harlem is one of the 10 areas selected, it will receive $100 million over two years, offsetting a loss of city money and, they hope, forcing the city to continue its commitment to an area in the national spotlight.
"If you can keep people off welfare, working, off the streets and paying taxes, that's a hell of a lot better than abandoned buildings and people on welfare and in the streets," Mr. Rangel said. "That's what we've been able to do with our abandoned buildings. If Giuliani is nearly as intelligent as his supporters claim, he should move forward."
Not everyone involved in development in Harlem is despairing at the change in administration. Evelyn King, the founder of the United Black Street Front Association, said she had found little support under the Dinkins administration for creating low-cost co-ops or condominiums for working families, who do not qualify for many public projects but cannot afford market rents.
 
Community on the Move
 "People love this community and they have to leave because they cannot afford to live here," said Ms. King, one of Mr. Giuliani's few vocal supporters in Harlem and one of two black members of his transition council. "We need housing that working people can afford to live in."
But for many community leaders, the Dinkins administration was a known and supportive quantity. Until they learn about the Giuliani camp, they can only hope their own strength is sufficient.
"I am not optimistic concerning the political situation," said the Rev. William James, chairman of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation and of the Consortium. "But I am optimistic concerning the community itself and what it has come together to do. I don't think whoever was elected could stop that."

HEADLINE: Francis Ferguson, Insurer's Chairman In 80's, Dies at 72

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Francis Eugene Ferguson, retired chairman of Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Phoenix. He was 72 and had homes in Scottsdale, Ariz., and Milwaukee.
He had had a long respiratory illness, the company said. 
 Mr. Ferguson was elected president and trustee of Northwestern Mutual in 1967 and named chief executive the following year. He became chairman in 1980 and served as both chairman and chief executive until 1983. He retired as chairman in 1985 and from the board in 1991.
Under his stewardship, Northwestern Mutual's assets more than doubled to more than $13 billion in 1983 from $5.7 billion in 1968. Most recently, the company posted assets of $35.7 billion.
"As C.E.O., he successfully led the company through the turbulent economy of the 1970's and early 1980's," said James D. Erickson, president and chief executive of Northwestern Mutual. "He also played a leadership role in the insurance industry as it coped with the effects of runaway inflation."
 
Civic Projects
 As a civic leader, Mr. Ferguson helped to invigorate the Wisconsin State Fair, bring the baseball Brewers to Milwaukee and revitalize downtown around Grand Avenue. He was a past campaign chairman for United Way, president of the Milwaukee Redevelopment Corporation and board chairman of the state fair.
He was born in Batavia, N.Y. In World War II, he served in the Army Air Forces, reaching the rank of captain. Piloting a B-17 bomber, he was shot down over Schweinfurt, Germany, and spent 19 months in a prisoner-of-war camp. After the war, he returned to Michigan State University and received a degree in agricultural economics in 1947.
He joined Northwestern Mutual in 1951 as an economic specialist in the mortgage-loan department.
Mr. Ferguson is survived by his wife of 48 years, Patricia Reddy Ferguson; two daughters, Susan Bonneau of Milwaukee and Penny Pratt of Hastings, Neb., and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Outflanking G.O.P.

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 5

 BODY:
By calling for tax cuts, a crackdown on crime and a welfare program that emphasizes work, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, once the darling of liberal Democrats, sought today to outflank the Republicans who want to hang him this election year from the twin nooses of joblessness and crime.
Days before he may announce a bid for re-election, the Governor used his 12th State of the State Message to systematically shore up each of his most distinct political vulnerabilities. In each case, he anticipated the criticisms capable of damaging him most severely and developed proposals to undercut them. 
 It was a demonstration of the political art of boxing one's opponents. But the larger issue remains whether this year's maneuvering will dazzle voters enough to obscure the perceived shortcomings in an 11-year record.
"It will take more than one speech to move the public's perception," said Assemblyman John J. Faso, a Republican from Columbia County and a frequent critic of the Governor.
 
Prose Instead of Poetry
 Emblematic of Mr. Cuomo's approach today was his opening. Sensitive to the criticism that his leadership has been more poetry than substance, he stated from the start that this speech would be all prose (even if he could not resist quoting a master poet to make the point).
"This I think is not a time for sweet recitations," Mr. Cuomo said. "Shakespeare said it best: action is eloquence. And this is surely a time for action."
Then Mr. Cuomo moved quickly to combat the notion that he is soft on crime, a side-effect of his firm stance against the death penalty. He proposed toughening penalties for violent criminals, hiring more state troopers and placing strict controls on guns.
Mr. Cuomo's emphasis on anti-crime legislation has sent Republican state senators scurrying to reclaim an issue they traditionally have owned.
Shortly after the Governor finished speaking, members of the State Senate's Republican majority met behind closed doors to discuss Mr. Cuomo's proposal to ban assault weapons, a bill they killed last year. They emerged to say their discussion was inconclusive, but they clearly feel public pressure for action against the deadly weapons as well as political pressure to prevent Mr. Cuomo from claiming the issue as his own.
 
Anti-Welfare Symbolism
 To rebut Republican charges that Mr. Cuomo's New York is "the Cadillac of welfare states," the Governor said in his speech that the state should exhaust efforts to find jobs for welfare applicants before allowing them on the rolls. And in a proposal that carries strong anti-welfare symbolism, he called for expanding a pilot program that requires welfare recipients in two counties to be fingerprinted as a protection against fraud.
In New York, fingerprinting has been the most emotional issue in the welfare debate, even though it is not nearly as punitive as measures in other states. Assembly Democrats fought the pilot project fiercely when it was enacted two years ago, saying it seemed to equate welfare recipients with criminals. They labeled its Republican supporters as welfare bashers.
But in an interview last week Mr. Cuomo disagreed with that notion. "I do not have the same conceptual concerns that some others do that this is somehow demeaning," he said.
Perhaps most significantly today, Mr. Cuomo offered himself so effusively as a new friend of big business that the formal response of Daniel Walsh, president of the Business Council of New York State, consisted of only one sentence: "Happy days are near again."
Rather than using his speech to honor an individual, as he did two years ago with the former hostage Terry Anderson, Mr. Cuomo paid tribute today to three New York companies -- Corning, Kodak and Carrier -- for recent technological innovations.
 
Reductions in Taxes
 Mr. Cuomo's historic weakness with the business community has been taxes. Although the Senate Republicans have approved every increase in taxes and fees enacted in the Cuomo years, the Republicans have scored political points over the years by blaming Mr. Cuomo for the state's forbidding tax environment.
The Governor tried to take that issue away today by proposing reductions in many of the taxes and fees that he and the Legislature have raised to fill the state's recession-era budget gaps. He called for cutting the corporate tax surcharge, phasing out the hotel tax, declaring a two-year moratorium on the real-property-gains tax and reducing a number of nuisance fees.
At one point in the speech, Mr. Cuomo seemed to acknowledge that the Senate Republicans have previously proposed many of the measures he endorsed today, particularly the cuts in business taxes and fees.
"No new taxes, no new business fees," he said, glancing impishly at the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino. "Read Ralph's lips."
 
Resolving Differences
 And Mr. Marino, like many of his members, said Mr. Cuomo sounded like a born-again Republican. "It seems he has resolved our differences concerning a candidate for governor in 1994," Mr. Marino joked. "I certainly would endorse the present governor for our own candidacy. It sounded like a speech that could have been written for me and any other Republican running for high office in this state. The problem is it took him 11 years to get the message."
In fact, many Capitol observers said, it is not just that the Governor has moved but that the Republicans have as well. They have dropped their insistence on major cuts in welfare spending and have abandoned calls for some of the most punitive measures against welfare recipients. For the first time, they are considering a ban on assault weapons.

HEADLINE: Fare Cards Make Debut In Subways

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO

 BODY:
The subway token has mingled with coins on dresser tops and in the purses and pockets of New Yorkers for 40 years. But today it moves a bit closer to extinction as the Transit Authority begins to sell electronic fare cards in the first two stations of its sprawling subway system, the nation's largest.
The introduction of automatic fare collection, starting with the Whitehall Street station on the N and R lines and the Wall Street station on the 4 and 5 lines, both in lower Manhattan, brings New York City into the company of other major cities, from Washington to London, that have long used cards instead of coins or tokens. Officials say it will eventually lead to fundamental changes in the transit system, making fare purchases quicker and more convenient and paving the way for discounts, monthly passes and other fare incentives intended to lure more riders.
 
69 Stations by April
 Between now and April, 69 of the busiest stations in the system will activate the sophisticated new turnstiles equipped with fare card machines. The remaining 400 stations will start offering the cards in phases, but not until early 1995 because officials say they need a year to work out possible problems in the technology. 
 The 3,650 buses operated by the Transit Authority will also be outfitted with the card readers during that time, enabling riders to use the MetroCard, as the thin plastic card is called, on both subways and buses. The entire network should be in place by the end of 1997, when the token should finally become an urban relic.
"It's a new era for our customers," said Peter E. Stangl, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which oversees the Transit Authority. "It opens up the possibility for fare structures that over time will help us increase our ridership, which is why we're in business."
The automatic fare collection system making its debut today has been studied, criticized, lobbied for and delayed for more than a decade. At a cost of nearly $700 million, it is one of the biggest undertakings in the 90-year history of the subway system and one on which officials are pinning lofty goals, from improving the environment by curbing car emissions to improving the economy by lifting the region's traffic burden.
 
$5 Increments
 Initially, the cards will be encoded in $5 increments, with amounts ranging from $5 to $80. Each time a passenger swipes the card through the electronic turnstile slot, a $1.25 fare will be deducted from the magnetic stripe and the machine will flash the amount left on the card. Once the value is depleted, the passenger will be able to re-use the card, buying more rides from a token clerk who will simply register a new dollar amount.
About half the stations in the subway system have been outfitted with the new turnstiles, which have both a slot for fare cards and a slot for tokens and are also designed to foil fare beaters. But upgrading the power supply and installing the electronics is a slow process.
Transit officials expect that only 8 percent of the riders who pass through the first 69 stations will buy the cards because most people will still need tokens for all the stations that do not yet accept fare cards. But financing is already approved for the switch to automated fare collection, and officials say the program's future doesn't hinge on how many riders participate at first.
Later this year, the M.T.A. plans to introduce the first of what it hopes will be a package of discounts, giving passengers a couple of extra rides, for instance, on a large fare purchase. When more of the system is outfitted with the electronic readers, the agency will be in a better position to offer monthly passes for unlimited rides at a set price, and free bus-to-subway transfers, two incentives urged by Mr. Stangl and supported in principle by the M.T.A. board.
There is also discussion by M.T.A. officials of off-peak discounts and weekly passes. But the agency says it will not offer varying rates for different distances traveled, as Washington's system does, because passengers would have to swipe cards through the turnstiles on their way in and out, slowing traffic in subway stations to a crawl.
 
Single Paper Fares
 The M.T.A. assumes that many riders will buy their fares in bulk as more and more stations offer the cards. However, the system will still need to accommodate passengers who want a single fare, and those cards will probably be made of paper rather than plastic, officials say.
Transit advocates were pleased about the start of automatic fare collection but raised concerns about whether the discount for monthly passes will be big enough to be attractive. The Straphangers Campaign, a transportation watchdog group that had been promoting fare cards since 1980, believes there should be a substantial discount to attract new passengers to a subway system that has lost half its ridership in the last four decades.
Joseph G. Rappaport, coordinator for the Straphangers Campaign, said a monthly pass that sold for the price of 40 trips, or $50 at the current fare, would win new passengers who use the subway to commute to work, since evening and weekend trips would in effect be free.
He fears that the M.T.A. will price the monthly passes in the $60 to $75 range. "They believe that some riders will find it more convenient to buy the electronic equivalent of a 10-pack of tokens, rather than the 10-pack itself," he said. "That's fine. But you don't spend $700 million for that. What you do is figure out ways of getting more people."
The M.T.A. is now studying how to price the monthly passes, as well as what incentives to offer. Its goal is to maximize ridership without severely hurting revenue. Increased ridership would offset the cost of a discount somewhat, but there could still be a significant gap, officials say.
Bernard Cohen, director of policy and planning for the M.T.A., said the agency wanted the package of discounts and incentives to yield a "5 to 10 percent increase" in riders. Average weekday ridership is now 3.4 million on the subways and 1.25 million on the buses.
 
No Rush at First
 With only a fraction of the system starting up this spring, passengers may not rush to buy the fare cards. "It's true that the faster you roll out a system, the quicker you'll get adoption," said Russ Broshous, president of the M.T.A. Card Company, the agency established to establish automatic fare collection. "But given the starkness of the change, we felt that we should be prudent and make sure that it runs well."
That could prove to be a challenge. Other cities experienced technical problems upon start-up of their automatic fare collection, with the machines not reading the cards properly. A critical report issued last year by the New York State Comptroller's Office challenged the claims made by the Transit Authority as to the durability of the card and the accuracy of the fare card machines.

 These stations will begin taking automated fare cards by April:

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Fall Sharply on Long Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Government securities fell sharply yesterday, with investors nervous over the inflationary implications of continuing economic growth.
The skittishness was heightened by a jump in oil prices, the Government's report that factory orders rose in November for the fourth straight month and comments by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen that he expected short-term interest rates to rise. 
 Bond traders were already wary ahead of the scheduled release tomorrow of data on employment for December, which could indicate strong economic expansion that might spill over into the first quarter and prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to head off a resurgence in inflation.
 
Longer Yields Rise
 While short-term rates fell slightly yesterday, yields of longer maturities rose, erasing the price gains made in Tuesday's rally. The price of a 30-year bond fell by 24/32 , to 981/32 , and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.40 percent, from 6.35 percent on Tuesday.
Mr. Bentsen, in a speech at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said that the Administration expected a modest increase in short-term rates. He did not make clear whether moves by the Fed would cause them to rise or whether they would be pushed up by market forces.
But Mr. Bentsen also said inflation was "even better contained than anticipated."
That view was shared by Thomas H. Hoenig, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, Mo. In a television interview yesterday, he cautioned against assuming that faster growth would necessarily generate higher inflation.
Analysts at MMS International said Mr. Hoenig's statements were consistent with their own: that an imminent tightening in monetary policy by the central bank was unlikely. But, they added, a move to raise short-term interest rates late in the first quarter or early second quarter is probable.
 
Narrow Range Seen
 Analysts expect the market will trade in a narrow range with a negative bias until the December employment report tomorrow. Until then, most investors are likely to trade cautiously, not prepared to make any major commitment at this time, they said.
Expectations are for nonfarm job growth of 215,000 in December, with expectations for the unemployment rate to rise to 6.5 percent, from 6.4 percent in November.
Maureen Allyn, the chief economist at Scudder, Stevens & Clark, said the 1.6 percent gain in factory orders in November was not unexpected. "Nonetheless," she added, "it was a good strong report and confirmed other data seeing a lot of production strength."
"This is the time to buy long bonds," she continued, "because this number -- factory orders -- is not a precursor of what is to come, but a confirmation of past strength."
A rise in heating oil prices because of cold weather contributed to weakness in government bond prices yesterday. Traders said the February futures contract for a barrel of light crude rose above $15 for the first time in almost a month.
 
Tax-Exempt Market
 In the municipal market, the New Jersey Building Authority competitively priced $310.1 million of tax-exempt state building revenue bonds, awarding the issue to Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Serial bonds were priced to yield from 3.25 percent in 1996 to 5.30 percent in 2017 through 2019, with the bonds rated Aa by Moody's Investors Service and AA- by Standard & Poor's.
Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, in a letter to the National League of Cities, responded to the league's request that the S.E.C. delay consideration of the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board's proposed Rule G-37 placing restrictions on political contributions by underwriting firms. The league asked that it be considered after the November elections.
The S.E.C. chairman said he was disappointed by the league's request and could not see a reason why "we should permit the continuation of practices which, at the least, raise serious conflicts of interest."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hits Its Highest Level In Nine Months Against Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday to its highest levels against the Japanese yen in nearly nine months as the market shrugged off comments by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen that appeared aimed at restraining its rise against the yen.
The dollar was mixed against other currencies. 
 Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery, the most active futures contract, fell $3, to $392.10 an ounce.
The dollar rose against the yen during early trading after reportes of comments by an unidentified Japanese official saying the dollar should rise to 115.00 yen. But it plunged after Mr. Bentsen said that a weaker yen was not "an acceptable way out of recession for Japan."
In New York, the dollar dipped to about 112.35 yen, but investors quickly snapped it up, which drove it to finish at 113.07 yen, up from 112.65 on Tuesday.
"As much as the Administration tries to knock it down with these statements, it bounces back immediately," said Bob Lynch, currency analyst at MMS International.
And Hubert Pedroli, manager of foreign exchange for Credit Suisse in New York, said, "Nobody's got any confidence in what's going on in Japan."
American officials are concerned that a weaker yen will make Japanese exports cheaper, increasing their sales to countries like the United States. That, in turn, would aggravate the huge American trade deficit with Japan.
Last spring, American officials helped drive up the value of the yen by saying it ought to be stronger. But now the Japanese economy is in such poor shape that traders are no longer as concerned that United States authorities will act to push up the yen.
Paul Alley, an associate at Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd. in New York, said the difference between the strengthening American economy and the ailing Japanese economy was "telling people right now, 'You've got to buy dollars.' "
Investors were also concerned about political instability in Japan, he said.
The dollar also rose in New York to 1.7405 German marks, from 1.7355 on Tuesday. The British pound rose to $1.4875 from $1.4858.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Making a case for regional banks as an undervalued segment.

BYLINE: By Kenneth N. Gilpin

 BODY:
INVESTORS looking for value in the stock market might do worse than consider regional banks.
Shares in many of these stocks have been battered in recent months on fears that rising interest rates and a recovering economy will lead to a repetition of the bad lending judgments that got banks in so much trouble in the late 1980's. 
 But analysts say the risks are overstated and that compared with the rest of the Standard & Poor's 500 index, regional bank stocks are selling at their lowest levels since 1990.
"There have been three years since 1956 when regional bank stocks were selling at these sorts of levels," Elaine M. Garzarelli, a stock market strategist at Lehman Brothers, said.
"During those periods, relative earnings momentum slowed for the group, but their stock prices advanced significantly because the group represented great historical value," she said. "We believe the current period resembles those of 1972, 1976 and 1990, and predict that current valuations will produce superior price performance."
Last month Ms. Garzarelli put out a favorable report on the 17 stocks that make up the S.& P. 500 regional bank group, a list including the Banc One Corporation, Fidelity Bancorp, Nationsbank, Fleet Financial Group and Wells Fargo & Company.
Ms. Garzarelli must have faith in history and in the ability of investors to recognize value, because according to Lehman's own estimates, regional bank earnings growth will slow quite significantly this year from the rapid pace achieved in 1993.
In the coming 12 months, the firm estimates, the regional banks in the S.& P. index will see earnings rise by 4.8 percent, compared with an estimated 37.9 percent increase for all of 1993.
Stewart J. Pillette, a former chairman of the stock selection committee at Drexel Burnham Lambert who now heads his own investment management company in Oakland, Calif., said regional banks not only looked attractive because of their valuations compared with the rest of the market, but for fundamental reasons as well.
"The worry is that in a rising economy, banks, who for the past few years have been making no-risk loans to the Government through their purchases of Treasury securities, will make loans to the real world," Mr. Pillette said.
"But if interest rates rise, that means there will be more demand for money. I see that as healthy for banks. I think they will look really good as investments, not trades, for the next six months, and maybe longer."
Of the 25 stocks cited by Mr. Pillette on Jan. 1 as representing good value, three -- the First Union Corporation, Suntrust Banks and First Tennessee National, are regional bank stocks.
James J. McDermott Jr., president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a bank-stock research company, noted that bank stocks were usually cheap relative to the market because investors had a tough time putting a value on loan portfolios. "Today, that risk has been reduced or eliminated," he said, "because of the improving economy and steps taken by management to bolster reserves."
Those efforts have raised bank equity capital to its highest level in 30 years. As a consequence, analysts said, stock buybacks and sharp dividend increases are likely during the coming year, providing solid underpinning to regional bank share prices.
Further, Mr. McDermott said banks would not return to the lending spree that marked the late 1980's because "there is just not that much lending going on any more."
The focus for banks in general and regional banks in particular in the coming year, he said, would be on fee generation -- "who can generate revenues and control costs." Keefe also expects a continuing consolidation in the industry.
Because of its major effort to alter its revenue mix, Mr. McDermott likes the Mellon Bank Corporation, which ended 1993 by buying the Dreyfus Corporation. He also favors Integra Financial, a Pittsburgh bank that could be a takeover candidate in the next few years.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Is France's Cultural Protection a Handy-Dandy Trade Excuse?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
"MARRIED WITH CHILDREN" is coming! To the barricades, Citoyens!
Of all the trade issues left hanging in the GATT deal, none, it is safe to say, aroused as much passion as France's insistence on continuing protection from America's entertainment juggernaut. It is equally safe to say that no other excuse for protection elicits so much sympathy from analysts otherwise disposed toward open trade. 
 Japanese rice growers and American textile magnates may, after all, be dismissed as sand in the wheels of progress. But who wants to see the good folks who brought you Truffaut, Godard and Chabrol buried in an avalanche of Love Boats, Inside Editions and Muppet Babies?
That, however, is not the last word on the subject. Before France's victory becomes the stuff of myth, it's worth a closer look at the logic behind the protection of "cultural services".
The European Community requires all TV channels, public or private, to carry a minimum of 50 percent European-made programming. France goes further, imposing a 60 percent minimum and enforcing the quota separately for prime-time shows. Then, too, Europe subsidizes local programming and films, often using taxes collected on movie tickets and video rentals to cover the cost.
Jacques Toubon, France's Minister of Culture, argues that the quotas and subsidies are needed to defend against the American industry's wish "to impose domination by any means." Jack Valenti, the head of the Motion Picture Association of America, dismisses the argument as a last refuge of scoundrels. "This is all about the hard business of money," he concludes.
Who's right? Eli Noam, the director of the Institute for Tele-Information at Columbia Business School, questions Europeans' assumptions. The premise that the game is rigged, that no one is in a position to beat Hollywood in a fair fight, he says, is based on a misunderstanding
Mr. Noam concedes that it does sometimes pay American producers to sell very cheaply in Europe, treating revenues as just a little extra on the side after costs are recouped at home. But the fact that royalties paid on European broadcast rights are low, he argues, says more about the lack of competition among European broadcasters than the willingness of Americans to sell their product for whatever the market will bear.
Indeed, Mr. Noam points out, what in other circumstances might be an "anti-dumping" argument against American imports can be turned on the alleged defenders of European culture. If the rights to non-European programming were bid up through greater competition, domestic producers in the same market would also benefit.
In any event, he notes, this shoe fits on both feet. If European producers can cover their costs at home, anything earned in America is lagniappe. And while America is larger and thus a seemingly stronger economic base than Europe, the American market is, in fact, equally fragmented: There are as many films made in America per million people as in Europe.
That said, it is still true that Hollywood blows away the European competition. Isn't that reason enough for the Europeans to nurture the business?
Harold Fruchtgott-Roth, an economic consultant in Washington, puts the cultural arguments in economic context. The fact that American entertainment sells so well, either because it is cheaper or better, is hardly in itself an argument for protection, he suggests, any more than the superiority of French Champagne to California bubbly would excuse an American quota on the former.
Nor is it possible to find much credibility in the "infant industry" argument -- the notion that protection is needed to prevent the European film industry from being strangled in the crib. "The French have been making movies as long as the Americans," he notes.
On the other hand, Mr. Fruchtgott-Roth says, it is plausible to defend a helping hand for the home product on the ground of "externalities" -- that Europeans as a community gain from exposure to European sensibilities in ways that aren't captured in the price of tickets, video rentals and television advertising.
The catch, Mr. Noam argues, is that the preservation of culture has become the handy-dandy, all-purpose excuse. It's one thing, he points out, to sweeten the pot for the best of the domestic product: Virtually every government subsidizes high culture. It is quite another to put a quota on American cop shows so that French studios can crank out their own car chases.
If there is a bright side here from Hollywood's perspective, Mr. Valenti says, it is the fact that the Europeans failed to get a formal exemption for cultural services from GATT rules. That means the American producers are still free to take the Europeans to court over alleged discrimination.
More ominously from the perspective of free traders, it will keep the pressure on the White House to invoke America's Draconian trade sanctions unilaterally against Europe. Wiser heads in the European Community may yet regret its 11th- hour cave-in to French demands.

HEADLINE: National Endowment Cuts Theater Training

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The National Endowment for the Arts, responding to a budget cut by Congress earlier this year, is eliminating its 20-year-old Professional Theater Training Program, which supports 16 of the nation's premier drama schools, including the Juilliard School, the Yale School of Drama and the New York University Tisch School of the Arts.
There has been no formal announcement of the endowment's action, but some schools have been informed by letter of the cutbacks and endowment officials yesterday confirmed them. 
 The elimination of the theater program saves only $250,000, but it is the leading edge of a $4.7 million reduction in the endowment's $174.5 million budget for 1994-95.
"I'm the first one, as an actress, to recognize the need for theater training, and I ached over the elimination of the Professional Theater Training Program," Jane Alexander, the endowment chairwoman, said in a telephone interview. "It's highly regrettable, but we have to respond to the cuts that Congress handed to us."
Ms. Alexander took over in October, a month after Congress cut the endowment's budget.
The endowment has also decided to eliminate another program, the Dance Heritage Initiative, which had planned to disburse $300,000 in 1994-95 to dance companies and other institutions to preserve dance productions on film and video tape.
Some arts organizations have already received notices of their cuts, and many others are waiting uneasily to see how their budgets will be affected by the Congressional action. Although the endowment grants are in many cases in the tens of thousands of dollars or less, they are crucial to recession-starved arts groups and are often used as a magnet in other fund-raising efforts.
 
Saving Theater Companies
 The theater-training-program cut was selected "because we wanted to preserve as much money as we could for theater companies themselves," Ms. Alexander said. Last year the endowment distributed $7.2 million to 234 nonprofit theater groups, and Ms. Alexander said that this category would be cut by only $75,000 in the new budget.
Among the drama schools that will be affected by the elimination of the training program are Juilliard ($25,000), Yale ($27,500), New York University ($17,500), the American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco ($22,500), the University of Iowa ($16,000) and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill ($10,000). Among the other institutions are Brown University, Rutgers University, the University of Delaware and the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass.
Joseph W. Polisi, the president of Juilliard, confirmed that the endowment had told the school about the loss of the grant, which was to have helped pay faculty salaries. The four-year undergraduate acting program has 78 students. Its graduates include Kevin Kline, Patti LuPone, Robin Williams, Christopher Reeve, Mandy Patinkin, Kelly McGillis and Val Kilmer. More than 700 students apply for the 20 spaces in the school every year.
"Of course, the money has financial importance," Mr. Polisi said, "and the endowment grant was also an anchor for other fund-raising, showing that our program had been reviewed by peers and was worthy of funding. But the greater significance is symbolic. We thought with a new Administration and a new chair of the endowment, we'd be moving forward. This sends a discouraging message."
 
Other Schools Hear
 Mary Schmidt Campbell, the dean of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, said its drama school had not received a letter from the endowment but understood that it would be losing its grant.
She said the money would have gone to graduate programs in acting, design, dance and other disciplines for about 200 students.
Victoria Nolan, the managing director of the Yale School of Drama, said the program "must have seemed an easy cut, because there are relatively few grantees in the program." Yale's $27,500 grant, the largest in the program, had already been reduced from $47,500 the previous year.
Ms. Alexander said many arts institutions other than theater schools would soon be notified about cuts in other categories, including dance, visual arts, museums, opera, music, film, video and radio programming.
A list of specific organizations and cuts would be premature, Ms. Alexander said, since she wanted the institutions to be told before public announcements are made. In addition, she said, cuts in many categories have not yet been decided upon.
But at least one Manhattan organization, the Kitchen, which presents performance art, dance and music, has been told that its grant will be cut 80 percent, to $10,000 from $50,000 last season (and $65,000 the previous season).
But at least one Manhattan organization, the Kitchen, which presents performance art, dance and music, has been told that its grant will be cut 80 percent, to $10,000 from $50,000 last season (and $65,000 the previous season).
 
No Growth in 12 Years
 Ms. Campbell of the Tisch School called the $4.7 million cut "Draconian, because the N.E.A. budget has had no growth in the last 12 years." She added, "This is going to put a large number of groups at serious risk and make it harder to perform their mission."
Ms. Campbell, a former New York City Cultural Affairs Commissioner who was mentioned last year as a possible head of the endowment, was the host of a New York reception in November after Ms. Alexander became chairman, and guests from the theater celebrated her confirmation. Ms. Campbell said that the round of budget-cutting "is the first serious issue that the new chair has to confront."
She added: "This will be an important measure of the kind of leadership Jane will provide. It's important that she make the Congress and the President understand the impact of these cuts on so many organizations."
Ms. Alexander said she deplored having to cut the endowment's programs. "It's cutting into muscle, since it's been a long time since there was any fat to cut." The endowment, she said, has suffered "a reduction of 46 percent in funding since the late 1970's."
Ms. Campbell said she worried about the impact of the cuts "on smaller arts organizations, some of which are on the edge." She added that "for larger universities, the impact won't be as severe, but it will limit the range of possibilities and the educational options we present to our students."
