HEADLINE: Composer Ensembles Are Focus Of Series

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
For young musicians of a certain stripe in the 1960's, getting a band together, setting up in a garage and hashing out some home-grown music was almost a cultural imperative. Usually the music was rock-and-roll; at least, the rock bands got most of the attention. But there was another kind of band scene coalescing at the time. Composers whose tastes had led them away from both atonality and neo-Romanticism were putting together bands of like-minded players to explore the experimental visions that led to Minimalism and to the many hybrids of rock, jazz and concert music that flourish in the Downtown new-music world today.
At first, these bands were matters of practical and economic necessity. They were laboratories for composers, who knew the capabilities of their players and often stretched them, and who were guaranteed performances that were entirely under their control. And composers discovered that they could often earn larger fees as players -- particularly as the sole performers of their own music -- than through the more traditional route of publishing works for other musicians to play. 
 The Kitchen, a haven for composer-led groups for more than two decades, is celebrating the band world in "Gruppen II: Chamber Music for the 21st Century," a series that opens tomorrow evening and runs through Jan. 15. The concerts are at 9 P.M. at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea. Information: (212) 255-5793.
 
Reduction in Grants
 Just at the moment, the Kitchen is doing a bit of scrambling. Early this week it learned that its grants from both the National Endowment for the Arts and the New York State Council on the Arts were being cut considerably. Because of a budget reduction imposed by Congress, the endowment slashed its overall grant by about 80 percent, to $10,000 from $50,000 last season. The part of the grant earmarked for music (the Kitchen also presents dance and performance art) was eliminated entirely (it was $8,000 last year). The council's grant dropped to $22,500 from $35,500, said Eric Latzky, the Kitchen's spokesman.
Offsetting these disappointments is a new grant from the Rockefeller Foundation -- to be used in the commissioning of a new-music theater piece, "The Negroes' Burial Ground," by Leroy Jenkins -- and renewed grants from several other foundations, including the Mary Flagler Cary Trust, the Aaron Copland Fund for Music and the Virgil Thomson Foundation. All told, the Kitchen has an annual production budget of about $400,000.
But Ben Neill, the 36-year-old trumpeter and composer who is in his second season as the Kitchen's music curator, is not letting financial pressures rain on his series. In fact, he regards the problems of paying for new music almost as an integral part of contemporary composing and performing life.
"The whole phenomenon of composers' ensembles is an important aspect in the development of new music," said Mr. Neill, who presented a similar series last year. "It's difficult for young composers who are not working at an academic institution to get their works performed. On the other hand, I know from experience that it's difficult to maintain an ensemble, given all the economic demands of working in New York today. So I put the series together because I thought it was important for the community to support this kind of work.
"The series is really focused on New York groups. But this year I tried to broaden it to include not only composer-directed ensembles, but ensembles like the Meridian Arts Ensemble, Essential Music and the Sirius String Quartet. They have composers within them, and they play their own music. But they also perform other composers' works."
 
A Quest for Balance
 The opening concert, tomorrow evening, has exactly the kind of balance Mr. Neill is seeking. Jon Gibson, the post-Minimalist composer and saxophonist, is to lead his quartet (with Blue Gene Tyranny on synthesizer, Martin Goldray on piano and Bill Ruyle on percussion) in his own works. But sharing the program with the Jon Gibson Quartet is the Meridian Arts Ensemble, a brass quintet that will play music by one of its members, Jon Nelson, as well as arrangements of pieces by Frank Zappa and the art-rock band King Crimson.
The other concerts offer similar stylistic variety, the balances depending on the peculiarities of the musicians taking part. Zusaan Kali Fasteau, a wind and reed player whose music combines jazz and third-world exoticism, is sharing a bill on Saturday with Julia Heyward, a singer whose music draws more on pop-music sensibilities. The Walter Thompson Orchestra, a jazz band, will play Mr. Thompson's music and works by Duke Ellington and Charles Ives next Wednesday.
"I wanted to bring these different angles in," said Mr. Neill of the jazz- and rock-influenced music in the series. "I did not want to limit it to people who are considered experimental or avant-garde."
One of the quirkier ensembles on the bill is Impossible Music, a trio that makes music using portable CD players. The group treats CD's as "found" sound sources, in much the same way musique concrete composers of the 1950's used pieces of tape. The three players -- Ikue Mori, David Shea and David Weinstein -- present the results as collaborative works, with titles like "Three Mistakes of Stravinsky and One of Yves St. Laurent," the featured piece on the program next Thursday. They are sharing the bill with Michelle Kinney, who writes music for combinations of computers, instruments and voice, with room for improvisation by the members of her band, Universal Time.
 
Collection of Hybrids
 Essential Music and the Sirius String Quartet will each play works composed for them by ensemble members and other composers on Jan. 14. And the festival ends on Jan. 15th with Toby Twining, a composer who writes microtonal music for an a cappella vocal ensemble, and Peter Gordon, whose Love of Life Orchestra Quartet is to present "Tone Poems and Video Painting: II," a program of Mr. Gordon's multi-media collaborations with the video artist Kit Fitzgerald.
"Everyone on the series is some kind of hybrid," said Mr. Neill of the swirl of popular and avant-garde influences his series embodies. "I think what's happened is that it's taken a generation of people experimenting with polystylistic music to get to the point where people could incorporate all of these things into their work without being self-conscious about it. I wanted to get into that area in the 'Gruppen' series.
"I don't think it's a matter of having to prove anything anymore. It's a given that composers can include anything from atonality to electric guitars, drums and a backbeat in a work. The question is not what you're putting in, or what you're borrowing. The challenge is to see how these things can be brought together in ways that are stimulating and which show all the elements in a new light."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
New Round in Revenue-Sharing Dispute

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Last week, Richard Ravitch fished for snapper in the Florida Keys. Today, he jumps into the water with baseball's sharks.
For the first time in nearly five months, Ravitch, the clubs' chief labor executive, will convene a meeting of the 28 major league club owners to try to produce a new agreement on distribution of their local revenue. The owners have to agree on revenue sharing before Ravitch can try to induce the players to accept a salary cap as part of a collective bargaining agreement that would replace the one that expired last Friday. 
 The meeting, in the Chicago suburb of Rosemont at a hotel near O'Hare Airport, will or will not produce a new revenue-sharing plan, depending on the point of view of the owner expressing his view.
Last August, when the owners met for 28 hours over two days in Kohler, Wis., 10 high-revenue clubs blocked adoption of a plan. One owner from that group said yesterday that the same clubs remain opposed to the plan currently on the table and that other clubs might even have joined them.
A supporter of Ravitch's plan, on the other hand, said that after speaking with many owners, he thinks chances are good that the plan, or some variation of it, will get the 21 votes needed for adoption.
 
A Call for Compromise
 "People have differing views," Ravitch acknowledged. "Compromise is essential if the owners wish to try to achieve a different kind of economic system in baseball. If they want some degree of cost control, they will have to agree on some new system of revenue distribution. They're aware of that."
Even if the owners adopt a plan, which in effect would take money from the high-revenue clubs and give it to the low-revenue clubs, it would be contingent on the players' acceptance of a salary cap. For that reason, Ravitch's effort could turn out to be futile because the players have shown no inclination to agree to a cap.
Nevertheless, Ravitch has to persuade the owners to take the first step. He could be aided by a potentially large hammer some National League clubs could wield against their wealthier brethren.
Half of the opposition 10 are National League clubs: the Mets, Los Angeles, St. Louis, Colorado and Florida. These clubs could be vulnerable because of the league television agreement that has expired. This agreement deals strictly with each club's local television practices, and has been the instrument by which teams televise games back to their cities from other parks. The other nine clubs, led by San Diego, Montreal and Pittsburgh, are threatening not to renew it if a revenue-sharing plan is not forthcoming.
"It's a weapon, and it gets people's attention," a high-ranking executive of one of the clubs said.
If they fail to forge a revenue-sharing agreement, the National League clubs could create their own plan by voting to charge the other teams fees for telecasting games from their parks.
The likelihood of a plan emerging from that scenario is far greater than the development offered speculatively in recent weeks by some baseball observers. Under that scenario, George Steinbrenner of the Yankees, perhaps the most outspoken opponent of increased sharing of revenue, would agree to it if Harvey Schiller is named commissioner. Schiller is executive director of the United States Olympic Committee, of which Steinbrenner is a vice president.
"That's absurd," said one owner, who opposes enhanced sharing.
"Not a prayer," said one proponent about the likelihood of Steinbrenner's giving up his money to insure Schiller's election.
 
Plan on the Table
 The plan on the table, details of which have not been disclosed, was proposed by Ravitch sometime after the Kohler meeting. Because the plan doesn't go far enough to meet their desires, it has elicited negative views from clubs at the low-revenue extreme as well as from the other end of the spectrum. Owners from both ends have made suggestions for altering it, but the changes would only widen the gap between the two sides.
Many people in baseball feel that failure to get an agreement would prompt Ravitch to leave his post. As a prelude to negotiations with the union, he has worked on revenue sharing almost exclusively for more than a year. Without a plan, he would have nothing to take to the bargaining table with the players. Furthermore, even if he developed a new negotiating approach, his ability to negotiate an agreement with them could be undermined by the owners' failure to back his plan.
"If there's nothing for him to do, it would be silly for him to stay," said one member of management.

HEADLINE: Lessons Well Learned

 BODY:

To the Home Section:
 Lisa M. Miller's interesting article on the boys in home economics ("Where the Boys Are: Home Ec, " Dec. 16) reminded me of my own experience. 
 In the fall of 1933 -- yes '33 -- I was the first boy to enroll in the home economics class of my suburban high school (Bronxville). The following year the group of 20 was almost equally divided between boys and girls. The third year the boys had taken over and, as I recall, only one girl was able to enroll.
The appeal then was probably more the prospect of free cake, cookies and assorted goodies in the middle of a long school day, but the lessons have served me well through life: on my own in college, where I earned extra cash catering; in the Army, where being assigned mess officer guaranteed plenty to eat; as widower and single parent of an omnivorous teen-ager, and now as the semiretired homemaking partner to a fully employed spouse.
 
ALEXANDER W. ALLPORT
New York

HEADLINE: Cost Analysis Doesn't Apply to Breast Cancer;
Link to Animal Fat

 BODY:

To the Editor:
There is much debate about mammograms for women younger than 50 (front page, Dec. 27), but virtually no discussion of preventing this terrible disease. Scientific studies have documented that breast cancer is strongly connected to fat, especially animal fat, in the diet. 
 In Japan, where fat consumption is far lower than in the United States, the breast cancer rate is only one-fourth of ours. Genetics don't seem to be the reason; when Japanese women move to the United States and adopt typical American diets, their breast cancer rate rises sharply.
While there is still debate among scientists about the role of fat in the diet, the Surgeon General's 1988 report on nutrition and health noted, "Indeed, a comparison of populations indicates that death rates for cancers of the breast, colon and prostate are directly proportional to estimated dietary fat intakes."
If we want to reverse the soaring health care costs that are projected to reach an incredible 20 percent of the gross national product in a dozen years, we must recognize the role of our diet.
 
RICHARD H. SCHWARTZ
Staten Island, Dec. 27, 1993
 
The writer is the author of "Judaism and Vegetarianism."

HEADLINE: U.S. PARES IMPORTS OF CHINA'S FABRICS IN A PUNITIVE MOVE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today cut by more than $1 billion the amount of clothing and fabrics China can export to the United States, retaliating for what it said were Chinese attempts to get around American limits on imports by shipping goods into the United States through other nations.
American apparel manufacturers quickly welcomed the Administration's punitive action, since it will slightly curb China's ability to compete with American-made goods and possibly save some jobs. But some American retailers complained that consumers could face shortages and higher prices, particularly low-income shoppers who may depend on some of these illicit Chinese sweaters, knit shirts and cotton trousers. The retailers urged the Administration to negotiate a settlement with Beijing. 
 All told, American retailers purchase about 6 percent of their clothing from China, according to the Johnson Redbook Service, a retail research organization.
 
 
Takes Effect on Jan. 17
 Because the punitive measure will not take effect until Jan. 17, there is a chance that the United States and China will come to an understanding that would better control or limit illicit Chinese exports. According to one Government estimate, about $2 billion of Chinese textiles and apparel is evading American import quotas each year.
The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, announced the decision at a news conference. It will take effect two days before Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen arrives in Beijing for high-level trade talks with Chinese leaders. Mr. Kantor said import quotas from China would be reduced by 25 to 35 percent on 88 categories of clothing, cloth and other products, including shop cloths used to clean industrial machinery.
 
Beijing Refuses to Talk

 Mr. Kantor said American officials had been monitoring the Chinese exports for some time and had been trying to persuade China to resume negotiations with the United States on an agreement for tighter controls and stiffer penalties to limit illicit exports. But Beijing refused this week to resume talks aimed at such an agreement, which the United States now has with 16 other major exporters.
There was no reaction today from Chinese officials to the American charges.
In foreign policy terms, the move underscores the degree to which China is gradually challenging Japan as the biggest trade headache for the United States, as well as the extent to which Chinese-American frictions are now as much over trade disputes as human rights abuses. China's trade surplus with the United States, now about $25 billion a year, is second only to Japan's.
In domestic policy terms, the move is a gesture by the Clinton Administration to American textile manufacturers and their representatives in Congress, who have been chafing over the fact that the Administration did not win them the long-term protection they were seeking from the recently concluded global trade agreement.
Mr. Kantor said that United States Customs Service investigators had found that Chinese fabrics and clothing had been illegally shipped to the United States through at least 25 other countries, including Honduras and Panama, as well as Hong Kong.
 
 
Sweaters to Macao
 In one case, he said, 3.6 million sweaters were shipped from China to neighboring Macao, a steamy Portuguese territory next to Hong Kong with a population of only 475,000.
"The climate is such that it would be quite unusual for each of them to buy eight sweaters in one year," Mr. Kantor wryly noted about the residents of Macao. What happened instead, he said, was that Chinese sweaters were relabeled "Made in Macao" and transshipped to the United States.
 In another case, he said, 625 million kilograms of shop towels -- small rags used to clean industrial machinery -- were made in China and then shipped to Honduras.
Honduras, Mr. Kantor said, is "not one of the great economic and manufacturing powers in the world." He added, "Given the limited number of heavy manufacturing industries in this country, obviously it would take decades for this volume of shop towels to actually be used in Honduras."
In fact, the goods were relabeled "Made in Honduras" and shipped to the United States.
"The President committed in his executive order last May, when extending most-favored-nation status for China, that the Administration would pursue resolutely all legislative and executive actions to insure that China abides by its commitments to follow fair, nondiscriminatory trade practices," Mr. Kantor said.
"In line with the President's policy in this regard," he added, "I am announcing today that due to our inability to reach agreements with China to stem or stop their illegal textile transshipments, which have reached massive proportions -- about $2 billion a year -- the United States is taking action to reduce China's 1994 textile quotas effective Jan. 17."
The Administration has been trying to console the American textile industry after agreeing, in the recently concluded world trade talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, to replace American textile import quotas with less restrictive tariffs over 10 years. The American textile industry had sought to phase in the new tariffs over 15 years.
Not surprisingly, the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, a powerful textile lobby, welcomed today's move. "Ambassador Kantor's bold action in cracking down on illegal Chinese textile exports is a strong message that the United States will not tolerate trade which violates our laws," it said. "Other nations, such as India and Pakistan, should also get this message."
 But American retailers, who sell the low-cost Chinese products, were not so happy. Tracy Mullin, president of the National Retail Federation, an industry group, said, "Let's hope that this action is a negotiating tactic, because if it is not and China's trade is cut by these significant numbers, then the American consumer, particularly the low-income consumer, will be severely impacted."
A spokesman for the Gap, which buys about 2 percent of its apparel from China, threw in a caveat. The cutback, he said, will strain capacity at apparel factories elsewhere in East Asia -- particularly Hong Kong -- "and that will lead to higher prices for the consumer."
Mr. Kantor said he estimated that the cuts announced today would cost Beijing $1.1 billion to $1.2 billion worth of exports. This, he insisted, would have "little if any impact on American consumers" but would show the Administration's determination "to stand up for U.S. jobs."
 
 
Shift on Satellite Sale
 The Administration, apparently in an effort to soften the impact on China of the textile quota cut, is also planning to lift its ban on the sale of two broadcast satellites built by the Martin Marietta Corporation in return for Beijing's agreement to enter discussions with the United States about its exports of missiles and other weapons, officials said.
 American officials remain concerned that despite the carrot-and-stick gestures they are applying on Beijing, China is still not demonstrating the sort of human rights and trade behavior that the Clinton Administration is demanding for the renewal on June 1 of China's most-favored nation trade status, which enables it to export its goods to the United States with the lowest possible tariffs.
 For months, American officials have warned China that it must show a pattern of good behavior in trade and human rights to secure most-favored status again, and that it cannot rush in on the eve of the decision, release a few dissidents, make a few concessions and expect President Clinton to reward it. But the Chinese are running out of months to set a new pattern.
"We are not there yet," said Joan Spero, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs. "The Chinese are not there yet. So we are far from a decision to renew M.F.N."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mickey Kantor, right, the United States trade representative, at a news conference yesterday in Washington, discussing the Clinton Administration's cut by more than $1 billion the amount of clothing and fabric that China can import into the United States. Looking on were Sam Banks, left, the acting deputy commissioner of the Customs Service, and Jennifer Hillman, the chief textile negotiator. (Associated Press) (pg. D2)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
The Administration cut the amount of clothing and fabrics China can export to the U.S. by more than $1 billion in retaliation for what it said were attempts by China to get around American limits on imports by shipping goods through other nations. The punitive measure will not take effect until Jan. 17, so there is a chance that the two countries will come to an understanding. [Page A1.] 
 The value of the Japanese yen is now in retreat after a year in which its steady rise struck fear into Japan's leading industries. The reversal could lead to a profit improvement for Japan's automobile and electronics giants and help foster a slow but eventual recovery of the stagnant Japanese economy. [D1.]
Peru had the highest growth rate in Latin America in 1993 because economic losses in the country's war with Shining Path Maoist guerrillas virtually dropped by half last year. [A9.]
 
The Economy
Most major retailers reported higher December sales, though the range was broad, from a 13.3 percent gain at Sears to 1.1 percent at Kmart. Sales of durable goods like appliances fared better than apparel and other soft goods. And profit margins were hurt by an enormous amount of price-cutting and sales promotions to satisfy consumers' desire for value. [D1.]
Commerce Secretary Brown announced a 27-member council to advise the Administration on information-policy matters and the creation of the data superhighway. But noticeably absent from the panel were the big three television networks, and there were few large movie studios or television programmers. [D4.]
 
Companies
An F.C.C. commissioner conceded that Infinity Broadcasting's expansion plan would be hard to stop. James H. Quello said blocking the purchase of three radio stations because of objections to the language used on the air by Howard Stern, one of Infinity's radio personalities, would face a long legal challenge. Macy's chairman insisted that Federated's move to seek a possible merger had put little pressure on management to come up with a plan of its own to keep the company independent. [D3.]
Several states joined California's attempt to halt hearings on Prudential Securities' class action settlement of sales abuses in limited partnerships in the 1980's. [D3.]
General Motors formed a joint venture in China to make and sell engine-management systems in that country. [D3.]
Large shareholders of TLC Beatrice supported the unexpected change in management that was announced Wednesday. [D3.]
Dell Computer's chief technology officer will join MIPS to help its effort to gain wider acceptance for its microprocessor. [D3.]
McDonnell Douglas agreed to a Pentagon order putting its C-17 cargo jet program on probation for two years. [D14.]
 
Markets
Interest rates fell after remarks by Labor Secretary Reich were interpreted as indicating that today's December employment data would show lower job growth than expected. [D1.]
The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 3,800 for the first time, helped by the drop in interest rates. [D4.]
Corn futures prices hit a five-and-a-half-year high amid fears that U.S. supply was near its lowest level since the 1940's. [D11.]

HEADLINE: Bond Move By Merrill

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company has temporarily suspended new business with Washington, D.C., after accusations that Merrill had a conflict of interest with the city's investment adviser, Lazard Freres & Company.
Merrill's move, announced Wednesday, prevents it from competing for about a month for underwriting deals for District of Columbia municipal bonds. 
 It came as two council members were asking for an investigation into a fee-splitting agreement between Merrill and Lazard concerning two financial deals known as interest rate swaps with the District in 1991 and 1992. Merrill and Lazard face similar conflict accusations in Massachusetts.
The two firms deny wrongdoing in both cases. They said they fully disclosed agreements in both cases for Lazard to advise Merrill on the swaps. The swaps are complex transactions designed to lower a customer's financing costs by exchanging fixed-interest payments for variable payments.
The two council members say they should have been told of an agreement between Merrill and Lazard, which is paid by the city to provide independent investment advice. The agreement brings into question the quality and impartiality of that advice, they say.
Merrill and Lazard said a report on Nov. 23 by the District's chief financial officer, Ellen M. O'Connor, cleared them of any wrongdoing. Merrill said Wednesday that it had suspended dealings with the city to give the council time to investigate.
Merrill's action comes at a time of intense scrutiny of the municipal bond market after accusations last year from several states of influence peddling or conflicts of interest.

PUB-DATE: January 7, 1994

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 1; National Desk

HEADLINE: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., a Democratic Power in the House for Decades, Dies at 81

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
Democrats and Republicans today bade a warm farewell to Thomas P. (Tip) O'Neill Jr., the gregarious and irrepressibly liberal Bostonian who symbolized the Democratic Party through much of the 1980's as Speaker of the House.
Mr. O'Neill, 81, died Wednesday night of cardiac arrest at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. Since his retirement from the House in 1987, he had lived in Washington and Harwich Port, Mass., on Cape Cod. 
 President Clinton issued a statement today paying tribute to "a beautiful life well lived," and ordered Government flags lowered to half-staff until Mr. O'Neill's burial on Monday.
"Tip O'Neill was the nation's most prominent, powerful and loyal champion of working people," the President's statement said. "He loved politics and government because he saw politics and government could make a difference in people's lives. And he loved people most of all."
The current Speaker of the House, Thomas S. Foley of Washington, called Mr. O'Neill "the model of what a representative and a leader of the American people should be."
Today, the capital's Republicans largely agreed. "Partisanship was put aside, and we could be the best of friends," the House minority leader, Robert H. Michel of Illinois, said of Mr. O'Neill today on the ABC-TV News program "Good Morning America."
The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, was one of Mr. O'Neill's most biting political critics in the 1980's. But today, on the CBS News program "This Morning," Mr. Dole called his old rival "the Congressman's Congressman."
Mr. O'Neill, he said, "certainly will go down in history as one of the great political leaders of our time."
He was also one of the last and least reconstructed liberals from the cadre of Roosevelt-era New Dealers who led Congress and the nation through most the 1960's and 1970's.
 
A Proud Liberal, Fashionable or Not
 Mr. O'Neill was an old-style politician and proud of it, a House Speaker comfortable with power, who clung to his brand of liberalism long after it ceased to be fashionable, even among his fellow Democrats.
An early opponent of the Vietnam War, Mr. O'Neill took strong positions on many controversial issues. He was the Congressional leader who pushed hardest for the impeachment of President Richard M. Nixon and later, as Speaker, put his prestige on the line for Congressional reform.
Mr. O'Neill was the Speaker from 1977 to 1987, during the Presidencies of Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, both of whom ran against entrenched Washington officials and considered Mr. O'Neill the ultimate insider.
But although he reached the heights of political power and mingled easily with national and world leaders, Mr. O'Neill was perhaps best known for his advice to colleagues to attend carefully to their constituents, because, as he put it, "All politics is local."
He was a large, joyous, generous-spirited man with a bulbous nose, yellowed white hair that flopped over his forehead and an ever-present cigar. He was a rabid sports fan, frequently attending baseball games and boxing matches, a skilled poker player and a devoted but struggling golfer.
To Mr. O'Neill, who spoke of the Democratic Party with near-religious fervor, the party was the one of the cities, the working people, the poor, the needy, the unemployed, the sick and the disinherited. "And no way are we ever going to let them down," he would insist. He opposed a balanced budget because, he said, it would "dismantle the programs that I've been working for as an old liberal."
When President Reagan persuaded Congress to curtail many of Mr. O'Neill's favorite social programs, the Speaker lamented that the Democrats had been too successful at their work. He said the Democratic programs had created a broad middle class whose members had forgotten the many benefits they had received from government -- in education and housing, for example -- and wanted to pull up the ladder behind them.
Republicans made Mr. O'Neill a target of their 1980 and 1982 campaigns, portraying him as a bloated old pol with outdated liberal ideas. They produced a television commercial that featured an actor who resembled the Speaker laughing off warnings that his car was low on fuel, until the vehicle finally ground to a halt. The announcer then proclaimed, "The Democrats have run out of gas."
Mr. O'Neill remained steadfast. "I haven't changed my philosophy," he frequently told reporters, with whom he met daily.
He made no apologies for the kind of politics he had mastered in Boston. As Speaker, he rewarded friends and punished enemies with the help of a long memory but few grudges.
 
O'Neill and Carter: Different Democrats
 Mr. O'Neill's became Speaker the year Mr. Carter took office as President. About all they had in common was their political party. Mr. Carter, an emotionally taut Georgian with a scant power base among Democrats, had reached the White House as an anti-politician, an outsider who publicly disdained Washington insiders personified by the gregarious Speaker, who had worked his way up from ward politics.
"Our first conversation," the Speaker recalled, "he told me how he had handled the Georgia Legislature, by going over their heads directly to the people."
Mr. O'Neill said he responded by referring to the 289 House Democrats in the majority. "I said: 'Hey, wait a minute. You have 289 guys up there who know their districts pretty well. They ran against the Administration, and they wouldn't hesitate to run against you.'
"He said, 'Oh, really?' "
The two men did not speak the same language. Mr. O'Neill said he had once told the President, "Keep your left hand high." But the Speaker found that Mr. Carter was no boxing fan and was unfamiliar with the boxer's classic defensive posture. "He didn't know what I was talking about," Mr. O'Neill said.
But as a loyal Democrat Mr. O'Neill felt morally bound to help Mr. Carter whenever possible. An autographed photograph from the President was inscribed, "To my friend Tip O'Neill, thanks for another lesson in good politics, Jimmy Carter, June 1977."
But in 1980, when the Republicans won the White House and the Senate, and cut deeply into the House Democratic majority, the Speaker privately blamed the President, believing him inept.
Today, Mr. Carter said in a statement that Mr. O'Neill "personified the finest of American politics."
"Of all the people I have known, Tip O'Neill knew best how to enjoy politics," he said.
 
O'Neill and Reagan: Different Irishmen
 Mr. O'Neill never shied from wielding power, although he frequently lamented that the power of the Speaker had declined since the days of Sam Rayburn, the Texas Democrat whose word became law during his 17 years in the post, ending in 1961. That was when a Speaker could get binding commitments from committee chairmen; it was before the diffusion of power that Mr. O'Neill himself worked to bring about.
From 1981 to 1987, Mr. O'Neill led the loyal opposition to President Reagan, a man with whom he shared an Irish heritage, an interest in sports and an outgoing personality. But the two men had a profound philosophical disagreement about government: the Speaker regarded government as the solution to many social problems, as an agent of social change; Mr. Reagan regarded it as a problem in itself, interfering in the lives of Americans and impeding economic and social progress.
The Speaker also found Mr. Reagan to be appallingly ignorant of the intricacies of government; indeed, he called him the most ignorant man who had ever occupied the White House. Publicly, Mr. O'Neill called Mr. Reagan "Herbert Hoover with a smile" and "a cheerleader for selfishness."
Early in his time as Speaker, when his bill for a new House code of ethics was in trouble, he lumbered to the well of the House and cut through the debate on the crucial provision, a limitation on outside income. The speech was vintage O'Neill.
Sure, he said, he knew what it was to be strapped. Wasn't he the one who had fought for a raise of $12,900 a year in Congressional pay? But in exchange he had promised the American people "the strongest code of ethics that this country has ever seen." The issue, after Watergate, he thundered, was "restoring public confidence in this Congress as an institution, restoring confidence in its membership."
He looked out at an audience that included the 80 Democrats for whom he had campaigned the previous fall, the scores of members he had appointed to the nine select and special committees over which he had jurisdiction, and the more than 200 beneficiaries of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Fund, for which he had been the chairman.
His listeners knew that the Speaker had a great voice in their committee assignments, the scheduling of floor action on bills, the disbursing of campaign money and the small favors that can make or break a Congressional career. Mr. O'Neill called in his chits. The result was a foregone conclusion. The vote was 344 to 79.
Four years later, when 44 Democrats joined in voting to overturn a ruling of the chair, the kind of parliamentary decision that is the lifeblood of the House, Mr. O'Neill wrote them that he was "extremely disappointed" and obliquely warned that "disciplinary measures" were under consideration.
Such measures could affect a member's committee assignments. He added that he felt that such measures were unnecessary. No future Democratic votes against the judgment of the chair were noted.
 
Tip (as in Foul Tip) Tastes Politics at 15
 Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. was born on Dec. 9, 1912, in a working-class area of Cambridge, Mass., which later became part of his Congressional district. His father was a member of the Cambridge City Council. His mother died when he was a child, and his father remarried.
He picked up the nickname Tip from a baseball player, James Edward O'Neill of the old St. Louis Browns, who had the knack of hitting foul tips until the pitcher walked him. So Mr. O'Neill's boyhood friends gave him the name. The Speaker was an inveterate fan of the Boston Red Sox.
Educated in Roman Catholic schools, he broke into politics at 15, campaigning for Al Smith in his 1928 Presidential campaign against Herbert C. Hoover. "All I knew was that Al Smith was an Irish Catholic and we had been suppressed all our lives," he said.
Four years later, he helped get out the vote for Franklin D. Roosevelt. "You'd have Mrs. Murphy ready to get into an automobile to take her to the polls," he recalled. "And then you'd go to the next house, Mrs. Sweeney, and you'd have the car come for Mrs. Sweeney. We walked the streets to get the votes out."
As a senior at Boston College, Mr. O'Neill lost his first campaign, for the Cambridge City Council, by 150 votes. But he was elected to the Massachusetts House of Representatives in 1936, where he rose to Speaker, and where he remained until 1952, when he was elected to the United States House.
He won the seat vacated by John F. Kennedy on Kennedy's election to the Senate. It was also the seat once held by James M. Curley, the Boston politician whose career was the basis of the Edwin O'Connor novel "The Last Hurrah."
 
A Protege Of a Future Speaker
 Mr. O'Neill and his wife, Mildred, decided not to move their family to Washington when Mr. O'Neill was first elected, and they did not go back on this agreement until Mr. O'Neill became Speaker, a quarter century later.
Until then, Mr. O'Neill roomed with Representative Edward P. Boland, Democrat of Massachusetts, his closest friend. Their refrigerator was said to be stocked almost exclusively with beer.
In Washington, Mr. O'Neill became a protege of Representative John W. McCormack of Massachusetts, the Democratic whip who went on to become House Speaker in 1962. Mr. McCormack introduced him to the House power structure as part of the informal "board of education" meetings that Speaker Rayburn held after hours for Congressional leaders and friends. By his second term in the House, Mr. O'Neill had won a coveted seat on the Rules Committee.
Mr. O'Neill's opposition to the Vietnam War in 1967, when he was a leader of the Rules Committee, was a decision affected by the anti-war feelings of his own children (three boys and two girls) as well as among the intellectual communities at Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in his own district. His blue-collar constituents, who made up the bulk of his support, were overwhelmingly in favor of the American role in the war.
But Mr. O'Neill wrote in his autobiography, "Man of the House" (Random House, 1987), that he had come to the conclusion that the conflict was a civil war and that American involvement in it was morally wrong. When President Lyndon B. Johnson called him to the White House to explain his change of position, Mr. O'Neill recalled, he told the President, "In my heart and in my conscience I believe your policy is wrong." Johnson accepted his position, Mr. O'Neill said, when he found out that the Congressman had not changed it for political reasons.
But his opposition to the war did eventually reap some political dividends: he won the trust and support of younger House members who shared his position on Vietnam, and they became important allies as Mr. O'Neill rose in power.
In 1971, having supported Hale Boggs of Louisiana as majority leader, Mr. O'Neill was selected by Mr. Boggs to be majority whip, an appointive post. After Mr. Boggs died in a plane crash in Alaska in 1972, Mr. O'Neill was elected majority leader.
Mr. O'Neill, as the whip under Speaker Carl Albert of Oklahoma, was the Democrats' strong man; he did the difficult things. He was instrumental in bringing changes that stripped the committee chairmen of their autocratic power, and he was the Democratic leader who pushed hardest for the investigation and impeachment of President Nixon, who resigned before a vote on impeachment was held.
Mr. O'Neill was elected Speaker by acclamation in December 1976, when he was 64, and took office the next month. "The wonder of it is that such a decent, compassionate man could rise to the top of a place like this," said Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens.
But Mr. O'Neill was not without lapses of judgment. He was among many House members who accepted favors from Tongsun Park, the South Korean lobbyist and intelligence agent. In 1973 and '74, Mr. O'Neill permitted Mr. Park to sponsor two lavish birthday parties in his honor, thereby bolstering Mr. Park's prestige.
Similarly, some questioned Mr. O'Neill's judgment when he intervened in an application for Federal money made by James P. Wilmot, who had been chairman of the Democratic Party's Finance Committee.
The Speaker telephoned the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Carla A. Hills, in July 1975, asking when there would be a decision on Mr. Wilmot's request for $2.2 million in annual rent subsidies for a housing project. Such inquiries tend to be viewed as requests for special consideration. In any event, Mr. Wilmot got his subsidies.
Although he had close ties to the Kennedy family, Mr. O'Neill remained neutral in the party's Presidential nomination fight between Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and President Carter in 1980. He played a role behind the scenes at the Democratic National Convention, however, negotiating an agreement that led to Mr. Kennedy's reluctant endorsement of the President.
 
Financial Security From a Book
 Until his retirement, the O'Neills maintained their home in Cambridge, enabling the Speaker to keep in touch with the city's intellectual community as well as its neighborhoods. A Saturday morning ritual when Mr. O'Neill was in Cambridge consisted of stops at the Chinese laundry, the Italian food store and the Star Market in Porter Square.
In retirement, Mr. O'Neill divided his time between a house in Harwich Port on Cape Cod and an apartment in Washington and spent some holidays at a condominium in Florida.
The Speaker's oldest son and namesake, Thomas P. O'Neill 3d, a former lieutenant governor of Massachusetts, is in public relations in Boston. Another son, Christopher, is a Washington lawyer, and a third, Michael, is in business in Cambridge. One daughter, Susan, has her own business in Washington, and another, Rosemary, is a political officer for the State Department. Mr. O'Neill is also survived by his wife and eight grandchildren. A family spokeswoman said the funeral would be held next Monday at St. John's Church in Cambridge, Reuters reported. On Saturday and Sunday, his body will lie in state in Boston's State House.
After suffering colon cancer, which led to a colostomy, Mr. O'Neill made public service advertisements in which he joined athletes and movie stars in talking candidly about having cancer.
Unlike some politicians who amassed a fortune, Mr. O'Neill retired from the Speakership in relatively modest circumstances. His book, "Man of the House," however, written with William Novak, became a best seller that made him financially secure. Mr. O'Neill also made commercials for a credit card company and a motel chain.
Mr. O'Neill's book was a treasure trove of stories, including some about his political campaign for the Cambridge City Council while he was a senior at Boston College. He finished ninth in a field of 60 candidates, of whom the top eight were elected.
The race taught him a lifelong lesson. He had not campaigned in his own neighborhood, which he had taken for granted and where he made a poor showing. In a post-mortem on the campaign, Mr. O'Neill's father told him what he had learned in a lifetime of politics: "All politics is local."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
G.M. Forms China Joint Venture on Engine Parts

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Jan. 6

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation has formed a joint venture with a Chinese business and a Chinese Government-owned enterprise to make and sell engine-management systems in China, a G.M. executive said today.
G.M. already runs a $100 million joint venture to produce pickup trucks in northeastern China and is exploring a joint venture to build mini-vans there. Its parts division has already joined in ventures and signed licensing agreements with Chinese businesses to make and distribute spark plugs, wiring harnesses and other components. 
 G.M.'s parts-making operation, called the Automotive Components Group, has been trying to lower manufacturing costs and increase sales to companies outside G.M. Like other automotive suppliers, G.M. views China as a prime area for growth.
"This joint venture represents one more step in the A.C.G.'s efforts to invest in the growth of China and its emerging automotive market," J. T. Battenberg 3d, the vice president in charge of G.M.'s parts division, said in a statement announcing the joint venture. "A strong local automotive systems and components infrastructure will foster the rapid growth of the Chinese vehicle market."
 G.M. will put up 51 percent of the initial investment of $30 million in the new venture. The total investment could eventually reach $120 million.
At first, all components for the engine-management systems to be distributed by the joint venture will come from G.M. plants in North America, Europe and elsewhere in Asia, but G.M. said that up to 75 percent of the parts could eventually be fabricated in China. Acting together, these components control the flow of fuel and air into the engine, manage the combustion process and govern the exhaust.
While the joint venture has no customers yet, it is negotiating with several potential customers, including the G.M. truck venture, a G.M. spokesman said.
G.M.'s partners in the engine-parts project, which will be based in Beijing, are the Beijing Wan Yuan Industry Corporation and the Beijing Economic Technology Investment Development Corporation, which is controlled by the Beijing municipal government.
Wan Yuan, a subsidiary of the China Aerospace Corporation, develops and manufactures launching vehicles. It has collaborated with G.M.'s Hughes Electronics division to put communications satellites in orbit.
Mr. Battenberg also announced today the parts-operation's revenues for 1993. Total sales were $24.9 billion, compared with $23.6 billion in 1992.

G.M. Has Profit for Year
 DETROIT, Jan. 6 (Reuters) -- John F. Smith Jr., the chief executive of General Motors, said today that the company earned its first profit in four years in 1993, and that he expected an even stronger year in 1994.
 "From an industry standpoint, 1993 was a good year and it was a good year for G.M.," Mr. Smith said. "It was a turnaround year for our North American operations. G.M. returned to profitability in total, and 1994 looks strong."
 Mr. Smith declined to say how much the company earned in 1993, but through the first nine months of the year it had net income of $1.3 billion, virtually assuring that it would end the year with a profit for the first time since 1989, when it earned $4.2 billion.
 Since 1989, G.M. has lost almost $30 billion, including a staggering $20 billion accounting charge for retiree health care benefits in 1992.
 Mr. Smith, who took over in late 1992 for Robert C. Stempel, the chairman who lost his job in a shake-up by the board, said G.M.'s directors had been "very supportive" of his efforts to turn the company around.
 "I think the board is quite pleased," Mr. Smith said. "We had a fantastic year for cash flow."
 He attributed G.M.'s success to a sharp change in attitudes toward Detroit's cars and to $2 billion in cost reductions by the company.

HEADLINE: U.S. Official Visits Graves in Croatia

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OVCARA, Croatia, Jan. 6

 BODY:
In one of several moves underscoring its determination to bring war criminals to justice in the former Yugoslavia, the Clinton Administration sent a Cabinet-rank official on a symbolic visit today to a grave here that is believed to hold the bodies of several hundred Croats massacred by Serbs.
On a more practical plain, that official, Madeleine K. Albright, the United States chief delegate to the United Nations, warned that the United States may use its Security Council veto to maintain the economic blockade of the Yugoslavian federation of Serbia and Montenegro until Belgrade hands over those accused of atrocities. 
 And John Shattuck, the Administration's chief human rights officer, announced that the United States will give $25 million more toward the expenses of the international tribunal set up to try them.
 
Graves at Garbage Dump
 On a mild winter day, Ms. Albright, Assistant Secretary of State Shattuck and Peter Galbraith, the Clinton Administration's Ambassador to Croatia, flew here in a white United Nations helicopter to spend about half an hour peering at an isolated scrub-covered garbage dump at the corner of a plowed field a few miles outside the town of Vukovar.
The site, now ringed by coils of shiny steel razor wire and guarded day and night by a platoon of armed Russian peacekeeping troops, is believed to contain the bodies of some 200 Croat patients who disappeared from Vukovar Hospital on Nov. 20, 1991, and were probably killed by the Serb forces who had just captured the town from the Croats after a fierce siege that reduced most of it to rubble.
Since its discovery in October 1992, when a test dig turned up the bodies of eight or nine Croats, all of them apparently shot, the local Serbian authorities, who have incorporated Vukovar into their breakaway state known as the Republic of Krajina, have systematically blocked the United Nations from digging up the rest of the grave area, although another attempt is to be made next April.
The Ovcara grave is one of 98 probable mass grave sites in the former Yugoslavia that have been identified by the War Crimes Commission the Security Council set up to start gathering evidence of atrocities. The graves are believed to hold thousands of victims of ethnic massacres by warring Serb, Muslim and Croat factions.
 
Stress on Rights Policy
 Ms. Albright said her reason for coming to the suspected grave now was to draw attention to the Clinton Administration's policy of advancing human rights and its determination to bring Yugoslav war criminals to justice before the tribunal the Security Council has set up in the Hague to judge them.
She called the grave "a symbol of the Yugoslavian war's inhumanity" and said it is "essential" that it be investigated by the war crimes tribunal. "It is a great tragedy that people end their lives in what is ultimately a garbage dump," she added.
At a meeting later in a decrepit office building in Vukovar with Goran Hadzic, president of Serbian Krajina, and Milan Ilic, head of its regional council, neither official questioned whether the grave really contained the victims of a massacre by Serbian forces.
Instead, they appeared anxious at the prospect of a war crimes investigation, accused the visiting Americans of not understanding "the history of the region" and played down the importance of the civil war in former Yugoslavia, saying the world has seen many wars in recent years.
 
Threat of U.N. Sanctions
 In a further strengthening of the Administration's support for the War Crimes Tribunal, Ms. Albright warned that the United States now favors Security Council sanctions against countries that do not cooperate with it either by refusing to surrender citizens accused of war crimes or by withholding evidence.
"In the issue of lifting sanctions, we believe that behavior vis-a-vis the War Crimes Tribunal must be considered," she said. "Withholding evidence or obstruction of justice or blocking aid are all appropriate issues for the tribunal."
On Wednesday at a briefing by United Nations relief workers here, she was told that only about 40 percent of needed supplies are being allowed through to those in difficulty in Bosnia and Herzegovina this winter, in large measure because of Serbian obstruction.
The emphasis the Clinton Administration is now putting on building up the war crimes tribunal appears to be an attempt to rescue an institution that many thought would fade into oblivion because it would never be able arrest suspects.
But American officials now argue that the Administration's support for the tribunal is part of a "twin track" approach to ending the conflict in former Yugoslavia that aids the process of national reconciliation between the rival ethnic factions.
 
Identifying the Guilty
 According to this view, identifying and prosecuting those responsible for atrocities will show that only a limited number of people are involved. Fixing the responsibility on individuals, it is argued, will prevent the ethnic groups from blaming the other for its sufferings for generations to come.
But the American enthusiasm for tracking down war criminals is not shared to the same extent by many European countries, such as Britain and France, which fear it may complicate the search for peace, which they see as their top priority.
For this reason, European countries tend to feel that war-crimes investigations and trials should come after peace has been agreed and not before.
And they have been reluctant so far to share evidence of such crimes they have collected with the tribunal's prosecutors.
The United States as well has rejected a request by the United Nations to send military engineers to help dig up evidence of war crimes, maintaining that such a step would put American soldiers at risk.
While the main emphasis of Ms. Albright's two-day visit here, the start of a tour of Eastern Europe and the Balkans, has been on war crimes, officials say she has also warned President Franjo Tudjman that his army's growing involvement in the Bosnian conflict is a source of concern to the Clinton Administration and that she hopes there will be "no more high-level discussions" in the United States Government about imposing Security Council sanctions against Croatia.
With the international mediators now scheduled to reconvene their peace talks in Geneva on Jan. 18, Muslim forces are seizing land from the Croats in central Bosnia, and the Zagreb Government is reported to have sent some 10,000 to 15,000 soldiers as well as dozens of tanks to stiffen Croatian resistance there.

HEADLINE: Word for Word;
A Talk With Ginsburg On Life and the Court

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
New Supreme Court Justices customarily introduce themselves to the Court family -- the 300 or so people who work in the building -- by granting an interview to the Docket Sheet, a newsletter published for Court employees.
It was a relaxed and reflective Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg who answered questions from Toni House, the Court's public information officer, and Kathleen L. Arberg, the editor of Docket Sheet. The result was a lively, informative interview, in some ways more revealing of the new Justice's approach to work and life than her days of cautious testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee last summer. 
 Excerpts from the interview, which took place in October and was published this week, appear below.
One bit of Court jargon requires translation: Justice Ginsburg's reference to "cert. petitions" and the "cert. pool." Cert. petitions are legal briefs that initiate a Supreme Court appeal, known technically as a petition for a writ of certiorari. Eight of the nine Justices -- all but Justice John Paul Stevens -- assign their law clerks to a pool that divides the work of reading and summarizing the thousands of petitions that reach the Court each term.
The cert. pool has come under criticism recently from Court critics, who assert that the process makes the Justices too reliant on their clerks for the important work of deciding which cases to hear. Justice Ginsburg quite clearly had that criticism in mind when she described her approach to picking cases. LINDA GREENHOUSE
Q. Has becoming a Supreme Court Justice changed your life?
A. Yes, indubitably, yes. Have you seen Sally Potter's film "Orlando"? It's based on a novel by Virginia Woolf. The principal character spends a few centuries as a man, and then wakes up one morning to find she's a woman. She looks at herself in the mirror and says, "Same person, just another sex." But her life becomes totally different because she's a woman instead of a man, although inside she is the same person.
That's what has happened to me. I have gone about my business as a very private person, as a law teacher, even as an advocate for women's rights. Now people recognize me in shops, even in movie theaters. Someone recently remarked to my husband, "Your wife reads her mail by flashlight in the movies." True enough, we went to our local movie house not long ago, and while we were waiting for the feature film to begin -- I don't care much for commercials and previews -- I did take out the day's mail and a flashlight. No one would have paid any attention to my compulsion to save time before.
Q. What is your daily routine like on a day when the Court is not sitting?
A. On most days, I am chained to my desk, but I expect to have a more flexible routine in time. A lot of the Court's work is new to me. One part of the job that's entirely new, and is particularly challenging, is the cert. petition review.
Some people outside the Court seem to think the cert. pool makes it all a piece of cake -- that the Justices simply read and follow what the law clerks recommend. But, to quote Sportin' Life, "It ain't necessarily so." We read pool memos with care and the judgment that comes with experience. And when in doubt, we do read the petitions and responses.
The law clerks are highly intelligent, very able, uncommonly diligent. They save us hours upon hours of labor. But most of them are also young and in need of the seasoning that experiences in life and in law practice afford. Whenever I think a case may be cert. worthy, I will do the homework required and will not rely solely on a pool memorandum.
Q. What characteristics do you think make a judge a good one?
A. It's important to be secure in your own judgment, to be ready to make decisions and not look back. Some of the best legal minds are not the best judges because they're constantly rethinking a position and won't let an opinion go. A judge should have the attitude, "I can resolve this as well as, or probably better than the next person. I'm as comfortable as one should be making the decision, and I'm not going to worry about it constantly after I've made it."
Q. An unprecedented step you've taken is agreed to a flexible schedule for one of your law clerks. What made you decide to do that?
A. You have in mind David Post. David clerked for me in the D.C. Circuit. I'm very grateful he was willing to come back to help me this first year. When I received his application for a clerkship several years ago, he explained he was attending Georgetown at night rather than in the day because his wife, an economist, had a demanding job, so he attended to the children in the morning and early afternoon.
I thought, "This is my dream of the way the world should be." When fathers take equal responsibility for the care of their children, that's when women will truly be liberated. I was so pleased to see that there are indeed men who are doing a parent's work, men who do not regard that as strange. People like David, I hope, will be role models for other men who may be fearful they won't succeed in their profession if they spend time caring for their children, or are concerned they will be thought of as less than a man if family is of prime importance.
More than anything else, I believe, the acceptance of full parental responsibility by men will make things genuinely equal for women. Women will have truly equal opportunity when men accept responsibility for raising children to the same extent that women do. Is that an impossible dream? I don't think so. The fact that there are people like David Post in the world encourages me.

HEADLINE: Retailers' December Sales Solid

BYLINE: By JOSHUA MILLS

 BODY:
Most major retailers reported yesterday that their sales rose during December, though the range was very broad, from 13.3 percent at Sears, Roebuck for stores open at least a year to 1.1 percent at Kmart.
But underneath those higher sales was an enormous amount of price-cutting and promotions, which took a toll on profit margins.
 Everywhere, the theme was value, value, value. 
 "Shoppers are very price-conscious," said Duncan Muir, a J. C. Penney spokesman at the company's headquarters in Dallas. "An item has to be good quality, and fashionable, but it's when the price is right that they buy." Mr. Muir noted that Penney spent $60 million on advertising during the Christmas season alone to draw shoppers to its promotions.
 
Rise in Salomon Index
 Same-store sales are generally regarded as the best measure of retailing performance, because they exclude new stores that often do well but have not demonstrated any sustained performance. Salomon Brothers said its retail index, a weighted average of the monthly comparable-store sales of 22 major retailers, rose 4.3 percent, a substantial improvement on the 2.9 percent gain in November but well below December 1992, when the index rose 7.4 percent.
Of course, December 1992 was marked by a burst of consumer confidence in the period between the election of President Clinton and his inauguration, built on modest signs of an improving economy.
Most retailers begin their fiscal year on Feb. 1, so full-year returns will not be available for several weeks.
 
Strong Sales in 'Hard Goods'
 As had been the case much of the year, stores whose main business is what retailers call "hard goods" -- appliances, tools, furniture -- generally had a good month, while those that sell "soft goods" like apparel and bedding fared worse. Yet everywhere there were exceptions, like Penney, whose main business is apparel but whose same-store sales rose 10 percent in December.
Looking ahead, Jeffrey M. Feiner, a retail analyst at Salomon Brothers, said he was cautiously optimistic while acknowledging "the tax increases will hurt."
Jeffrey Edelman, an analyst at C. J. Lawrence, also said he expected retailers to enjoy a strong first quarter compared with last year, partly because of "good economic momentum" and also because "last March was wiped out by the snowstorms."
Yet Mr. Edelman stands apart from the chorus chanting "value shopping."
"Department store sales were stronger than we thought, and at discount stores, apparel was weaker than store averages," he said. "And apparel stores were weak, too. In spite of what everyone says about value, the customers wound up shopping at the department stores."
The strongest performance of any major chain came at Sears, Roebuck & Company, whose turnaround continued after years of slippage. Wal-Mart Stores, the nation's largest retailer, said same-store sales rose 4 percent for the month.
At the Limited, a chain of apparel shops, same-store sales fell 1 percent, while at Gap Inc., same-store sales rose 4 percent.
The tension between increased sales and slipping profit margins was demonstrated yesterday in consumer electronics. Circuit City Stores said its December sales exceeded expectations but that it planned to cut prices in 1994 because of increased competition. That sent its stock tumbling, and it closed down 20 percent, or $4.50 a share, at $17.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Backs Loan Program For Broadway

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has pledged to create a new state-financed program of loans for the repair and upkeep of Broadway theaters, whose owners have complained for more than a decade about government indifference.
With that -- although not as a quid pro quo, according to the official line -- two of Broadway's major theater owners dropped their opposition to the Walt Disney Company's plans to take over the New Amsterdam Theater on 42d Street, clearing away a high political hurdle faced by the project. 
 After years of feeling that the state and city governments were ignoring their economic plight, Broadway owners were outraged last year when they learned that Disney might receive a low-interest construction loan from the state to help reconstruct the badly deteriorated New Amsterdam for live entertainment.
But after Mr. Cuomo announced his loan plan for the Broadway theaters, one critic of the Disney project, Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization, said: "We are now a non-objectant to the Disney proposal. And we hope that it will regenerate and stimulate the development of 42d Street."
 
To Preserve Commercial Theater
 Mr. Cuomo said the new loan program would be "dedicated to preserving commercial theater on Broadway." The director of economic development for New York State, Vincent Tese, said yesterday that the program, whose details are still sketchy, would provide the "capital improvements necessary to make sure that the structures are well maintained and keep their historic character in good condition."
Although details have yet to be worked out, the program may begin with $1 million being made available by the State Urban Development Corporation, of which Mr. Tese is chairman and chief executive.
"It's an important moment for theater in New York," said Jack L. Goldstein, special assistant to Ron Silver, the president of Actors' Equity Association. "I think it marks a new partnership."
Mr. Schoenfeld made his opposition public at a hearing before the Urban Development Corporation in November. He suggested that Disney was gaining an unfair advantage in offering "legitimate attractions that would otherwise be presented in non-subsidized theaters."
Rocco Landesman, president of Jujamcyn Theaters, had also objected to the Disney subsidy. Together, they control two dozen Broadway houses. The Nederlander Organization made no public comment then, and its executives could not be reached yesterday for comment.
Mr. Schoenfeld applauded Mr. Cuomo and Mr. Tese yesterday for having endorsed a "comprehensive plan for the long-term preservation" of Broadway's commercial theater, which the industry has been advocating since 1984.
Mr. Schoenfeld said the loan program "would be a sort of quasi-equivalent for the low-interest loan fund that Disney was receiving, although not in the same amount at first."
"It's a significant recognition of the need for such a long-term plan," he said.
 
Queasy About Competitors
 Mr. Tese said Broadway theater owners have "always been queasy about having a competitor" on 42d Street. But that was not what prompted the idea of starting a loan program, he said.
"They went through a litany of problems," Mr. Tese said: "the way they've been misunderstood, the way they've not been helped, the way they've been taken for granted by the city and state."
"The truth of the matter is -- after they went through the litany -- I felt to a certain extent that they had a case," Mr. Tese said. "They're an important part of the cultural and economic fabric of New York, and we should do everything in our power to see that they are prosperous and healthy."
Theatrical unions have welcomed the prospect of Disney's bringing live entertainment back to the New Amsterdam, Mr. Goldstein said.
 
No Better Amusement Partner
 "The key to revitalization of 42d Street is a serious marketing effort to bring in entertainment, retail and tourist- and resident-related amusement enterprises," he said. "If I were to reach out in the universe of available partners, I could not come up with a better one than Disney."
The prospect of Disney's turning the New Amsterdam into what Mr. Cuomo called a "showcase theater" is one of several developments in the long-delayed rejuvenation of 42d Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. In his annual message to the Legislature on Wednesday the Governor also mentioned a "modern version of Madame Tussaud's Wax Museum with electronic exhibits."
The plan also includes the retail rehabilitation of existing buildings that were to have been demolished to make way for four giant office towers. Construction of the skyscrapers has been postponed indefinitely.
A Disney spokesman at its Burbank, Calif., headquarters said the company had no comment on the New Amsterdam project.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Up on Reich's Jobs Remark

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities traded sharply higher yesterday, and interest rates fell after remarks by Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich were interpreted as indicating that data on payroll employment for December, which are due out today, would show job growth below expectations.
Arousing the ire of a number of economists, Mr. Reich, who was in Washington participating via satellite in a television forum in Paris, responded to a questioner seeking an indication of what the December employment numbers would show. 
 He said that while he could not tell exactly what the numbers would be, he thought they would show "employment rising, probably in the area of another 160,000 to 200,000" jobs.
 
Lower Than Forecast
 That figure was lower than most forecasts, and bond traders seized on the remark as an indication that the economic expansion remained moderate and would not rekindle inflation, which erodes the value of debt securities. Bond prices had been battered earlier this week on fears that the economy would pick up speed too fast and prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to counter possible inflation.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 23/32 , to 98 24/32 , and its yield fell to 6.34 percent, from 6.40 percent Wednesday. Short-term interest rates also declined moderately. The declines helped lift stock prices, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing above 3,800 for the first time. [Page D4.]
Although Mr. Reich's remark prompted traders to buy bonds, it also stirred the wrath of a number of Wall Street economists, who complained to the Labor Department.
"In our opinion, a person in his position should be saying nothing about the employment report this close to the release date," Stephen Slifer, chief financial economist at Lehman Brothers, wrote in a commentary distributed to the firm's customers yesterday.
Mary Meagher, a spokeswoman for the Labor Secretary, said Mr. Reich was merely repeating what he thought was the consensus forecast of private analysts.
"He did not know what the number was and gave his own estimate based on other public information and past data," she said.
 
Only White House Knows
 The Labor Department said only the White House, not Mr. Reich, received the numbers ahead of their early morning release, which is usually on the first Friday after the end of the month in the report. The jobs report is the first significant economic report of the previous month.
Some hard data were released yesterday, however. The Government said new applications for jobless benefits last week increased by a stronger-than-expected 70,000, to 363,000, from a revised 293,000 the week before, which was shortened by the Chirstmas Eve holiday.
But economists and credit market traders dismissed the surge as an aberration, saying the holidays and other factors made the report an unreliable indicator.
More important will be today's jobs report. Some estimates of jobs growth last month are as high as 300,000. Market participants have been preoccupied all week with the jobs number because they hope to get a clue in the December economy of whether the fourth quarter's momentum will be strong enough to carry into the 1994 first quarter.
 
Inflation Threat Denied
 Secretary Reich contended there was no inflation threat in the United States and thus "no need for a tightening of monetary policy."
Dennis M. Bushe, a managing director at Prudential Investment Advisers in charge of fixed income funds, said the importance of Mr. Reich's remarks was magnified by the bond market's skittishness all week. "Every day this week has been a seesaw," he said.
Today's employment number "will set the tone of the market for the next couple of weeks," Mr. Bushe added. "The issues in the market are: Will the Fed act now and make a pre-emptive strike against inflation, which has been behaving itself, or will the economy slow in the first quarter with no need for the Fed to act immediately?"
At the Treasury's one-year bill auction yesterday, investor demand was strong and the average rate was 3.52 percent. Noncompetitive bids totaled an impressive $568 million, well above typical one-year bill auctions.
The following are the results of yesterday's auction:

HEADLINE: Giuliani Instructs Agencies To Cut Spending 1 Percent

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

 BODY:
Facing a gap in next year's budget estimated to exceed $2 billion, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has ordered most New York City agencies to cut spending by 1 percent immediately.
And to insure that he wrestles spending under control, Mr. Giuliani has imposed what he called "a strict monitoring system" that requires agency heads whose spending goes over budget to meet with the budget director, Abraham M. Lackman, or Deputy Mayor Peter J. Powers to explain why. Anyone whose agency's spending rises more than 2 percent will have to explain the reasons to the Mayor himself. 
 The spending reductions -- ordered by Mr. Giuliani in a letter on Wednesday to each of the city's commissioners and directors of other agencies -- will pare $75 million from the current budget, which ends in June, Mr. Lackman said.
Trimming all city services except for the police and fire departments and the school system by 2 percent over a full year should also save about $150 million in next year's budget, which Mr. Giuliani and his aides are now drafting.
"It's a sizable down payment," said Mr. Lackman, who is assembling the options for closing the $2 billion budget gap without the politically troubling cuts in service that the Mayor has promised to avoid.
By imposing a rigid review process, Mr. Giuliani clearly intends to be deeply involved not only in making the city's budget but also in overseeing the spending of each agency.
In the letter, Mr. Giuliani said that similar reviews would be conducted every three months from now on to help to insure that agencies keep spending within the budget.
"It's a message to the commissioners that this Mayor wants to get control of this budget," Mr. Lackman said. "And you can't wait till next year. You have to start right away."
 
No 'Border Wars'
 Mr. Giuliani also met yesterday with Governor-elect Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, and together they pledged to help improve the region's economy by ending the "border wars" that have erupted between the city and its neighbor over jobs, commuter taxes and sports teams.
Mr. Giuliani and Mrs. Whitman offered no details on initiatives or agreements on any of the issues that have divided the city and state, particularly taxes on commuters. But after their brief meeting at City Hall, they agreed that outright hostilities, especially over luring companies and their jobs, had proved only harmful.
"Our competition right now in the State of New Jersey is not New York," said Ms. Whitman, who is to take the oath as Governor on Jan. 18. "We are here in a region with New York. It behooves us to have a strong region. Our competition right now is with North Carolina, South Carolina and Texas."
It remains to be seen whether amity between Mr. Giuliani and Ms. Whitman -- two Republicans who ousted Democrats last fall on campaign platforms that promised economic turnarounds -- can bridge the deep divisions that have existed, and any spirit of cooperation will surely undergo strain when their often contradictory interests arise.
Mr. Giuliani and Ms. Whitman said they would establish a formal relationship between their offices, with regular meetings, like the alliance Mr. Giuliani has already established with the county executives of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland.
Their meeting, though, indicated that in some respects at least, relations between the city and New Jersey had improved. When asked whether the bidding wars over corporate giants would continue, Mr. Giuliani and Ms. Whitman acknowledged that there would always be some disagreements.
"What it means," Mr. Giuliani said, "is that maybe that game isn't as tough as it was before."
 
Freeze on Hiring
 Mr. Giuliani's letter to city agencies also included his order to agencies to stop hiring new employees unless those hirings are approved by the highest mayoral deputies. Mr. Lackman has also asked commissioners and directors to draw up plans to reduce their budgets for next year by 5 percent or 10 percent.
If needed, those cuts will be included in the budget now being drafted. After receiving an extension from the City Council on Monday, Mr. Giuliani must submit a preliminary financial plan by Feb. 1.
