HEADLINE: Dow Rises 5.06 to Reach Record Close of 3,803.88

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average eked out another record high in hectic trading yesterday, closing above 3,800 for the first time.
Helped by a drop in interest rates, the Dow rose 5.06 points, to 3,803.88, eclipsing Wednesday's record of 3,798.82. 
 Despite the Dow's record close, many analysts said they were not that impressed with the market's performance. Gains were not broad-based: On the New York Stock Exchange, 1,076 issues rose in price, but 1,054 declined.
"Normally, when you have more than 1,000 stocks gaining ground, it's a great day," Larry Wachtel, a vice president at Prudential Securities Inc., said. "But right now, the Dow is an average that is getting in the way of a rotation of ownership. And the enormous volume you are seeing represents money managers choosing up sides."
 
Heavy Trading Week
 There were 367.9 million shares that traded hands on the Big Board yesterday, bringing total volume for the week to more than 1.37 billion shares traded.
Barring some sort of calamity today, volume for the week will almost certainly be the second most active in the history of the exchange, exceeding the 1.55 billion shares that changed hands during the week of Nov. 5, 1993. But it is unlikely that volume will come anywhere close to the 2.3 billion shares traded during the week of Oct. 23, 1987, when the stock market crashed.
"The volume is extraordinary, and is a tribute to the huge amount of money that is in mutual funds, pension funds and other sources being pushed through the market," David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, said. "But I view this as being a little bit negative, because we are getting all this volume and the market is going nowhere."
 
Nasdaq Index Up 2.36 Points
 Among broader market averages, the Standard & Poor's 500 index dipped 0.43 point, to 467.12. The American Stock Exchange composite index rose by 0.21 point, to 479.00. And the Nasdaq's composite index was up 2.36 points, to 780.41.
Though the market appeared to be moving sideways yesterday, there were stocks that went places.
Led by railroad stocks, the Dow's transportation index soared by 23.38 points, to a record 1,802.21.
Among transportation issues, Union Pacific gained 1 3/4, to 66 3/8. Burlington Northern gained 1 3/4, to 58 3/4. And the AMR Corporation, parent of American Airlines, rose 1 1/8, to 69 7/8.
Leading the 30 issues that make up the Dow were Allied Signal, up 1, to 77 1/2; Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which rose 1 1/2, to 107 1/4, and American Telephone and Telegraph, up 1 1/8, to 53 3/4.
 
Retail Stocks Fall
 Some retailing stocks were among the session's biggest losers, as investors dumped shares of companies whose performance in December and stated prospects for the new year failed to meet expectations.
The losers included Circuit City Stores, which fell 4 1/2, to 17 5/8, after the electronics retailer reported that while December sales exceeded expectations, it saw the coming year as being increasingly competitive. The stock was the Big Board's most active of the day. Investors also sold Best Buy, which fell 7 1/2, to 39 3/4, on heavy volume after the electronics retailer posted its December results.
But Gap Inc.'s sales performance last month was good, and its stock rose 3 1/8, to 41 1/2.
Newspaper and publishing stocks continued to do well, with the Washington Post Company's B shares showing considerable strength.
The stock closed up 20 3/4, to 282 1/4. Early in the session, the New York Stock Exchange briefly suspended trading to ask Post management why the stock was rising so strongly. The company said it had no announcements planned.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Yen Slide Cheers Business in Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 6

 BODY:
After a year in which "endaka" -- the rise of the yen -- struck fear into Japan's leading industries, the Japanese currency is now in retreat.
The strengthening of the dollar against the yen since the dollar's historic low point in August, amounting to a rise of more than 12 percent, could lead to improved profits for Japan's automobile and electronics giants and help pave the way for a slow but eventual recovery of the stagnant Japanese economy, company officials and economists suggest.
 
Toyota Now Sees Profit
 Last summer, for instance, when currency rates had fallen to just above 100 yen to the dollar, the Toyota Motor Company said it might report its first operating loss ever. But with the dollar having risen, Tatsuro Toyoda, the company's president, recently reaffirmed that the company now expects a small operating profit in the current fiscal year ending June 30. 
 The one cloud hanging over this outlook for Japan is the possibility that the United States will intervene in the market to make the yen stronger to reduce Japan's huge trade surplus. Secretary of the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen raised such fears on Wednesday when he said that allowing the yen to decline would not be an acceptable way for Japan to try to escape from its recession.
The comment had some effect. In Tokyo trading today, the dollar slipped to 112.65 yen from 113.12 yen Wednesday. Later in New York, it eased to 112.60 yen, from 113.07 on Wednesday. Still, it is up substantially from the record low of 100.40 yen reached last August and also up significantly from about 108 yen a month ago. It is still down, however, from 125 yen at the beginning of last year.
Economists say that aside from the political factors, the dollar has been gaining because the American economy appears to be getting stronger, especially in comparison with the Japanese economy.
The changing trade situation is also helping. Last year, the yen rose in part because United States officials indicated they would like to see a stronger yen to help trim Japan's huge trade surplus. Recent monthly figures suggest that Japan's trade surplus with the world, although not yet with the United States, is starting to fall.
 
Dollar Seen at 115 Yen
 Economists have been saying the dollar could continue rising against the yen until it reaches the 115 to 120 range. But traders say Secretary Bentsen's comments could make it hard for the dollar to get much above 115 because the currency market would fear American intervention at that point.
Another factor is that the trade talks between the United States and Japan are not making much progress. If that remains true, approaching Feb. 11, when President Clinton is scheduled to meet Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan, the yen could be bid up on speculation that the United States will again resort to using the strong yen as a weapon.
Even without political considerations, there is a difference of opinion as to how the currency exchange ratios will move in the long run.
Robert Alan Feldman, director of economic research for Salomon Brothers in Tokyo, said that Japan's trade surplus was still very large, which would put upward pressure on the yen. "It's very hard to get the yen to stay on a weakening path for much longer than a couple of months," he said.
But Geoffrey Barker, economist at Baring Securities in Tokyo, disagreed, arguing that the dollar had begun a sustained climb that would last two to three years and bring it above 130 yen.
"The economic backdrop is absolutely unequivocal -- a stronger dollar," he said. "It's breaking out of the downtrend that the dollar's been on against the yen since 1990."
 
Export Profits Sag
 As the dollar sank last year, Japanese export-dependent companies saw their revenues and profits drop sharply because their products became less competitive abroad, while foreign products became more competitive in Japan's market. Furthermore, the Japanese sales that were made abroad became worth less when converted into yen.
Companies responded by shifting manufacturing offshore, importing more foreign components or finished products to Japan and raising prices on exports. Economists and company executives say it is still too early to consider reversing any of those steps. Because of high costs for land, labor and materials in Japan, it still makes sense to import parts and to shift manufacturing offshore.
Toyota, for instance, just raised prices by an average of 1.8 percent on cars sold in the United States to account for the yen's appreciation last year, and there is no plan to lower prices now. "We do not decide according to temporary fluctuations of the yen," a spokesman said.
 
Industry Favors 115 Yen
 "If the yen comes down to 115, the majority of Japanese industry would be quite happy with that," said Toru Kusukawa, chairman of the Fuji Research Institute, last month.
Yukio Ozawa, deputy general manager of investor relations for the Sony Corporation, said the company made its profit predictions for this fiscal year assuming 105 yen to the dollar. As a result of the dollar's recent rise, sales and operating profits might come in better than expected, although pretax earnings are not likely to change much because the company had hedged against currency fluctuations, he said.
But Mr. Ozawa said that more important than any short-term impact on reported earnings was the impact on the general economy.
"Psychologically, it's very helpful to us," he said. "The sentiment of top management in Japan may be a little brighter and the general consumer might also loosen their spending a little bit," he said.

Dollar Up Against Mark
 By Reuters
 The dollar climbed against leading European currencies yesterday, reaching a five-month high against the German mark on expectations for brisk American economic growth in the coming months.
The dollar rose to 1.7462 marks, its highest level since August, before closing in New York at 1.7453 marks, up from 1.7395 marks late Wednesday. The British pound, meanwhile, slipped to $1.4815, from $1.4870.

HEADLINE: Workers Redirect Their Kindness to Help the Neediest

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
For decades, lawyers at the small Manhattan firm of Pulvers, Pulvers, Thompson & Kutner celebrated the holidays by giving gifts to the people who helped make their lives easier, such as paralegals, court reporters and secretaries.
But since 1986, the firm's 11 lawyers have redirected the money they would have spent on scarves, cologne or liquor, and instead have written a check to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. This year they gave $700. 
 Patrice M. Pulvers, a partner in the firm, said the lawyers abandoned traditional gifts because they believed that the former recipients would rather see the money used to help those in need. "We all live and work here," Ms. Pulvers said yesterday. "And we all know when we look around that it's a city that needs our help."
 
Establishing a Tradition
 Around the city, at law firms, brokerage houses, medical practices and countless other businesses, hundreds of people have established similar traditions, forgoing gifts to each other or to their clients in order to help the Neediest Cases Fund reach the homeless, disabled and elderly.
The fund, which is conducting its 82d annual appeal for contributions through Feb. 28, was created in 1912 with the idea that New Yorkers would help the poor in their city if they were made aware of the dire conditions. All contributions go directly to seven social-services agencies because The Times pays all overhead.
The campaign has raised $3,009,953.85 this year, nearly $100,000 more than at the same time last year. The money helps the charities, whose resources are already stretched thin, to provide needy New Yorkers with more of the most basic necessities such as winter coats, hot meals, dental care and temporary shelter.
While fewer individual contributions have been received -- 7,692 compared with 8,198 at this time last year -- donors have reached deeper into their pockets despite the lingering effects of the economic downturn in the New York region. But the fund still lags behind the level of its most successful campaign in 1991-1992, when more than $5 million was raised.
For more than a decade, the employees in the asset management and business development divisions at the United States Trust Company of New York have used their collective power to help. This year, instead of exchanging holiday cards, the employees contributed 37 checks for the Neediest Cases Fund, raising $1,150.
 
Bake Sales and Odd Jobs
 Other companies and groups that contribute range from large financial concerns like Sterling Group, a marketing and design consulting firm in Manhattan that gave $500, to smaller companies like Cityproof Corporation, a window-installation company in Queens.
"As we go through our daily routine and deal with our everyday problems, we often lose sight of those who are less fortunate than ourselves," wrote Michael Damelin of Cityproof, in a letter with the company's $100 donation.
Sometimes the fund-raising efforts are made by groups of donors who have not yet entered the business world and must rely more on elbow grease and baking savoir-faire than on financial clout.
The 15 students in Elizabeth Block's fourth-grade class at Rye Country Day School in Rye, N.Y., gave $227.10 after they held a bake sale and collected money by doing odd jobs at home.
"Some of the jobs were cleaning rooms, folding wash, cooking, cleaning our parents' offices, shoveling away ice, baby-sitting, watering plants and back rubs," the students wrote. "We hope you will make good use of our money."

HEADLINE: Whitman's Right-Hand Woman in Trenton;
Hazel F. Gluck, Lobbyist, Friend and Political Pro, Has No Office but Plenty of Power

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
In the summer of 1992, two old friends, both political pros, finally found time for a long-promised lunch together.
"Right away I asked Christie, 'Are you going to run for governor?' And she said, 'Yes,' " Hazel Frank Gluck recalled the other day. 
 "And then Christie asked, 'Are you going to run?' and I said, 'No. I want you to be the next governor.' "
Hazel Gluck reflected and smiled, "It was the best choice I ever made."
As almost every schoolboy (and schoolgirl) knows, Christine Todd Whitman went on to defeat Jim Florio for New Jersey governor. Her good friend Hazel may have swallowed her own ambitions, but now her fortunes are soaring as well.
 
No. 2 Woman, No. 1 Lobbyist
 Though largely unknown outside her state, Hazel Gluck has probably become the second most influential woman in New Jersey politics. She will go to the Whitman inauguration on Jan. 18 as a kind of godmother to the New Jersey Republican women's movement. She has served as co-chairwoman of both Mrs. Whitman's campaign and her transition office, having a major hand in the new Governor's cabinet appointments. And without question Ms. Gluck will enjoy the best access and greatest influence among all Trenton's thronging lobbyists.
"Has it helped my business? Absolutely." That is how Ms. Gluck describes the impact of Mrs. Whitman's victory on the fortunes of Public Policy Advisers Inc., the lobbying firm that Ms. Gluck founded in 1989 after weighing but rejecting a run for governor.
To Ms. Gluck's way of thinking, it took guts for a Republican woman to set out in the influence business at such an inauspicious time -- even someone as accomplished in state government as she. New Jersey was in deep recession, Mr. Florio had crushed his Republican opponent and Democrats controlled both houses of the Legislature.
Now, of course, Mr. Florio is the goner, and the men and women that Ms. Gluck has helped pick for the Whitman cabinet will soon be measuring the walls of imposing offices for portraits of their families and political friends. They include her former partner, Judith Shaw, as the new Governor's chief of staff.
 
Clients Tramp the Stairs
 Since the election, clients and would-be clients have been tramping the narrow stairs to Ms. Gluck's second-floor office suite in a refurbished brownstone next to the Department of Environmental Protection and Energy. Casino operators, garbage haulers, land developers want to enlist the friend of the Governor. State House Democrats say Ms. Gluck is telling people she will bill a million dollars in fees during her friend's first year in office.
So far, Ms. Gluck's firm is still a small one. Her clients reported paying Public Policy Advisers $82,102 for lobbying at the state level in 1992, according to a compilation of lobbying spending for the last available reporting period by New Jersey Common Cause, the government reform group. (That amount excludes what she earned from lobbying local governments and public relations work.)
By contrast, the biggest lobbying firm, Harold L. Hodes's Public Strategies Inc., was paid $1.7 million in 1992, and Roger A. Bodman's Impact Inc. received $1.2 million for state-level lobbying.
 
A Shadow Government
 Ms. Gluck is by no means the only lobbyist on Mrs. Whitman's 300-member transition team. Last month, The Record of Hackensack counted 36 registered lobbyists on the Governor-elect's panel, including Deborah T. Poritz, whom Mrs. Whitman has chosen to be her Attorney General, and Judith Shaw, the new chief of staff.
Like Ms. Gluck, many of these Whitman advisers are alumni of the Kean administration. During the Florio years, they became an informal shadow government in law firms, academia and lobbying concerns. But no one else acquired the reputation for decisiveness and dependability that Ms. Gluck now enjoys.
"You just don't stop Hazel," said former Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who promoted Ms. Gluck up a ladder of progressively more challenging jobs during his administration in the 1980's. "She has no hesitation. Whether it's a union leader or a legislator or whoever happens to be standing in the way, she comes right at them."
"It sort of surprises them sometimes," Mr. Kean added and chuckled at the recollection.
Ms. Gluck, then married to a pediatrician, got her start in politics in the early 1970's when she won appointment as head of Ocean County's first Office of Consumer Affairs. Within five years, she had become head of the County Board of Freeholders that had appointed her. In 1979, she won a seat in the Assembly. Defeated in a campaign for the Senate in 1981, the year Mr. Kean won his first term, she became the new Governor's Lottery Director. The key to the position was learning and promoting new games; in three years under Ms. Gluck, the young agency increased its revenues to $900,000 a year from $500,000.
 
Patience and a Big Room
 In 1984, Mr. Kean, facing a crisis in municipal liability coverage, made her Insurance Commissioner. Insurance rates were soaring, and some townships could get no coverage at all. Ms. Gluck imposed order on the chaos by using her favorite management tools: patience and a meeting room big enough for all sides to sit down together.
Where she really established her reputation as a trouble-shooter and Kean insider was in her next job as head of the giant Transportation Department. The Transportation Trust Fund, a major source of financing for roads and bridges, was almost depleted. The New Jersey Turnpike Authority was bulling through a plan to widen the interstate without so much as a by-your-leave from Trenton.
"You could see that Tom Kean grew to rely on Hazel for more and more difficult jobs," said Donald T. DiFranceso, the Senate majority leader. "She was lottery commissioner, which is not necessarily a very heavy lift. Then she went to Insurance, which has always been a tough job, and then she went to Transportation, which is a huge department."
Ms. Gluck shepherded a 2.5 cent gasoline tax through the Legislature to replenish the trust fund, and she spearheaded a Kean program to make cabinet members ex-officio members of all state authorities, a step that helped rein in the Turnpike Authority. As a kind of parting gift, Mr. Kean appointed Ms. Gluck to one of New Jersey's seats on the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, a term that expired in July.
 
Sticking to Her Business
 Had she wished, Ms. Gluck said, she might have parlayed Mrs. Whitman's sponsorship into becoming the first woman to head the Port Authority. But she said she had rejected the idea of new state appointments in favor of sticking to her business.
Ms. Gluck acknowledges a muted but distinct feminist consciousness in the new Whitman administration, more rooted in pride than ideology. She often refers to Mrs. Whitman as "New Jersey's first female governor," and in an interview, she described the state Republican Party, which is broadly progressive on social issues and distinctly in favor of abortion rights, as a natural home for women.
Indeed, Republicans are quick to say that the state G.O.P., with its roots in suburban township councils, school boards and volunteer agencies, has done far better at promoting women than the Democrats. Mr. Kean elevated more women, Ms. Gluck prominent among them, to high places in his administration than Mr. Florio did. In the legislature, Republican women outnumber their Democratic sisters 12 to 2.
Now long divorced and her two children grown, Ms. Gluck pours on the hours at the office on East State Street. Her client list includes dozens of companies seeking contracts or regulatory advice or help with permits from state agencies. They include K. Hovnanian Companies of New Jersey (the state's largest home builder), the Exxon, Mobil and Texaco corporations (who face environmental and land use constraints), and National Waste Disposal, a garbage hauler in one of the most tightly regulated markets in the country.
Ms. Gluck's firm also represents the G-Tech Corporation, a maker of lottery equipment, which is embroiled in a fight with Automatic Wagering International over a $100 million state contract for lottery computers. Automatic Wagering, which is represented by Roger Bodman, another lobbyist on the Whitman transition team, has protested that G-Tech is going to win the contract even though G-Tech's bid was higher than its own. The lottery commission has put off announcing the award until Jan. 20, two days after the Whitman inauguration.
 
Choosing Clients Carefully
 Ms. Gluck said that she always chose her clients carefully and had raised her level of vigilance even higher since Mrs. Whitman's election.
"I've had trash haulers come in here with a list of violations as long as their arms and say 'We want you to save our souls,' " Ms. Gluck laughed. "I won't do it."
Ms. Gluck is buying out Judith Shaw's interest in the lobbying firm, to remove any chance of the sort of conflict that touched Mr. Florio when his chief of staff, Joseph Salema, became embroiled in charges of conflict of interest with a business partner seeking state contracts.
"I am not going to take any clients who are in opposition to Christie's policies," Ms. Gluck vowed. "And I'm not going to do anything to embarrass Judy, and I'm not going to do anything to embarrass the first female governor of this state. And I sure as hell am not going to do anything that would embarrass me."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Though largely unknown outside her state, Hazel F. Gluck has probably become the second most influential woman in New Jersey politics, serving as co-chairwoman of both Mrs. Whitman's campaign and her transition office. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times) (pg. B1)

HEADLINE: Jobless Filing Up for Week

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6

 BODY:
The number of Americans filing for first-time unemployment benefits jumped by 70,000 last week, to the highest level in more than five months, the Labor Department said today.
But economists dismissed the surge as an aberration and said the economic expansion remained on track. They said the holidays and other factors made the report an unreliable indicator of the job market's health at the end of the year. 
 A more accurate picture of the economy is likely to emerge on Friday, when the December employment report is released. The report is expected to show a large rise in payroll jobs last month.
Initial claims for benefits rose to 363,000 in the week that ended on Saturday from a revised 293,000 the previous week, after adjusting for seasonal factors. The department previously said the claims figure for the week ending Dec. 25 was 291,000.
The number of claims last week was the highest since 395,000 were filed in the week ending July 24 of last year, and the jump itself was the biggest since July 1992.
The four-week moving average for claims -- considered a better gauge of conditions in the job market -- rose moderately, to 328,500 in the latest week from 322,000 the previous week.

HEADLINE: Jane Alexander Asks Arts Professionals' Help

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
In her first major speech to a New York audience since she took over as the chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts in October, Jane Alexander yesterday called for a new partnership between commercial and nonprofit groups to counter what she called "the financial crisis in the arts."
"It's unrealistic to expect to get more public money in this time of widespread budget-cutting," she said, "so a practical partnership between the commercial sector and nonprofit groups is essential in the future." 
 Ms. Alexander was the keynote speaker at Showbiz Expo East, a three-day gathering of theater, film and television professionals at the New York Hilton and Towers that is to end tomorrow. The last time Ms. Alexander addressed a large audience on a public stage in Manhattan was last summer, when she was starring in "The Sisters Rosensweig" on Broadway.
Ms. Alexander asked the help of the professionals at the convention in "removing the stigma that's been unfairly attached to the arts endowment because of a handful of grants that some people didn't like."
 
First Cuts
 Her speech came on the heels of news articles about the first cuts in arts financing by her agency, which had its budget reduced by Congress in the fall. She told the convention that "although it almost made me feel ill," she had approved elimination of the 20-year-old Professional Theater Training Program, which has helped pay for instruction at 16 of the nation's premier drama schools.
She said that although it was "discouraging," the agency was beginning to notify arts groups of other cuts in drama, dance, museum, opera, music, film and video programs.
Explaining that "we had to cut somewhere, and there is no way to be fair," Ms. Alexander said that the affected arts groups "are surprised, but so far most people aren't blaming the endowment; they're blaming the Congress." The endowment's budget was cut by $4.7 million, from $174.5 million.
Ms. Alexander said that the lack of money was "a quiet crisis in the arts" and that economic hardship had led to a "stagnation in the arts structure and community." The resulting "talent drain" in the arts, she said, can be reversed only by increased participation of the commercial sector. "The name of the game in the future is partnership," she said.
 
'Proving Ground'
 She suggested that nonprofit theater companies "are the proving ground for many of the most well-known and acclaimed stories and dramas in America, and the crucible for many of our playwrights, screenwriters, directors and actors." Therefore, she said, "we need the help of the commercial theater sector and its sister industries in film and television to support a movement to re-inspire theater in New York and across the country."
Although joint financing arrangements between nonprofit theater companies and commercial producers have been increasing in recent years, Ms. Alexander said in an interview after her speech that there was need for "a basic change in mind set that would involve commercial producers more systematically in nurturing new works."
She called for a significant increase in "commercial support early on for writers, actors, directors and others in theater workshops and laboratories."
In the interview, she said that as the chairwoman of the agency she would support controversial or provocative artworks recommended for financing by the endowment's peer panels: works of the kind that caused such difficulties for her predecessors at the agency, often because of contoversial sexual content.
"The right wing is very organized with its campaign against the endowment," she said. "We are in precarious times when an organized segment of our society seeks to control the dissemination of information, and seeks to ban elements of our common culture on moral grounds without even knowing the art, or the books, or the plays, or the human beings they fear."
Therefore, she said, she is organizing the creation of what she called a national task force to lobby for arts financing on the local, state and national levels.
In the interview, Ms. Alexander said that as the agency's chairwoman, she is forbidden to lobby politicians about the endowment's 1995 budget, "but I'm talking to Congressmen and Senators, giving them information about the value of the arts." "I've also spoken to the President," she said, "and I have much more to tell him."
Ms. Alexander also announced that the endowment would sponsor a national conference in Chicago in mid-April for nonprofit arts groups. The conference will "attempt to map out the agenda for the arts at the dawn of this new century," she said.

HEADLINE: Review/Art;
An Early Champion of Modernists

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN

 BODY:
When the collection of the dealer Charles Daniel was auctioned at Parke-Bernet Galleries in New York in 1946, an article about the sale referred to "the late Charles Daniel." In fact, Daniel was forgotten but not gone. He lived until 1971. No doubt the gallery he ran, which closed in 1932, had faded so much from people's minds by the end of World War II that the confusion was understandable.
Today, probably only a handful of people have more than the vaguest knowledge of him. But a first-rate exhibition at the Zabriskie Gallery honoring Daniel and his gallery should help to rectify that. 
 The show presents works by artists he exhibited, and a few works that were displayed in the Daniel Gallery itself. The list of artists, diverse and impressive, includes Man Ray and Alexander Archipenko, Joseph Stella and Marsden Hartley, Charles Demuth and Charles Sheeler, Peter Blume and Yasuo Kuniyoshi, Marguerite Zorach and William Zorach, Raphael Soyer and Glenn O. Coleman.
It was Coleman who Daniel said turned him on to art. The son of immigrants who ran a German restaurant at 28th Street and 10th Avenue in Manhattan, Daniel opened, with his brother George, a cafe (he called it a saloon) on 42d Street and Ninth Avenue where Coleman regularly ate lunch. He and Daniel became friends. "That's all I needed; I was introduced to art," Daniel recalled.
In 1908 he began collecting. Four years later he rented a space on 55th Street, calling it the Daniel Studio, where artists could meet and the public could see their work. The next year, 1913, was the year of the Armory Show; Daniel sold his interest in the cafe and used the money to finance the Daniel Gallery on the top floor of a building on West 47th Street. Rockwell Kent created the logo, and Man Ray designed and hand-lettered the catalogues.
The critic Murdock Pemberton considered Daniel a genius at discovering artists. He was clearly sympathetic and wide-open to the new in art. Daniel gave dozens of artists their first solo shows in New York. He was one of the earliest dealers to treat photography as a fine art. (A pair of Man Ray photographs at Zabriskie is outstanding.) During its 20 years, the Daniel Gallery exhibited the works of 15 women. Daniel came to be identified with the Precisionists. (Some of the finest and most beautiful drawings and paintings at Zabriskie are by Demuth, Sheeler and Dickinson.) But one of his gallery's most striking qualities was the range of work that over the years encompassed artists as different as the Zorachs, B. J. O. Nordfeldt, Hartley, Blume and Soyer.
As it happened, the Daniel Gallery's life span covered the years of modernism's extraordinary, often tumultuous rise in America. Not long before the Armory Show, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Sir Charles Parton Clarke, dismissed Impressionism as something "invented in the absinthe shops of Paris." And the Met's curator of paintings, Bryson Burroughs, was almost dismissed for buying a Cezanne out of the show. Hardly anybody collected modern art; Alfred Stieglitz's 291 Gallery, which Daniel credited for his interest in modernism and where he bought works by John Marin as early as 1910, was alone in exhibiting the works of artists like Matisse, Rodin, Lautrec and Picasso.
But the Armory Show inspired a spate of new galleries dedicated to modernism, including the Montross, Coady, Valentine, Bourgeois, Washington Square and Modern. Charles Daniel had plenty of company. New magazines and societies were founded. Stieglitz had his journal, also called 291, and publications like The Soil and The Blindman arose. The Society of Independent Artists came together to combat traditionalist establishments like the National Academy of Design. And great collectors like Duncan Phillips, Katherine Dreier, A. E. Gallatin, Walter Arensberg, John Quinn, Arthur Jerome Eddy, Albert Barnes, Abby Aldrich Rockefeller and Lillie Bliss -- collectors with an evangelical zeal -- began to concentrate their resources not only on buying new work, but also proselytizing for it.
Another distinguished collector was Ferdinand Howald, a retired mining engineer from Columbus, Ohio, who lived on Park Avenue and bought almost exclusively through the Daniel Gallery. Thanks to Howald, it survived World War I, when many other galleries didn't. The war stirred isolationist feelings in America, and modern art was suspiciously European. The weak economy was the biggest problem. Among the galleries to fold was 291; Daniel inherited several of Stieglitz's American artists, including Stanton MacDonald-Wright, Marin and Abraham Walkowitz.
Except for the reviews of Henry McBride, one of the great champions of modernism, the shows at the Daniel Gallery, like those at other galleries of modern art, were routinely panned. You can get an idea of the persistent, and occasionally peculiar, hostility that Daniel and his modernist colleagues had to endure from the reaction in 1921 to the Metropolitan's first exhibition of Impressionist and Post-Impressionist art, which included no work more recent than a pre-Cubist Picasso. Lenders to the show, like Quinn, were denounced in newspapers for promoting "the same form of degeneracy that brought on the war." It was years before the Met exhibited modern art again.
Still, the 1920's was the decade when modernism finally took hold in America, and by its end institutions of modern art included the Phillips Collection in Washington, the Barnes Collection near Philadelphia (Daniel sold works to both Phillips and Barnes), A. E. Gallatin's Gallery of Living Art on Washington Square in Manhattan and, of course, the Museum of Modern Art, which in its inaugural year, 1929, was able to borrow works for its exhibitions from collections in 51 American cities in 20 states. The Whitney Studio Club, which had been founded by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney, closed in 1928, but in 1931 it was succeeded by the Whitney Museum of American Art.
By then Daniel was almost through. The Depression hit him hard. Howald made the last of his 300 purchases from the gallery in 1929 and moved back to Columbus. Many of Daniel's best-known artists quietly found other dealers like Edith Halpert. Daniel had moved in 1924 to 600 Madison Avenue, near what had become the center of New York's art scene on 57th Street. (The Museum of Modern Art was first located at 57th and Fifth Avenue.) But by 1932, Daniel could no longer pay his rent, and authorities closed the gallery, seizing everything in it.
Pemberton once wrote: "Daniel probably never made a nickel out of art. He was that rare genius -- a patron-dealer who came to art only for the love of it." In Daniel's later years, artists who owed him their start gave him small works as gifts, which he was forced to sell to support himself. In the 1960's, Daniel began to offer some of these to the Zabriskie Gallery, and Virginia Zabriskie came to know and admire him.
She recalls him in the show's smart little catalogue (which includes an especially useful essay by Julie Mellby and entries by Heather Nevin): "Charles Daniel's interest in contemporary art continued well into the last years of his life," Ms. Zabriskie writes. "I remember his conviction that Larry Rivers 'knew how to handle a brush' and his reservations about de Kooning's ability to do the same."
At the end, she adds, "he was very poor, living shabbily with a nephew." Daniel died at 92. With this thoughtful and very beautiful tribute at her gallery, he is now gone but no longer forgotten.
"Charles Daniel and the Daniel Gallery: 1913-1932" remains at the Zabriskie Gallery, 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, Manhattan, through Feb. 12.

HEADLINE: Home Video

BYLINE: By Peter M. Nichols

 BODY:

For Children, and Parents
For Kidvidz, a distributor of children's videos in Newton, Mass., there are two not unrelated problems with supplying good tapes for viewers aged 2 to 12. 
 "Parents are baffled about what they are and where to find them," said Karen Tucker, the company's president. "And the suppliers are baffled about how to get them to the parents."
To address the situation, Kidvidz has published the first issue of Kid's Special Delivery Video, a four-page circular that lists 25 videos chosen by a panel of experts from the fields of television, education and children's publishing.
The panel was formed by Kidvidz, which distributes three of the titles in the circular. Ms. Tucker said the guide, to be issued twice a year, will be circulated with other publications from various children's organizations. It is also available directly from Kidvidz. (Information: (800) 914-5678.)
Producers are invited to submit tapes for consideration. Manifestations of "cooperation, tolerance, nonviolence and fair treatment," a "socio-economic mix of talent" and "a respect for kids' intelligence" are needed to qualify.
Among the Kidvidz titles are "Piggy Banks to Money Markets, a Kid's Video Guide to Dollars and Sense" and "Squiggles, Dots and Lines, a Kid's Video Guide to Drawing and Creativity." Both are winners of Parents Choice awards.
Other titles in the circular stress both education and entertainment: "Beethoven Lives Upstairs," for example, a critically praised dramatic feature with passages from the composer's oeuvre, or "Teaching Kids Basketball With John Wooden."
 
Three Degrees of Heat
 Steamy movies occasionally come in three versions (R, unrated and NC-17), but now one version of a steamy movie comes in three packages.
For "Red Shoe Diaries: Another Woman's Lipstick," Republic Home Video put the film, an unrated sex fantasy, in three different boxes.
"For cover art we used to pick one image and aim at a narrow audience," said Glenn Ross, a vice president of Republic Pictures. "Now we can appeal to several audiences."
Dealers choose whichever cover art suits their customers. A box with a couple entwined is intended for males. Another box, aimed at women, conveys the image of having sex but omits some of the body parts. A third box, meant for grocers and other nonvideo merchants, pictures just the lovers' heads.
"Grocery stores don't want stuff exposed on shelves where kids walk by," Mr. Ross said.
 
Latin American Films
 "Latin American cinema hasn't come into its own in this country," said Milos Stehlik, co-director of Facets International, a Chicago dealer and distributor. "Americans know very little."
To enable its clientele to see many of these titles listed in one place, Facets has issued its Spanish and Latin American video catalogue, describing hundreds of films and other features. Information: (800) 331-6197.
 
NEW VIDEO RELEASES
 
Menace II Society
1993. New Line. $95.25. 104 minutes. Closed captioned. R.
The graphic killing of a Korean grocer and his wife by a young black man sets the tone for the Hughes Brothers' riveting tour of teen-age life in the Watts district of Los Angeles. Though slice-of-life realism sometimes turns to sensationalistic gore, there is an especially strong sense of how plentiful firearms, television and video-game violence and a macho ethic mix with boredom and hopelessness to create combustible situations. "More acutely than any movie before," Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times, "it gives cinematic expression to the hot-tempered, defiantly nihilistic ethos that ignites gangster rap."
 
Robin Hood: Men in Tights
1993. Fox. $96.83. 105 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.
In its sendup of every Robin Hood movie ever made, Mel Brooks's breezy spoof scores its most direct hit on the clammy political correctness of Kevin Costner's "Robin Hood, Prince of Thieves." Unfortunately, steeped as it is in the horrendous taste and up-front rudeness one has come to know and love in the better Brooks films, this one struggles with dozens of bad gags that should have been fixed or thrown out. The director also has the bad habit of reprising bits from his "Young Frankenstein" and other movies, thereby focusing attention on the weaknesses of "Men in Tights." While it's acceptable to be offensive, "it's something else to scrape the bottom of your own barrel in front of everybody" (Vincent Canby).
 
Heart and Souls
1993. MCA/Universal. $95.25. Laser disk, $34.98. 104 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13.
Here, basically, is the story: Four passengers are killed in a bus crash, but their souls enter the body of the newborn baby of a woman who was also on the bus. Later, when the baby has grown into a yuppie, portrayed by Robert Downey Jr., the four spirits emerge to express themselves. Charles Grodin is a shy loner who wants to sing, Kyra Sedgwick is a lovelorn waitress, Alfre Woodard a loving mother and Ted Sizemore a jovial greaser. In a story sodden with sentiment, only Mr. Downey shines through. "The best thing about the film is to watch his uncanny impersonations of his co-stars" (Janet Maslin).
 
The Golden Coach
1952. Interama. $59.95. 103 minutes. In English. No rating.
In Jean Renoir's film, Anna Magnani is the star performer in a commedia dell'arte troupe touring Peru in the early 1700's. The golden coach belongs to the Spanish viceroy. Over-emoting as a supposedly ravishing beauty who juggles three lovers at once while holding all of society in thrall, Miss Magnani has a hard time disguising her raucous instincts. Wooden plotting and dialogue are no help either, but "the mingled decor of Harlequin costumes, 18th-century flamboyancy and Spanish rococo makes for considerable excitement" (Bosley Crowther).

FROM YEARS PAST
 
From Art to War to Revolution:
A Documentary Catalogue
Along with the films of Luis Bunuel, Carlos Saura, Pedro Almodovar and other directors, the Spanish and Latin American Video catalogue from Facets International of Chicago includes dozens of documentaries and arts titles. Here are some examples. (Note that some tapes are also available from other dealers.)
THE MYSTERY OF PICASSO. As part of an agreement between the artist and the director Henri-Georges Clouzot, Picasso created six paintings for this film (an award-winner at Cannes and a commercial flop in the United States) and then had them destroyed. 1957. $39.98. 77 minutes. French with English subtitles.
ART OF HAITI. Mark Mamalakis's film features interviews with artists and views of their work. 1982. $39.95. 26 minutes.
FRIDA KAHLO. Sada Thompson narrates a study of the life and work of the Mexican muralist and wife of Diego Rivera. 1983. $39.95. 62 minutes.
IMPROPER CONDUCT. The plight of intellectuals and homosexuals in Cuba under Fidel Castro is explored in Nestor Almendros's film. 1984. $79.95. 112 minutes. Spanish with English subtitles.
GUAZAPA: FACE OF WAR IN EL SALVADOR. The war correspondent Don North's award-winning account covers a rebel attack on a National Guard outpost, the Government's counterattack and a look at the everyday lives of civilians caught in the middle. 1987. $35. 37 minutes.
PICTURES FROM A REVOLUTION. The American photographer Susan Meiselas examines the Sandinista revolution with an outlook that has its biases but still works to transcend partisanship. 1991. $29.95. 92 minutes.
EVELYN GLENNIE IN RIO. A visit to the carnival in Rio de Janeiro by the deaf percussionist includes performances with the London Symphony Orchestra. $24.95. 93 minutes.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
FISHERS BIG WHEEL TO CLOSE 55 STORES IN LIQUIDATION

BYLINE: Reuters

 BODY:
The discount retailer Fishers Big Wheel Inc. is closing 55 stores and putting 2,000 people out of work. The store chain filed for bankruptcy court protection on July 8, and on Wednesday a United States Bankruptcy Court judge approved a request by the company's creditors to liquidate Big Wheel. Big Wheel will close 55 stores in eight states, either returning them to the landlords, selling those it owns or abandoning them. In its Chapter 11 filing, Big Wheel listed assets of $97 million and liabilities of $141.5 million. Big Wheel, based in New Castle, Pa., operated stores in Ohio, Michigan, Pennsylvania, New York, Connecticut, Indiana, West Virginia and Rhode Island. The stores sell clothing, footwear, home furnishings and toys.

LENGTH: 479 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Cuomo's Sobering Summons

 BODY:
Plenty of people have said that Gov. Mario Cuomo sounded like a Republican in his speech to the New York State Legislature on Wednesday. Many have also observed that the three main issues he addressed -- the economy, welfare and crime -- are uppermost in the minds of New York voters and thus an excellent formula for victory should he decide to run for a fourth term.
Yet far too little has been made of a more compelling point: As legislative programs go, the Governor's is eminently achievable. In that sense his address is a pointed challenge to the Legislature, especially the Republicans who have so often thwarted him -- and to Mr. Cuomo, who has a habit of thwarting himself. 
 The Governor's speech contained few of his customary oratorical flourishes, and not much in the way of passion or his usual promises to the poor. His most important theme was that New York needed to create an "aggressively hospitable" climate for business. To that end he called for cutting the corporate tax surcharge, phasing out the hotel tax, giving tax breaks to developers and eliminating a bunch of "obnoxious" fees.
Whether he can do all that in the face of a $1.5 billion budget deficit is doubtful; even so, Governor Cuomo is clearly aware that New York has lost 500,000 jobs in the last four years of his reign and that, recession aside, an inhospitable tax environment may have been partly to blame.
On welfare, Mr. Cuomo also emphasized jobs. He proposed that the state find work for welfare applicants before allowing them on the rolls. He would also cut benefits to families whose children are not attending schools and fingerprint welfare recipients as protection against fraud. He sounded a similarly tough note on crime, urging an overdue ban on assault weapons and harsher penalties for repeat offenders in violent crimes.
All three issues have long been part of the Republican domain. Politically, the G.O.P. cannot be pleased that Mr. Cuomo may have shrewdly positioned himself to outflank whoever runs against him; legislatively, however, it staggers the imagination to think that the Republicans who control the State Senate can, in good conscience, resist him. Indeed, his strongest opposition is likely to come from his fellow Democrats, who do not like the idea of fingerprinting welfare recipients, for example, and who can be expected to argue that cutting taxes will hurt programs for the poor.
Presumably as a call to arms, Mr. Cuomo quoted Shakespeare's "Coriolanus": "Action is eloquence." In the play, however, the line is a plea to Coriolanus from his mother to get off his high horse and go on bended knee to ask the Roman people for support. The quote actually works both ways: as a summons to action in the State Legislature, and as a reminder to himself that he must work harder than he has in the past to get his program through.

HEADLINE: Despite Settlements, Mideast May Find Peace;
The Bedouins Adapt

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Bedouins' Eviction Notice" (Op-Ed, Dec. 29), Prof. Clinton Bailey's attack on Israeli Government policy toward Bedouin citizens, is emotional and unfounded. To make his case of Government mistreatment, Mr. Bailey uses such inflammatory language as "waging a kind of war against the Bedouin tribes," "ethnic cleansing" and expulsion. 
 Throughout the Middle East, nomadic life is coming to an end. Israel is no different from Egypt, Jordan and Saudi Arabia in its efforts to settle Bedouins in towns. The reason is simple -- nomadic people require vast tracts of desert to maintain their herds of goats, and these often transcend closed national borders. United Nations committees have looked with disfavor on the negative ecological impact of grazing by herds of goats in the fragile desert habitat. Nomadic life in Israel, as elsewhere, is bowing to the exigencies of the 20th century.
Before Israel became a state, Bedouin children never went to school. Today, through compulsory education, all start in school, but unfortunately girls attend only through the fourth grade. Girls are removed at an early age because Bedouin culture frowns on education for women.
Soon after a girl reaches puberty she marries and has a large family, often 10 to 12 children. The Bedouin birth rate is 5 percent -- about the highest in the world. Despite this, the infant mortality rate is lower than in New York City's Harlem. This is a tribute to the commitment of the Health Ministry to deliver quality health care to Bedouin women through clinics and outreach teams.
I recently visited Tel Sheva, a Bedouin town outside Beersheva and saw some of the problems Mr. Bailey describes, that is, poverty and unemployment. But I also saw Arab-owned businesses, villas, a health clinic and a spanking new school building.
Finally, let us not join Professor Bailey in romanticizing the nomadic life of the Bedouin family scratching out a meager subsistence in the inhospitable and ofter cruel desert. Daily life is tough, grinding and especially harsh on women. The Bedouins in the townships are adapting reasonably well to their new communal life style.
 
MILTON PINCUS
Chmn., Bklyn College Hillel Foundation
Brooklyn, Dec. 30, 1993

HEADLINE: Seymour Lawrence, 67, Publisher For a Variety of Eminent Authors

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
Seymour Lawrence, an independent book publisher in New York City and Boston for almost 30 years who brought the first works of many important writers to the public, died on Tuesday at the Englewood Community Hospital in Englewood, Fla. He was 67 and lived in Wilton, Conn.
The cause was complications of a heart attack, said Irene Williams, the publicity director of the publisher Houghton Mifflin, with which Mr. Lawrence was affiliated. 
 Among the dozens of distinguished authors published by Mr. Lawrence, who was known as Sam, were Thomas Berger, Richard Brautigan, J. P. Donleavy, Jim Harrison, Katherine Anne Porter, William Saroyan, Kurt Vonnegut and Frank Conroy.
 
'Good Scout'
 "Sam's importance in the literary world was as a very good scout of talent," Mr. Vonnegut said yesterday.
Mr. Lawrence published Mr. Vonnegut's novel "Slaughterhouse-Five" in 1969, after the manuscript had been rejected by the publishing firm with which the author had a contract.
He published the works of four authors who won the Nobel Prize for Literature: Miguel Angel Asturias, Camilo Jose Cela, Pablo Neruda and George Seferis.
Mr. Lawrence started his independent imprint in 1965 with only one book on his list, "The Ginger Man," by Mr. Donleavy. Later he published such notable books as "Ship of Fools," by Ms. Porter; "Trout Fishing in America," by Mr. Brautigan; "Going After Cacciato," by Tim O'Brien; "Little Big Man," by Mr. Berger, and "Selected Poems," by Mr. Neruda.
 
Survival as an Independent
 He was unusual on the publishing scene in that he survived as an independent for more than 25 years, well into the era of merger and consolidation. In 1983, he was affected by the turmoil of the times. After 17 years of association with Dell, primarily with the Delacorte label, his imprint fell victim to the economy ax wielded by the troubled management team at Doubleday, Dell's owner.
After a stop at E. P. Dutton, Mr. Lawrence's imprint went to Houghton Mifflin in 1988.
At a party for Mr. Lawrence given by Houghton Mifflin in 1990, a number of authors, among them Mr. O'Brien, Mr. Vonnegut and Mr. Harrison, gathered to pay him tribute. Also present was a bookstore owner, John Evans of the Lemuria Bookstore in Jackson, Miss. Mr. Evans was described then as probably having sold more of Mr. Lawrence's books than any single bookseller. "Sam," said Mr. Evans, "has given the reader a fine bowl of literary gumbo."
Mr. Lawrence's authors described him as a publisher who was passionately committed to writers and writing, but who was not always tolerant of "misguided reviewers" or the publishing bureaucracy.
Joseph Kanon, an executive at Houghton Mifflin, said at the 1990 tribute: "The first time I met Sam Lawrence, he was making an argument on behalf of one of his authors. The last time I spoke with him, this morning, he was doing the same thing. On both occasions, as usual, he got what he wanted."
Mr. Lawrence, who grew up in New York City, became absorbed in books early in life. He was the editor of Wake, a literary magazine, when he was a student at Harvard University, from which he graduated in 1948. After working as a traveling book salesman, he joined the Atlantic Monthly Press in Boston in 1952. He became that firm's director three years later.
He is survived by his mother, Sophie Lawrence of Stamford, Conn.; a son, Nicholas Lawrence of Cambridge, Mass.; a daughter, Macy Ratliff of Bothell, Wash.; two granddaughters, and his companion, Joan Williams of Oxford, Miss.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 8, 1994, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary yesterday about Seymour Lawrence, an independent book publisher who died on Tuesday, misidentified the publisher of "Little Big Man," a 1964 novel by Thomas Berger. It was the Dial Press, not Mr. Lawrence.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
A Good Call on NATO

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
President Clinton is making some of America's best friends very unhappy -- Europeans who lived under Communism, fought it, and helped bring down the Soviet empire. Next week he will make them even unhappier when he tells them face to face that the U.S. will not agree to their becoming members of NATO.
Face to face, he will have to deal with people like the Czech writer Vaclav Havel, who went from a Communist jail to the presidency of his country, and President Lech Walesa of Poland, the electrician who created a freedom movement that bound together workingman and intellectual. 
 They will tell him of their still-vivid fears of the Russian imperialism that enslaved their countries under czarism and Communism. They will say they have earned the protection of NATO membership. Mr. Clinton -- he will say many things but essentially no, not yet.
My time as an American correspondent in Eastern Europe during the Communist ice age binds me to Eastern and Central European democrats. In some of their countries, "ex"-Communist politicians are strong, and in others fascists use democracy to try to destroy it. Those dangers give the passions of Mr. Havel and Mr. Walesa special meaning.
So when I sat down at a Presidential lunch for columnists about NATO I was emotionally and politically behind quick membership for some of the former Communist colonies.
Mr. Clinton did not present startling new reasons for delaying. But he put enough good existing reasons together lucidly enough so that I changed my mind. What? Yes.
I went away thinking that American friends of democracy in Eastern Europe could give him enough time to play it out without getting panicky.
Boris Yeltsin fears that immediate NATO membership for countries on Russia's border would help Russian nationalists sell their line of Russia imperiled. Mr. Clinton said the Russian President sends the message that Russia should not be pushed back, treated again as an enemy.
Is this appeasement of a foreign ruler? It seemed to me, listening to that question in my head, that appeasement is trying to buy off an enemy -- not trying to help a friend survive a growing threat at home. If it takes a couple of years and another election to make Russia comfortable with NATO neighbors, it is worth the wait. If not, or if the fascist-Communist alliance washes over Russia, NATO could extend membership protection fast to Eastern and Central Europe.
Anyway, the West would have to meet any Russian military adventure against Eastern Europe. The key point is not how many new members NATO brings in but how strong its current members stay.
Mr. Clinton said the reduction of U.S. forces in Europe from 326,000 to 100,000 was enough. But has it been too much, given the rise of the Russian uglies? Is Mr. Clinton's new Secretary of Defense going to decide for himself and tell us?
Mr. Clinton did not go into it, but there is another good reason for waiting before expanding NATO. Eastern and Central Europe have not settled down politically. Yugoslavia is eating itself alive, Czechoslovakia has split in two, Poland has elected a Government of "ex"-Communists, and in Hungary and Romania fascists name plazas after their heroes in hell.
The West should have expected upheavals, not a a straight, calm line, after so many decades of Communist and Nazi brutalization. Still, it would be an even nastier shock to find a national alliance of blackshirts and Communists sitting at a NATO table.
Some of my friends say that without Eastern Europeans in NATO, between Germany and Russia, the Germans would be very upset. I can live with that thought.
The President kept saying that while they were not getting membership, the former captive nations would be brought into closer political, military and economic cooperation with NATO members. So the tests of the Clintonian policy will be these:
Will closer ties with Eastern Europe turn out to be real or mumbo-jumbo? Will we put money and some military integration on the table or play Monopoly? Will "not right now" mean exactly that, or "not ever"?
The President's policy, as he said, is a judgment call. That is what he gets paid to make. This one seems reasonable and carefully thought out. I ate my full portion but for now feel a little lighter.

CORRECTION-DATE: February 8, 1994, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Correction: My statement in the column of Jan. 7 that Hungarians were naming plazas for dead Fascists is incorrect; my apologies.

HEADLINE: VIACOM ANNOUNCES MERGER AND RAISES BID FOR PARAMOUNT

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
After a week of speculation about how he might pull together the money to win Paramount Communications Inc. in a fierce bidding war, Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom Inc., submitted an offer yesterday that on the surface seemed stunning.
Trying desperately to beat a rival bid from QVC Network Inc., Viacom offered $105 a share in cash for 50.1 percent of Paramount's stock, with the rest to be purchased with Viacom stock. And in a companion move, he said Viacom would merge with the Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation, the giant video-rental company that has backed his bid for Paramount, in an exchange of stock worth $8.4 billion. 
 Before the merger is completed, Blockbuster will buy Viacom stock worth $1.25 billion, giving Mr. Redstone, who controls Viacom, the cash he needs to raise his Paramount bid.
 
Questions About Bid
 Despite considerable fanfare on Wall Street over the moves, financial analysts and traders quickly disparaged Viacom's bid. Because of the value of the stock portion of the offer, they pegged Viacom's bid at about $78 in cash and stock for each share of Paramount. That would be less than QVC's offer of about $83 a share, which Paramount's board has approved.
 By any measure, Viacom's return shows how intense the takeover battle has become. No media company can be certain of how entertainment programming will be distributed in the future, but all of them are aware of the need to have films and television series, like those that Paramount owns and produces, to attract viewers.
"It's a soap opera," said William LeFevre, an analyst at Ehrenkrantz King & Nussbaum, an investment firm in New York. "It's just going to go on and on."
 
MTV and Movie Rentals
 Indeed, even if Viacom fails to win Paramount, it said it would still merge with Blockbuster to create a media company with holdings including MTV: Music Television, the Nickelodeon and Nick at Nite cable channels, broadcast television programming and 3,600 video-rental stores across the country. Blockbuster sees Viacom as a way to expand out of home video, whose long-term prospects are tenuous as more and more programming is sent to homes electronically.
 Under the rules of the bidding process set up by Paramount in response to a ruling last month by the Delaware Supreme Court, Viacom had until yesterday to raise its offer before Paramount shareholders sold their shares to QVC, the home-shopping network. Paramount said yesterday that its board would meet next week to consider Viacom's revised proposal.
Many analysts on Wall Street were not happy with Viacom's latest offer. "To induce me to sell Mr. Redstone my stock, he will have to offer more total value," said a trader who owns Paramount stock that he said he had agreed to sell to QVC.
Several traders said Mr. Redstone, 70, seemed to be hoping that shareholders would focus on the $105 a share for 50.1 percent of the shares, instead of on the combined value of the stock and the cash in the bid.
Gordon Crawford, a senior vice president of the Capital Research Company, a big shareholder in Paramount, Viacom, QVC and Blockbuster, was among those critical of the new offer. He said, "To go to all the trouble of merging two companies, causing the value of both stocks to decline sharply when trading opens Monday, just to launch a bid that is clearly inferior to the existing QVC bid, seems like an exercise in futility."
The Viacom bid was announced after the stock market closed yesterday, but rumors of a Viacom-Blockbuster union had been circulating for some time. Viacom's class B shares closed at $41, down $1.75, while Paramount stock closed at $79.25, up 75 cents. QVC's shares jumped $1.125 to $40.625, and Blockbuster stock fell $1.625 to $28.25.
 
QVC Chairman's Response
 Even as Mr. Redstone and the chairman of Blockbuster Entertainment, H. Wayne Huizenga, were fielding calls from Wall Street investors yesterday, QVC's chairman, Barry Diller, said he thought the Paramount board should accept QVC's tender offer, which was scheduled to close last night, and which he noted was higher than Viacom's. Mr. Diller was speaking by phone from the offices of QVC's law firm, Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz.
The Paramount board had agreed to accept QVC's bid if 50.1 percent of Paramount's shareholders tendered their stock to QVC by last night, unless Viacom made a higher offer.
But with news of the new bid, many investors held their stock back from QVC, assuming they had more time to make a decision. A person close to QVC said late yesterday that Viacom confused the market by announcing a bid at the 11th hour and trying to convince people that Viacom's new offer was higher than QVC's.
Under the terms of its new offer, Viacom's total cash investment is $6.3 billion, or about $700 million more than the cash portion of QVC's most recent bid.
But Viacom has raised its offer from $85 a share in cash for 51 percent of the company, or a cash investment of about $5.2 billion, to $6.3 billion. Traders did not simply focus on the cash portion yesterday, however, since about 49 percent of the offer is in stock.
 
Creating a New Company
 The merger will create a new company to be called Viacom-Blockbuster Inc. The core business of Blockbuster, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is the rental of films on videocassettes, a business that is seen as highly vulnerable to the technical flexibility of interactive information systems, which would let people get the programming they wanted at home, any time they wanted.
Despite Blockbuster's current economic health -- it generates hundreds of millions of dollars annually -- Mr. Huizenga is well aware that it needs to expand into businesses with a more secure future. There is some logic, therefore, to a merger.
But Mr. Crawford and several other analysts wondered whether Viacom would do well to invest so heavily in such a tenuous business. It has agreed to acquire Blockbuster's stock for about $31 a share in Viacom stock, a 10 percent premium over its trading value.
While Viacom and Blockbuster promoted the values of their merger proposal yesterday, because it would allow cost savings in various television businesses, they admitted that the talks heated up only before Christmas, just after QVC raised its bid to its current level.
The news of a merger surprised some entertainment industry executives because Mr. Redstone had said he would not give up control of his company, of which he controls 85 percent of the voting stock.
He kept his word. Mr. Redstone will end up with about 61 percent of the vote in the new company, while Blockbuster and the public will hold the balance.
Mr. Huizenga is selling control of his company to Mr. Redstone without actually putting the company on the block, and Mr. Crawford wondered last night whether Blockbuster had the legal right to do so. He said Paramount had been reprimanded by the Delaware Supreme Court for taking a similar course, selling out to Viacom without giving other companies a fair chance to bid. Blockbuster officials could not be reached for comment last night.

HEADLINE: U.S. Offers Joint Military Games As Step to Poland's NATO Ties

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, Jan. 7

 BODY:
The United States told Poland today that NATO was willing to hold joint military exercises with Polish forces in Poland later this year as part of an effort to persuade East European countries to accept a relationship short of full membership in NATO.
The offer was made to President Lech Walesa by Gen. John M. Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who was born in Poland. He has been sent to Eastern Europe on a special mission with Madeleine K. Albright, the chief United States representative to the United Nations, to get approval of the "Partnership for Peace" plan, which the 16 NATO nations are expected to adopt at the organization's summit meeting in Brussels next Tuesday. Ms. Albright is Czech born. 
 Secretary of State Warren Christopher told reporters in Washington today that although the NATO plan would be the focus of the meeting, it would also deal with the Bosnian war.
President Clinton is to meet with Mr. Walesa and the leaders of Hungary, the Czech Republic, and Slovakia in Prague next Wednesday. Mr. Walesa said today that he would give his response to the NATO offer to Mr. Clinton when he sees him. In recent weeks, the Eastern Europeans have been expressing unhappiness with the plan.
 
Offer Falls Short
 The plan, while offering membership at some time in the future, falls short of the Eastern Europeans' desire for prompt membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which they have said was necessary to provide them with security against possible Russian moves in the future. General Shalikashvili said he might make similar offers to the leaders of the other three East European countries when he and Ms. Albright visit them individually over the next couple of days.
Holding joint military exercises in the former Soviet bloc would have a symbolic meaning, demonstrating how far these countries have come since throwing off Communism as a ruling ideology in 1989.
 
Gradual Ties
 The United States initiative seeks to avoid antagonizing Russia's belligerent nationalists by inviting the former Communist countries of Eastern Europe to build gradually closer ties with NATO that could eventually lead to membership. But those ties would come without the immediate ironclad security guarantees that the Eastern Europeans want but that Moscow finds provocative.
The initiative also reflects President Clinton's judgment that Congress would balk at extending America's defense umbrella any farther east at present, and that it would refuse to come to the aid of these countries in the same way it is committed to defend its existing NATO allies.
American officials said the offer to hold a NATO exercise in Poland this year, which seems likely to annoy some Russian leaders, was intended to convince President Walesa that the United States is seriously interested in protecting Poland even if it is not ready to anger Moscow by guaranteeing protection against a Russian attack.
"Our message is that the security and stability of Poland is of direct and material interest of the United States," Ms. Albright said at a news conference at the end of the talks. But both she and General Shalikashvili said it would be wrong to do anything that would create new divisions between Russia and its former allies.
"At this delicate period we are going through, we should not create new divisions in this part of Europe," General Shalikashvili said, alluding to Russia's angry reaction in recent weeks to East European requests to join NATO for protection against a possible revival of Russian imperialism.
President Walesa neither rejected nor accepted the American offer of a weak security partnership.
Ms. Albright and General Shalikashvili both expressed optimism that Poland would agree to join the partnership next week. "We remain optimistic Poland will be an active participant in the Partnership for Peace," General Shalikashvili said afterward.
Backing for that optimism came in a statement issued here after parallel talks between the Defense Ministers of the four countries attending a meeting next week in Prague who call themselves the Visegrad group, after the loose cooperation agreement they signed in that Hungarian city in 1991.
 
'The Right Direction'
 The Defense Ministers said they "actively discussed the Partnership for Peace initiative" and "believe it is a step in the right direction, favorable to the idea of multilateral security, and leading to a broadening of cooperation between NATO and the states of central Eastern Europe." But the Visegrad Defense Ministers also asked for a clear commitment from NATO that it will let them join the alliance as full members at some time in the future.
General Shalikashvili suggested that NATO will in fact give such a promise at its summit meeting in Brussels next week when it is expected to endorse the initiative formally.
"Our hope is that the NATO summit will say they expect and welcome the extension of NATO to the democracies of the East," he said at his news conference.
 
The Only Link Offered
 At a brief meeting with Ms. Albright and General Shalikashvili, American officials said the Visegrad group appeared resigned to accepting the proposal as the only link offered with NATO.
"The sense of the meeting was that it meets their minimum needs but not their maximum needs," United States officials said. However, while Poland, Hungary and Slovakia are interested in a joint approach to NATO, the Czech Republic does not want to be slowed down in its effort to join the alliance. It signaled that more independent approach today by sending only its Vice Defense Minister to the meeting.
Diplomats say an understanding that joining the partnership will eventually lead to full alliance membership is important for the Eastern European Governments because they will be expected to spend money bringing their military equipment and training up to alliance standards.
Only last Wednesday Russia reacted angrily to Lithuania's request for immediate NATO membership. Lithuania is the only one of the three Baltic states from which Russia has withdrawn all of its forces.
"The President is worried that expanding NATO to new countries in direct proximity to Russian borders will prompt a negative public opinion reaction," said a spokesman for President Boris N. Yeltsin.
Officials here say President Walesa expressed deep concern in his talks with the American team today about the rising tide of nationalist feeling in Russia, then made clear that he wants the United States to guarantee Poland's safety by promising to admit it to NATO eventually.
Such fears are shared by all the Visegrad countries. President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic recently spoke of the possibility "that in Russia forces still enamored of the imperial ambitions of the former Soviet Union would temporarily gain the upper hand."
Under the partnership proposal, American officials say all former Warsaw Pact countries, eventually including Russia itself, will be invited to work toward a series of political and military goals that will qualify them for NATO membership.
On the political level these would include parliamentary democracy and adoption of a free market economy. But the military would also be expected to train with regular NATO troops, to acquire compatible equipment, to accept ultimate civilian control over its activities and to provide a full public accounting of its spending.
General Shalikashvili said tonight that the faster these countries pressed ahead with such reforms the quicker NATO was likely to admit them.

(Associated Press) (pg. 6)
